 Dear voters 
 and voters, 
On June 9, 2024, you have the choice. We are faced with the decision as to whether we will receive what we
and strengthen that which protects us. Nothing less than our peace and prosperity is at stake. This is the basis for social and societal cohesion in a united Europe.
Where we come from: a Europe that creates peace
It is the greatest achievement of our continent: where just a few decades ago Europeans fought against each other on the battlefield, trust and cohesion now prevail. Where once front lines and barbed wire separated us, and later walls and border posts, we are now united by our commitment to freedom, the rule of law and democracy.
Enemies have become neighbors, neighbors have long since become friends.
In a world full of conflicts, the idea of the European Union stands as a guarantor of protection and peace: it was not so long ago that many still took this for granted. This certainty was shattered at the latest with the Russian war of aggression against Ukraine.
This war is directed against the will of Ukrainians to live in peace and freedom. It is directed against their desire to be and remain part of the European family. But it is also directed against internationally enshrined European values such as democracy, the rule of law and human rights - and reminds us of the protection the European Union offers us all. In order to preserve this protection, these values must also be upheld in the European Union.
every day. This also means issuing a clear rejection of anti-democratic, nationalist and right-wing extremist forces.
In a world whose challenges do not stop at national borders, a strong and united Europe can provide the security and prosperity that so many people long for and assume responsibility as a global player. If we strengthen freedom, democracy and human rights internally, the European Union can also convincingly represent them externally as a fair and responsible partner in the global community.
Where the assertiveness of the individual nation state ends, that of the European Union only begins.
Against this backdrop, we want to protect Europe so that it protects us. We want to strengthen it because it makes us strong. We want to secure its ability to act in order to preserve freedom.
Where we want to go: a Europe that increases prosperity for all
Peace and prosperity are inextricably linked in the European idea. Moreover, their linkage was the starting point of European unification: The interests of the individual states were to be so closely interwoven that war would henceforth be "not only unthinkable, but materially impossible".
It was a gamble. And it succeeded. From the ruins of war and destruction emerged a political order with shared values, based on democracy and the rule of law.
on freedom and solidarity - the indispensable complement to economic unification.
Now we are facing the next big task. Growing tensions in the world, social injustice, technological change and the climate crisis as a catalyst for all of this: they present us and our society, the economy and politics with new challenges. We must therefore do more than simply maintain existing prosperity. We define prosperity in terms of fairness, climate neutrality, quality of life and provision. This is the foundation for personal financial security and a life in dignity. We must now move forward where the jobs and prosperity of the coming decades will be created, create social security and at the same time preserve our natural resources. In this way, we can turn the promise of prosperity for all Europeans into reality.
Strengthening Europe and protecting the climate is therefore not an end in itself; we do it to protect and increase your prosperity, freedom and security.
We want to create an infrastructure union: of solar plants and wind farms, of hydrogen networks and fiber optic lines, of power lines and railways, but also of modern hospitals and educational facilities
- of institutions and standards that strengthen justice and protect your rights, for consumer protection and fair wages, against arbitrariness and exploitation. An infrastructure union that brings us closer together in Europe and
more sustainably, thus strengthening our cohesion and enabling innovation and progress. We want to connect Europe quite literally.
The climate crisis is global and must be solved globally. At a time when China and the USA in particular are finally investing massively in the climate-neutral modernization of their economies, we need an equally formative, strategic European investment policy to ensure that Europe can compete internationally and become the first climate-neutral business location. For such a policy, we need investments that
but it pays off. When we protect the climate socially and ecologically, we create: good jobs, clean infrastructure and secure prosperity.
However, good policy not only builds infrastructure, but also reduces bureaucracy: it regulates where necessary to safeguard the common good, maintains important standards of protection and participation
- at the same time, however, turns back unnecessary regulation that slows down the economy and society, inhibits investment and makes everyday life more difficult.
Digitalization that serves people and the harmonization of regulations and standards at different levels and countries, as made possible by the European Union, will help.
By securing the competitiveness of our companies in the markets of the future, we are laying the foundations for good jobs and fair wages, for attracting skilled workers and employees and for security in uncertain times. We don't just want to increase our prosperity for the few, we want to ensure that it reaches the many: across the breadth of society.
We pursue this claim.
By putting our prosperity on a climate-neutral footing and using fewer resources, we are protecting perhaps our most critical infrastructure: our environment and our climate, our biodiversity and the diverse nature of which we are a part. We have felt the consequences of climate change more and more drastically in Europe and around the world i n	recent years. Extreme weather such as heatwaves and floods have cost lives, homes and harvests, prosperity
and jobs destroyed. The extinction of species and the pollution of nature are endangering the ecosystems on which we are directly dependent. It is also in our own best interest to stop this trend: That is why we want to protect the climate, but also protect ourselves from the changing climatic conditions and adapt to them. We have taken important steps in this direction with the European Green Deal. We want to continue along this path.
By investing in the locational advantages of tomorrow - renewable energies and rapid
Digitalization, state-of-the-art battery technology and green steel or the education of our children and liveable villages - we are building a Europe that offers protection: for its citizens, for you and for all of us.
We know that: All of this can only succeed on a European level. European
But sometimes it works.
The way there: attitude and responsibility
We want to take responsibility. That is why we ask for your trust. We stand for a policy that does not drown out, but convinces. For a policy with clear goals that also builds bridges to common solutions. For a policy that provides answers.
What gives us strength are the successes of the last legislative period. We have met the corona and energy crisis with European solidarity. European climate protection has moved in the direction of the Paris climate targets - thanks to the expansion of renewables and, for example, the phasing out of combustion engines. And large digital companies are now following democratic rules.
We want to make the European Union more democratic and closer precisely because we know that we can achieve more together than by going it alone at national level. We want Europe, absolutely
- but even better. Better for you. A Europe as it could be.
We are prepared to jump over our shadows if it means that we can make progress together.
Responsibility that is taken seriously always means compromise. There
We have our clear values behind us as strength and orientation; they are our guiding principles. One thing is clear: human rights apply without restriction and are non-negotiable. At the same time, European progress, especially in a Europe of diversity, has never been a supposedly pure doctrine, never for or against, never black or white. However, anyone who rejects compromise as such is concerned with being right, not with finding solutions; they accept that trust
democracy is eroding; it accepts that the unity of Europe will suffer.
Europe has experienced both: the darkest chapters of our history, but also the ability of people to open new chapters, fight for freedom and defend democracy. The European Union may be exhausting at times and yes, it needs to improve. But it remains the key to a life of prosperity and security. Today, when we are faced with several tasks of the century, all of them man-made, even if their simultaneity and magnitude may seem overwhelming at times, we as Europeans know that the answer will be the same: The answer will be the same - man-made and European.
What counts in all of this is not who wins or who is right. Success has no political color.
Success is what makes life better for people in Germany and Europe. What makes us stronger together. What holds our society together. What also protects you.
BÜNDNIS 90 / DIE GRÜNEN are competing for the best ideas for such a policy. Such a policy is our offer to you.
We ask you for your trust in this path: Vote for Alliance 90/The Greens.
 What protects prosperity 
From small craft businesses to regionally anchored SMEs and large international companies: Europe's diverse and innovative economy is globally competitive - and Germany benefits from European integration and the single market like no other member state. Products and services from Thuringia or Hesse are traded between An- dalusia and Lapland, between Riga and Nicosia, as if these places were only a few kilometers apart. We are also the fourth strongest economy in the world because we join forces at European level.
Europe makes us strong. Strengthening Europe is therefore in our own best interests. We have already come a long way - with the Green Deal, we have set the right course across the EU. From 2050, Europe should no longer emit any greenhouse gases. Above all, it is now a matter of moving forward where the strength of the coming years and decades will come from, also and especially in order to bring the economy in line with planetary boundaries. We have a plan for this: the climate-neutral modernization of our economy and infrastructure. For us, this is not an end in itself, but also the key to competitiveness and prosperity, to quality of life, to good jobs and fair wages, to securing our natural resources - and thus to a stable basis for more social cohesion. security and social cohesion throughout the EU.
We are doing everything we can to ensure that Europe does not stand on the sidelines while China or the USA invest massively in the development of their location and future technologies. We accept the challenge: We want Germany and the EU to be at least on a par with their international partners in the markets of the future - in renewable energies
and hydrogen, in digital services and artificial intelligence (AI), in state-of-the-art batte-
technology and green steel. This makes Europe a pioneer for sustainable solutions and can define that new technologies are used for the benefit of people. This is a question of independence. Today, economic policy is also security policy. This also means that we protect critical infrastructure and strategically important industries from geostrategically motivated takeovers.
Europe's prosperity and quality of life are directly linked to its natural foundations - with fertile soils, near-natural forests and clean waters, with habitats for a wide variety of species, with intact nature on our coasts and in our landscapes. In their interplay, agriculture thrives in the immediate vicinity of high- tech companies, craft businesses are anchored in livable rural areas, and it is possible to travel from the cities to attractive cultural and natural landscapes for recreation in a short time.
Prosperity in Europe means fairly paid jobs, affordable housing and good public services in a functioning economy. It means justice and a fair social division of burdens and labor, not least between the sexes. But prosperity also means clean air, clean water and affordable, good food.
We are setting out to renew our prosperity by placing it on a climate-neutral foundation - one that will last for years and decades to come. We have put the European Green Deal on the agenda and it is the right strategy. We are continuing to fight for its continuation and full implementation. We are now ensuring thatithasan impact in all areas: from energy generation to mobility and agriculture to industrial policy. After all, climate protection and climate resilience are increasingly becoming decisive competitive factors.
and location factors. If we want to preserve our prosperity and create new ones, we Europeans must not only protect the climate, but also embrace this competition.
The prerequisite for this is an active European economic and industrial policy that enables innovation and builds sustainable infrastructure; that has the courage to make targeted strategic investments; that makes us independent of the autocracies of this world - and thus makes all our lives crisis-proof and affordable. We therefore want to expand renewable energies, the electricity grids and the hydrogen core network throughout Europe now - from solar energy from southern Spain to wind over the North Sea. We want to promote a modern and functioning rail network for climate-neutral travel from Florence to Flensburg and from Budapest to Barcelona and thus make our rail network truly pan-European. If we want to turn the European Union into a modern infrastructure union, then we will do so in order to secure production by industry and trade, electricity and heat, affordable energy and climate- friendly mobility for all - sustainably and in line with people's needs.
When we invest in research and development, we do so so that the best ideas continue to feel at home on our continent. When we reduce bureaucracy, we do so in order to put the EU at the service of Europeans, not paragraphs and authorities, without restricting quality standards. And when we use the potential of digitalization, we do so tomake data usable for the benefit of the people of Europe, not the other way around.
No country in Europe is up to these tasks alone. But together we are. Together in the EU, we are in a position to provide political answers that are effective and powerful enough to deal with global warming and systemic competition in equal measure.
This is the path we are taking. We want a fair and effective EU that creates security in the here and now - and at the same time sets the course for the future.
the prosperity and cohesion of tomorrow. We want an EU in which prosperity is created in harmony with nature and the climate. And we want an EU in which social or geographic origin, access to education, disability, gender or religious beliefs do not determine the chance of a good life. All people should be able to share in prosperity and contribute to it.
We are standing up for this Europe. This is the Europe we want to be.
1. A climate-neutral Europe
Investing in energy security
In order to achieve the climate targets, Europe needs a genuine energy union with an efficient and sustainable energy supply that utilizes and combines the potential and cost advantages of renewable energies across the entire continent.
We are massively expanding renewable energies throughout the EU as part of an active economic and industrial policy: By 2035, they should make a significant contribution to securing the EU's energy supply on the way to 100 percent climate neutrality. Because only renewables guarantee an independent and affordable energy supply in the long term, with which Europe can operate competitively in the long term. We want Germany to set a good example on this path.
To achieve this, we need an increase in energy efficiency and decarbonization intransport, industry and heat supply throughout Europe in the coming years, massive investments in the expansion of wind power, photovoltaic, solar and geothermal plants, energy storage systems of all kinds as well as waste heat recovery and heat pumps. In future, we want to work together even more closely on a European level in order to continuously develop the necessary requirements in unison.
In order to reliably transport electricity to where it is needed throughout the EU, we want to strengthen the European electricity grid as part of the Infrastructure Union and, above all, massively expand the connections between the member states. A decentralized, stable and interconnected European electricity grid makes us more resilient and increases our security of supply. The energy crisis showed this very clearly when the countries of Europe were at each other's mercy.
were able to do. We now want to make it fit for 100 percent renewable energies. This will enable us to exploit synergies in the EU, where the wind is always blowing or the sun is always shining somewhere. We are establishing integrated European grid planning - especially for c r o s s - b o r d e r projects and the expansion of wind energy in the EU's seas. In future, electricity grids, hydrogen grids, gas grids and heating grids must be considered together. We are gearing the electricity market design, grid fees and the regulation of energy storage systems of all kinds towards a system based on 100 percent renewable energies and the integration of the transport, heating and industrial sectors. The new electricity market design must allow electricity consumers to benefit from the cost advantages of renewable energies.
and at the same time secure the refinancing of
renewables. The price of renewable electricity should be decoupled from the rising costs of emissions trading. The decentralized nature of renewable energies allows many people and companies to generate their own electricity. The use of self-generated electricity should be encouraged through a favorable legal framework, as it not only brings them cost advantages, but also relieves the burden on the grids and thus the general public. Production peaks of renewable energies for which there is no use in the electricity grid should be able to be easily used on site, for example for electrolysis, in batteries or heat storage, in accordance with the principle of "use instead of shutting down".
Generations of people in the coalfields have made a valuable contribution to energy security, progress and our business location. We are building on this commitment and this expertise in the European energy
regions. However, coal is becoming increasingly unprofitable, is also the most harmful form of energy production in terms of climate and health and therefore has no future. We will create the conditions for ending coal-fired power generation in the EU. We will support the coal regions in their transition to new energies by 2030. We reject new obligations to pay compensation for the phase-out of fossil fuels. With new infrastructure, economic development, renaturation and innovation promotion, we are enabling the affected regions to make the transition to renewable energy.
regions are taking this path into the future. Companies, local authorities and a wide range of civic projects are crucial to the success of this comprehensive structural change. In this way, we ensure that the newly created prosperity reaches the local people and create reliable structures.
At the same time, the Russian war of aggression against Ukraine in particular has shown us how dependent we still are on natural gas and the difficulties this entails. In the coming years, in line with our climate targets, it will therefore be necessary to say goodbye to the development of new oil and gas fields once and for all.
We want to stop using fossil fuels to generate electricity in Germany by 2035 at the latest. In doing so, we are supporting the end of the extraction of CO2 sources in Europe and around the world. At the same time, we want to align our economic policy in Germany and Europe in such a way that fossil fuels are also phased out beyond this date.
production and combustion worldwide can be ended by 2050, in line with the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement. We can and will completely replace the fossil model with renewable energies combined with green hydrogen.
Nuclear power is not a sustainable form of energy generation and is not suitable for combating the climate crisis. It increases import dependencies, is considerably more expensive than renewables, involves high risks and is unreliable, especially in times of heat and drought. We advocate sanctions on uranium imports and Russia's nuclear business. Nuclear
Power plants are not least a threat to t h e safety of the population in war situations. Their construction is expensive and time-consuming. The danger of nuclear proliferation is ever-present, and the waste will burden countless generations to come. The shutdown of the last three nuclear power plants in Germany was therefore a key step towards a future-proof and affordable energy supply and a major success for the anti-nuclear movement. And it is for these reasons that we in the EU are campaigning against nuclear power as a viable form of energy generation. It is wrong to classify nuclear energy as sustainable and to support it with EU funds. We are striving for a comprehensive reform of the Euratom Treaty that makes the safety of decommissioning and nuclear waste disposal a central task and reflects the true costs and risks in the price.
We are excited about the future opportunities and potential of new energy technologies, which is why we want to drive forward the research and development of new ideas and, for example, continue to scientifically investigate storage technologies and nuclear power. Whether fusion or other approaches can make a contribution to energy supply in the future remains the subject of ongoing research, which always takes safety issues into account. Irrespective of this, the accelerated expansion of renewable energies must be implemented immediately and consistently, as it is a safe way forward
to solve the climate crisis - also for the urban agglomerations of the future.
Paving the way to a climate-neutral continent
Real progress has been made: to date, Europe has reduced emissions by around a third compared to 1990. With the "Fit for 55" plan, the EU aims to reduce emissions by at least 55 percent by 2030.
of their emissions compared to 1990. The free allocation of emission allowances to sectors that will fall under the carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) in future will be phased out. This reformed emissions trading will make a faster European coal phase-out profitable. We have doubled the expansion targets for renewable
energies. And for fossil fuels
Energy, steel or chemical products imported into Europe will soon have to pay a price for their carbon footprint at the border.
The car industry is switching its production to electric vehicles. Buildings in the EU are being insulated and incentives are being provided for climate-friendly heating. Europe has thus taken the right path.
The EU must resolutely continue on this path to climate-neutral prosperity. Europe should become the first climate-neutral continent. There must be no backing away from this goal and it must be reliably achieved. It is a great success that the EU is moving towards the 1.5 degree pathway. We want an EU climate policy that leads to climate neutrality with clear interim targets based on the scientific recommendations of the EU Climate Council. At the same time, we also want to shape European climate policy in the future in such a way that social cohesion is not jeopardized. We also want to make the interim target for 2035 binding at the United Nations (UN), as all countries have pledged internationally as part of the Paris Climate Agreement. Among other things, the framework for climate protection measures and the European emissions trading systems must be adapted for implementation. The agriculture and fisheries sector must also make its contribution to reducing emissions. In addition to pricing greenhouse gases, the instruments of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) must also be consistently geared towards climate protection.
With the inclusion of methane in emissions trading
and the new methane regulation, the EU has taken important steps to reduce this climate-damaging gas in line with its high warming potential, particularly in the short term. What is needed now is a rapid introduction of requirements for detecting and closing methane leaks in the upstream chain and a threshold for imports of coal, oil and gas into the EU.
Using natural CO2 sinks and technological progress
In order to achieve the climate targets, we need to get out of coal, oil and gas quickly and into renewable energies.
and green hydrogen. In a few sectors, however, there will still be emissions in the future that cannot be avoided using current technology, such as in the cement industry. In these areas, we want to take advantage of technological opportunities and capture the CO2 directly during production, store it in a safe and stable form and, if necessary, use it in closed carbon cycles (Carbon Capture Use
/ Storage, CCU / CCS). Where technically unavoidable emissions occur, this can be actively promoted. In principle, the polluter pays principle applies to funding. We reject the active promotion of CCS for the production of blue hydrogen in Germany. The energy transition and Decarbonization in industry is our priority. This focus will also be reflected in funding. We want to create a uniform Europe-wide regulatory framework for this, including a binding liability law, and develop an integrated European infrastructure
- including joint European CO2 storage facilities. We take into account existing uses, especially at sea, binding ecological criteria and the exclusion of protected areas.
According to analyses by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, it will become increasingly difficult to achieve the 1.5-degree pathway in the future. The predicted possibilities of achieving this path require an active reduction in the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere. It is therefore essential to actively reduce them in order to return to a stable and sustainable level. To achieve this, we are researching and developing negative emissions - natural and technical processes thatremove CO2 from the atmosphere in the medium term. Intact ecosystems are our best allies, because
Forests, floodplains, peatlands and oceans in particular are natural CO2 reservoirs. Protecting and restoring such natural CO2 sinks is a priority for us. In addition to the climate, they also have a positive influence on water cycles and the weather. That is why we need
We need smart regulation and increased support for natural climate protection, agriculture, humus formation, the rewetting of
The restoration of peatlands, the renaturation of floodplains and seagrass beds, the sustainable use of wood and the restoration of near-natural, species-rich and structurally rich forests that promote both ecologically and economically sustainable management in the future. To this end, Europe needs a comprehensive "Natural Climate Protection" package to implement the Nature Restoration Law, which also lays the legal foundations for the swift designation of priority areas for forest restoration.
renaturation and natural climate protection. Reducing livestock farming in Europe will also free up more land for the restoration of nature. At the same time, we want to examine the potential of technical negative emissions such as bioenergy with CO2 storage in application and evaluate them in pilot projects. As with other technologies, the principles of precaution and technology assessment apply. The EU needs clear targets for achieving negative emissions without trading them against emission reduction targets.
Using green hydrogen as the energy source of the future
Green hydrogen, i.e. hydrogen from renewable energies, can store energy and make it transportable. It is an important component of our future energy supply, as it can replace fossil fuels in many cases where electrification is not an option. The production of green hydrogen in times of surplus wind and solar power also has a stabilizing effect on the integration of renewable energies into our electricity grid. We want to ensure that Europe becomes a pioneer in the hydrogen economy. In order to reduce the currently quite high costs and efficiency losses in hydrogen production and transportation, we will continue to support research and development in this area of technology. With instruments such as climate protection contracts and a comprehensive investment program, we are ensuring a rapid ramp-up of production of this key technology.
We want to increase investment in a new trans- European hydrogen core network in order to
to transport green hydrogen from the sunny and windy regions of Europe to European industrial centers by converting the existing gas infrastructure and building new pipelines such as H2Med. In order to minimize grid expansion costs and enable regional hydrogen production and use as early as possible, we are accelerating the development of a decentralized hydrogen infrastructure at the same time. We are dovetailing this with the expansion of the electricity grids and a cross-sector European storage strategy that also incorporates the process and waste heat potential of industry. This is part of an efficient infrastructure union.
We are also committed to building a global market for green hydrogen and strategic partnerships for its global trade. Thanks to a large number of potential partner countries, which we also evaluate in terms of democracy and human rights, we can ensure a diversified energy supply and avoid one-sided dependencies. Through fair partnerships at eye level, the sharing of know- how, better access to renewable energies and the protection of local water supplies, we enable the countries of the Global South to integrate themselves into the value chain and benefit from the green energy future. We are committed to high standards for the certification of green hydrogen at European level. We want to avoid importing hydrogen that has not been synthesized using renewable energy wherever possible.
As production capacities first have to be built up, hydrogen will remain a very scarce raw material for the time being. To reduce CO2 emissions, we are therefore focusing primarily on energy efficiency and the electrification of drives, production processes and heating systems, as this is the most efficient way to use green electricity. We therefore want to prioritize the use of hydrogen in areas where electrification is not possible or only possible with great difficulty. This includes the production of basic materials such as steel, glass, paper or chemical products, heavy goods transportation and the transport of goods.
intercontinental sea and air transportation. In the future, we will also use green hydrogen to generate electricity when solar and wind power generation is low and loads are particularly high, if this is economically necessary or to ensure security of supply with renewable energies at all times.
Achieving climate neutrality in a social and citizen-oriented way
Climate neutrality secures and increases prosperity, but is also associated with change. This process demands a lot from all of us. This is not the only reason why climate neutrality must always mean social and gender equality. That is why we want to introduce a climate money as soon as possible. We will evaluate how this can be made socially just in the long term. The climate money will relieve the burden on people with low and middle incomes in particular, who produce less CO2 anyway. With the Social Climate Fund, which is primarily fed from emissions trading, we are giving the member states the means to implement this. It finances benefits for people who are particularly affected by rising energy prices.
and transportation costs are affected. The new European emissions trading scheme for buildings and heating will generate additional revenue. We therefore want the Member States to use these revenues to pay out a per capita climate bonus - as is already the case in Austria with the climate bonus. We will evaluate how this can be designed to be socially fair in the long term.
Renewable energies are citizen energies. They enable people and communities to take their energy supply into their own hands. This shows solidarity and is democratic, as it means that the revenues remain local. The German government has made it much easier for people to use renewable energy themselves. This should apply throughout Europe: The use of community energy is to become even more financially attractive and easier. We want to make it easier for citizens to participate in the energy transition at a European level - by becoming members of a community wind farm, selling the electricity from their photovoltaic system directly to their neighbors or using the electricity generated in their cars to power their homes.
and buffer batteries simply to stabilize the grid.
Renewable energies guarantee that people will still be able to heat their homes affordably in the future. We therefore support the further development of European requirements for the efficiency of buildings and heating systems in order to quickly and cost-effectively free buildings in poor energy condition in particular from their
d e p e n d e n c e on fossil fuels and ensure their long-term affordability. High energy standards for new buildings are another important building block here. When renovating existing buildings, we want to reduce housing costs through targeted investments. In doing so, we are focusing primarily on providing advice as well as socially structured and sufficiently large financial incentives.
We want all Member States to develop municipal heating plans or integrated energy infrastructure plans that show what potential there is for renewables and how waste heat, for example, can be used in an energy-efficient way.
To safeguard the right to clean air, we also advocate strict emissions protection
all systems that use combustion processes. Wood is a valuable natural material that should be used in houses and furniture, also as a CO2 storage medium. As part of cascading use, energy use should be limited to residual and waste wood.
With an efficient and fair electricity market design, transparent infrastructure costs that are as low as possible, greater flexibility on the consumer side and intelligent load management, the benefits of low-cost renewable electricity generation will reach consumers. As a first step, we are protecting the energy market by converting the promotion of renewable energies to two-sided differential tariffs.
contracts with upper and lower limits for electricity generation revenues protect electricity consumers from high costs. The price of renewable electricity should be decoupled from the rising costs of emissions trading. With clear European regulation of energy storage systems of all kinds, we want to drive forward their market i n t e g r a t i o n and provide the urgently needed
Leverage flexibilization potential. In the long term, an electricity market design is needed that ensures the refinancing of renewable energies and at the same time ensuresthat consumers benefit from the cost advantages of cheap wind and solar power.
2. A competitive business location
Investing in innovation, sovereignty and resilience
To make the infrastructure union a reality, we are opting for a strategic European investment policy. The NextGenerationEU (NGEU) recovery program has saved us from a severe crisis during the pandemic and has played a major role in holding the EU together economically and politically. With the end of NGEU in 2026, this important pillar of European investment financing is in danger of breaking a w a y . NGEU can serve as a model for effective joint European financing of major investment projects - such as the development of the infrastructure union.
We therefore want to create a major investment program for innovation, sovereignty and resilience from 2028 with three clear goals: Firstly, we want Europe to continue to grow together through strong common infrastructures as part of the Infrastructure Union - with a fully developed, integrated European rail, electricity and hydrogen network that is adapted to the worsening climate crisis. Secondly, we want to promote the climate- neutral conversion of industry throughout Europe as well as the development of the industries of tomorrow. And thirdly, we want to make our economy and our societies more resilient to and less dependent on autocracies.
Actively shaping industrial policy
Europe is a strong business location with a diverse landscape of small, medium-sized and large companies.
large companies, which is an essential foundation for our prosperity. We will ensure that this remains the case. Two levers are central to this:
Firstly, we are strengthening the internal market,
i.e. the EU's common regulatory framework for companies. This common framework, in which no member state may give its own companies unfair advantages and whose rules set the gold standard in many areas around the world, makes an invaluable contribution to our prosperity, especially for Germany as an exporting country. We will continue to deepen it and defend its foundations.
On the other hand, we have to realize that China in particular, but also the USA with its Inflation Reduction Act, are investing massively in the development of new production sites for key and future technologies. We accept this competition: The EU must counter this with its own active economic and industrial policy that builds on Europe's strengths to reclaim, develop and scale key and future industries. It starts with research and ranges from the training and further education of skilled workers to support for investments. This includes a supply policy that reduces bureaucracy and provides incentives for private investment on the one hand, and strong public funding programs for future technologies such as electrolysers, solar plants, wind turbines, energy storage systems, e- cars and microchips on the other. We want the EU to be at the forefront of the markets of the future and for the products of the future to be conceived and manufactured in the EU. The aim and mission of our industrial policy is to secure jobs and prosperity in Europe by strengthening Europe as a business location and renewing it in a climate- neutral way. The development of a European semiconductor industry is fundamental to the renewal of Europe as an industrial location and serves our economic capacity to act and independence.
We will push for a new start here: A funding jungle has developed in the EU that makes it very difficult for companies to access the available funds quickly and unbureaucratically.
to come. This is a decisive competitive disadvantage - compared to the USA, for example. We advocate a coherent and easy-to-understand industrial policy in which subsidy policy and state aid law also go hand in hand. To this end, we want to transfer relevant parts of the current national industrial policies to the European level, which will be much better funded and put in a position to act quickly and effectively. In addition, we need to mobilize private capital for the climate-neutral renewal of industry. Scaling up the renewable energy industry requires clear targets, strategic management of value chains and a coordinated European structural policy.
Equipping our economy for global competition
European industry can only be competitive in the long term and the EU can only meet its climate targets if industrial production processes become completely climate-neutral. To achieve this, we will renew the industrial base and focus on new value creation opportunities.
More and more companies are investing massively in converting their production. Politicians must create the framework for this: a clear reduction path in European emissions trading. We are bringing it to life by massively expanding renewable energies and the infrastructure for electricity and green hydrogen so that enough green energy is available everywhere at competitive prices.
is available in Europe. Until this is the case to a sufficient extent, we want to ensure, in particular with suitable measures linked to the use of renewable electricity, that energy-intensive companies can also continue to produce in the EU and make the transition to climate neutrality.
This is one of the reasons why we want to support companies with a European programme to decarbonize industry. To this end, we want to finance the EU-wide use of climate protection contracts (carbon contracts for difference) from the EU budget and thus
financially support those companies that convert their production to climate-neutral as quickly and cost-effectively as possible and save the most CO2 in the process. We want to focus on all industrial sectors.
In addition, we want to create European green lead markets for some particularly energy- intensive products from climate-neutral production, such as green steel. To this end, we want to stipulate a minimum quota of green steel for public contracts, for example, which will steadily increase. This will create a new sales market that will trigger climate-neutral production via a market mechanism. We also want to enable industry to make its electricity consumption more flexible and set appropriate incentives so that it can already benefit from the price advantages of renewable energies and reduce grid infrastructure costs. Finally, we also want to significantly accelerate planning and approval procedures for the conversion of production processes to climate- neutral processes, as this contributes to a faster reduction in emissions while at the same time maintaining industrial subs- tance and good jobs.
With the staggered introduction of resilience and sustainability criteria in public tenders and public funding programs, we want to specifically promote the production of these products in the EU. In the long term, we want to orient our economy more towards the common good.
Strengthening the internal market
The EU internal market is central to the prosperity of the EU population and helps to counteract distortions of competition. It is also a key lever for advancing the climate-neutral modernization of our economy. It enables European companies to offer goods and services anywhere in the EU. And it enables employees to work anywhere in the EU. That is why we want to strengthen and deepen the internal market: Where there is one common rule in the EU, companies no longer have to follow 27 different ones.
We are shaping the rules for the single market in such a way that it helps to achieve overarching goals: Democracy, prosperity, social justice, environmental and climate protection and the creation o f	fairly paid jobs. We also want to use the internal market to become more resilient to crises and less dependent on imports of raw materials.
In order to ensure functioning competition for the benefit of consumers and small businesses
we have tightened up competition law in Germany. EU competition law also needs such an update. To this end, we want to revive the New Competition Tool, which the Commission has already proposed.
A strong competition policy that combats the formation ofexcessive market power and prevents subsidy races within the EU as far as possible is what makes the single market a success. We want to maintain this in the future. However, in the struggle for the markets of the future, the EU is now in global competition with other countries that do not adhere to these rules. The EU Commission must therefore create a permanent new state aid framework, particularly for the green technologies of the future, which will enable the member states to pursue a more active, European- coordinated industrial policy and at the same time prevent distortions of competition. This includes faster planning security for state aid procedures as well as exemptions for the support of new production facilities in future technologies and for the conversion of production processes to climate neutrality and the circular economy.
One approach to this is the IPCEI strategic funding projects, with which the EU aims to enable and coordinate the industrial policy of the member states in key sectors such as the development of the European hydrogen infrastructure and the value chains around microelectronics. To ensure greater planning security for companies, the state aid procedures must be accelerated, especially in the context of the IPCEIs.
Train, attract and retain skilled workers
A stable European economy secures our prosperity. With good working conditions, secure jobs, decent wages and further training, we can attract and retain the necessary workers and specialists. This applies equally
for academically trained specialists as well as for those with training in the skilled trades, industry or the public sector. We want everyone to be able to contribute to prosperity - and for it to benefit all those who create it. This is how we grow from the middle. The success of the energy transition also depends on this. This also means that by investing in climate protection, we are simultaneously promoting secure and future-proof jobs.
To achieve this, we need to train young people accordingly, provide further training opportunities for everyone - especially for older workers - and attract skilled workers from outside the country. Refugees who come to us should also be allowed to work and have quick access to language courses. At the same time, we must give women the opportunity to play a full part. In many EU countries, millions of women often work part-time involuntarily or not at all. At EU level, we need a feminist economic, labor market and time policy that takes into account the social infrastructure for reconciling family, work and democratic participation.
We want to make it easier for women to choose a technical - and therefore often well-paid - profession. We want to introduce a bonus that companies and businesses from sectors inwhicha below-average number of women have been employed to date can receive in the allocation of EU funding if they train or employ an above- average number of women. Together with the trade unions and companies, we will develop new ideas on how we can enable equal participation and pay for the sexes in the economy. At the same time, we want to improve the pay, working conditions and recognition of predominantly female occupational fields in a targeted manner.
With their diverse skills, people with disabilities offer great potential as skilled workers. We want to bring about a cultural change towards an inclusive labor market policy and also focus EU funding programs more strongly on this. We want to consistently enforce the legal regulations on the employment and training of people with disabilities and on barrier-free workplaces.
Europe is competing with other regions of the world for skilled workers. From civil engineers and tradespeople to nurses in hospitals. We therefore advocate a comprehensive EU strategy for skilled workers. When recruiting from third countries, the EU Blue Card initiative should be extended to non- academic professions, provided there is a concrete job offer at standard market conditions. At the same time, the recruitment and migration of skilled workers can also lead to serious challenges for the regions of origin. Our aim is therefore for the EU to invest more in the partnership-based training of skilled workers - to the benefit of the labor market in the country of origin as well as in Europe.
Many employees who work in the fossil fuel industry are worried about their livelihoods if their industries are electrified. We therefore want to combine the transition to a climate-neutral economy with well-paid jobs, attractive training and further education opportunities, collective wage agreements and economic and social security, especially in regions that are still structurally weak. Our industrial policy offers a lever for this: we want to link the allocation of EU funds more closely to the fact that training places are available in the region.
social standards are observed and applicable tariffs are adhered to.
3. Stable finances
Arming Europe financially
A key factor in the EU's ability to act is its financial resources: whatever we undertake together in the EU must also be financed to a relevant extent with European funds.
be able to finance them from our own resources. We want to finally meet this requirement, as far- reaching decisions will have to be made over the next five years regarding the financing of our joint European projects well into the 2030s.
We will be guided by two principles: Firstly, we want to improve the financial resources of the EU as a whole through new own resources and higher national contributions. Joint European bonds have also proven their worth in tackling major challenges. Secondly, the EU must be given significantly more room for maneuver in the use of its funds in order to use them for joint investments in strategically important areas such as industrial policy and for an infrastructure union. With this in mind, we will fight for a strong Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), the basis for the EU budget, as well as for a new major investment program.
We want the MFF for the years 2028 to 2035 to grow significantly compared to the current one. Germany must also make its contribution to this. We need to specifically strengthen the expenditure items that improve the EU's ability to act in the crucial areas of the future. To this end, we must also critically review the impact of expenditure in the MFF. This applies in particular to the areas in which the Member States manage expenditure.
The protection of our common good requires an EU that is also financially capable of acting.
Especially in times of massively growing tasks, it cannot finance itself in the long term solely from the contributions of the member states. It also needs its own revenues to secure its financial resources in the long term. To this end, we want to enshrine the principle that the majority of revenue generated by European instruments should in principle come from the EU.
benefit the EU budget. In a first implementation step, we want to stipulate that 75% of the potential money creation profits of the Eurosystem will benefit the EU budget in future. 75% of the income from the new CO2 border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) should also go to the EU budget.
To ensure that the upcoming interest and redemption payments for the NGEU program do not lead to a reduction in the EU budget, we want to implement the roadmap for new own resources adopted by the Council and Parliament in 2020 as quickly as possible. In doing so, the financing of the necessary national climate financing in the Member States must be ensured.
Completing economic and monetary union
A stable and cohesive economic and monetary union is a basic prerequisite for prosperity and political and social cohesion in Europe. However, the architecture of the monetary union is still incomplete and Europe therefore remains vulnerable to crises. We want to change this with a comprehensive package of measures.
With the new investment program for innovation, sovereignty and resilience, we are consolidating the common fiscal policy - also as an important buffer in times of crisis. By transferring the European Stability Mechanism to the EU legal framework and switching to majority decisions, we are abolishing national vetoes in crises and finally establishing joint European parliamentary control over future EU aid programs.
By introducing unemployment reinsurance along the lines of the EU short-time work allowance (SURE), we are creating an additional safety net in times of crisis so that the member states can protect jobs. We want to complete the banking and capital markets union to transform the EU from a monetary union into a genuine economic union. By removing structural barriers to cross- border capital flows, we are improving the financing conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), releasing potential for investment and making our financial system more robust at the same time.
A resilient monetary union also needs functioning rules for the budgetary policies of the member states, which ensure that the debt burden is not too high.
ensure viability in all countries at all times and at the same time create enough room for investment and growth. The rules that have been in place for a decade are too restrictive and have prevented necessary investments in many EU member states, while at the same time they were no longer sensible and comprehensible for the European Commission to apply. That is why we are fighting for an ambitious reform that creates more transparency and more scope for investment and whose results are consistently enforced by the Commission.
A crisis-proof monetary union also requires that all member states within the community have the most balanced current account balances possible in order to avoid dangerous imbalances that can arise from undercutting competition in wages, taxes and social security systems, for example. The European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) should play an even stronger role in promoting the
climate-neutral renewal of the economy through a politically sharpened mandate.
We support the introduction of the digital euro as a supplement to the book money of commercial banks and to cash, which will remain possible as a barrier-free means of payment.
The digital euro promotes the digitalization of the economy and gives consumers digital access to secure and stable value.
Central bank money. As a public good, it can make a valuable contribution to financial inclusion, the sovereignty of the EU and the stability of our payment system in the digital age.
Shaping financial markets responsibly
Our economy and society depend on functioning financial markets. We want to strengthen the responsibility of all financial market players - for corporate investments, for employees and for the common good. We want to use strong financial market regulation to protect basic needs such as housing and health from speculation. In order to prevent speculation and the focus on short-term goals
the financial markets, we want to create a Introduce a financial transaction tax.
In order to support the climate-neutral renewal of our economy, the financial system must become more resilient and be consistently aligned with the European sustainability goals. This requires clear rules against greenwashing. Every financing decision is a decision about the economy of the future and must therefore also be compatible with our commitments under the Paris Climate Agreement.
The banking sector in the EU is central to financing the investments of companies and citizens in the modernization of our economy. For this reason alone, we cannot afford another banking crisis.
With a significantly higher unweighted capital ratio of at least 10 percent, regular stress tests and the completion of the banking union, we are putting the banks on a stable footing. The interdependence of states and banks should be reduced. This is why we are working at EU level to further reduce concentration risks in bank balance sheets, including through government bonds.
With a European deposit reinsurance scheme that allows the institutional protection schemes of savings banks and cooperative banks to be maintained, a functioning resolution regime andthe separation of lending business with private customers from investment banking at major banks, we can prevent credit institutions from
have to be bailed out with taxpayers' money in the event of insolvency. By obliging banks to gradually reduce the emissions they finance, we ensure that their business is in line with the goal of climate neutrality.
In addition to banks, all other players in the financial sector such as rating agencies, insurers and pension funds must also disclose and take into account climate and biodiversity risks. We advocate greater coherence in European legislation in order to prevent unnecessary bureaucracy - especially for smaller companies.
The EU's green taxonomy is a means of supporting the financing of environmentally friendly economic activities. Therefore, it remains wrong to classify nuclear energy and natural gas as sustainable.
However, sustainability is more complex than a binary yes or no, because we also need strong and innovative suppliers, for example for e-cars or wind turbines, which have not yet been included in the taxonomy. We want to better reflect this in the future. We want to add further gradations to the green taxonomy so that investments in the transition to a sustainable economy are adequately financed. In addition, we want to actively support the EU Commission's proposals for the design of social instruments, such as a social taxonomy, in order to channel investments more strongly into social sectors.
Green investments have become mainstream, as many people want to participate in future- oriented industries and protect the climate at the same time. However, financial supervision has not kept pace with the rapid growth of sustainable financial products. In order to strengthen investor confidence, we therefore want to equip the European financial supervisory authorities with far-reaching powers against greenwash- ing and introduce a state labeling system for sustainable investments. Consumers should have clarity about how a financial product contributes to the climate-neutral modernization of our economy.
We want to make the Capital Markets Union a success. To achieve this, we need to win back the trust of savers. Conflicts of interest due to commissions have meant that savers have far too often been sold expensive, risky or unsuitable financial products. We want commissions to no longer play a role in financial advice in the medium term and for everyone to have access to independent, commission-free advice. This is the only way we can make the potential of the Capital Markets Union accessible to everyone. We want to put an end to misleading formulations, inadequate labels and non-transparent ways in which financial products work.
4. 
Tax justice
Combating tax evasion
The financing of our democratic system depends oneveryone making a fair contribution - for schools and childcare, for hospitals, for a good bus and rail infrastructure. In recent years, courageous whistleblowers and independent media have uncovered a whole series of international tax scandals. They have shown how the super-rich and many large companies use tax tricks to shift profits to low-tax countries: from tax loopholes, letterbox companies and tax havens to tax fraud. These practices shift the tax burden onto citizens, especially SMEs, who rightfully pay their taxes. It is estimated that tax abuse causes losses of more than 170 billion euros annually across the EU. Tax fraud and tax evasion are often cross-border problems. The EU can make an effective contribution to combating this.
We also want to make further progress in the fight against tax avoidance, for example by shifting profits to tax havens. Stricter criteria are needed to ensure that the EU list of tax havens is truly complete. For example, well-known tax havens such as Singapore are currently missing. Countries with a tax rate of zero percent must automatically end up on the EU list of tax havens, such as Bermuda or the Cayman Islands. Decisions on which country is placed on the list must be made transparently, according to uniform criteria and impartially.
We also want to significantly improve cross-border cooperation between tax authorities in order to strengthen the EU-wide exchange of tax-relevant information. We welcome the fact that cryptoassets are now also to be fully covered.
We will tackle the abuse of letterbox companies,
i.e. companies that only exist to evade or shift taxes. We call on the member states to adopt the EU Commission's proposal quickly and without watering it down - the EU would be a global pioneer with this legislation. We also want to use AI to detect tax fraud and identify loopholes on a non-discriminatory basis.
Withholding taxes reduce the risk of tax evasion and avoidance, as demonstrated by the cum-ex and cum-cum scandals, as well as the shifting of profits to low-tax countries. We therefore support the EU Commission's plans to introduce an EU- wide system for withholding tax on dividends and interest payments and advocate a further step - an EU-wide minimum withholding tax rate.
Internationally, we must tackle the problem of withholding tax on foreign payments in third countries outside the EU.
End tax dumping
The patchwork of national tax regulations and tax competition between EU member states in terms of corporate tax rates make it difficult to achieve a level playing field in the single market. To counteract this, tax legislation must keep pace with new business models that have become more international, complex and digital. For example, large digital companies with their intangible assets (such as data, knowledge or algorithms) benefit from the fact that corporate profits are taxed at the location of a physical branch or factory and not, for example, where the users of digital services are located. We want to prevent the bakery store around the corner from paying a significantly higher tax rate than
a major international corporation. All companies must contribute their fair share to financing the common good.
A major step has been taken towards fair and effective corporate taxation in Europe: The EU has
- as a result
The two countries have finally agreed on a minimum tax rate of 15 percent for large multinational companies following a breakthrough at the level of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). This means that they can no longer escape a minimum standard of taxation.
draw. Implementation in the member states and the European Commission's proposal for a new EU framework for corporate taxation (BEFIT) must now follow. The agreement on minimum taxation is a key step in the reform of the international tax system. However, it is still not enough to ensure that large digital companies, e-commerce or multinational companies in Europe are taxed more fairly. If no progress is foreseeable in the currently faltering negotiations at OECD level in this area, the EU Commission should propose how this goal can be pursued at European level.
Tax transparency is an effective instrument as it makes tax dumping visible to all. The agreement on public country-by-country tax reporting by large companies
in 2021 was a milestone in this sense. When large companies disclose how much tax they pay in the individual EU member states, they
This leads to better control of their tax practices. But not all countries are covered yet. We will work towards using the review clause in the law to improve the directive and achieve a global breakdown of relevant tax data. To prevent destructive tax competition between EU member states, there also needs to be a clear EU framework for tax concessions that individual member states can grant to companies.
We are committed to addressing the market- dominating position of the large auditing firms. This requires a clear separation between auditing and tax consulting, more joint audits and a sustainable reduction in the financial links between auditors and the companies to be audited.
Financing the community in solidarity
Tax justice means that high levels of wealth and billions in corporate profits must make a fair contribution in order to finance the community in a spirit of solidarity, promote climate protection and sustainability and reduce social inequality. The high level of inequality and concentration of wealth in particular has continued to increase throughout the EU.
In order to address these problems, the EU must also be able to act in the area of tax policy. We support the member states in the introduction and implementation of suitable measures to reduce wealth inequality. Efforts to combat tax dumping and tax evasion are repeatedly prevented by vetoes from individual EU member states. We want to exploit the existing possibilities of the treaties to take qualified majority decisions. In the future, overcoming the unanimity principle will open up greater scope for joint action.
As a result of the Russian war in Ukraine, oil and gas companies made extremely high windfall profits from high energy prices. These disproportionate profits made by some of the winners of the crisis are offset by record levels of poverty, which have been exacerbated by a sharp rise in the cost of living. The fact that the EU has agreed on an excess profits tax in this situation, through which the large energy companies return a crisis contribution to society, is a great success.
Part of the current inflation was caused by excessive profits and
is not justified by increased production costs. We call for the instrument of a progressive excess profits tax to be firmly anchored for other areas as well in order to relieve the burden on public budgets in special economic situations. Loopholes such as the small calculation of profits over several financial years or the shifting of profits abroad must be closed.
5. 
Innovative strength and reducing bureaucracy
Anchoring European research at the top of the world
For the great technological, social and economic challenges of our time, we need the combined knowledge of our entire continent and beyond. That is why a European science and research policy that connects people and institutions from all over Europe and supports them in the development of free science is a key element for a future of freedom and prosperity. We want the next major breakthroughs in the areas of climate-friendly mobility, information technology
or the treatment of diseases such as chronic fatigue syndrome ME / CFS, cancer or Alzheimer's are conceived and produced in Europe.
Expenditure on research and development must therefore increase significantly in Europe as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP).
At the heart of this is the Horizon Europe program, which bundles the EU's research activities. It is a highly successful funding program that is very popular with applicants and is unparalleled worldwide. We want to expand its scope in the next European financial framework.
European research policy must include free basic research as well as mission- and application- oriented research and transfer. Central to this is climate research, for which we were able to establish a fixed quota of 35 percent for European climate research in the current Horizon Europe cycle.
In future, we also want to establish much stronger funding for biodiversity research. We advocate well- funded basic research - for example in the European Research Council, the excellence research par excellence.
We want to consolidate the Marie Sklodowska Curie mobility funding, which is so important for researchers.
We will continue to campaign for the social sciences and humanities to be given a permanent place in the EU funding framework and for critical sciences to be taken into account, as they are of great importance for a vibrant and resilient culture, society and democracy. By creating a better understanding of social contexts and necessities, they help to overcome multiple crises with holistic solutions. Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine, which violates international law, teaches us that peace research and research on the countries of Eastern Europe, the South Caucasus and Central Asia must be intensified. We want to promote cooperation between European and Ukrainian universities. We want to continue to strengthen Open Access, i.e. the principle that research results and research data should be findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable, as a principle of Horizon Europe and support it in international cooperation.
Horizon Europe is already connected to many partner countries worldwide, which promotes the exchange of knowledge. However, we want to make Horizon Europe more accessible and more international for our researchers. To this end, we want to simplify the application process, reduce bureaucracy and involve more partner countries. In scientific cooperation with non-European partners, it is important to protect European technological sovereignty and guarantee scientific freedom.
Good policy is based on verifiable facts and scientific findings. We advocate standards and transparency guidelines when commissioning scientific studies and expert opinions.
Turning ideas into wealth
Innovation is crucial for Europe's economic future. We want to support ideas on their way from the laboratory to practice. Innovations are a decisive building block for the economic success of tomorrow.
Building on basic research, we are shaping mission- oriented research that helps us to tackle the major challenges of our time and understand their causes: For example, we need a faster roll-out of renewable energy, effective treatments for cancer, smart digital solutions and approaches to tackle social inequality. The missions of Horizon Europe should continue to be guided in particular by the Green Deal. To implement them, we want to bring together universities, institutes, civil society and business.
Innovation policy is an important part of our active economic and industrial policy. We want to expand the transfer-oriented program components of Horizon Europe so that the best ideas are supported on the way to their implementation. In order to make participation in funding programmes more attractive for SMEs, municipal institutions and non- governmental organizations (NGOs), the application and documentation of projects should be simplified as much as possible.
To this end, the EU should also increasingly support regional innovation ecosystems in which science, society, business and the public sector work together on the necessary solutions for the future. Such clusters of research, teaching and practice are key to promoting innovation, accelerating its application and creating climate- neutral prosperity locally. In addition to universities, universities of applied sciences and universities of applied sciences should also be considered. To date, they have often not benefited from EU funding to the same extent as universities, but are particularly strong in applied research. In order to improve this, we want to look at the application and funding conditions of the relevant programs.
We want to make the existing instruments more manageable and faster. This applies, for example, to the Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs), which are particularly dedicated to training young talent, for example in master's or further education programs. By strengthening the
knowledge triangle of higher education, research and innovation, we can give as many people as possible the chance to get involved in key issues of the future.
Transparency and traceability of decisions are also of great importance in this relevant area: the Commission has created a large number of public- private partnerships that manage EU funds together with industry. We would like to launch a transparency initiative here, review existing partnerships and ensure that universities, research institutes and start-ups benefit more from these funding instruments. In addition to proven research formats, long-term studies are also an important contribution to balanced research.
Space is crucial for Europe's technological and strategic sovereignty. Europe must therefore play a leading role in space and needs independent and reliable access to space. We are strengthening the competitiveness of the space industry under the principle of "New Space", for example by promoting new technologies and a European launcher competition. We promote the EU space program, the European Space Agency (ESA) and the astronaut program.
With a European Space Act, we are leading the way internationally, ensuring sustainability and creating growth opportunities and legal certainty for European companies.
Taking off with European start-ups
An innovative corporate landscape needs a lively start-up scene. This is where the start-ups and business models of tomorrow are born. To achieve this, founding must become easier and faster. We want to ensure that there are one-stop stores in every member state. There, founders can find support and advice from a single source. A digital compass should provide an overview of all funding programs for start-ups. Our goal is to make it easy to apply with just one click.
We need a clear responsibility for young companies in the Commission so that the transfer of know-how in the EU is better coordinated. With a European start-up strategy, we are bundling important measures to improve access to venture capital, to attract talent and to public contracts for young companies. The potential of underrepresented groups, especially women and people with a history of migration, should also be better utilized and supported sothattheir ideas have a fair chance of being implemented.
The European Tech Champions Initiative, which the German government has launched together with other EU member states, is an important building block to better support start-ups in the growth phase. In addition, we want to create regular European matching hubs that bring private investors together with founders, a trade fair for business models of the future. Good innovation support also consists of implementing and sustainably securing good and reliable working conditions in science and business.
We want to expand and make greater use of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to strengthen innovative start-ups and climate- friendly industry, especially in cross-border regions.
Promoting SMEs and skilled trades
The innovative capacity and drive of SMEs and the skilled crafts sector are the driving force behind the European economy. Particularly in rural areas, the skilled trades and SMEs provide jobs and stability. They develop, produce, install and maintain future technologies such as solar systems and heat pumps. Europe thrives on cooperation and local problem solvers. However, SMEs, from industry to the skilled trades, are particularly burdened by the introduction of new regulations and bureaucratic hurdles in funding programs. We will therefore improve and consistently apply the SME tests, which assess the impact of new laws on SMEs in line with the "Think
small first" principle should always be reviewed in advance and adjustments made accordingly. We also advocate appropriate exemptions and transition periods for SMEs in new laws and provide support during the changeover. We particularly promote training in the skilled trades. By simplifying application procedures and reducing reporting requirements, we are making it easier for SMEs to access EU funding and investment programs. With the help of fixed SME quotas, we ensure that they actually benefit from these programs. We will standardize the funding landscape in the EU and dovetail it more closely with national funding instruments.
Some legal regulations are now outdated, while others are unsuitable in practice. We advocate a regular review of all regulations in order to simplify bureaucratic requirements and remove regulations that fail to achieve their objective. Where possible and equally effective, we prefer graduated and flexible regulation for companies instead of hard regulation. For example, we want to replace the reporting requirement for overnight stays in tourism and A1 certificates with a more practical approach with pragmatic solutions for small businesses.
A central means of reducing bureaucracy is the digitalization of administration. This can eliminate many administrative procedures, automate data exchange and make it easier to submit applications.
Administrative services should be digitally as far as possible. The status of
procedures should be accessible online. Through stronger networking between European and national authorities, the once-only principle is to be introduced so that in future data will only be requested once from companies so that it can then be exchanged within the framework of data protection regulations and within the authorities. We want to largely abolish the written form requirement in administrative procedures.
6. 
Digital sovereignty
Making Europe digitally fit
Digitalization provides a key to the central challenges of our time. It makes it possible to completely rethink fundamental areas of life such as transportation, education, health and energy. As a result, it offers enormous opportunities for economic development and for simplifying many tasks for everyone - from tedious administrative processes and the management of supply chains in industry to the research and treatment of serious diseases. We want to make it the foundation of a fair, decentralized, highly networked and resilient economic system.
We are also experiencing systemic competition in the digital sector - between emancipatory digitalization that empowers citizens and strengthens freedom, and digitalization that disempowers citizens and promotes surveillance for economic or political interests. Europe must consciously position itself in this competition and take a big step towards being an attractive location for talent and innovative companies and thus help shape the rapid digital development. We therefore want to secure, strengthen and expand Europe's digital sovereignty.
The basis of European digital sovereignty is, among other things, a resilient and climate- friendly infrastructure, which includes broadband networks, mobile networks, hubs, data centers and the reliability of sensitive supply chains. We want to drive forward the development and production of infrastructure components in Europe, be it the production and development semiconductors, satellite communications and mobile communications technology. We want to shape the connection to the global network infrastructure, whether for submarine cables or nodes, with strong European players.
Digital sovereignty means the development and application of key technologies such as AI, quantum computing and communication in Europe.
Here, too, we can rely on strong European companies in various sectors and strengthen this development with a bundling o f measures - for example, targeted investments as part of the investment program for innovation, sovereignty and resilience.
Wherever possible, we advocate the preference for free and open source software.
software and open data solutions. For critical infrastructures in particular, the European Commission must work together with the Member States to ensure that European standards for
