We also want to replace the so- called A1 certificate with a digital real-time register in order to prevent cross-border labor exploitation and ensure effective social protection.
Working from home was part of everyday life for many employees during the corona crisis and has been appreciated by more and more employees since then. We support these developments where it is practicable to do so. We also want mobile working not to stop at European borders, but to be possible in principle from a country other than the country of employment. We are therefore committed to ensuring that there is a guideline for working from home that makes it easier to work from home throughout the EU.
Fighting exploitation
For freedom of movement to work for all workers, effective protection against exploitation is also essential. Regardless of whether a worker from Austria is working in France or a seasonal worker from Georgia in Romania: EU citizens and people from third countries need comprehensive protection against discrimination and exploitation when they work in another EU country.
This is clearly demonstrated by the scandals in the meat industry, 24-hour care, truck drivers, seasonal workers and the construction industry. We are declaring war on these forms of exploitation.
Workers in these sectors often live and work in more than one place in the EU. They therefore make a substantial contribution to a functioning internal market and to maintaining our social systems, but are exposed to additional risks. We want to use European levers to combat bogus self- employment and wage and social dumping in these areas.
Regular labor inspections can also be an effective tool, for which the member states should increase staff and improve training in European legislation and cross-border issues. The protection of employees should be the top priority, and better cooperation between the national authorities and the European Labor Authority (ELA) is also necessary. This also includes suitable offers for advice and participation. The ELA's mandate should be extended to third-country nationals.
We welcome closer cooperation between the ELA and the trade unions. It should also be given a stronger role for joint coordinated inspections.
We want to take further measures to prevent abusive practices by subcontractors, such as enshrining joint and several liability in law. Time and again, workers are housed in catastrophic conditions, in overcrowded rooms, in poor hygienic conditions and with overpriced rent that is deducted directly from their wages. We therefore want to legally secure and effectively enforce the obligation to provide adequate accommodation.
An effective fight against labor exploitation begins with ensuring that those affected can inform themselves easily and in their own language about their rights - and receive help to enforce them. We are committed to long-term and reliable funding for the creation and Europe-wide networking of appropriate advice centers.
and support structures. With their technical expertise, trade unions are valuable partners in the development and implementation of such offers.
We welcome the fact that European payments in the area of the Common Agricultural Policy will in future be made dependent on compliance with labor standards in agriculture. This so-called social conditionality must now be implemented effectively.
Reducing child poverty
One in four children in Europe is at risk of poverty and social exclusion - that equates to almost 20 million children who have very limited access to healthy food, sport, education and culture. Child poverty means, on the one hand, existential deprivation in the here and now and, on the other, fewer opportunities for a self-determined and successful life in the future. We want all children to have access to a well-developed care and social infrastructure. Their future and the promotion of their potential will determine our future as a society. The European Child Guarantee is intended to ensure that every child at risk of poverty and social exclusion in Europe has access to free healthcare, early childhood care, education and upbringing, adequate housing and a healthy diet.
This is particularly important for children who
currently have poor opportunities. We want to ensure that the Child Guarantee is implemented throughout Europe with concrete measures.
In implementing the Child Guarantee in Germany, we are also actively involving civil society as well as children and young people. With the Child Guarantee, the federal government has launched a key instrument in the fight against child poverty in Germany on our initiative. It is a necessary step towards ensuring that children at risk of poverty are better off, that poverty is no longer hidden and that parents can live a more carefree and anxiety-free life because they and their children are protected. We are committed to ensuring that the shift away from the parents' obligation to collect and towards the state's obligation to provide is implemented throughout Europe. In order to benefit more from each other
In order to learn from our experience, we promote Europe-wide exchange on how families can be better supported and how a good upbringing can be ensured for all children in Europe.
Strengthening children's rights
Children have independent rights. They have a right to participate and require our special protection and care. The welfare of the child must be given priority in all matters concerning children. Particular attention must be paid to protecting children from violence and neglect. We want to further develop and consistently implement the EU child rights strategy. We want to promote European research and practical projects in the field of child protection and children's rights in order to make national experiences, practices and models usable for the further development of child protection everywhere.
Anchoring minimum social standards
Over 95 million people in the EU are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. The high cost of living has exacerbated people's social situation, in some cases to an existential level. We want everyone in Europe to be able to rely on strong social systems that protect them from poverty. To achieve this, the welfare states of the member states need binding minimum standards.
We want to develop the existing European recommendation for adequate minimum security systems into a binding directive and link the standards set out therein with an individual entitlement to social rights for those affected in the member states. As part of this, all member states should gradually make their social systems poverty-proof in line with their respective levels of prosperity, promote sustainable integration into good work and expand the social infrastructure. For Germany, too, this means a tailwind for a strong welfare state and more social justice.
Making social security crisis-proof
The welfare state must prove its worth, especially in times of crisis. Better precautions against the economic and social consequences of external shocks must therefore be a key lesson from the crises of recent years. The fair participation of all citizens makes an important contribution to this. The social systems of the member states must be made crisis-proof and enable fast and effective protection for people in emergency situations.
However, crisis-induced mass unemployment with high social costs and hardship is overwhelming many EU member states. Its consequences destabilize the entire EU. The European crisis instrument SURE provided member states with financial loans and guarantees during the coronavirus pandemic in order to create jobs through the use of
of short-time working benefits - a great success. The instrument saved an estimated 1.5 million jobs in Europe in 2020 alone. Building on this experience, we want to createa permanent crisis instrument in the form of unemployment reinsurance for the member states, which will support national unemployment insurance schemes.
In times of multiple crises, young adults need perspectives that encourage them and a system that supports them in an emergency. This is why we are continuing to focus on European youth unemployment. The European Youth Guarantee is a way of opening up career prospects for young people and integrating them into the labor market as skilled workers. We welcome its strengthening in the context of the corona pandemic and continue to advocate for its continuation. In particular, we want t o further develop the standards of the training and qualification offers. With good advice and training, every young adult in Europe has the chance to learn a trade.
Making housing affordable
Housing is one of the central social issues of our time. For us, housing is a fundamental right
and must be secured as part of services of general interest. We want secure housing for all people. Affordable housing is particularly scarce in cities, with rising rents in many places and a declining stock of social housing putting a strain on tenants right up to the middle of society and leading to displacement and insecurity. In major European cities, a particularly large amount of living space is being used for short-term rentals and thus withdrawn from the rental market.
Rising rents must not exacerbate social inequality and poverty risks, for example for older people. We want to quickly create more affordable housing and limit rising rents - for example with refurbishments of existing buildings and interior insulation, sustainable construction, a skilled labor offensive and improved investments via the European Investment Bank (EIB). We are combating the housing shortage with additional barrier-free and disabled-accessible housing.
Investors who are buying up large amounts of urban residential real estate and valuable building land across Europe are driving up property and rental prices in many places.
upwards. The Europe-wide concentration on a few investors in the housing market harms competition and people. We are committedto transparent business practices. We are scrutinizing the existing European regulations in order to better protect tenants in the member states from rising prices and to safeguard the quality of our housing. This also includes protecting households from index- linked rental contracts. In light of the rising cost of living, we want to cap existing index-linked rents and restrict new ones, and we want to initiate a land turnaround in Europe. We are committed to protecting the scarce resource of land in the EU from speculation. We welcome long-term rental and lease models by the public sector instead of short-term sales. We want to integrate the land and real estate market more closely into EU competition law. We want to make the valuation of real estate and land Europe-wide oriented towards the common good. To this end, we also want to tackle a change in international accounting standards so that CO2 emissions can be integrated across all sectors.
and other socio-ecological values can be included in the financial valuation.
Homelessness violates human dignity and is one of the most extreme forms of poverty. The EU has set itself the ambitious goal of ending homelessness by 2030 and has launched a European Platform to Combat Homelessness. We want to implement its measures quickly. The dialog between the member states must be further strengthened. The opportunity to learn from each other and to adapt proven concepts such as Housing First or social housing agencies across the board should be strengthened.
We are committed to more effective prevention, sufficient living space and more individual, humane and less bureaucratic services for the people affected. These should also provide better care for people with mental illnesses and addictions. We want to expand European funding for corresponding plans and projects.
2. Strong regions
Strengthening municipalities
The strength and attractiveness of the EU also lies in the diversity of its regions and municipalities.
They are the foundation of the EU. This is where people live, learn and work. Strong municipalities thrive in a strong Europe, which attaches particular importance to municipal needs and freedom of action. The principle of subsidiarity - i.e. making decisions as close to the people as possible - is the basis for a Europe that protects and enables. We want to strengthen this principle and ensure the ability to act locally by providing sufficient resources.
This also means that the EU should use its possibilities to provide support where municipalities reach their limits. The everyday lives of citizens take place in Europe's municipalities.
This is where people live and work, where children are looked after and volunteer work is carried out, where people come to cinemas, restaurants, parks or sports facilities.
together. Municipalities form the basis of our social coexistence and, with functioning basic services, also offer attractive locations for companies and employees from all over Europe. The implementation of competition rules must not lead to municipalities being forced to privatize public goods or being restricted in their municipal planning sovereignty. We therefore need good procurement and concession law that focuses on social and ecological criteria - and at the same time strengthens the decisions of the public sector. It promotes legal certainty and enables municipalities to opt for high-quality regional offers. In this way, local authorities themselves can strengthen the added value of public infrastructure. They should also retain the ability to control and limit the use of space in order to ensure a supply close to where people live. By enabling the remunicipalization of past privatisations in the EU, we are creating new scope for local decision-making and reliable services of general interest. We continue to support local authorities in pursuing this path. An EU that defends the municipal scope for action
and expands, ensures quality of life and social
cohesion.
In particular, access to clean and affordable drinking water is an existential basis for a healthy life. Thanks to the success of the Right2Water citizens' initiative, Europe guarantees the highest standards for drinking water worldwide. The supply of drinking water should remain in municipal hands and not be determined by purely market-based economic interests. We therefore defend the exemption of water supply from the Concessions Directive and protect the right to drinking water in the EU.
Europe must be lived on the ground. Municipalities, regions, companies and civil society need a greater say in shaping European policy. That is why we want to strengthen the European Committee of the Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee. Cross- border European cooperation, such as town twinning or
Initiatives to strengthen cross-border regional competitiveness and connectivity (INTERREG programs) strengthen municipalities and regions, as do knowledge transfer and networking programs (e.g. Climate- ADAPT). We want to strengthen these programs. The level of the European regions (Euregios and Eurodistricts) should be made less bureaucratic and more flexible. They contribute with cross-border programs such as advisory services.
We are committed to simplifying the everyday lives of cross-border commuters and binational families by reducing bureaucracy and harmonizing administrative services and processes.
Promoting local cohesion
The success of the Green Deal and the cohesion of the EU will be decided on the ground: on the basis of concrete projects in the European regions. This is where important expertise for shaping change on the ground lies. An efficient funding policy in the EU involves local people and is geared towards the opportunities and challenges of digital and ecological change. We focus on the economic and social convergence of the regions in Europe. The size of the funds and funding programs should be geared towards the challenges.
So far, European regions have been prepared to varying degrees for these challenges. This applies both within and between the European member states. A consistent funding policy based on clear criteria will help to overcome these challenges.
to be both a driving force and a compass. We want to focus on structurally weak and rural regions as well as regions with an industrial character and modernization challenges in order to create equal living conditions for all people.
Demographic change poses a major challenge, particularly in structurally weak regions.
tion. The exodus of skilled workers, especially young people and women, is leading these regions into a spiral of hopelessness.
The EU must counteract this with better support for structurally weak regions. In this way, we strengthen the local shapers of the future and create good prospects for the regions.
Major challenges require a major effort and at the same time efficiency and precision in the use of funds. We ensure this by aligning funding with criteria in line with the European Green Deal. The European Social Fund (ESF+) plays an important role in this. It is also used by us to advise, support and provide lifelong training for numerous founders, employees and jobseekers. The promotion of long-term
projects should not be held up by delays in EU consultations. We are providing the ESF+ with sufficient funds to promote active employment policy and increased social participation, among other things. We are committed to ensuring that the administration of funds is simplified, that the conditions of good work play a major role and that the funds become drivers for a fair EU. A strong commitment to collective wage agreements, good employment and health protection and a wide range of opportunities for training and further education will turn attractive jobs into a locational advantage for the funded regions.
European funding offers a great opportunity to develop innovative projects. However, the programs are often not sufficiently well known and the application for funding and the implementation of the funding are often too complicated. This reduces the number of applications. Some good projects and ideas are not realized. We are changing this by working to simplify access to funding, increase awareness and accelerate the implementation of projects. To simplify the structures, we are reviewing the current system of individual funds. In order to reduce bureaucratic hurdles, we want to introduce, among other things, more packages and funding opportunities that
exempt volunteer applicants from pre-financing after project approval. Reducing bureaucracy thus creates more efficiency.
Every important change requires the participation of local citizens and civil society. A policy of being heard makes use of local expertise and creates mutual understanding.
This knowledge can be incorporated through the partnership for citizen participation (partnership principle). Mechanisms such as citizen dialogues, public consultations or forums should be part of the processes for allocating funds in all member states. Digital and hybrid formats should enable family-friendly participation. This is how we ensure co-determination and democratize the EU's funding policy.
Seizing opportunities in rural areas
Rural areas are spaces of future and opportunity. Their development is a central goal for us. It has a significant impact on cohesion in the EU. The transport transition can bring rural areas closer together, while the energy transition can create new added value and financially strengthen municipalities. Coworking spaces can revitalize town centers. We are also focusing on the rural outskirts of cities with their considerable development potential. Local people should be able to participate in decision-making and benefit from it. To do this, they need reliable services of general interest and places where they can meet and exchange ideas.
We want to strengthen services of general interest by supporting citizens' cooperatives and multifunctional facilities that, for example, carry out intergenerational projects with young and older people. In order to
To achieve this, we want to further strengthen funding approaches such as LEADER to support rural regions and the multi-fund approach in structural policy. Support for rural areas via the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) should be better dovetailed and expanded with the so-called cohesion funds and thus make a better contribution to the structural development of rural areas.
creates additional added value here. To this end, it should be fed into the electricity grid and used in a decentralized manner. We want to secure the necessary land, but minimize land consumption and consistently consider multiple uses, for example through agri-photovoltaic systems, biodiversity photovoltaics or more renewable electricity generation on sealed surfaces. We will continue to drive forward the expansion of renewables and support the modernization of the economy and society through the targeted use of subsidies in a way that benefits local people.
Regional agricultural value chains and near-natural forest management continue to be important economic factors and are characteristic of these areas.
Modernizing public procurement law
A genuine infrastructure union, a strong European market and the implementation of the Green Deal throughout the EU go hand in hand with massive investment in a secure future, at both national and European level. With public procurement law based on social and sustainable criteria, these investments will once again become the driving force for a fair and future-proof EU. We can make a big difference, especially where we invest in stable European infrastructure, efficient electricity grids, a reliable rail network or a people-oriented healthcare system. Boosting the European infrastructure union has positive effects on the European labor market: new jobs are being created in these sectors in particular. These jobs should also begood jobs. Strong public procurement law secures the future of many workers throughout the EU.
The state itself is a major economic player. We want to use this huge lever. Whether services or goods: Public procurement in the EU should be consistently sustainable and oriented towards the common good. We therefore want to modernize the Public Procurement Directive and align it with sustainability and public interest criteria. This also favors the awarding of contracts to small and medium-sized enterprises and thus strengthens regional value creation.
An intact public space and the fulfillment of public tasks are the basis of our social coexistence. We want the EU to take measures so that tasks can not only be put out to tender, but also awarded.
Transparency, less bureaucracy, digitalization, acceleration and uncomplicated procedures remain our guiding principles. Necessary investments should not be unduly delayed. Every company should be able to bid for public contracts easily and successfully. Waste of money is minimized through a clear procurement policy.
Simple communication of the rules and active support for small and local providers, for example with references to the legal framework, ensure fairness. The awarding of public contracts thus becomes a competition for the best conditions.
3. Reliable healthcare
Overcoming health crises at European level
We want a Europe that works together to protect and promote the health of all people.
The coronavirus pandemic has shown once again that the major challenges facing our health know no national borders. It has also shown us that we can tackle them better together. The rapid development and availability of coronavirus vaccines, for example, was also a European success that came about thanks to many years of research, innovative companies and cross-border cooperation. During the pandemic, the EU has driven forward the joint procurement of protective equipment and vaccines, strengthened joint research activities, coordinated the free movement of people and goods during border closures and cushioned economic emergencies.
The competencies of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) have also been expanded in order to facilitate the exchange of information.
with and between the member states and to recognize and overcome health crises at an earlier stage.
In order to better manage cross-border health crises and strengthen crisis preparedness, we want to work together even more closely at European and global level. The EU has an important role to play here in ordertoensurethat national measures
and supplement the measures taken. It can also exert an important influence globally. At international level, we are committed to strengthening the World Health Organization (WHO) and multilateral health initiatives politically, financially and in terms of personnel, promoting the innovative power of European health research more strongly and improving global access to affordable medicines and healthcare services for all people, which is a question of solidarity, as health crises often hit the poorest hardest. But it is also in our own interests, because pandemics are global challenges. We are committed to the active transfer of technology and knowledge regarding the production of key medicines. Monopolies on intellectual property to combat diseases must not prevent access to vital protective materials, health technologies, vaccines and medicines. Where voluntary production partnerships are not sufficient, we support applications for the granting of mandatory licenses in return for compensation for these goods in health crises and pandemic situations and advocate for the temporary suspension of patents at the World Trade Organization (WTO) in these contexts. our goal is for all EU citizens to have health insurance. We therefore want better coordination of social security systems in the EU - including direct billing options between health insurance providers.
Strengthening preventionWe place prevention and health promotion at the heart of our health policy. This is how we can prevent diseases from developing in the first place. Good prevention structures, better information about the risks of illness and a healthy lifestyle are
important building blocks for a better quality of life and a longer life expectancy. In this way, we can also prevent diseases such as obesity, diabetes mellitus and cardiovascular diseases. To make it easier for consumers toeat healthily, we want to provide reliable information about the ingredients in food. We want to prevent the development of tobacco and alcohol-related diseases as far as possible. This requires greater efforts to reduce risky forms of alcohol consumption and tobacco use, for example by reducing the nicotine content in tobacco and nicotine products. We are committed to the goals of the European Beating Cancer Plan. According to this plan, the proportion of smokers in the EU population should fall below 5 percent by 2040.
Gaps that still exist in advertising - for example on
social platforms and particularly in the area of sponsorship - must now be closed across the EU. The protection of minors also requires us to push ahead with advertising restrictions for alcohol, gambling and sports betting. In order to be able to better counter future health crises, we want to strengthen preventive health research in addition to research into the causes of diseases and new treatment methods.
The EU should work towards intensifying global cooperation in the area of the authorization and monitoring of medicinal products.
Learning lessons from the pandemic
Even if the most visible signs of the corona pandemic have disappeared with the lockdown restrictions or the mask requirement, many people are still suffering from the consequences of a Covid-19 infection (long/post-Covid) and quite a few from the much less common consequences of a Covid-19 vaccination (post-Vac). We therefore want to intensify research into infectious diseases such as Covid-19 and their sequelae (e.g. myocarditis or ME/CFS) at European level and make research funding available for this purpose. We also need more European exchange, for example through an EU network of experts.
Prevention is at the heart of everything we do. For people with illnesses and shadow families in particular, this is an important building block for equal participation in society. This also includes making healthy indoor air a matter of course.pandemics do not affect everyone equally. People on low incomes, those in precarious employment and people in large institutions are significantly more likely to be affected by Covid-
19. These groups must be given greater attention during the next pandemic.
Covid-19 is - alongside AIDS or Ebola, for example - another case of a so-called zoonosis, i.e. a disease that is transmitted from animals to humans. The corona pandemic thus underlines once again that human health should not be viewed in isolation, but is closely linked to the environment and animal health. This is why planetary health and the One Health approach are guiding principles for our health policy: sufficient space for animals and nature and a reduction in industrially farmed livestock help in the fight against zoonoses; fewer antibiotics in factory farming leads to less antibiotic resistance; clean air and fewer toxins in the environment save human lives.
In particular, we need an effective European early warning system against pandemics in order to be able to identify dangerous pathogens at an early stage and make information about them available in a transparent manner. At the same time, pandemic scenarios must be practised regularly, above all to ensure that a crisis and emergency organization can be set up quickly.
Focusing on mental health
War, inflation, climate crisis, pandemic - the past few years have been turbulent, conflict-ridden and characterized by crises and upheavals that have left no-one unscathed. For many people, this period is also a psychological burden. For many young people in particular, psychological problems have worsened. We set
We are committed to ensuring that mental health receives the attention it deserves and that those affected no longer have to suffer from stigmatization. We also want to achieve this with support from Europe. We are committed to both improved Europe-wide prevention and to improving existing approaches to mental health and better treatment of illnesses. To improve patient safety
In order to guarantee the quality of creative therapies, comparable legal regulations and protected professional designations are needed across Europe, such as for artistic therapies. We support research into creative therapy approaches and advocate the networking of experts in Europe and want to develop comprehensive solution strategies together with the member states, also in order to further strengthen community-based, human rights-based care, increase care security and avoid coercive measures. As the causes of mental health problems are manifold, we must also tackle them at all levels. That is why we are committed to ensuring that the impact on mental health is minimized.
health must be considered across the board in all relevant policy areas. This also applies to the effects of mental illness and neurodiversity. This requires greater awareness of the problem in the EU and its institutions. In this respect, we welcome the EU Commission's strategy for mental health and are committed to implementing it as quickly and comprehensively as possible.
More and more people in Europe are also experiencing loneliness. This is often a very stressful situation for those affected. Older people in particular are also affected. The pandemic has further exacerbated the situation for many people in this regard. With our policies, we are committed to greater social cohesion, inclusion, participation and integration.
Ensuring the supply of medicines
The challenges facing European healthcare systems are immense: ageing societies, an increasing number of chronic diseases and epidemics. The corona pandemic has
also made it clear that the EU is too dependent on manufacturers with unreliable supply chains for medicinal products and their active ingredients. and therefore often accepts production under poor working conditions and poor environmental standards. Vulnerable groups suffer particularly from drug shortages.
In order to address the major challenges facing the healthcare sector, the EU Commission has presented a legislative package to reform the pharmaceutical sector. We welcome the proposals, which aim to diversify supply chains and make them more sustainable, as well as to oblige pharmaceutical companies to better prevent drug shortages and report them earlier. Pharmacies also contribute to a reliable supply of medicines.
In order to encourage companies to develop and produce new medicines, active ingredients and medical devices in Europe, incentives and less bureaucratic procedures are needed. We have two priorities here: Firstly, critical medicines that are indispensable at all times, such as important antibiotics, must be reliably available through crisis-proof supply chains. The partial relocation of production back to Europe can contribute to this. On the other hand, new incentives for the development of medical innovations must be created for previously neglected diseases and in view of the emergence of therapy resistance.
This includes, in particular, new financing models such as adapted remuneration models for reserve antibiotics. Incentives for research and development and the protection of intellectual property must not jeopardize the affordability of essential medicines and disproportionately delay the market entry of generics. We are also committed to gender-sensitive research and medicine so that gaps in knowledge about gender- specific differences in diagnosis and treatment are closed and taken into account. Studies in the field of pediatric and adolescent medicine should also be intensified to ensure that access to safe and effective medicines is improved.
becomes. At the same time, greater consideration must be given to the diversity of people, especially in studies on new drugs and treatment methods.
It is far too opaque how prices for medicines are set. The lack of transparency and accountability in this area sometimes leads to immense price increases. Especially when public funds are used for drug development, this must generally be accompanied by transparency regarding the costs of research and development as well as pricing. In addition, publicly funded development projects should ensure that
resulting medicines are made sufficiently accessible in countries of the Global South.
Using health data securely
Digitalization in the healthcare sector has great advantages for patient healthcare and research. Diseases can be better diagnosed, the causes of diseases can be researched, unnecessary examinations can be avoided and the treatment of patients between different doctors and hospitals can be simplified across borders throughout Europe. The European Health Data Space should therefore enable EU-wide access to digital patient records.
We want to strengthen patients' rights through effective data protection, comprehensive IT security and personal access to the data stored about them. The
is fundamental to people's trust in the processing of health data. Fundamental transparency in data management and technical solutions such as a digital consent assistant can support this. After all, personal health information is some of the most sensitive and personal data of all.
and at the same time not to pass on any data against the patient's will, we rely on the possibility of objection (opt-out) and the focus on the protection of personal data in the case of pseudonymized health data.
good data quality. In this way, we want to increase the availability of data for public-benefit research and provide public authorities with better assessment options in emergency situations. This represents an important paradigm shift in the use of health data, which we want to shape. Access to and analysis of larger amounts of data promotes innovation potential and can therefore improve patient care. Traceability of data should be excluded as far as possible and violations of this should be prosecuted. Comprehensive protection against discrimination for all and, in particular, the needs of vulnerable groups must be taken into account in a comprehensive manner. standardized data formats and interfaces are fundamental to the success of digitalization in the healthcare sector in order to enable the consolidation of data and cross-border use in Europe. We therefore want to ensure the development and mandatory use of internationally used data standards and interoperable interfaces by the software systems right from the start.
Curbing antibiotic resistance
Antibiotics can save human lives. This should also be guaranteed in the future. Measures must therefore be taken to guarantee their long-term effectiveness. By using antibiotics responsibly, we want to prevent the emergence and spread of multi-resistant germs. After all, these are one of the greatest health challenges facing humanity.
Particularly in people with weak immune systems, such as the elderly, children or people with pre- existing conditions, they lead to the emergence of multi-resistant germs every year.
to hundreds of thousands of deaths worldwide. It is therefore important that antibiotics and highly potent disinfectants are only used wherethey are really needed or where they are appropriate. We want to strengthen the prudent use of antibiotics in human and veterinary medicine and promote research. In addition, rapid diagnostic tests that check whether treatment with antibiotics is necessary before prescribing should be available in sufficient quantities.
We want to align the EU list of reserve antibiotics, which are reserved for human medicine and may not be used in industrial animal husbandry, with the corresponding WHO criteria. We also want to end the import of animal products in which antibiotics banned in the EU have been used. We want to reduce the entry of antibiotic residues into the environment through measures to improve hygiene and wastewater disposal. We want to promote the development of new antibiotics and effective alternative treatment methods through incentives.
Ensuring good care
A strong public and non-discriminatory healthcare system and needs-based care and assistance for older, sick and disabled people are essential to protect human dignity and promote self- determination. The shortage of nursing staff is becoming increasingly acute, both in the EU and here in Germany. We therefore want to increase the attractiveness of the nursing profession, facilitate the free movement of professionals within the EU in this area and improve the working conditions of nursing staff. Our aim is to simplify recognition procedures for degrees as well as for initial and further training for nursing professionals within the EU and from abroad. As part of the EU care strategy, we advocate competitive working conditions and salaries in professional care compared to other sectors. Appreciation also needs wages that reflect this - ideally through good collective agreements. In addition, more investment is needed in care facilities, especially in forms of housing and care that enable people to live independently in their own neighborhoods and living environments, care services and the training and further education of care professionals. We also want to promote greater EU involvement in research and model projects as well as a transfer of knowledge and experience to improve working conditions in health and care facilities in the member states.
In order to improve the situation of care workers in home care, we are calling for a revision of occupational health and safety legislation to ensure that employed care workers in private households are also included and have good working conditions. In the coming decades, there will be a further increase in the number of people in need of care and suffering from dementia. Our aim is to enable these people to lead a dignified, self-determined and active life.
In order to drive forward more innovations in the area of care and participation, we want to strengthen the European exchange on new approaches, for example on inclusive forms of housing and care, neighborhood-oriented support and personal assistance. We also want to provide better support and relief for family caregivers and loved ones. This is why we are working at a European level to ensure that family caregivers, the majority ofwhom are women, have good social security and do not fall into old-age poverty due to care responsibilities. Their skills acquired in care work should be recognized and access to further training should be promoted.
We also want to implement the requirements of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in the care sector.
Legalize cannabis across Europe
We are also committed to a modern drug policy in Europe that prioritizes health and the protection of young people and effectively combats the criminal structures behind the drug trade. In Europe, too, the purely repressive approach to drugs has brought more suffering than blessings, thousands of drug-related deaths and an important source of income for organized crime. What is needed is a drug policy based on science and risk-based assessment. In various places around the world, the shift to a risk-based approach to cannabis has already been successful. With the regulation of cannabis, we are focusing on reason instead of criminalization. We are striving for EU-wide legalization and controlled dispensing of cannabis.
national law currently imposes strict limits on the member states when dealing with cannabis. We want to extend this so that each country can decide for itself. At the same time, we are strengthening prevention and the protection of minors.
The increase in problematic drug use, new and synthetic substances and the consequences of social impoverishment in public spaces pose a major challenge. They pose dangers for consumers, pose particular challenges for authorities and require social measures, and we must take more effective action against invisible and visible addiction problems. This is why we are intensifying cross-border cooperation in the interests of health protection. In addition, we want to
improve health care for addicts, turn away from repression in dealing with users, strengthen social support structures and improve access to treatment. We also want to further advance research into the use of psychoactive substances, in particular their medical benefits, in European research networks.
4. Education and opportunities
Networking Europe's universities better
The European Higher Education Area contributes to making higher education in Europe more comparable and internationally competitive and is invaluable for promoting academic mobility.
Europe's universities are an important part of the education system, a place for shaping the future, for critical self-reflection in society and for social and technological innovation. If we network them, we can make even better use of their diverse skills and profiles for the entire continent. We have therefore long been committed to establishing and strengthening European university networks. We promote the use of artificial intelligence and learning analytics in teaching and education. We want to shape these in such a way that teachers, students and pupils can use them independently and confidently.
The new applications must be designed in a socially fair and non-discriminatory way. Access to these new applications must be designed to be socially fair and non-discriminatory.
In line with the idea of a European degree, we support the further development of the European approach as part of the Bologna Process in order to facilitate the recognition of joint programmes and joint degrees and to create incentives for the internationalization of degree programmes.
Regardless of the country, students rarely have a lot of money at their disposal. Visits to museums, theaters, but also excursions to other cities, for example, open up new horizons. Many of these institutions offer discounts for students. But especially for students from other countries
It is often difficult for students to obtain these benefits with their home student ID cards. With the European Student Card (ESC) and the digital student card in the Erasmus+ app, the EU has already taken the first steps towards a European student card, but only for a very limited group of people. We want all students at European universities and higher education institutions to be able to obtain a (digital) European student card.
Recognizing professional qualifications throughout Europe
The opportunity to study or work in any European country opens up many new perspectives.
However, when it comes down to it, things often become difficult: we have created a comparable degree system in the EU with the Bachelor's and Master's degrees in the Bologna Process. But it is not automatic, for example, that a Bachelor's degree from one country will be recognized for a Master's degree in another country. Students and graduates, including those in further vocational training, have to go through an often still very bureaucratic procedure in the respective country. In some cases, the domestic degree is then given less value.
In some cases, recognition is very costly. That is why we are committed to ensuring that vocational training qualifications and educational qualifications within the framework of the European Qualifications Framework are more easily and quickly recognized in every EU country instead of having to be laboriously recognized.
It is even more difficult with professional qualifications. Here, recognition is often complicated, lengthy and expensive. In times of skills shortages, this is particularly counterproductive. For a handful of professions, people can therefore apply for the European Professional Card (EPC) in their home country. This electronic procedure makes it easier to have a qualification in a regulated profession recognized in another EU country. We want to significantly increase the number of professions for which the EBA is possible. We want to improve the position of applicants by introducing comparable recognition procedures across Europe and offering comprehensive guidance and support through multilingual advice and information services.
Political education against disinformation
Our democracies and our values are under constant attack from authoritarian and anti- democratic movements at home and abroad. Their means: disinformation, fake news and manipulation of their distribution mechanisms as well as deliberate disruption and flooding of digital debate spaces. They are increasingly operating across borders and trying to undermine cohesion in the EU and our European values. Their conspiracy myths sow hatred and exclusion. We need to counter this more strongly and in a coordinated manner across Europe. We therefore want to establish a European Center for Civic Education, a point of contact for civic education that specifically addresses the European dimension of disinformation. It should primarily address young people and young adults, but at the same time be available to all citizens as a source of information and create a wide range of offers in the digital space. This European Center for Civic Education is also intended to
People in the EU candidate countries are open.
It can explain the European idea and complex European processes in a way that is appropriate for the target group. This center should also strengthen people's digital media literacy in times of disinformation and fake news. To this end, it can also promote the networking of European players in research and education. It should be able to work independently and according to clear scientific and ethical criteria.
In this way, we promote our democratic values and strengthen the fight against discrimination.
Get to know Europe with Erasmus
For many, Erasmus+ is their first and often most personal encounter with the EU. Erasmus+ promotes a living European community and facilitates academic and professional exchange.
Student exchanges are at the heart of the program: we want more people to be able to have these experiences, especially those from families who lack the money for vacations or exchange time abroad. This means thatwe need to increase financial support for stays abroad. We are therefore campaigning for an increase in Erasmus funding. For many people, leaving home to go abroad is a big step and the prospect of not being able to afford to visit family during this time is a barrier. That's why we want to introduce a mobility ticket for Erasmus participants, which would allow them to travel to and from their place of residence once every semester free of charge, for example. To make it easier to integrate semesters abroad into the curriculum, we are striving to harmonize semester times.
We want people with disabilities to be able to opt for a valuable Erasmus+ experience. That is why we want to expand the advisory services (e.g. information on national contact points for assistance) before and during the project implementation and make information available without barriers
and ensure that the additional costs are covered. We want to work with the UK to find ways in which people on both sides can benefit from exchanges again after Brexit.
Many students are familiar with Erasmus+. However, trainees are not yet sufficiently familiar with the program. We want to change that. After all, it offers many opportunities to learn new professional skills and gain new experiences. We want to strengthen Erasmus+ for trainees with better information, more advice and simpler applications and recognition.
We want to enable as many trainees as possible to participate in the Erasmus+ program by offering support to small craft businesses.
Erasmus+ is one of Europe's success stories, including for youth work. With a view to the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework from 2028, we will work to double the funding for Erasmus+.
5. Europe's youth
Involving young people
Europe thrives on community, encounters, tolerance and mutual understanding. To make this possible, European and international youth work plays an extraordinary role. It enables young people to think outsidethe box and make friends across Europe. Youth associations and youth groups are the basis for the leisure and educational activities of millions of young people in Europe. In our civil society, we must ensure that the voluntary commitment of young people is valued and that youth work does not fall victim to bureaucratic hurdles. We are therefore in favor of strengthening and simplifying project funding via Erasmus+. We want to make Europe more tangible and easier to experience, especially for young people in our eastern neighboring countries such as Poland and the Czech Republic. We want to strengthen European youth work and focus on Eastern Europe.
Many people talk about young people and their needs. We want them to have their say and have a say in the Europe in which they live. They are currently massively underrepresented in the political arena. That is why it is good that young people in Germany aged 16 and over can now vote in the European elections for the first time. We are committed to ensuring that this becomes a
r e a l i t y a t a l l levels in all member states and in Germany.
Beyond the right to vote, we also want to further strengthen youth participation in Europe in structural terms. Through the EU Youth Dialogue, the EU has created a direct channel for the participation of young people and youth associations at European level. This is to be further strengthened and integrated into other participation formats. The results of these consultations should be incorporated even more strongly into the work of the EU Commission in future and young people and their representatives should be regularly consulted in future.
be heard in the European Parliament. We also support the EU Youth Check, which aims to review the impact of EU decisions on young people. The EU Youth Strategy sets out the guidelines for European youth policy. We want ensure that the further development of the EU Youth Strategy strengthens the interests of young people in all policy areas. To this end, existing participation formats for young people must be sensibly linked, structurally safeguarded and their connection to national participation structures ensured, and we are also committed to upgrading the position of EU Youth Coordinator.
Expanding voluntary services
A community is only as strong as the commitment of its members. Civil society has a special role to play here. The commitment of young Europeans in particular is fundamental - for example in refugee aid, projects to promote democracy, climate protection or social justice.
That is why we want to create one million places in the European Voluntary Service, especially for young people from low-income families. We must ensure better framework conditions for them, such as appropriate compensation, so that volunteering is something that everyone can afford. However, voluntary services also need clubs, associations and organizations to offer them. We want to strengthen these, as they create places of democracy and civic engagement. With a Voluntary Ecological Year (FÖJ or EYE - European Year for Ecology), we enable young people aged 18 and over to engage in an intercultural European exchange in the field of nature conservation and thus create the opportunity to stand up for Europe's nature.
Through the FÖJ, we want to motivate young
people to prepare and qualify for jobs in the climate and environmental sector.
We don't just want to offer this idea to young people. We also want to harness the experience, knowledge and commitment of senior citizens throughout Europe: Many of them have knowledge that they still want to use when they retire. With a European program, we want to provide the framework for senior citizens to participate in projects throughout the EU.
can work in training, placement or civil society.
Discover Europe
With the DiscoverEU program, 18-year-olds can experience the EU first-hand. Twice a year, so- called travel passes are raffled off among young people, allowing them to travel through Europe by train for 30 days during a specific period.
Together with other young people from different countries, they can discover just how diverse Europe is. This is why we support the DiscoverEU program and want to expand it in the future. Our aim is to create more shared experiences from many parallel journeys. We want to make the program better known, especially among young people from less affluent backgrounds. We also want to create incentives for
Groups from several European countries traveling together.
6. For an age-friendly Europe
The average age of people in Europe is the highest of any region in the world, and the trend is rising. We want demographic change to be seen as a challenge and an opportunity for us all. The knowledge, life experience and activity of Europe's older citizens can be an important factor for the cohesion of society. Thousands of elderly volunteers prove this every day: older people are discriminated against or excluded in many contexts, but this is often not immediately recognizable as such. That is why we want to better protect older people throughout Europe from discrimination in the workplace and in everyday life and create equal opportunities.
Accessibility in the world of work and in public spaces is important, and we want as many municipalities and regions in Europe as possible to join the global network of age-friendly cities and municipalities.
"Age-friendly cities and communities" of the WHO. Age-friendly cities and communities are also child-, family- and disability-friendly, and one of the network's aims is to enable people to age healthily, safely and independently in their living environment. People in old age and with increasing age-related limitations should also be able to remain in their own four walls, including barrier- free public transport networks and housing construction as well as heat protection measures for the elderly. We also advocate for more public places and opportunities that are designed in such a way that the generations can meet, interact and learn from each other in everyday life. In order to improve the situation of older people internationally, we will campaign for a UN convention on the rights of older people.
Everyone in Europe should have the opportunity to learn any other European language free of charge and without discrimination. For this
we want to advocate the creation of a European language learning app that can be used to learn any other European language. This is how we strengthen European identity.
7. Consumer protection
Understanding consumer protection as a locational advantage
The legal protection of consumers makes the EU a union of strong citizens. The freedoms for goods, capital, services and people in the European single market are among the EU's greatest locational advantages.
Consumer protection provides far-reaching safeguards for consumption, health and freedoms, making the EU a global pioneer: fee-free roaming, a user-friendly electricity market, modern infrastructure and safe and durable consumer goods are just a few examples.
And it works: a uniform charging cable for mobile devices, for example, promises to put an end to the tangle of cables in countless drawers. The binding European standard strengthens the European circular economy, reduces electronic waste and makes consumers' lives noticeably easier. We want to cover the entire spectrum of digital devices such as smartwatches, e-readers and headphones and also include wireless charging technologies.
Binding eco-design, i.e. production according to criteria of durability, reparability and ecological compatibility, provides consumers with better products. We are committed to the rapid implementation of the directives so that relevant product groups such as toys, furniture and clothing are covered in a timely manner.
If a product does break down, the European right to repair promises consumers long-term access to spare parts and repair instructions. A broken smartphone battery, printer or vacuum cleaner does not necessarily mean a new purchase. The lifespan of expensive or cherished purchases
is extended considerably with the right to repair. This means that durable and repairable products will be easier on people's wallets.
Update cycles and expiring update periods must be based on comprehensible and rational criteria. It is not in the interests of consumers if they are forced to buy new devices due to short update periods. This
We want to put a stop to "planned obsolescence" in the hardware and software sector.
Being able to use everyday products safely is becoming a matter of course with the EU. From food and clothing to cosmetics, toys and simple everyday items, safety comes first. Harmful substances, nanoparticles and residues of semi- metals or heavy metals that are harmful to health are found in many of these consumer and consumer goods. To ensure safety and transparency, we are expanding risk research and creating a register for nanoparticles.
We also want to shape the design of the European electricity market in the interests of consumers so that the price advantages of renewable energies are widely available. With transparent infrastructure costs that are as low as possible, the decoupling of the consumption price of renewable electricity from the rising costs of emissions trading and intelligent load management, the advantage of low-cost electricity generation remains with them.we protect electricity consumers from high costs by supplementing the promotion of renewable energies with a cap on revenues. We also strengthen consumer participation by enabling time-flexible electricity tariffs and simplified prosu- ming. This makes it easy to integrate heat pumps or wall boxes for electric cars into the electricity market, for example, and we are paying particular attention to protecting consumers in the area of medical products and aids. The plight of particularly vulnerable consumers is often exploited. Above all, we want to protect older people, carers and people with disabilities from unsuitable or overpriced products and give them access to individually tailored aids.
In order to combat the addictive mechanisms of betting, gambling and games on the Internet, which seek to entice users to wager more and more money, we will make it easier to identify mechanics with addictive potential and take greater account of them in age classifications across Europe.
Guarantee passenger rights
Freedom of travel in the EU should be comfortable and safe for all citizens. Passengers should be protected in their rights when traveling through Europe - whether by bus, train or plane. This is another reason why we want to use a cross- provider ticketing system to enable booking platforms to offer consistent tickets across borders, making traveling by train more attractive and significantly reducing planning costs. Meeting the needs of people with disabilities
We are committed to the comprehensive protection of passenger rights. Compensation for train delays should be increased to 50 percent of the ticket price after 60 minutes and 75 percent after 90 minutes, as called for by the European Parliament. In terms of the right to barrier-free mobility, we advocate the assumption of costs for alternative transportation options if the promised accessibility has not been met.
In addition, the rights of EU citizens, especially cross- border workers, should also apply to companies with different regional operations. We are committed to uniform minimum standards in local and regional transport. These should also apply to discounted tickets and interrupted travel chains.
Anyone who decides to travel by air should also arrive at their destination safely and on time. The amendment of air passenger rights is intended to close the existing gaps in consumer protection for air travel and further expand rights. We are strengthening consumers' entitlement to compensation in the event of delays or postponements of air travel. Travelers' claims should be
be included in the regulation in the event of a long delay of three hours or more. If flights are postponed, the deadline for informing travelers should be extended to four weeks before the start of the trip. References to the claim
on compensation should be placed prominently throughout.
Especially for travelers who only fly occasionally and families, the regulations for taking baggage with them are often intransparent and complicated. We are committed to a standardized regulation for the dimensions of carry-on baggage and transparent pricing for all baggage variants.
Cancellations must not be at the expense of passengers. That is why we want all airlines to have to insure themselves against insolvency.
Protect yourself from cost traps
should be the termination. Consumers often find it impossible to terminate contracts concluded online or have no certainty about the receipt and legal security of the termination. Being tied to unwanted or no longer needed contracts quickly becomes a cost trap. For long-term contracts that can be concluded online, we want to introduce an easily accessible termination button on the company's website. In this way, we will ensure a high level of consumer protection throughout Europe, following the German model. This will make the Europe-wide use of services simpler and safer. The burden of proof for proper implementation should lie with the companies. If this is not legally secure, this will not be to the detriment of consumers: Contracts should then be able to be terminated at any time without notice. We are committed to supplementing the relevant consumer directive and thus giving customers back control over their contracts.
Concluding contracts online has long been part of everyday life for many people and makes things much easier. Just as uncomplicated as concluding
 What protects peace 
The Russian war of aggression against our European neighbor Ukraine has shown that peace, freedom, security and human rights cannot be taken for granted: Peace and freedom, security and human rights cannot be taken for granted. They must be defended and strengthened again and again. Moscow has challenged the European Union (EU) peace project. We support our Ukrainian friends who are facing up to this challenge with all their strength - and are standing firm together.
But tensions are also increasing worldwide beyond Ukraine. China is becoming increasingly authoritarian, threatening its neighbors and challenging the rule-based international order.
China's competition with democracies around the world also poses significant challenges to our lives and economies. In Africa, Asia and South America, states and societies are calling for
meanwhile rightly demand more representation, a fair say and an equal seat at the negotiating table.
These shifts in the global power structure are challenging the EU. Together with the consequences of the pandemic, inflation, sovereign debt and climate crisis, they once again make it clear that we must join our democratic forces to protect peace in Europe and make a strong European contribution to the security of Europe and the world.
Together we are capable of acting. The EU has proven time and again how capable it is of working internationally for peace, security, the rule of law and sustainable development. It has proven this: Peace can be learned, stabilized and shaped for the benefit of all. The
gives hope in difficult times: An EU that acts confidently and constructively on the world stage and speaks with one voice is able to assert itself against unfreedom and war, defend our interests and values, fend off external influence, shape the future and peace - and noticeably improve people's lives. This Europe offers prospects for political and sustainable economic development worldwide - and thus an urgently needed counter- offer to the influence of China and Russia in particular.
That is our perspective, that is our political mission: the EU's global capacity to act
to defend and strengthen it. When many were still "Change through trade", the Greens have warned that autocratic regimes such as Russia act against the interests of their own citizens in orderto enforce their imperial goals by force. We therefore advocate a sovereign and self-confident Europe that does not wait and see, but takes the reins of action into its own hands; a Europe that frees itself from its dependencies and assumes global responsibility.
An EU that is capable of action and stands on its own two feet is the best protection against all those forces that conjure up isolation and exclusion, both within and outside the European alliance. Above all, the EU can effectively assert its interests if it also places its values at the center - the often claimed contradiction is not one.
Peace and freedom do not come from isolationism, but from values-based and fair dealings with our partners. The most important forum for this is the United Nations (UN) and its organizations, which we want to strengthen and make fairer and more representative. They are the best way to achieve multilateralism in which the strength of the law prevails, not the law of the strongest.
In these challenging times, the EU must actively seek all opportunities for international cooperation and use all channels of cooperation in order to preserve peace, realize human rights, strengthen democratic forces and promote the rule of law.
to prevent conflicts and promote prosperity. In addition to strengthening the relationship with In addition to its allies in the transatlantic and trans-Pacific region, the EU must actively seek partnerships with countries of the Global South.
We want to promote global justice in line with the Sustainable Development Goals. In doing so, we pay attention to the coherence of our political action across all policy areas such as economic and trade policy.
Often enough, however, women in particular are not at the table during negotiations. This makes it more difficult to develop fair and viable solutions. Societies are demonstrably more peaceful and prosperous when all people can participate in political, social and economic life. Peace and security are more sustainable when women are involved.
That is why we
We are actively committed to ensuring that women in particular are represented comprehensively and equally in foreign policy.
The most existential challenge facing humanity, the climate and environmental crisis, can only be tackled globally. Europe and the other industrialized countries have a special historical and dual responsibility due to their decades of emissions: in their own interest, they must quickly become climate-neutral themselves and at the same time support poorer countries in partnership on their path to climate-neutral and climate- adapted prosperity. This is why we are placing climate diplomacy at the center of our plan for a European foreign policy and thus paving the way for resilient partnerships - partnerships that create win-win situations and benefit both the people in our partner countries and help to secure our supply of renewable energy and raw materials. A strong European external climate policy also means that the EU must play a pioneering role in the implementation of the Paris Climate Agreement and, together with the private sector, make a decisive contribution to the necessary investments for climate-friendly development worldwide. In the same way, Europe must tackle the global biodiversity crisis: pursue ambitious goals itself, finance
and support the countries of the Global South in implementing their goals.
If the worst comes to the worst, we must be able to defend our peace in the alliance militarily. The use of military force remains the last resort for us. For the EU's ability to defend itself, overall national and societal resilience is also indispensable. To this end, it is essential to be able to withstand shocks and disruptions in the sense of a comprehensive concept of security. This includes increasing cyber security and the fight against disinformation, strengthening infrastructures as well as state and economic supply structures and strengthening civil protection. This can
We can do this better, more efficiently and more effectively if we coordinate our security policy at European level and exchange information faster and better. We want a comprehensive approach to European foreign policy that focuses on human security, focuses on the prevention and civilian management of crises and conflicts and actively seeks opportunities for de-escalation.
Those who contribute to maintaining peace prevent the need to create peace - this is how Europe protects itself. The commitment to a culture of non-violence, military restraint and a world without war is an important cross-cutting task that encompasses far more than the area of foreign policy. We think security in terms of each individual person, whose dignity and freedom are at the heart of our policy. This understanding of a precautionary and values-based security policy is part of the European promise.
Its weight, in turn, is most evident where there is invitation and hope. The aspirations of many Ukrainians to assert their freedom and become part of the European family may have been met with brutal armed force by Vladimir Putin. But it lives on and proves the power of the European project beyond its own borders. The idea of a common European home was linked to the wish that people from different nations could live together peacefully under one roof.
It is precisely this wish that Russia has clearly rejected with its war of aggression against Ukraine in violation of international law and against Ukraine's right to self-determination. Nevertheless, we are sticking to this wish. We are committedto the start of Ukraine's accession process - and at the same time see it as recognition of the immeasurable work that the country does every day for the security of us all and for European values.
The Europe we want to shape does exactly that. It protects and defends its own values. It asserts itself - and at the same time confidently reaches out to others. We want to work on this Europe.
This is the Europe we want to be.
1. A European foreign policy
Acting together on foreign policy
We need a strong and sovereign EU that can act as a global political player. So far, however, EU foreign policy still requires the approval of all 27 member states. We advocate an expansion of majority decisions in the Council that takes into account the interests of both the larger and smaller member states. In order to achieve this, we want to use the existing possibilities within the European treaties and at the same time advocate treaty amendments.
Our values and interests need a common EU voice
- we want to turn the existing role of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy into that of a European Foreign Minister. We also want to strengthen the European External Action Service in terms of personnel and institutions. In order to implement a common European foreign policy, we need a genuine European diplomatic service. That is why we want to firmly establish the European Diplomatic Academy in order to develop competencies in the area of EU foreign policy among
diplomats from the member states. We want to increasingly bundle consular services of the member states, such as visa issues, legal assistance or applications, in the European embassies.
At the same time, there is a need for better coordination of the foreign policies of the EU Member States and closer coordination between the European Commission and the European External Action Service. For better democratic control, we advocate a stronger role for the European Parliament in the Common Foreign and Security Policy.
We want to strengthen foreign cultural, education and science policy as well as science diplomacy, which can build cultural bridges in the face of major global challenges, have a positive impact on civil society, advance research and promote peace.
Protecting the climate globally and fairly
The climate crisis is the central global challenge of our time. It threatens livelihoods in many parts of the world and is driving millions of people to flee their homes. It is exacerbating conflicts over increasingly scarce resources such as food, water and raw materials. Its consequences are already having a noticeable negative impact on people's habitats and future opportunities.
No state can stop the climate crisis alone. Our goal is a strong European foreign climate policy that is in line with the Paris Climate Agreement and the sustainable development goals. We stand for an EU that establishes global climate partnerships to mitigate climate change.
emissions, supporting partner countries in the socially just and climate-neutral development and restructuring of their economic systems, infrastructure and energy supply as well as in adapting to the unavoidable consequences of the climate crisis. As one of the largest emitters of greenhouse gases in the world, the EU must, in accordance with the agreement in the Paris Climate Agreement, advocate that USD 100 billion per year from public and private sources for climate change mitigation and adaptation be mobilized quickly, in a targeted and targeted
manner.
in line with the UN's sustainability goals in countries of the Global South. Just Energy Transition Partnerships, which the German government has already concluded with several countries together with other international partners, are a model for this. They make offers for a comprehensive and socially just energy transition and modernization. We are also supporting the international process to design a loss-and-da- mage fund to provide appropriate financial support to communities affected by the effects of the climate crisis.
Our goal is to drive forward socio-ecological modernization in all areas. We are therefore committed to phasing out fossil fuels, a binding global target for the expansion of renewable energies and ambitious climate financing. This requires
additional funds to the Official Development Assistance (ODA) quota, taking into account the principle of "common but differentiated responsibilities" of the Paris Climate Agreement. International financial institutions such as the World Bank, the regional development banks, the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) must play an even greater role in modernizing the economies of our partner countries in a spirit of partnership.
We want to strengthen and expand the Team Europe approach - closer cooperation between the Commission, member states and EU financial institutions - in order to forge international alliances. The climate club proposed by the G7 can play a central role in supporting international structures within the framework of the Paris Agreement and promoting ambitious goals for climate protection, climate adaptation and sustainable growth. We would like to take the Federal Government's planned strategy for foreign climate policy as a basis for further development at European level.
Climate neutrality and the management of climate impacts must be incorporated into our international political action across all departments.
The climate crisis has long been a reality in many places. Despite all our efforts, this c r i s i s will force people to leave their homes.
Historically, the western industrialized countries are the main producers of climate-damaging greenhouse gases and therefore bear a special responsibility. The EU should therefore support the affected countries technically and, if necessary, financially with the necessary adaptation measures. In addition, Europe should lead the way together with other industrialized countries and support processes in which international regulation is discussed with affected states within the framework of international law to deal with climate-induced migration, flight and displacement as well as access to international protection.
Like the climate crisis, the global loss of species and biodiversity poses an enormous threat. That is why we want to accelerate the implementation of the Kunming-Montreal Convention on Biological Diversity
in Europe and worldwide. We are increasing European engagement with the countries most affected by biodiversity loss and supporting the protection of land while respecting the rights of indigenous peoples. Our goal is to put Europe's and the world's biodiversity on the road to recovery.
Making Global Gateway a success
In many parts of the world, there is a huge need for investment in order to achieve growth and prosperity with good mobility and digital participation. This must happen under the conditions of climate neutrality, climate adaptation and social justice. So far, the Chinese "New Silk Road" program, which creates financial dependencies and systematically uses them as political leverage, has been the main response to the need for investment.
