Money laundering and financial crime cause great financial damage to the state and society. In Germany alone, it is estimated that around 100 billion euros are "laundered" every year. The scandal surrounding Wirecard AG has harmed many thousands of small investors. We want to take decisive action against money laundering and financial crime. We will also target organized tax and subsidy fraud.
Financial investigations often offer initial investigative approaches and can help to deprive criminal groups of their business basis. We therefore want to strengthen instruments to better track financial flows in particular and to detect money laundering and the transfer of assets. For us, one thing is clear: crime must not pay!
We want to develop the new European anti-money laundering authority AMLA into a powerful institution in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. We are pushing for all EU member states to implement European and international standards for combating money laundering at national level without delay. In developing the AMLA, we are also working closely with the private sector, for example to shed light on cryptocurrency trading and take measures. In addition, the automatic exchange of tax information is to be intensified. We are committed to ensuring that international
an anti-money laundering action plan is driven forward at G7 / G20 level. We advocate a European asset register. Authorities across Europe should be allowed to view the beneficial owners of assets that are regularly misused by criminals for money laundering.
We will further restrict loopholes and opportunities to circumvent the transparency registers used to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. Access to the transparency registers should be simple, free of charge and anonymous for civil society, journalists, researchers and other groups with a legitimate interest. Real estate must be effectively protected against speculation by illegal money. This is also how we protect tenants. To this end, we will improve transparency regulations and controls on the acquisition of real estate.
We want to improve cross-border cooperation between law enforcement authorities and instruments in the area of asset recovery. It must be easier to confiscate assets of unclear origin in connection withcriminal activities. We will set EU- wide maximum limits for cash in ordertomake the transfer of incriminated funds more difficult. We will strengthen the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) in terms of personnel and funding sothat it can take effective action against fraud and corruption offenses, such as the misappropriation of European funding.
Stop terrorism
Terrorist attacks or acts of violence, currently mainly motivated by Islamist and far-right extremists, cause immeasurable human suffering. They are a threat to public safety. In recent years, the cross-border networking of violent groups and actors has increased. The EU can and must make an effective contribution to protection here.
Consistent and well-coordinated police and intelligence cooperation across Europe with uniform rule of law standards and definitions is necessary,
to take action against terror. To this end, we want to upgrade the position of the EU Anti-Terrorism Coordinator and oblige the member states to engage in more exchange and cooperation.
Good prevention work is the best way to prevent people from slipping into the political violence scene and terrorism. To do this, we need a Europe- wide exchange of experience between democratic forces, which we want to support financially. This includes educational work in schools and youth facilities. We want to establish deradicalization programmes or offers for people leaving the Islamist or right-wing extremist scene throughout the EU. We are closely monitoring the development of other and new forms of extremism, such as the delegitimization of the state relevant to the protection of the constitution. We incorporate findings from research and science into this. Online platforms, online gaming and messengers play an important role in the spread of terrorist propaganda. We want providers of such services to take more decisive action against this and delete the relevant content.
By resolutely combating the financing of terrorism, we want to remove the operational basis for terror. We focus on where terrorist and criminal structures overlap. In this way, we are preventing access to black markets and drying up important sources of finance or making access to weapons more difficult. We are committed to common standards and an intensive exchange in the prosecution of terrorists.
When monitoring potential violent criminals, a uniform approach is needed across Europe so that the security authorities do not lose track of them for administrative reasons. We therefore want to define the term "dangerous person" in a uniform way across the EU in order to ensure that cases are processed across borders.
In the past, serious acts of violence and terrorist attacks have repeatedly shown that firearms or explosive precursors are too easily available. We want to
restrict the availability of illegal firearms and dry up the black market. We want to introduce effective European standards for so-called prima facie weapons, such as collector's items, so that reactivation of the
weapons is no longer possible. Weapons and relevant weapon parts must be fully registered. We advocate common and strict standards for background checks for gun owners. We want to prevent the misuse of explosives precursors through strict monitoring.
Setting up intelligence services effectively
Cross-border terrorism, illegal activities by foreign intelligence services, industrial espionage and disinformation campaigns threaten our liberal and open society. Authoritarian states such as China, Russia and Iran in particular, but also criminal groups, are targeting the entire EU. In some cases, they coordinate their actions in the various member states. Examples of this include the massive spread of fake news - also to influence elections -, attacks on opposition members on EU territory or on our critical infrastructures (KRITIS). We in the EU must stand together and resolutely against this. The intelligence services play an important role in this and are part of a resilient democracy.
We are calling for effective intelligence services based on the rule of law, which will enable us to better guarantee the security of the EU. Up to now, their work has often been hampered by the fact that information and intelligence cannot be shared sufficiently within the existing European structures. We therefore want to establish a European Intelligence Agency (ENA) for better cooperation between European intelligence services, which will further develop the existing European intelligence structures, both civilian and military, on a clear constitutional basis.
It is intended to make knowledge gathered in the Member States
in compliance with strict legal requirements.
to strengthen the European analysis capability. In this way, strategic and long-term security policy assessments can be made. Strong, effective and democratically legitimized mechanisms based on the rule of law are needed to control the agency, which we want to develop with the involvement of the European Parliament.
We want to cooperate more closely in the development of European IT solutions in the area of intelligence services in order to secure digital sovereignty here too. We are committed to ensuring that intelligence service powers are based on clear legal foundations throughout Europe, are appropriately limited and are subject to strong parliamentary control in all member states.
Intelligence activities and instruments must be evaluated and be in line with civil rights. We reject the unlawful sharing of questionably obtained data between intelligence services. Furthermore, we advocate better networking and cooperation between the supervisory authorities of the Member States at European level.
Expanding joint prosecution
Efficient and joint prosecution of criminal offenses requires a uniform European legal framework - this applies to the entire spectrum, from OC to hate crime. To this end, we want to further harmonize criminal law in particular. We want to include hate crime in the list of EU criminal offenses so that
it can be tracked throughout Europe. This also requires uniform Europe-wide monitoring and regular dark field and victimization studies.
In order to enforce the law in Europe, we want to strengthen European structures: we want to improve the staffing and funding of Eurojust and expand the European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO). In future, it should also be responsible for cross-border cases in the area of terrorism and OC. We want to simplify cross-border criminal proceedings and bundle them in one country so that they can be carried out jointly.
can be conducted. By digitizing cross-border electronic legal transactions while maintaining IT security and data protection, we are creating faster and more efficient judicial cooperation in Europe. We all have a duty to protect children from sexualized violence. This requires structural reforms as well as investments in prevention work and more staff in counseling centers and the police. Instead of monitoring all private chat and messenger messages ("chat control"), we advocate targeted measures.
The focus is on the rights of citizens: We advocate effective legal protection for defendants and defense lawyers. Whistleblowers, witnesses and investigative journalists play a key role in the investigation of criminal offenses and violations of the law.
We therefore want to protect them better. To this end, we are proposing an EU network that offers effective protection across Europe for people involved in the detection and prosecution of criminal offenses. All this should help people to cooperate safely with the justice system in solving crimes. We want to make use of this. In future, the testimony of key witnesses should play a greater role in cross-border prosecutions.
Protecting the population
Natural disasters, serious accidents or humanitarian emergencies: extraordinary emergency situations can turn the lives of thousands of people u p s i d e d o w n and cause enormous environmental damage. Attacks on our critical infrastructure can also have incalculable consequences. They are the lifelines of our modern society. They supply us with
energy or information. Individual member states are quickly o v e r w h e l m e d by threats of this magnitude. The EU can provide practical help through its own resources and coordination - and thus protect security and prosperity on our continent.
We want to improve and combine the physical and digital protection of KRITIS.
We are taking transnational networks more strongly into
the view. We are introducing a mandatory IT vulnerability management system to prevent attacks on digital systems.
The climate crisis threatens to further increase extreme weather events with their sometimes unforeseeable consequences. Strengthening European civil protection can help to reduce damage. We want to further strengthen the European Civil Protection Mechanism and equip it with its own European capabilities. To this end, we initially want to set up a genuine E u r o p e a n fire-fighting aircraft squadron and integrate it into the rescEU reserve. In order to better protect the population and vulnerable groups in particular from extreme heatwaves, we want to support the member states in developing joint heat protection concepts. Europe also needs better preparation for transnational disasters. That is why we want to develop joint plans for risk prevention and management at
and think along with them across all planning
processes. We want to expand population health protection and, for example, capacities to provide assistance in the event of earthquakes or other major emergencies.
7. Digital civil rights
Safeguarding human rights in a digital world
Rapidly advancing digitalization has anenormous impact on theway we live together. That is why we are developing a human rights policy for the digital age based on our values. We want to strengthen the EU as a role model and partner for the rule of law and human rights in a globalized digital world. To this end, we must always consider people's rights when shaping the digital dimension. People have the right to live a self-determined life and not to be taken over by AI or other technologies.
We advocate that the digital space should better reflect our diverse society and that existing discrimination should not be transferred to the digital space.
is transferred. We promote consistent action against discrimination and the active participation of women in shaping digitalization. We want to strengthen the international legal framework for the digital space and be guided by the model of a free, open, global and secure internet.
We therefore reject instruments of mass surveillance. These include, for example, the unprovoked retention of pri- vate data or chat control, biometric facial recognition and the monitoring of behavior or emotions. In particular, we reject AI-supported technologies for the recognition of emotions or the attribution of sometimes highly personal characteristics such as gender, sexual orientation, political or trade union affiliation, also due to the potential impact on already marginalized groups. However, research and the use of emotion recognition in particular to provide support in the medical and social fields should not be affected by this. We want to strengthen and expand the right to digital privacy, secure communication and end-to-end encryption. We want to protect the anonymous use of the internet. Particular attention should be paid to ease of use by users. This is particularly important for free press reporting or for the work of opposition forces in authoritarian countries.
We clearly oppose the processing of comprehensive passenger data without cause and the expansion of corresponding systems to other sectors. Spyware is also used in the EU, which deeply invades privacy. We want to regulate the use of spyware more strictly and strengthen parliamentary oversight. Stronger action must be taken against misuse, for example to monitor journalists or public prosecutors.
Not everyone has the opportunity to make full use of digital services. Even though digitalization is advancing at a rapid pace, we are committed to ensuring that services that are necessary for participation in society are available to everyone.
The same applies to all other services that are necessary, such as doctors, authorities, banks or local publictransport, which remain accessible without additional costs.
Tackling hate and disinformation online
Access to reliable information and news is a prerequisite for democracy. Today, social media and other modern communication platforms make it possible for information and news to be prepared and discussed in a wide variety of ways.
Propaganda campaigns jeopardize the democratic formation of opinion. Elections and other opinion-forming processes as well as trust in our democratic institutions are being deliberately undermined by means of disinformation.
be influenced. We are resolutely opposed to this, for example with measures to strengthen media competence or the promotion of fact-checking platforms. We want to examine the possible inclusion of systematic disinformation in the catalog of EU criminal offenses. We also advocate theconsistent enforcement of sanctions against propaganda platforms that deliberately spread disinformation, such as Russia Today. We want regular, Europe-wide situation reports on disinformation to be drawn up in order to create the basis for an effective fight against it.
Hate, incitement and disinformation are deliberately attacking open debate in these places. Open misogyny is used in an attempt to force women out of the digital space. The instruments for combating violence against women as well as hate and incitement to hatred must be applied consistently. Stronger action must be taken against the publication of nude images without the consent of those affected. Algorithms and targeting on dominant digital platforms make a significant contribution to this byincreasing the spread of hate messages and disinformation. As a result, people affected by hate speech often withdraw or restrict their expression of opinion - to the detriment of democratic debate.
We are targeting the algorithmic amplification of hate and hate speech. Hate speech must be deleted consistently and accounts spreading it must be blocked. We are committed to fast and simple procedures. With the Digital Services Act (DSA) and the Digital Markets Act (DMA), we have laid the foundations in Europe for countering hate speech with user rights, transparency and clear rules, creating a more democratic internet and restoring competition. These rules must now be consistently enforced and further developed in Germany and Europe. Hate and disinformation must not be a profitable business model. We want to examine measures to dry up such business models, for example by skimming off the profits generated by them.
Civil society organizations must be able to support people affected by hate and hate speech more easily in exercising their rights. To this end, we also want a Europe-wide
Establish victim counseling and low-threshold offers of help. Civil society organizations should be allowed to represent victims in proceedings or take action on their own initiative in cases of incitement to hatred.
We want to support the establishment of special units within the police and public prosecutor's offices in the member states. The consistent enforcement of criminal law can also be supported by the legally secured automated detection of criminally relevant material, such as hate posts, which is then checked by the investigating authorities. Euro- pol should take action against Europe-wide networks that specifically spread hate and hate speech online.
At the same time, traditional media can also play an important role in the spread of disinformation if, for example, they take information from social media without verification or even actively contribute to the spread of misinformation themselves. The dissemination of high-quality fake videos, so-called deepfakes, or AI-manipulated
Images make disinformation appear even more credible and are difficult for many people to recognize. This is why we have successfully anchored the adequate labeling of deepfakes in the AI Act. An important building block in the fight against disinformation in a democracy lies in strengthening information literacy so that people can better recognize disinformation.
So-called social bots, which automatically distribute content on social media, must be labeled accordingly and thus be distinguishable from human users.
Protecting Europe's IT
As our digital infrastructure plays an increasingly important role in our coexistence, its protection is of great importance. However, the best protection against cybercrime lies in the prevention and resilience of digital systems. We ensure that high IT security requirements are consistently established in digital products, services and processes. We are committed to the swift implementation of the updated EU directive on cyber security in order to establish an EU-wide level of security. In order to make the security of IT products transparent for consumers and increase the level of IT security in the private sector, we want to examine the introduction of an IT security label at European level. We want to strengthen European cooperation in the area of cyber security.
security and are committed to a common
European security architecture. We are further developing the European Union Agency for Cyber Security (ENISA), the work of the European Information Sharing and Analysis Center (ICAC) and the foreign policy instrument of the "Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox" for this purpose.
Cyberspace is increasingly becoming the scene of wars and conflicts. We can see this clearly in Ukraine, where Russia's military aggression is being accompanied by cyber operations.
Cyberattacks, for example on digital electoral and administrative systems, are also a threat to our democracy and security. We are committed to
a norm- and rule-based cyberspace characterized by diplomacy and international cooperation. At the same time, cyber security goes hand in hand with digital sovereignty. We want to expand competencies in the EU in this area.
We want to create the legal and technical framework for secure "digital embassies" in Europe. This should enable state and publicly relevant databases and technical infrastructures in other European member states to be kept secure in ordertoenablethe ability to work and access to data, for example from parliaments, public administration, the judiciary or social insurance, even in crisis and war situations.
The rapid pace of digitalization and the increase in digital services have also led to a shift of crimes to the internet. Law enforcement must respond to this, especially at a European level, because cybercrime, like the internet, knows no borders.
To this end, we are strengthening Europol's role in the fight against online crime. We are also strengthening Europe-wide police cooperation to detect and combat crime. We are also taking decisive action against the spread of sexualized violence against children and young people online by strengthening the investigative authorities in terms of personnel, technology and procedural law. To this end, we also want to use the possibility of automated applications to support investigations. We want to use targeted campaigns to raise citizens' awareness of fraudulent crimes that are committed online.

Preamble
¦ Rethinking Europe
Since its foundation, the Alternative for Germany has stood by the idea of a Europe of fatherlands, a European community of sovereign, democratic states that work together for the benefit of their citizens in all those tasks that can be better accomplished together.
The EU and its supporting elites abandoned the founding fathers' original idea of a European community many years ago. They are continuously eroding the sovereignty of nation states and striving for an EU superstate. Such an entity has neither a nation nor the necessary minimum level of cultural identity, which are essential prerequisites for successful, democratically constituted states.
The complete failure of the EU in all areas that affect Europe's existence is exemplified by the negligently induced migration crisis. Although the protection of Europe's external borders is one of the EU's essential tasks, it is standing idly by in the face of illegal mass immigration organized by criminal smuggling gangs. Borders must once again be understood for what they are: as protection against attack and appropriation, as a distinction between one's own and foreigners, as a prerequisite for sovereign statehood.
Another misguided development can be seen in climate and energy policy. The dogma of man-made climate change serves as a pretext for the EU to intervene and regulate all areas of life. EU programs such as the "Green Deal" and "Fit for 55" are having a destructive effect on the European and, in particular, the German economy. None of these measures will have any impact on the global climate in the foreseeable future.
We consider the idea of a single currency for countries with completely different economic development and structures to be a failure. It is a political wishful thinking that cannot be reconciled with economic laws. The resulting high inflation leads to the creeping disenfranchisement of citizens.
As an economic and export nation, Germany is catastrophically affected by the EU's sanctions policy. We reject any dominance of non-European superpowers in European foreign and security policy. The states of Europe are thus drawn into conflicts that are not their own and are diametrically opposed to their natural interests - fruitful trade relations in the European-Asian region. It is therefore necessary for Europe to gradually take its defense capabilities into its own hands. A defensible Germany is indispensable for our sovereignty and security in a fundamentally changing world. The passivity of the German government after the Nord Stream pipelines were blown up shows the extent to which a large European state is giving up on itself. Supplying weapons to war zones does not serve peace in Europe either.
All crises since 2008 - the global financial crisis, euro crisis, migration crisis, corona crisis, energy crisis, inflation crisis and the alleged climate crisis - have been used to drive forward the EU's statehood, supported by the European Court of Justice and an autocratic bureaucracy. Their determination was demonstrated not least by the fact that, "if necessary", they even violated treaty principles on the functioning of the EU, such as the ban on liability for foreign debt (Art. 125 TFEU) and the ban on borrowing to finance the EU budget (Art. 311 TFEU).
We believe that the EU cannot be reformed and see it as a failed project. We therefore strive for a "Confederation of European Nations", a newly founded European economic and interest grouping in which the sovereignty of the member states is safeguarded. The welfare of Germany and its citizens is our top priority.
We consider (1) a common market, (2) the effective protection of external borders against illegal immigration, (3) the attainment of strategic autonomy in security policy action and (4) the preservation of European culture and its various identities to be the central common interests of this alliance. Resting on these pillars, the member states can autonomously and flexibly conclude functional bilateral or multilateral treaties according to their needs. Peace and a balance of interests must be at the heart of this. "Unity and strength on the outside - national diversity on the inside" is our formula for the European pole in the emerging multipolar world order.
A Europe of nations
¦ The EU is an undemocratic and unreformable construftt
The EU is undemocratic because the European Parliament is not elected according to the original democratic principle of equal voting weight for each voter. Instead, Art. 14 para. 2 sentence 3 TEU stipulates a "degressively proportional" election mode, which leads to large differences in the weight of votes within the electorate. The smaller the country, the greater the weight of the individual vote.
The Council, as the most important legislative body of the EU, consists of members who are also members of national executive bodies. This also represents a violation of a fundamental principle of any democracy, namely the separation of powers.
The European Court of Justice uses the "doctrine of the primacy of Union law" to arbitrarily override the constitutions and constitutional courts of the Member States. There is no basis for this in the treaties. Moreover, it sees itself as a driver of integration and not just as a mediator in disputes.
Our criticism of the EU's democratic deficits illustrates that the EU is failing to meet the democratic standards it has set itself and that only the nation state can be an authentic source of democracy. However, even if the EU were to succeed in remedying its democratic deficit, this would not solve the fundamental problem. Irrespective of democratic deficits, the EU is increasingly developing into a European federal state in which the individual member states are degraded to mere constituent states without their own sovereignty. The only way to counter this is a consistent return to the principle of unanimity between the member states.
All measures of the so-called euro rescue violate the treaty prohibition of credit financing of EU states according to Art. 123 TFEU and the treaty prohibition of aid ("no bail out" clause) of Art. 125 TFEU - as happened with the debt relief and financial aid for Greece in 2012 and the unconditional distribution of money to all EU states from the EU budget in 2022 according to the "Reconstruction Program for Europe" (NextGenerationEU). Their repayment will be disproportionately imposed on the net payers among the euro member states, which have received disproportionately low funding.
While the single market in the EEC prospered and created prosperity for all participating states, under the EU regime international competitiveness is increasingly being strangled by over-regulation of the EU and the common currency of the eurozone.
S	D
¦ The EU project has failed
The EU has developed into an undemocratic construct that is attracting more and more power to itself and is governed by a non-transparent, unchecked bureaucracy.
The Schengen, Maastricht and Lisbon treaties have undermined the principle of popular sovereignty. The attempt to dissolve functioning democratic nation states and replace them with a kind of European superstate is doomed to failure. The diversity of European cultures and languages is the result of centuries of historical developments. It is a source of identity for us all. It is illusory to want to replace national identities with a "European identity". There is no such thing as a European nation, which would be a basic prerequisite for such a project, nor are there any signs that such a nation will emerge. The widely differing national languages alone prevent this.
We reject an EU that wants to become a state with legislative powers and its own government, as well as the idea of a "United States of Europe". Only in nation states with a democratic constitution can the sovereignty of the people and the fundamental rights of citizens be lived and preserved.
As the EU cannot be reformed in line with the AfD, we advocate the reestablishment of a European
economic and interest community.
¦ A federation of European nations
The peoples of Europe are bound together by a shared history and their orientation towards common humanitarian values of coexistence. In particular, Greek philosophy, Roman law, Christianity and the Enlightenment have had a formative effect on all European peoples. This also includes the separation of spiritual and secular power as well as the free development of science and art, which have formed the basis for Europe's leading role in the world since the beginning of the modern era.
In view of the fact that the EU cannot be reformed, we advocate the establishment of a federation of European nations. The AfD believes that the decision on a new form of coexistence of the peoples of Europe in Germany should only be made by referendum.
Freedom and self-determination of the member states
Any restriction of the sovereignty of each European state by the interests of the newly created community is ruled out, as is the establishment of community norms that take precedence over national constitutions. In principle, freedom of contract should apply to every state and every individual policy area on the basis of international law with a regulated right of withdrawal. This ensures that treaties are only concluded and continue to exist as long as they are beneficial to all contracting parties and do not unreasonably and permanently restrict their sovereignty.
Transparency is also the top priority for government activities in all intergovernmental agreements. Every citizen has the right to full information.
Interstate disputes are to be settled by a court whose judges are delegated by the national constitutional courts.
Single market with Destination country principle
We are committed to the social market economy, the common market, the customs union and a common trade policy. The Community guarantees unrestricted reciprocal market access. Immigration into the social systems is effectively prevented. Structurally identical countries can retain or create a common currency.
A common external border protection: Fortress Europe
Mass immigration must be stopped in order to protect European nations and cultures. The protection of Europe's external borders is the first and most important Community task. It includes the construction of physical barriers, technical surveillance and the deployment of border guards. Implementation is delegated to national authorities on the basis of multilateral treaties.
¦ The path to a union of European nations
A primary goal of the AfD in the existing EU Parliament is to win over parties from all countries for the future project of a new European economic and interest community in the upcoming election period. Together with them, we want to concretize our ideas.
As long as the misconstruction of the EU continues, we will work to prevent further restrictions on national sovereignty and further redistribution of our citizens' wealth and assets through EU regulations.
Referendums on the EU at Federal level
There must be no treaties in Germany regarding EU enlargement and the granting of sovereign rights and liability commitments without a referendum. It is the self-evident right of every people in the European Union to vote on remaining in the EU, monetary union and other supranational projects. This right has been denied to us in Germany by the parties that have been in power for decades.
Abolish the EU Parliament
We want to abolish the undemocratically elected EU Parliament. Until the situation is reorganized, legislative competence will be transferred solely to the Council, whose members must, however, be bound by the decisions of the national parliaments in their voting behavior.
¦ The EU - centralism and bureaucracy
Europe's leading political decision-makers have bloated the European Union into a monstrous bureaucracy and administrative apparatus: twelve EU institutions with more than 32,000 employees, personnel costs of over eight billion euros, 25 EU agencies with a publicly unknown number of employees and legions of service providers such as interpreters and experts. MEPs, commissioners, civil servants and other EU employees receive inappropriately high salaries and excessive pension entitlements, including tax-free allowances. In the EU, for example, around 4,000 EU officials earn more than the German Federal Chancellor ( 290,000 gross/year), the head of government of the largest EU member state.
Until a new European economic and interest community is founded, we will support any reduction in the administrative apparatus. The funding of European parties and their foundations from taxpayers' money must be stopped.
Lobbying, corruption and enrichment
Due to the lack of proximity to citizens, the lack of transparency of the EU institutions, their far-reaching regulatory power and their decisions on huge amounts of money, a machinery of representatives with more than 25,000 lobbyists has spread throughout the EU. The influence on the Brussels bureaucracy is intensive and uncontrollably shameless; sometimes EU legal acts are drafted directly by the lobbyists. The measures taken to regulate lobbying following countless scandals are inadequate and largely ineffective. We are therefore calling for a mandatory lobby register in which all contact with lobbyists is published promptly and in full.
Information and Transparency
While lobbyists and interest representatives are informed comprehensively and in advance, citizens are generally denied information from the EU institutions. In negotiations on trade agreements such as TTIP, even the democratically elected representatives of the nation states were kept in the dark. That is why we are calling for an unrestricted right to information for all citizens and maximum transparency through mandatory publication of all data generated in the EU institutions along the lines of the Hamburg Transparency Act. All privileges for lobbyists must be abolished. Non-governmental organizations (NGOs) must publish an annual report detailing their financial sources and activities.
Bodies that serve to circumvent democracy, such as a "Conference for the Future of Europe",
We as the AfD reject "citizens' councils" and the like! These are simulations of democracy that are intended to conceal the existing democratic deficits.
Fundamentalist Islam - a danger for Europe
We want to preserve Europe in the spirit of freedom and with its democratic values for us and our descendants in the long term. We defend Europe against a social regression caused by fundamentalist Islam, whose rules of life from the Koran and Sunnah cannot be reconciled with the basic European principles of law, freedom and democracy. Fundamentalist Islam, which is still valid today, sees itself not only as a religion, but also as the only authoritative legal and social order that wants to enforce its claim to rule over all people by means of Sharia law. This Islam makes no distinction between state and religion. Sharia law regulates not only the private lives of Muslims, but also all areas of social coexistence. In contrast, the legal systems of European countries provide for unrestricted freedom of faith, conscience and religion, as enshrined in the Basic Law's catalog of fundamental rights (Art. 4). Freedom of religion is alien to fundamentalist Islam. Islam sees itself as the only valid religion on earth to which all people must be converted. Turning away from Islam (apostasy) is punishable under Islamic law.
Since the 1960s, more and more migrants have gradually arrived in Germany and Europe, particularly from Islamic countries. This trend has continued to accelerate over the past twenty years and has taken on enormous proportions since 2015. In many countries of the European Union, such as Sweden (Malmö) with its extremely liberal immigration policy, France (Parisian banlieue, Marseille) with its former colonies on the African continent or Brussels (Molenbeek), this has led to unsolvable integration problems in the form of ghettoization.
and rampant crime. In some countries, such as France, Belgium and the Netherlands, entire districts are already inhabited by Islamic immigrants. The native population has been almost completely displaced. Such a development, which prevents the integration processes necessary for coexistence, must be avoided.
Immigration to EU countries must be subject to strict rules and massively restricted. Unequal legal and social treatment of men and women cannot be tolerated in our liberal democratic states. Child marriages, polygamy and forced marriages under Islamic law are not compatible with our legal system. This also applies to ritual genital mutilation. The applicable criminal law must be consistently enforced. Following the French model, the full veiling of women in public should be banned.
¦ Recognizing Muslim anti-Semitism and combating it
The romanticized glorification of immigration often obscures the newly emerging anti-Semitism in Europe, which has its roots in Islam. We therefore call for the social ostracism of all forms of anti-Semitism - even if the perpetrators are to be found in the left-wing or Muslim milieu.
Preserving the identity of nations
The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union postulates "respect for the diversity of cultures and traditions of the peoples of Europe and for the national identities of the Member States". In direct contrast to this political promise, we have been experiencing an asylum and migration policy in Europe for years that has led to massive social upheaval. The rifts are getting deeper and deeper. The EU community of states currently lacks a common political will to adequately analyze the migration issue, in particular to assess its long-term effects and to develop political strategies on this basis. The German government's migration policy has further increased Germany's magnetic effect on uncontrolled and illegal migration. This contributes significantly to the fact that the criminal smuggling business cannot be brought under control and that there is rampant immigration, particularly into the German social system.
The German government's stance is turning Germany's loss of control into a permanent state of affairs, which is overburdening the federal government, the federal states and local authorities financially, logistically, in terms of support and security policy. One of the main reasons for this is the continuing inadequate protection of the EU's external borders. In order to preserve the positive aspects of the Schengen area, Germany must abandon its pseudo-moral arrogance and initiate results-oriented political processes on this fateful issue within the EU. The AfD supports a migration policy that brings about a turnaround. This includes, in particular, effective external border protection that prevents illegal entry. Immigration to Europe must be managed in such a way that the peace and identity of the European cultural area and its nations are preserved.
¦ National sovereignty in asylum and immigration policy
Only the national parliaments have the necessary democratic legitimacy to decide on the type and scope of immigration, which is an existential issue for a community. The self-determination of the EU member states in asylum and immigration policy must therefore be restored.
The Common European Asylum System (CEAS) must be removed from the European Treaty (TFEU) and responsibility for asylum and immigration policy returned to the nation states. This would be a situation similar to that which already exists in Denmark today.
Preventing migration from crisis regions must focus on local aid in order to enable as many people as possible to find refuge close to home and remove the incentive for dangerous journeys. Strict border protection is required, combined with the rejection of illegal migrants - as far as possible at the EU's external borders, if necessary at the German border. If asylum seekers reach Germany despite border protection, their asylum procedures must be carried out in a third country that is prepared to do so, where they will also be accepted if they are actually in need of protection ("Rwanda model"). For humanitarian reasons, we support the voluntary and exclusively temporary admission of a sovereignly determined number of particularly vulnerable persons, for example in the course of medical care for children, as a further option. At the same time, we would like to point out that we are only in favor of such humanitarian admissions and that they can only be communicated to citizens once Germany's massively overstretched financial, material and cultural reception capacities have recovered. The indispensable prerequisites for such a recovery are consistent action against illegal migration and a tight restriction and control of legal migration. Internationally, we are focusing on increased cooperation in the care of genuine refugees close to home and the establishment of local protection centers. We reject international regulations and obligations to take in people willing to migrate - as provided for in the UN migration pact and the UN refugee pact.
In coping with the flight from Ukraine, the approach of granting protection close to home, i.e. granting temporary refuge to Ukrainian war refugees in Europe, has proven its worth. Germany's resources are exhausted after taking in one million Ukrainians, which is why the Ukrainians who are still fleeing must be forwarded to the countries in Europe that have been far less affected to date on the basis of the solidarity mechanism anchored in the Mass Influx Directive. In addition, third-country nationals arriving via Ukraine must be immediately returned to their home countries if this is safely possible.
¦ Protection from criminals and dangerous individuals is indispensable
The right to life and limb of people in Germany must be given higher priority than the protection of criminals and terrorists from deportation to countries with a difficult security situation. Numerous acts of violence and homicides in recent years could have been avoided by the timely deportation of criminals. If criminals cannot be deported to their countries of origin, they should be transferred to third countries that are willing to accept them.
¦ End Germany's loss of control
Germany is a migration magnet in the middle of Europe due to the very high social benefits compared to other European countries, even for rejected asylum seekers who are obliged to leave the country. In addition, there is a lack of willingness to repatriate and regulations on the right to stay, which overall lead to a consolidation of residence for those obliged to leave the country and to later naturalization. As a result of this political failure, Germany has for years recorded a similar number of asylum seekers as the classic immigration countries Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the USA combined. By unconditionally accepting illegal secondary migration via other EU states, Germany has taken on an outsider's role in other European countries. We will put an end to this fatal policy. In particular, we will stop all
Abolish the right to stay for those obliged to leave the country. In addition, recognized asylum seekers must not automatically be granted permanent residence and German citizenship. As soon as it is possible to return to a country of origin, this must be enforced. We will put an end to the unreflected and unrestricted German "welcome culture" - similar to Sweden, Denmark or Great Britain!
¦ Amendment of the Schengen Agreement
Due to the lack of external border security, there is still an uncontrolled influx of foreigners entering the country illegally. The "borderless Europe" created by the Schengen Agreement increasingly poses a threat to the internal security of individual nation states and creates considerable risks not only in the area of terrorism, but also with regard t o organized and gang crime. Internationally active gangs of burglars and robbers make use of this "freedom", as do people and drug traffickers. In Germany alone, there has been a significant increase in all forms of organized crime; the same applies to violent crime.
Cross-border and migration-related crime is reflected in the official statistics. For example, more than 65,000 cases of domestic burglary were reported nationwide in 2022 - an increase of 21.5% compared to the previous year. So-called knife attacks have also reached a high level: in Berlin alone, more than 3,300 attacks involving the use of a knife were recorded in 2022; of the cases solved, more than half were committed by foreign suspects.
The existing options for refusing entry to criminals and sending them back must be intensified. However, this requires consistent and effective border controls. Temporarily introduced border controls, for example, have yielded corresponding successes: for example, more than 400 arrest warrants were executed during the G7 summit in 2022.
The Schengen Agreement therefore requires a comprehensive reform so that the sovereign nation states can once again guarantee their own internal security through efficient border protection. This also includes the consistent rejection of so-called economic migrants at the Schengen external borders by an appropriately equipped and jointly financed Frontex unit.
As a result, the AfD is striving for dual border protection. This means that the external borders of the Schengen area and the European Union are protected jointly by the community of states, but that the individual member states are also allowed to carry out border controls on their own initiative and take other proportional measures to prevent illegal migration at their own national borders in accordance with the rule of law.
¦ Internal security and justice are national tasks
For years, the EU has arrogated to itself competences that are reserved for nation states under the EU treaties, including in the areas of police and justice. For example, the European Public Prosecutor's Office was established alongside the existing authorities Europol and Eurojust.
The effective police cooperation between Germany and Switzerland on the basis of the German-Swiss police treaty, for example, shows that there is another way. That is why we are focusing on a substantial and practical facilitation of all mutual legal assistance traffic through inter-
state agreements. Otherwise, there is a risk of a further transfer of sovereign powers from the nation states to the EU level. We oppose this as well as the creation of supranational authorities.
We clearly reject any restriction of the sovereignty of nation states through EU legislation, including in the area of internal security.
¦ Fending off Islamist terrorist potential and combating
The open Schengen borders in conjunction with inadequate EU external border protection make it difficult to clearly identify illegal immigrants. Mass immigration has led to Islamist radicalization tendencies becoming a comprehensive security problem. In Germany alone, a total of 28,290 people were registered in 2021 who are classified as "Islamism/Islamist terrorism".
Terrorist attacks across Europe in recent years have shown that the likelihood of new attacks remains very high. It is therefore of the utmost importance in terms of security policy to ensure an intensive exchange of information with regard to dangerous individuals in Europe. In order to be able to counter this threat situation in the long term, we call for the closest possible cooperation between European security authorities in addition to combating parallel societies. The ideological radicalization of children has become an important security issue in the EU. Children from Muslim fundamentalist homes in particular are at the mercy of radical ideologues who repeatedly call for violence in religious sermons. The EU member states have a responsibility to protect children and young people from indoctrination.
¦ Fortress Europe
To protect our freedom, our way of life and our identity, irregular and illegal mass immigration to Europe from culturally unfamiliar regions must be stopped.
The protection of the external borders of the European Union is seen as the responsibility of all Member States. It includes the construction of effective physical barriers, modern technical surveillance and the deployment of border guards. It is carried out by national authorities in cooperation with the Federal Border and Coast Guard Agency.
All costs associated with the protection of external borders are borne by the Community. The national authorities of the border states may request the assistance of authorities from other Member States in crisis situations. In this case, federal and state police forces support other Member States in controlling their external borders. They then act as support for the police and border guards of the respective state. The border states are also authorized to call in technical and personnel support from their armed forces (military) to carry out border protection.
Third countries whose airlines are unable or unwilling to guarantee correct and complete checks on the entry credentials of passengers with European destinations will be excluded from flying to these destinations. Entry controls at international airports on the territory of the European Union are to be tightened, passengers without entry authorization will be returned to their departure airport without exception and on the next flight.
On the seas, smugglers' boats are escorted back to their ports of origin or the nearest non-European ports without exception. Temporary transfers of persons to coast guard vessels only take place in exceptional cases to avert an imminent danger to the life and limb of migrants and must under no circumstances result in the entry of migrants into Europe. The effective protection of its external borders is a visible and tangible expression of the constitution and demarcation of the European pole in the multipolar world order. It makes it unmistakably clear: this is where Europe begins and this is where Europe decides who gets access.
¦ The future role of the EU: supporting Member States in border management, repatriation and assistance on the ground
In future, the role of the EU institutions in migration policy should focus on practical and formal assistance in the implementation of external border protection and deportations, as well as diplomatic negotiations on repatriation agreements, in strict compliance with the principle of subsidiarity. In order to finance effective border protection facilities, the EU's investments must be significantly increased. On the other hand, the temporary practice of the European border protection agency Frontex of indirectly providing assistance to smuggling gangs should be rejected. It turns the idea of border protection into its opposite. We want to restrict development aid, the issuing of visas, access to the European labor market and market access to the EU to those states that take back people who are obliged to leave the country.
¦ Remigration instead of talent recruitment
The millions of young people from developing countries in Africa and the Middle East being admitted to Europe are depriving the countries of origin of those high performers who are urgently needed there for development and reconstruction (so-called "brain drain"). Due to the high standard of living in this country, the drive to contribute to the development of the country of origin is often lost. This creates a vicious circle of even greater impoverishment; uncontrolled emigration from these countries is therefore itself a cause of further migration movements.
As soon as peace is restored in most areas of a country of origin, the EU or Germany must immediately negotiate the conditions for the return of asylum seekers who have been accepted here and enforce this return consistently. Protection from the consequences of war should only be granted for the duration of the war and must not lead to permanent immigration. The order of the day is not "resettlement", i.e. resettlement programs to Europe, but the opposite: remigration programs must be established and expanded at national and European level.
¦ Border protection is Citizen protection
The incompatibility of Schengen and Dublin also leads to the dysfunctionality of the European asylum system, as migrants cross open borders in the Schengen area unhindered and thus reach Germany from the EU countries of first entry. Notification of the German internal border to the EU Commission is therefore necessary until German sovereignty over our borders is restored. This is the only way that the Federal Police can act as a border protection authority, as the EU internal border would then become an external border and the Federal Police would become a border authority. Detention centers to be set up near the border would serve to secure measures to end residence in the event of inadmissible applications for protection. In this way, unauthorized persons would not be allowed to enter the country in the first place. This would eliminate time-consuming and cost-intensive administrative and
1C	17
Legal proceedings that have been putting a huge strain on the administrative authorities, the courts and all security forces for years.
¦ EU freedom of movement: reduce privileges - end abuse
The EU Freedom of Movement Directive grants EU citizens in Germany a legal status that is almost completely equivalent to that of German nationals. This legal provision has led to massive migration movements within the EU from poorer to richer countries. We demand that poverty migration into the national social systems be prevented more consistently than in the past, including at EU level. Against this backdrop, the criteria for the free movement of workers within the EU must be tightened.
EU citizens who are a permanent financial burden on another EU country or who commit serious crimes must be able to be easily and permanently expelled from the country. In addition, all EU countries must be given the opportunity to make entitlement to tax-financed social benefits dependent on at least ten years of continuous employment subject to social insurance contributions without state subsidies. In order to make the Western Balkans an important part of Europe, the AfD advocates a privileged partnership with the countries of this region. Migration via these states must be contained through close security cooperation. The AfD rejects the admission of these states to the EU, but supports the formation of self-determined economic associations on the ground, such as the "Open Balkans" initiative.
¦ Defense against migration as a means of hybrid warfare
In recent years, migration movements have been used specifically as a means of hybrid warfare and for the purpose of political blackmail. For this reason, fixed border facilities must be set up at the external border, the costs of which must be borne by the international community. Airlines involved in the transportation of illegal migrants should have their landing rights in the EU revoked. Countries that deliberately turn themselves into hubs for illegal migration should be deprived of all financial support. In addition, a visa requirement should be introduced for entry into the EU.
¦ Control instead of Human trafficking
Criminal trafficking gangs are also supported by the work of so-called non-governmental organizations (NGOs), often from Germany. Their business model leads to people risking their lives in the dangerous crossing of the Mediterranean. The AfD is committed to consistently combating these inhumane activities. The smuggling of third-country nationals into the EU by non-governmental organizations must be prohibited as a serious criminal offence in the future. People rescued from distress at sea must be brought to their ports of origin or the nearest non-European port. This requires a visible signal from all EU states that illegal entry via the Mediterranean must not lead to a right to stay in Europe. We want to launch broad-based information campaigns, financed by the EU, to draw attention to the dangers and hopelessness of a crossing.
¦ Qualified immigration based on the Japanese model
The emigration of domestic, mostly highly qualified workers should be prevented as far as possible. Instead of such emigration, we need recovery programs for expatriate Germans
top performers. Technological solutions such as artificial intelligence (AI), robotics and digitalization, which can replace human labour, or economic productivity increases also have priority over immigration. In the case of unskilled workers, it is primarily those who are able to work and already live in Germany today who need to be qualified. In addition, there are workers who come to Germany within the framework of the EU free movement of workers, ana logical regulations with the EFTA countries or the Western Balkans regulation. A priority check must be carried out in future as part of the Western Balkans regulation. We reject an extension to other countries, such as the Maghreb states, as well as the immigration of unskilled workers from third countries.
With regard to skilled workers, we will introduce a strict priority and alternative test. First of all, it is imperative that domestic potential and the European labor market are exploited. For non-European skilled workers, the immigration law for skilled workers must be reformed in line with the "Japanese model". As part of a selection process, we will introduce a points system with clear selection criteria, such as sufficient language skills, combined with an annual determination of sectors and quotas by the federal government, depending on the economic situation and the situation on the labor market. For highly qualified non- European applicants, we want to further develop the proven instrument of the EU Blue Card and in future target experts in the STEM professions (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) in particular.
Monetary policy: the euro has failed
¦ Back to justice, prosperity and social peace in Europe through the reintroduction of national currencies
The AfD advocates a monetary policy based on a market economy, national responsibility and friendly cooperation between European states. The creeping transformation of the European union of states into a centralized EU state, which has been progressing for 30 years, has never been democratically legitimized by the European peoples. The euro does not have the institutional basis that would be a constitutional prerequisite for its legitimacy. The stability criteria as the basis for the euro currency are constantly being violated. The euro has been "rescued" with billions for years. We are experiencing joint liability in violation of the treaty, transfer payments, debt at EU level, prohibited state financing and (planned) economic policy by the ECB and EU in violation of their mandates - all largely at the expense of Germany.
The euro is a misconstruction for an economic area with 20 very different economies and cannot function in this form either economically or socially. Unemployment in southern Europe has been alarmingly high for years. This is the result of the loss of competitiveness of these countries within the euro corset. Every supranational monetary union in history has failed so far. Only through national currencies will each country regain its sovereignty over its economic and monetary policy. This will also resolve the internal conflicts in the eurozone: the states can then restore their competitiveness by making their own decisions on the exchange rate, as they did before the introduction of the euro.
A new German mark could regain its higher purchasing power compared to other countries. The associated reduction in import prices would lead to rising real incomes and thus to a "social dividend" that would benefit the German people as a whole and not just a few export companies, as is currently the case. Similar to Switzerland, we would have considerably lower inflation without the ECB's excessive money printing policy.
1S	1D
¦ Cancel the transfer union
Germany must return to a social market economy - and therefore abandon the transfer union of the euro system. Any further participation in the permanent bailout policy is tantamount to insolvency at the expense of German taxpayers. The AfD is aware that the reintroduction of a stable national currency cannot take place without conversion costs. However, these will be lower than the permanent costs of remaining in the Eurosystem.
¦ Ending the anti-treaty and planned economy policy of the ECB and EU Commission
The ECB's policy is destroying the markets for government and corporate bonds. Manipulating the bond markets has been the ECB's daily "business model" since 2015. It has now purchased government and private bonds worth five trillion euros. This supranational "rescue policy" violates applicable EU law, including the ban on state financing by the central bank and the ban on liability for the debts of other member states. The ECB is also pursuing an ideological and forbidden economic policy - via multi-billion euro earmarked guarantees and sureties as well as purchases of "green" or otherwise ideologically issued bonds. These are, in effect, direct gifts of money to "distressed" states via a joint EU debt issue ("NextGenerationEU" fund, "Ukraine" bonds, etc. or TARGET2). All of these measures are in breach of the treaty, as they violate the prohibitions on monetary state financing and mutual assumption of liability.
The ECB's policy of low interest rates and government bond purchases must lead to inflation. It destroys company calculations and, in the long term, all funded pension systems and private savings. The ECB's interest rate policy is detached from any realistic consideration of risk and leads to uncompetitive companies remaining on the market as "zombies" and providing unfair competition for healthy companies.
Here too, the AfD demands a return to the law and the market economy: all measures by the ECB to manipulate the free capital market must be stopped. The AfD demands the enforcement of the contractual prohibition of state financing by the ECB and the de facto communitization of debt via the ECB. The ECB only has a mandate for monetary policy, not for economic policy programs to support individual states and ideological political goals.
¦ No borrowing by the EU - rescue loans only at national level and only for national investments
Today, the EU presumes to take on its own debt, contrary to the explicit wording of the EU treaties, at the expense of future German generations. The funds are procured through new debt and are then used by EU bureaucrats via countless, mostly ideologically motivated
"Green Deal" projects are issued in a landlord-like manner. However, liability and repayment remain with the national states. Germany's joint liability for these loans taken out by the EU, which largely benefit the euro crisis countries, inevitably leads to a deterioration in Germany's credit rating. The EU's controversial "ESG" and "taxonomy" requirements, which ideologically and to a large extent bureaucratically regulate which economic activities are "green" and therefore worthy of support, ultimately represent planned economy macro-control.
The AfD demands a return to the concept of an open market economy and the immediate cessation of any EU borrowing: no communitization of debt in violation of the treaty, no ideological
and centralized monetary or economic policy, return to capital allocation via functioning markets! Debt and tax collection should generally only take place at national level in line with the principle of subsidiarity! We want to free up money for national economic and social programs with a clear focus on long-term, sustainable infrastructure investments.
However, as long as the euro continues to exist at Germany's expense, Germany should also settle a large part of its new debt via the ECB and the EU. The funds should be used strictly for aid and investments in Germany.
¦ Preservation of the cash
Cash is freedom and protection against expropriation and total surveillance.
Our cash is in danger. With the support of the German government, the International Monetary Fund and the European Central Bank, it is being gradually abolished. The abolition of cash would restrict the role of money as an inviolable and fee-free store of value. The abolition of cash makes it possible to expropriate account holders in the event of a crisis. Cash is a natural bulwark against a further reduction in interest rates into negative territory. A cash ban would mean that payment transactions could only take place electronically. This would give the state and banks total control over all cash flows and economic activities, over every financial activity of citizens, even over their whereabouts. The transparent bank customer would become the transparent person - full surveillance and control right into private, even intimate areas of life (Chinese "social credit" system) would be pre-programmed. Such surveillance and control options are not compatible with a liberal constitutional state. Furthermore, electronic systems are not fail-safe or tamper-proof.
The AfD demands the permanent preservation of the unrestricted use of cash as an important civil right and its enshrinement in the Basic Law. The AfD is opposed to a digital euro issued centrally by the ECB, which would be a gateway for the creeping abolition of cash. The availability and store of value function of cash must be preserved. The AfD is opposed to the total monitoring and control of all financial activities through regulatory or de facto mandatory electronic payment transactions.
¦ No German liability for foreign banks
Banks are vital for the functioning of national economies. The European Banking Union would also subject the German savings banks, cooperative banks and the German private banking sector, which are currently anchored at local level, to EU redistribution. At several trillion euros, the planned European deposit guarantee scheme would be the largest joint liability facility in the EU. This communitization would make German savers and bank customers liable with their deposits for ailing banks in other countries, such as the Mediterranean countries, which already have large irrecoverable loan claims on their balance sheets. Huge defaults would only be a matter of time and would directly trigger a German payment obligation! This would be a further step towards the deepened liability and transfer union rejected by the AfD.
We demand that German banks limit liability to the national level and continue to be able to create their own liability and deposit guarantee association solutions. We advocate restoring national sovereignty over banking and financial services. The AfD opposes the European communitization of liability risks.
2
¦ End TARGET2 risk
The German Bundesbank's TARGET2 claims (overdraft facilities in the ECB's settlement system) against the ECB and indirectly against individual southern eurozone countries amount to over one trillion euros. According to the applicable ECB rules, these Bundesbank claims are unsecured, do not bear interest at a risk-adequate rate and cannot be called in. There are a number of probable scenarios for the derecognition of these amounts. TARGET2 value losses represent a high risk worth billions for the federal budget and therefore for the German taxpayer. It is certain that in the event of a (partial) dissolution of the eurozone, the ECB, as the Bundesbank's counterparty, will only settle the German TARGET claims in devalued euros or not at all. The irrecoverable receivables balances must be made usable if they cannot be melted down. One option would be to invest the assets already generated in the form of TARGET2 - using past work performed by Germans - in tangible assets, for example via a German sovereign wealth fund.
The AfD demands that the Federal Government and the German Bundesbank put an end to the overuse of the TARGET2 clearing account that has been tolerated to date. These claims of the Bundesbank must be reduced, balanced daily, subject to appropriate interest and backed by collateral. The AfD is also open to further sensible proposals to "monetize" the TARGET claims or make them usable. For example, Germany should invest its TARGET claims in foreign shares or gold or in a national real asset fund.
¦ Protection against the euro crisis, reforming the monetary system, bringing state gold back to Germany
Germany must also be able to act in the event of a sudden monetary crisis. In the event of a reintroduction of the Deutsche Mark, the state gold partially stored abroad could serve as a temporary cover option. According to all historical experience, gold is a potential cover for a currency, which is particularly relevant in crisis situations or after the introduction of a new currency to build confidence. Sovereign gold must be held as a potential last currency reserve without counterparty or custody risk in the country itself.
The AfD is calling on the German Bundesbank to transfer all of the state gold stored abroad to Germany. In addition, the AfD is calling for the gold reserve to be given a special constitutional status on the balance sheet to avert the risk of it being written off. In the long term, we consider a fundamental reform of the monetary system to be necessary, towards free currency competition or a gold-backed currency.
Preserve the economic and social sovereignty of EU member states
The AfD is striving for a new European economic community of sovereign nation states whose cooperation is geared towards increasing prosperity within a common market. However, the EU is currently pursuing not only an economic but also an ideologically motivated agenda with its economic policy decisions, which includes goals such as climate rescue, euro rescue, Russia sanctions and the inclusion of the Western Balkan states.
As the EU Member States are heterogeneous in terms of their economic strength and their historically evolved socio-economic value systems, majority decisions often violate legitimate economic interests.
individual interests of the member states. Moreover, such decisions often lead to the redistribution of wealth between states. One example of intergovernmental redistribution is the 750 billion euro "NextGenerationEU" fund, from which 390 billion euros are to be granted as non-repayable subsidies to EU member states. This alleged post-pandemic recovery facility has also been pre-financed by the EU Commission through borrowing in violation of EU law. Art. 311 TFEU expressly prohibits the Commission from incurring debt. As always, German taxpayers bear the main burden of this redistribution, which is carried out via the EU contributions of the Member States, which are graduated according to economic strength.
¦ Competition instead of bureaucracy
The AfD sees the purpose of a European association of sovereign nation states primarily in shaping the framework of a common European economy and ensuring fair competitive conditions. Competition is a basic prerequisite for technical progress, favorable consumer prices and the sustainability of our social systems. Economic risks must always be borne by the investor, not the state and therefore ultimately the taxpayer. We reject centralist interventions that are tantamount to expropriation.
The AfD is expressly committed to free trade. We strive for interest-based trade agreements that provide for import facilitation and customs exemptions for the contracting parties. Such trade agreements based on partnership help to promote economic development, for example in African countries. Germany owes its economic success to the creativity of its inventors and engineers as well as the courageous entrepreneurs who have invested in know-how and production facilities.
As a result of the EU's increasingly wide-ranging powers, parallel legislative procedures at national and European level are occurring more and more frequently with the effect of superseding national law. As a result, companies have to change their internal procedures after just a few years, as national regulations are replaced by European regulations. The AfD calls for a review and reduction of the relevant EU directives,
e.g. the EU Public Procurement Directive, the EU Services Directive, the Lending Directive, the Ecodesign Directive and the documentation requirements, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
The Supply Chain Act, which came into force at the beginning of 2023 and which the AfD has fought against from the outset with reference to the primary responsibility of EU states in enforcing social standards, also represents a distortion of competition. This regulation puts EU companies at a disadvantage in international competition because only they are burdened with additional social and environmental standards.
¦ Maintain added value, promote key technologies
An important prerequisite for innovation is openness to technology. The AfD therefore opposes the EU ban on combustion engines with all the political means at its disposal. This puts European automotive companies and suppliers at a considerable competitive disadvantage at international level. We take a fundamentally critical view of subsidies.
¦ Ensure quality standards
National and regional quality standards and indications of origin must be protected, including quality seals such as "Made in Germany". German training standards must not be lowered. The equivalence of professional qualifications acquired abroad must be proven by passing an examination at the place of work in accordance with the national standards applicable there.
¦ Investment management by the market instead of EU taxonomies
There are currently efforts in the EU to strengthen centrally controlled investment management for ideological reasons as part of the so-called taxonomy, for example in the case of so-called "green technologies". We reject the EU's Green Deal.
In the case of investment decisions in private companies, the companies themselves are liable for the consequences of poor decisions. In the case of public investments, however, it is not the responsible political decision-makers who are liable, but the taxpayers.
Entrepreneurial diligence is a better guide than political ideology. Planned market interventions with subsidies in line with a "socio-ecological transformation" and the banning of successful industries pose a huge threat to prosperity, freedom and the security of supply in the Member States.
¦ Immigration of workers
Within the common economic area, labor mobility can be valuable. However, the immigration of workers must always be geared towards the respective national or even regional labor market. Otherwise, there is a risk of wage dumping and the associated displacement of local workers.
Foreign EU workers must be paid in the same way in the member states in which they find employment and must be subject to the same legal regulations as domestic workers. Last but not least, this also promotes a more skills-based immigration of workers.
The current legal regulations, such as the Posted Workers Act, are largely sufficient. However, the AfD demands effective controls to ensure that they are complied with so that the abuse of temporary work and contracts for work and services is actually prevented.
¦ Freedom of establishment
We welcome the freedom of self-employed persons and entrepreneurs within the EU in principle. However, it must not be misused to obtain entitlements to social benefits through bogus self-employment.
The EU's freedom to provide services leads to the circumvention of minimum wages, taxes and social security contributions, particularly in the transport industry. This damages the welfare state. We therefore want to put an end to wage and social dumping.
¦ 
EU and Social policy
The AfD stands for a just and fair social policy, which must be guaranteed by a sustainable, intergenerationally fair design of the social security systems as well as reliable social security for pensioners, unemployed and employees in the lower wage or salary segment.
As the EU's competences under the treaties are limited to supporting and supplementing the measures of the Member States, the responsibility and competence for shaping social policy remain with the Member States. They are responsible for aligning their national social systems with their own values and shaping them according to their economic performance.
The Member States' ability to shape their own policies and the socio-economic differences that still exist between the Member States create incentives to migrate to countries with a higher level of social benefits. This leads to a conflict of objectives between the national interests of limiting the receipt of social benefits to one's own citizens and the goal of free movement within the EU. The AfD advocates that, in this conflict of objectives, the exercise of freedom of movement by EU citizens should be excluded if it primarily serves the purpose of receiving social benefits in Germany.
¦ Social benefits for EU- foreigners
Before EU foreigners are placed on an equal footing with Germans in social law, the respective country of origin should remain responsible in cases of need.
We are committed to ensuring that foreigners from EU countries only receive social benefits in Germany once they have paid taxes and social security contributions in Germany for ten years and have been able to support themselves without state assistance during this time.
¦ No European social union
