The social security systems of the various EU countries are regulated very differently. The same applies to the labor markets. We want to preserve this diversity in the interests of competition between systems within the EU.
We are in favor of a coordinating social law including a social agreement, according to which social security entitlements acquired in other EU member states can be transferred to the social security system in the country of origin.
We regard any attempts by the EU to introduce minimum standards in the EU member states as violations
of the European Treaties. We consider the EU Social Charter to be superfluous.
The AfD rejects all attempts to undermine the Member States' competence to shape social policy, as laid down in the Treaties, by means of declarations (e.g. the "European Pillar of Social Rights") and thus to create new responsibilities for the EU institutions. Under no circumstances should there be a standardization of social systems, as this would entail the risk of domestic employees having to pay contributions for the insurance of employees in other EU states. Such a redistributive union contradicts the spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon. This applies in particular to the already envisaged European unemployment insurance.
24	25
Taxes and finances
Fiscal sovereignty belongs to the national parliaments. Like other international organizations, the EU is to be financed exclusively by contributions from its member states.
¦ Taxation of internationally active large corporations
Major international corporations are very adept at minimizing their tax burden or avoiding tax payments altogether. We believe that it is no longer appropriate in the 21st century to tax large corporations according to where they are headquartered, for example. The actual economic activity that a group carries out in a country should be decisive for the tax burden. Instead of calling for a global minimum tax rate in order to eliminate tax havens, we believe it makes more sense to reach an international agreement that the tax burden imposed on a group at a national level should be calculated primarily on the basis of the proportion of the group's economic activity in the country levying the tax (so-called total group taxation). Countries such as the USA and Canada have been using this model since the 19th century for companies that operate in more than one state or province in order to create tax fairness. And unlike with global minimum taxation, each state could continue to use lower taxes to incentivize a company to expand its economic activity in a country. There would also be no need to differentiate between digital and non-digital business models.
¦ International Corporate taxation
Contrary to the EU's efforts, the permanent establishment principle must be retained for corporate income taxation. German companies, with their high proportion of exports, generally bear their risks at the location of their registered office. This is where the key business decisions are made, for example in the areas of research, production development, supply relationships, strategy, investments and much more. This is where the economic opportunities and risks are realized, which must also be taxed there in the case of company profits.
This applies with the exception of certain digital business models. Here, sales and advertising markets can be used as the starting point for corporate income taxation.
¦ No EU- taxes
The AfD rejects any kind of EU taxes. This applies both to taxes levied directly by the EU and to the EU's participation in taxes levied by the federal states. We reject the proportional transfer of proceeds from the minimum taxation of large corporations to the EU as additional own resources.
¦ Active promotion of own companies through tax relief
Countries such as Luxembourg secure competitive advantages by specifically promoting individual companies through tax breaks. We also consider it to be in Germany's national interest to support our own companies with lower taxes in special cases. However, existing regulations of world trade law must be complied with.
¦ 
Leave excise duty law with the Member States
We reject the harmonization of European consumption tax law. Past crises, which have always hit the lower and middle classes particularly hard, have clearly shown how important it is for states to have sufficient flexibility in tax structuring in order to be able to relieve the burden on citizens quickly and effectively through tax law. As consumption taxes in particular place a disproportionately heavy burden on low- and middle-income citizens, a reduction in these taxes can be an effective means of providing relief. It would therefore be counterproductive to restrict this freedom of the nation states by imposing strict EU limits.
¦ Financial transaction tax
We reject a financial transaction tax. We fear that this would place a greater burden on savers, as this tax would make unit-linked pension provision in particular more expensive. The very low proportion of small investors in the equity market in Germany would be further reduced by the introduction of the tax. Large investors and professional investors can move their transactions to stock exchanges outside the EU and thus easily avoid the tax. In addition, an EU-wide financial transaction tax would violate the fundamental tax sovereignty of the member states.
¦ Market economy instead of CO2 pricing
The AfD strictly rejects any form of CO2 pricing - be it via CO2 certificate trading or a direct CO2 tax - as well as the planned border adjustment mechanism.
Within the EU, CO2 pricing applies via CO2 certificate trading. In addition, imported goods will also be subject to a CO2 levy in the future via a CO2 border adjustment system. This will lead to a further increase in the price of all imported goods traded in the EU and thus inevitably to a further loss of prosperity for citizens. There is also a risk of a trade war, as this special tax on imported goods will be perceived as protectionism by other countries.
¦ Strengthen regions
The AfD is striving for a reform of EU public procurement law. Tenders at municipal or national level should be awarded primarily to regional or national providers. To this end, the threshold values for EU procurement should be raised and the regulations should be made more flexible so that the most favorable bidder from the entire EU does not always have to be awarded the contract.
¦ Reduce the EU budget
The AfD rejects an expansion of the EU budget and instead calls for a significant reduction in EU spending. The fines collected by the EU should be passed on proportionately to the Member States.
Numerous EU programs worth billions are used to distribute EU funds widely and effectively to the public without providing measurable impetus for the prosperity of local population groups, such as the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) or the Cohesion Fund. This money is better spent by the EU member states, which are primarily responsible for their own infrastructure.
raised. After all, the "cohesion" of the economies of all member states has always been and will continue to be a fiction. To reduce the expenditure of the EU administration, the costly and time-consuming commuting between the three places of work - Strasbourg, Brussels and Luxembourg - must be ended.
¦ Reform of EU own resources
The GNI-based own resources based on gross national income represent the largest share of EU revenue, currently around 70 percent. Although Germany has a high gross national income, wealth in Germany is unevenly distributed relative to other countries. In addition, Germans are in the bottom third of wealth comparisons with other EU member states and bring up the rear in terms of home ownership rates. Pension benefits in Germany currently amount to 53% of final net income, which is well behind countries such as Greece with 84%, Italy with 82% and France with 74%. The claim that Germany is a rich country is false.
Due to the unequal distribution of wealth, there is considerable wealth among a small top group, which is why average wealth is in the middle internationally. However, the median wealth of Germans paints a different picture. Here, Germany is in second-last place in a comparison of OECD countries. This is also due to the fact that the home ownership rate in Germany is so low. In future, the basis of measurement for the member states should therefore no longer be gross national income (GNI), but national income. While GNI is a figure that is linked to gross economic revenues, national income represents the annual economic output of an economy that accrues to citizens and companies. In investment-intensive economies such as Germany, the difference between GNI and national income is very high. The GNI is therefore unsuitable and unfair as a yardstick for the EU contribution and leads to an excessive burden on Germany.
Foreign policy
¦ Germany and Europe in the changing international relations	
We believe that the prerequisite for German foreign policy is a sovereign Germany that guarantees freedom, justice, prosperity and security for its citizens. We stand for a Europe of nations and firmly reject the centralist efforts of the EU. The federation of European nations, which we aspire to as an economic and community of interests, preserves extensive sovereignty internally and enables coordination in external relations. The guiding principle of German foreign policy must once again be realpolitik requirements instead of unrealistic ideologies.
A stable peace order in Europe requires balanced cooperation between all European states, whose legitimate security interests must be taken into account. The role of the Organization for Security and Co- operation in Europe (OSCE) in stabilizing crisis regions in Europe and its periphery must be further developed. We advocate respect for international law and, in particular, for the right of peoples to self- determination. At the same time, we call for compliance with the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of states by other powers and non-state actors. This also applies to EU interference in the affairs of member states. We reject further demands for reparations, such as those put forward by Poland and Greece, because these issues have already been conclusively clarified under international law. The legal and peaceful order that has developed in Europe must not be called into question by unacceptable demands.
¦ 
Pooling common European interests
The AfD is in favor of bundling pan-European interests in foreign policy without restricting the sovereignty of the national states, their democratic decision-making and the design of their legal systems. We reject a legally formalized common foreign and security policy of the EU (CFSP) as well as a common European External Action Service. Instead, we advocate intensifying intergovernmental coordination among the European partner countries and, where possible, acting jointly.
We are in favor of a flexible network in which each European state can participate according to its own interests and possibilities.
¦ USA
Good relations with the USA are essential for Germany and Europe. We want a partnership with the USA "on an equal footing". This includes, in particular, the further development of economic, technological and scientific exchange. However, the geopolitical and economic interests of the USA increasingly differ from those of Germany and other European countries. One example of this is the energy supply, such as the massive attempt by the USA to prevent the Nord Stream gas pipeline from going into operation.
The Nord Stream project is of paramount importance for Europe's energy supply and cannot be replaced without far-reaching economic problems. Germany must not allow itself to be drawn into conflicts with other powers as a result of soft decisions made by the USA. The foreign and security policy of the USA forces Germany to formulate its interests independently. This should be done in the closest possible coordination with other European states.
¦ Russia
The Russian invasion caused a great deal of suffering among those affected in Ukraine. The war has made Germany's foreign policy extremely difficult. Russia's geostrategic position and the resulting historical and economic ties, especially with Germany, make it necessary to use diplomatic means to work towards an end to the war and thus ensure peaceful German-Russian relations. For decades, Russia has been a reliable supplier and guarantor of an affordable energy supply, which is the Achilles heel of the German economy due to our energy-intensive industry. Restoring undisturbed trade with Russia requires the immediate lifting of economic sanctions against Russia and the repair of the Nord Stream pipelines. Germany's relations with the Eurasian Economic Union should be expanded.
¦ China
The relationship with China must be geared towards Germany's realpolitik interests. China is one of Germany's most important trading partners. Patent protection, the intensification of participation in Chinese companies, the protection of company secrets and bilateral free trade must become the focus of German-Chinese relations.
With the "New Silk Road" project, China has embarked on a project of the century. In order to be able to help shape it on an equal basis, the AfD advocates Germany's proactive participation. Germany should complement the Silk Road strategy from East to West with an initiative from West to East. This applies in particular to supra-regional infrastructure projects.
Germany should strive for observer status in the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) in order to take the importance of this market adequately into account.
¦ European Neighborhood
North Africa and the Middle East are geostrategically important regions of the world for Europe. The AfD is committed to the peaceful resolution of conflicts. Peace, stability and prosperity are the prerequisites for an end to mass migration.
Turkey is an important strategic and economic partner for us. However, we reject interference in our internal affairs by means of ideological or financial support for Islamist groups in Europe. Culturally, Turkey does not belong to Europe. The AfD demands the immediate termination of EU accession negotiations with Turkey and the cessation of financial pre-accession aid.
Defense and security policy
¦ Strategic autonomy: Europe's security autonomy in the new age
The world is undergoing a transition to a multipolar order, which presents Europe with security policy challenges.
The future of European security lies in pooling the military capabilities of states in a separate system of collective security. The European nation states should be guided by the will to pool their armed forces in a defense community.
Germany and its European neighbors must no longer rely exclusively on the protection or assurances of non-European countries, but must finally achieve far-reaching military and strategic autonomy.
Currently, NATO is the essential cornerstone of our security and defense capability, insofar as NATO limits itself to its task as a defense alliance. Operations outside the Alliance area in which German armed forces participate should always take place under a UN mandate and only if German security interests are taken into account.
We welcome meaningful cooperation at European level in the qualification, procurement and development of military capabilities.
The AfD rejects a European army and maintains a fully capable Bundeswehr as the cornerstone of German sovereignty. With a strong armed force of its own, Germany can be put in a position to replace the American armed forces on German soil in the medium term.
German contribution to European security
As things stand at present, the Bundeswehr is not in a position to defend Germany's territory, neither in terms of numbers nor equipment. Germany's defense capability must be restored without delay. The focus should be on the ability to defend the country and secure trade routes.
We see the greatest challenge here in increasing personnel to the necessary size and procuring and introducing new weapons systems on the appropriate scale. Securing the personnel basis and adequate structures of the Bundeswehr will only be possible if we reverse the suspension of compulsory military service. The defense budget must be adapted to the requirements of Germany's security policy strategy.
Preservation and expansion of the German and European defense industry
The AfD demands the preservation and expansion of defense technology capabilities, the safeguarding of existing jobs in this high-tech sector and planning security for German industry and our armed forces. To this end, new defense technology programs must be initiated. In the context of future armaments cooperation, we insist on the protection of German interests. Our key technologies must not be sold to third countries. In addition, attention must be paid to a balanced relationship between financing and proportional production in Germany. Germany must strive for system leadership in key capabilities. New procurements of military equipment should primarily come from German and European production.
¦ Foreign trade policy
The AfD is striving for a new version of European cooperation. Against this background, there should also be a closely coordinated European foreign trade policy in the future. We are in favour of a reform of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and increased cooperation, for example with the BRICS countries or regional organizations such as ASEAN and Mercosur.
All agreements must be negotiated in transparent procedures and ratified by national parliaments. The AfD rejects the transfer of national sovereignty rights to private arbitration tribunals outside of bilateral investment protection agreements. The interests of small and medium-sized enterprises must be given much greater consideration in foreign trade policy. We reject bureaucratic obstacles such as the Supply Chain Act. Nevertheless, standards in consumer and environmental protection as well as in the social sector must be maintained. In principle, we support the relocation of manufacturing for Europe back to the European region. In this way, we would like to increase industry's share of value creation in Germany again and develop regional, sustainable and less disruptive economic cycles.
Foreign policy must not be geared towards attrition in an economic war, but must once again be committed to the goals of economic growth, prosperity and the protection of domestic industry. We want to lift the existing sanctions against Russia and Syria and reject any sanctions against China. Appropriate measures must be taken against unjustified trade restrictions by third countries and the protection of intellectual property and equal treatment of companies must be ensured.
Foreign trade, security and development policy must be coordinated. The freedom of sea and trade routes and thus access to raw materials, energy and sales markets must be ensured.
3
¦ Development policy
The AfD is calling for development policy to be shifted back to the national level. Both sides should benefit from joint projects. Development aid should be help for self-help. Projects must be subject to strict monitoring of their use and regular evaluation of the results. The granting of development aid should be linked, among other things, to the willingness to take back migrants who are obliged to leave the country. Private sector initiatives, competitive jobs and security of supply should be promoted. The Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW) should be strengthened in the area of international development financing. The German government must develop a coherent cross-departmental Africa strategy for the African continent. Nuclear powers and states that grant development aid themselves should no longer receive development aid. We reject a European development policy alongside the development policy of nation states, if only because of the fragmentation this would cause.
¦ Foreign cultural policy
The task of Germany's foreign cultural policy must be to build bridges to other peoples, to deepen knowledge of German culture and history and to support the domestic economy and tourism by establishing and maintaining international contacts. The institutions currently entrusted with these tasks (foreign broadcasters, Goethe-Institut, various individual regional projects) have not lived up to this claim for years. German is the most widely spoken language in the EU. For this reason, German must be given de facto equal status with English and French in the European institutions.
The AfD is expressly committed to Germany's duty of care towards German minorities abroad and will strongly support their interests. This includes, in particular, the promotion of language teaching in German minority areas, the promotion of German schools, kindergartens, newspapers and libraries as well as the exchange of cultural workers across borders. We are critical of the Polish Ministry of Education's decree, which came into force on September 1, 2022, to reduce German lessons for the German minority from three to one hour per week.
The AfD is committed to ensuring compliance with the European Charter for Regional and Minority Languages.
Traffic
The AfD advocates a transport policy based on the needs of citizens. The AfD rejects an ideologically driven policy that favors, disadvantages or even prohibits certain means of transport. For us, the freedom of citizens to choose their means of transportation is paramount. I n d i v i d u a l mobility must remain affordable. States can work together on the realization of infrastructure projects on a consensual basis. However, we fundamentally reject granting the EU further powers to standardize transport and infrastructure policy. The AfD is against age-limiting measures for driving licenses and, in particular, against EU plans for driving-license-limiting measures such as driving fitness checks for everyone over the age of 70.
¦ Protecting motorized private transport
The AfD supports and promotes motorized private transport as the most popular and modern way of getting around. Intelligent technology and congestion-avoiding traffic management protect the environment. Scientifically unfounded measures, such as bans on diesel vehicles or the introduction of
lanes, do not achieve this. At the same time, the AfD demands the preservation and expansion of inner-city lanes and parking spaces to avoid increasing traffic chaos and to protect the attractiveness of the retail trade. The AfD strictly rejects a general speed limit on federal highways. It would like to enable young people from the age of 16 to drive under supervision in order to participate in road traffic responsibly and at an early age.
¦ Strengthening European transport links
The growing importance of the East-West connections in Germany for the European transport network must also be recognized by the European Union and promoted accordingly. In particular, the gaps in the highway network that have existed for many years must be closed as quickly as possible. Many highways and bridges in Germany have long been in urgent need of renovation and repair. This is only possible with efficient measures in the planning and execution of construction sites as well as fast work by the administration. In addition, the AfD demands a sufficient number of truck parking spaces and the consistent application of existing truck overtaking bans to protect all road users.
¦ Relieve congestion on federal highways - shift transit traffic to rail and waterways
The truck toll, which we want to shape nationally and whose regulation by the EU we reject, should contribute to directing transit freight traffic to rail and waterways. The concept of the "rolling highway" and swap body handling should be established for transit connections through Germany with regular intervals. The network of loading points and multimodal freight transport scenarios (road, rail and waterways) must therefore be densified. Deutsche Bahn must be upgraded so that it can cope with this task. In order to relieve road and rail traffic across borders, we call for the more efficient use of natural water resources and the comprehensive renovation of dilapidated locks and weirs.
¦ Making European rail transport fit for the future
The AfD would like to expand the Rhine route from Basel to Rotterdam in a sustainable manner, also in order to be able to fulfill existing contracts with our Swiss neighbors. In rail transport, the blockade caused by country-specific signaling systems must be overcome. The fundamentally good idea of introducing a uniform European Train Control System (ETCS) has developed into a billion-dollar grave under the influence of national isolationist interests. The AfD is committed to reducing this system to the lowest common denominator in order to ensure Europe-wide compatibility and reduce costs. The first step in expanding the European rail network is to stabilize the precarious power supply in Germany, which has already led to numerous train cancellations.
¦ Road haulage without wage and social dumping
Since almost half of the trucks in long-distance transport today come from Eastern Europe at dumping prices and the freight transport of foreign companies in a neighboring country (cabotage) is increasing considerably, there is a need for action. We are planning increased controls and higher penalties for driving time and driver leasing in pan-European road haulage as effective instruments. The AfD will work to ensure that German companies become more competitive again.
32	33
¦ Strengthening air traffic as an economic factor
The AfD is in favor of abolishing the aviation tax and opposes unrealistic EU CO2 reduction targets. Global air traffic is of fundamental importance for Germany and Europe - and must not be sacrificed to unscientific climate hysteria. The AfD rejects any ban on short-haul flights.
¦ Maintaining the automotive industry as a leading industry
The AfD is aware of the strategic importance of the German automotive and supplier industry. The small and medium-sized enterprises responsible for the majority of jobs, particularly in the metalworking industry, are dependent on the continued existence of the combustion engine. It is not the task of the EU to determine how and whether drive technologies for motor vehicles are developed. The AfD is generally in favor of preserving the combustion engine. The EU's one-sided preference for electromobility must be stopped immediately, as it cannot be used across the board due to a lack of electricity capacity and infrastructure. Battery production also has a far greater impact on the environment than the combustion engine.
Whether the combustion engine will one day be replaced by other forms of propulsion or continue to exist must remain purely a question of technical progress and the market. Vehicles with combustion engines powered by synthetic fuel must be treated equally to electrically powered vehicles in terms of their tax burden. This applies both to the energy source itself and to the vehicle as a whole. The AfD is opposed to the planned tightening of European emissions standards and rejects Euro 7 in particular.
Building and living
For centuries, Europe has been characterized by a diversity of national architectural styles. The way of building and living in Europe has grown historically and is characterized by national and landscape characteristics. The urban and rural housing culture that has evolved is a treasure that must be preserved.
Building law and the associated regulations are exclusively a national responsibility. Any intervention in the construction planning sovereignty of the individual EU Member States must be rejected. The AfD defends the diversity of European building culture and opposes the standardization and tightening of building directives by the EU, which lead to an enormous increase in costs and thus also rents in housing construction.
¦ No EU competence for construction and housing
Although the EU has no independent legislative competence for the areas of construction and housing, it is also attempting to exert political influence in this field. This is done via EU energy policy. However, there can be no EU regulation that is suitable for all buildings from Finland to Portugal!
The AfD is fighting against the EU's efforts to only allow the construction of so-called climate-neutral residential buildings from 2030. We also reject the unrealistic goal of making the entire building stock in the EU emission-free in the medium term. The EU only wants to allow exceptions for historic buildings, churches and defense facilities.
This EU agenda disregards the desire of citizens for affordable housing that meets their needs. The AfD rejects an EU-wide solar obligation on the roofs of new and renovated residential buildings and industrial facilities. With the AfD, there is no EU refurbishment obligation for allegedly inefficient buildings.
¦ Funding, promotion and migration
The European Mortgage Credit Directive often prevents the necessary credit financing for young families, the self-employed and older citizens. The AfD is therefore calling for the European Residential Property Credit Directive to be repealed without replacement.
All EU funding for housing construction must be transferred back to the national and regional level so that it can be used there in a targeted and efficient manner.
The EU's migration policy is a major contributor to the fact that the housing market in Germany is also overloaded, rents are rising and locals are being displaced. This policy must be ended immediately.
¦ Infrastructure
As with the strategic oil reserve, appropriate storage facilities for gas must be kept available for German companies and consumers. If intact, the Nord Stream pipeline must be released for gas supply immediately. The repair of lines damaged by a terrorist attack must be arranged immediately.
¦ Ideology-free spatial planning and use
Existing regional development plans in Germany and other EU countries are currently being amended in the direction of supposedly "climate-proof spatial planning and use". T h e primary aim here is to build more wind farms and large-scale photovoltaic systems throughout Europe. Landscape and nature conservation are being subordinated or even sacrificed for the sake of supposed climate protection. This creates countless new problems at the expense of the environment. We therefore demand: No blanket privileges for buildings to generate so-called "renewable energies" in outdoor areas!
Instead, we strive to preserve and strengthen the unique character of European regions. This relates to the structure of agriculture and local settlements.
¦ Equal rights for urban and rural areas
Living conditions in rural areas must not lag behind those in cities and metropolitan areas. We expressly support the strengthening of transport and digital infrastructure. Appropriate promotion of the economy in rural areas is a further building block on the way to equal living conditions. The goal is the "vital rural area".
Agriculture and forestry, nature conservation, animal welfare, hunting, environmental and consumer protection
Our evolved cultural landscape and the environment are increasingly endangered by an ever-expanding and relentless EU centralism. Under the guise of so-called climate protection policy, lobby interests are opposing a sensible environmental and agricultural policy that is geared towards regional needs. By implementing the "Green Deal", a multi-billion euro redistribution machine is being set in motion, leading to deindustrialization and the destruction of nature. This harms citizens, the environment and the economy. At the same time, the right to self-determination of the member states - one of the key founding principles of the EU - is being further undermined.
The EU has failed to combine agriculture and environmental protection in a meaningful way. Ideologically driven misguided incentives and vested interests prevent the sustainable promotion of forestry and agriculture as well as the preservation and protection of our natural environment. Sprawling bureaucracy is destroying the existence of the regionally rooted farming community and rural areas that have worked for society for generations.
The AfD is fighting for a Germany in which food security and self-sufficiency are guaranteed for future generations. At the same time, our agriculture should ensure that consumers are supplied with high-quality and affordable food in harmony with nature and animal welfare. Therefore, instead of centralized EU bureaucracy, we demand an environmental, forestry and agricultural policy that is geared towards regional needs.
¦ Promotion of agriculture and rural areas
The various branches of agriculture - arable farming, livestock farming, viticulture, forestry and horticulture - create jobs and are important service providers for our population as regionally connected primary suppliers. We need to pay more attention to this elementary branch of the economy again. Young people should develop an understanding of nature and agriculture. Regional products such as vegetables, fruit, meat and fish must be given priority over imported goods. The structural framework conditions of agriculture must be designed in such a way that small and medium-sized farms can also operate successfully in the long term. This is the only way to guarantee regional value chains, short transportation routes and the supply of high-quality food, even in times of crisis.
The AfD is committed to strengthening the independence of farmers and bringing market economy principles back to the fore. Proper and performance-based remuneration for farmers, livestock farmers and food producers must be ensured for generations to come. This can only happen with more independence and without EU regulation mania - as with the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), which we reject.
It is necessary to structure marketing and trade in such a way that smaller farms are not at a disadvantage compared to the wholesale chains. This must be made possible by creating fair relationships between producers, retailers and consumers and by strengthening direct marketing.
The AfD stands for the preservation - and, wherever possible, the expansion - of agriculturally usable land. We reject the reallocation of high-quality agricultural land in favor of so-called renewable energies. Here, too, we demand: Less EU, but more regional and national decision-making power!
Effective plant protection must be based on professional training, good professional practice and the latest scientific findings. We are aware that many of these scientific findings are manipulated by green anti- farmer and anti-technology propaganda. We have recognized green lobbying in this field as a threat to our farmers and will actively counteract it. Here too, the national-regional scope for action should be given preference over a centrally bureaucratic EU administration. The use of genetic engineering should be strictly monitored and always checked for its actual benefits.
Increased use by ground-mounted photovoltaic systems is contrary to the goal of land conservation. In particular, the consumption of biotopes and agricultural land by so-called agrivoltaics must be prevented. Euphemistically referred to as "energy harvesting", the use of landscape and arable land is in contradiction to self-sufficiency and degrades local agriculture to an accomplice in an already failed energy transition experiment. In addition, the consequences for crop cultivation have not been sufficiently researched to be able to reliably estimate possible crop losses.
¦ Forest management and forestry
Europe's extensive forest areas must be protected in terms of ecology, economy and recreation. However, this can only be done in strict compliance with the principle of subsidiarity. This is because the different climatic and geographical conditions require adapted regional forest management without overbearing control by Brussels.
Planning games far removed from national particularities are therefore out of place. Forest management belongs in the regional hands of forestry experts and owners. The benefits of forests as water reservoirs, suppliers of natural building materials and wood as an energy source are undisputed. Sustainable management over generations must be the unalterable goal!
We reject the further set-aside of forestry areas in the sense of a misunderstood idea of protection. Due to its dense population, Germany needs a rational balancing of interests when it comes to forest use. Professional management is indispensable for the preservation of the forest, also with regard to climatic influences. In this context, the AfD stands for sustainable forest conversion.
We demand the reduction of excessive bureaucracy and excessive documentation requirements. The lobbying of self-appointed environmental associations in favor of the wind power industry, which has been going on for years under the auspices of the EU, must be ended as quickly as possible. We reject the clearing of forests, a cultural asset, for wind turbines. Such wind turbines cannot solve our energy problem.
¦ Animal welfare and protection
We are committed to animal husbandry in Germany. The AfD stands for the consistent implementation of animal protection laws in line with our responsibility for animals as sentient fellow creatures! We want to promote species-appropriate husbandry systems in livestock farming.
Regional livestock farming close to home reduces the need to transport animals. We are committed to limiting the transportation of live animals to no more than six hours. For the purposes of
3C	37
breeding, the transportation of live animals must be possible under defined conditions and under strict veterinary control by certified companies.
The robust and healthy livestock that develop in species-appropriate husbandry contribute significantly to the prevention of multi-resistant germ development by reducing the necessary use of antibiotics.
Slaughter according to religious rituals is only permitted after sufficient stunning. The duration of stunning must be guaranteed for the entire slaughter process. The German standard for slaughterhouses should also be applied to imported goods.
¦ Hunting, conservation and species protection
Hunting is nature conservation in action. The AfD supports hunting in harmony with nature. We stand for the proven principle of forest with game. We clearly reject the "forest before game" ideology prevalent in left-green circles, which degrades game species to pests. This is because it is contrary to animal welfare and game biology - and therefore to hunting in accordance with hunting principles!
The further impairment of hunting by EU regulations in hunting, weapons and food law must be prevented. Existing regulations must be reviewed and brought into line with the interests of farmers, forest and land owners and hunters. The good training of hunting license holders in Germany must not be watered down by EU regulations.
Active management should enable problematic wild animal populations to be monitored and corrected at regional level in a timely manner. As the example of the wolf shows, a sense of reality must take precedence over uncontrolled settlement. The wolf population must be understood as a uniform European population. It should be regulated spatially and numerically in line with the Swedish and Norwegian models. To this end, the wolf should be transferred from Annex IV to Annex V of the Habitats Directive.
Invasive species and their wildlife populations threaten our native biodiversity, game populations and agriculture and livestock farming. Regulation and suppression of these species must be possible without bureaucracy in order to stabilize nature and prevent a threat to native flora and fauna.
¦ Wind power industry versus species and landscape protection
Wind turbines pose a fundamental threat to plants and animals as well as an impairment of people's health and quality of life. In particular, the death of birds, bats and insects is accepted as collateral damage of the left-green energy transformation. The consequences of this are population declines that can lead to the extinction of protected species. No other form of energy takes such a heavy toll on wildlife as the wind power industry! The effects of soil erosion and wind drag caused by wind turbines must be researched as quickly as possible. Further approvals must be suspended until these effects have been established. This type of energy generation also has a massive impact on the soil and water balance. Further damage to our natural environment in the name of supposed climate protection must be prevented at all costs.
¦ 
Water protection
The European Water Framework Directive sets central limit values for the EU that are binding for the member states. Such a centralized regulatory framework causes different adjustment difficulties and excessive bureaucracy in the individual regions, which prevent measures from being taken when evidence- based limit values are exceeded. Water protection therefore belongs primarily in the hands of the nation states and, in Germany, the federal states. In coordinated cooperation with representatives of local authorities, agriculture and other stakeholders, they can ensure water protection much more effectively.
¦ Consumer protection
Consumers must be able to deal with increasingly global companies on an equal footing. However, consumers lack essential information about the origin and quality of many foodstuffs, financial products and material goods. The AfD wants to put consumers in a position to make informed purchasing decisions and calls for the asymmetrical information situation between consumers and companies to be balanced out. In doing so, we do not want to give consumers preferential treatment by the state or confuse them with too much information. Our goals are clearly recognizable, transparent information and informed consumers. However, this must not lead to impractical regulations.
Germany has a well-functioning food control system. There is no need for a superordinate EU authority here. We reject supranational intervention in procedures and advocate the transfer of competencies back to the nation states. Pan-European issues can be discussed at European level and then decided in a coordinated manner - not the other way around. The European harmonization of food safety must not result in a lowering of standards in Germany. We therefore reject centralized regulations.
We call for an efficient rapid alert system for feed and food safety. In the event of reasonable suspicion of harmful products, food toxins or animal diseases, we advocate controls at the European internal borders. We also call for the labeling of products with a clear declaration of content and weight in relation to the sales price in order to prevent consumer deception. For example, there must be no hidden addition of insects to foodstuffs; instead, this must be clearly labeled. In general, we advocate the reversal of the EU insect ban. The AfD is in favor of prominently displaying on packaging whether insects or insect parts are included. The AfD firmly rejects any weakening of existing standards through unilaterally negotiated free trade agreements!
Climate, energy and digitalization
CO2 is one of the foundations of our existence. Without CO2 in the air, there would be no plants. The climate has always changed since the earth's existence. There has never been a constant climate over long periods of time. Even since the last ice age around 10,000 years ago, the climate in Europe has alternated between phases that were colder or warmer than the current climate. The current climatic changes are fully in line with these changes - also in terms of their speed. Despite the alarmism spread by the media and politicians, in reality there has been neither an increase in extreme weather events nor a rapid rise in sea levels. Ever since humans have settled in Europe, they have always adapted to climate change. Even today, adaptation is the only possible way to deal with climate change.
Responsibility for adapting to climatic conditions lies with the individual nations of the EU. In the event of any changes, it is up to the countries to decide on measures in response to how they are affected. On the German side, the climatic changes of the recent past do not require any special measures. Expending resources and regulations in response to only possible future changes is unnecessary, economically and ecologically irresponsible.
A country's high level of prosperity, strong industry and economy allow it to react to both weather events and climatic changes at short notice if necessary - this is another reason why the AfD wants to put a stop to the destruction of prosperity in the countries of the Union.
An intact landscape and nature, for example, with high biodiversity, little sealed surfaces, sensible water management with natural rivers and floodplains, is also more resilient and flexible in relation to different weather conditions. This is why the AfD is committed to an appropriate environmental policy. This includes, in particular, the AfD's energy concept, which aims to conserve resources and use less land.
Fossil fuels were and are the basis of our prosperity. The claim of a threat from man-made climate change is not based on scientific findings. Rather, it is a political agenda to tax the air we breathe and thus implement social transformations (Great Transformation). It is an eco-socialist project that will inevitably lead to a dramatic reduction in prosperity and a totalitarian restriction of freedom. The already dwindling prosperity and our lack of future viability are a direct consequence of decarbonization, which is being pursued for purely political reasons. The EU, caught up in the ideology of the great transformation of society, is increasingly embarking on a special international path. The main global drivers of this fatal ideology are the Brussels bureaucrats with their Green Deal, who have no democratic legitimacy.
¦ No eco-socialist redistribution: "Fit for 55"
The "Fit for 55" package is a dystopia of an eco-socialist Brussels liability and redistribution state, cast in the form of regulations and directives by the EU Commission. The number 55 stands for the 55% reduction in CO2 emissions required by 2030 compared to 1990 levels. In other words, emissions are to be reduced by 31% in the remaining years up to 2030 - 24% has already been achieved in the last 32 years. This alone shows the ignorance with regard to the data basis, feasibility and common sense. The "Fit for 55" package is the legal underpinning of the "Green Deal" and thus of a transformative change in our economy, society and industry. It is based on the European Climate Law adopted in 2021.
This general law, described by its initiators as "irreversible", demands the adaptation of all future and existing laws. The aim is for Brussels to rule directly into the personal lives of every citizen, bypassing all democratically elected and legitimized national parliaments. Many citizens are not aware that EU regulations are automatically valid without the approval of the German Bundestag. Using the media-fueled climate catastrophe predictions, "Fit for 55" not only wants to implement an energy transition, but also a consumption transition, a resource transition, a mobility transition, a food transition and an industrial transition. The planned ban on oil and gas heating is a serious encroachment on citizens' property and fundamental rights, which the AfD is fighting politically.
Through political reforms, the EU wants to implement comprehensive carbon pricing throughout the economy. This should then bring about changes in consumer and business behavior. Exploding energy prices are only the first signal of a "green world rescue". The deliberately induced energy shortage is intended to create a society that is helplessly at the mercy of the Brussels central state and dependent on monetary benefits.
citizens. At the same time, it cements an unprecedented redistribution of German taxpayers' wealth at EU level. Thanks to the continued proclamation of so-called crises, such as the climate, financial, migration, corona and gas crises, Brussels is able to demand financial packages of unprecedented size with "the distribution of the associated burdens among the Member States according to their relative prosperity".
These lead to the joint borrowing of the "NextGenerationEU" fund. In addition, the Commission wants to use the upcoming European emergency law to take direct control of the economic sector right down to individual companies. A "coordinated" concept for risk and crisis communication to the public is planned. A crisis would then be declared without parliamentary control. The path to a surveillance state with a planned economy is mapped out.
¦ CO2 tax, climate madness and limit values
The AfD does not allow people to be judged by their carbon footprint. We do not share the irrational CO2 hysteria that is structurally destroying our society, culture and way of life. We stand for freedom, progress and science!
We do not want EU limits that climate lobbyists can push through against Germany's most basic interests. We are clearly in favor of a rational discussion on limit values: measures must be objectively justified, sensible, affordable and feasible! The AfD also consistently opposes
"Greenwashing", whereby raw materials are mined in third countries under precarious conditions with considerable damage to the environment.
With the EU's decision to ban combustion engines by 2035, which is supported by all the old parties, it is pursuing the goal of abolishing private transport for the majority of the population. The AfD is on the side of citizens who are dependent on cars or who see the freedom of individual transport as an achievement of civilization. The Alternative for Germany therefore strictly rejects driving bans.
¦ Energy
Cheap and reliable energy is the key to prosperity and progress. Despite decades of subsidies, volatile energy sources are expensive and unsuitable for supplying the EU. They destroy natural and settlement areas. Storage facilities are not feasible. "Bio" gas and fuels take valuable land away from food production and make both goods more expensive. Due to this ideological energy policy, electricity, mobility, warm homes and food are becoming a luxury for citizens. Industrial companies and consumers alike are suffering from the world's highest energy prices. The result is emigration or impoverishment. As can be seen from the Ukraine conflict, there is a direct link between energy and foreign policy.
Cheap natural gas for households and businesses is of geostrategic interest to Germany and Europe. In future, one-sided dependencies must be avoided. The AfD is striving for a reorientation of the German energy supply without ideological blinkers. Neither unconventional shale gas extraction nor nuclear energy or lignite can be ruled out. Shale gas extraction has also been practiced in Germany for decades. Environmental pollution can be ruled out if current regulations are observed. Nuclear energy offers an environmentally friendly and affordable energy supply for the next millennia thanks to decades of proven high-safety technology. Coal-fired power generation is clean thanks to sophisticated air filters and is necessary for gypsum production, among other things.

For citizen-friendly data protection
The GDPR is not only an example of over-bureaucratization by the EU, but also stands for the systematic disregard of the principle of subsidiarity. Responsibility for data protection must also be returned to the nation states.
The General Data Protection Regulation in its current form must be replaced by a citizen-friendly national
regulation.

¦ Digitization
The freedom of citizens on the Internet is being increasingly restricted from year to year by mostly politically or ideologically motivated interventions ranging from range restrictions to exclusion from services (deplatforming). This contradicts our understanding of freedom. Instead, the state must return to the purpose of the internet: to connect people and information. We reject the EU's digitalization regulations, as they always involve surveillance or censorship. They threaten the freedom of citizens and the competitiveness of EU countries. Over-bureaucratization costs billions and prevents start-ups and the development of new digital technologies. These include the GDPR, upload filters and ancillary copyright. EU member states are largely dependent on external hardware and software. Even with hardware, there are problems with regard to the security and freedom of citizens due to deliberate loopholes (backdoors) or undefined spyware in the background. A primary goal must therefore be to restore the security of the IT infrastructure and to become more independent of non-European markets, also with regard to data sovereignty. For a free society, it is essential that digital networks and services are trustworthy and that the privacy of users is protected.
Our demands are concrete:
? The civil liberties of citizens must not be restricted by digitalization.
? The EU must demand that platform providers disclose and stop all censorship activities.
? Ensure citizens' freedom of speech and data (right to encryption and net neutrality).
? The regulation of digitalization must be in national hands and data economy must prevail at EU level.
We reject an "EU data octopus".
The GDPR, the ancillary copyright regulation and upload filters must be abolished.
? The development of European, open-source hardware and software should be promoted to strengthen digital s o v e r e i g n t y .
? Public procurement must be based o n strategic and security policy considerations.
? A right to an analog life for citizens: dealing with authorities and using public facilities must also be possible without a digital identity.
? The preservation of cash as an unrestricted means of payment (keyword "digital euro").
? No digital recording of all assets in an EU central register.
Health policy must remain a national responsibility.
Since the start of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, it has become clear that the EU's influence in health policy is also increasing at the expense of individual states. The result is a massive expansion of the influence of the EU Commission and the EU agencies EMA, ECDC, HERA and, in future, EHDS on the health policy of the nation states. In future, the EU Commission will be able to declare pandemics and health emergencies without the approval of the EU Parliament. The epidemic control authority (ECDC) is then authorized to monitor the health policy of countries, intervene and send emergency assistance teams to the countries. Decisions in EU institutions with questionable legitimacy and, not least, the case law of the European Court of Justice (ECJ) are intended to dictate to citizens how they should deal with eminently important health issues and what restrictions they should accept on their personal freedom of choice. We call for clarification under EU law that health policy remains the responsibility of national parliaments. We also firmly reject the transfer of competences to the WHO.
¦ No further privatization of hospitals
In recent decades, there has been a steadily increasing trend towards the privatization of hospitals. The market share of privatized hospitals nationwide is now around one third and has thus reached a critical size to jeopardize the diversity of public, non-profit and private owners required by German law. As critical infrastructure, hospitals must remain predominantly in public or non-profit ownership. The public sector's statutory mandate to ensure safety must also be guaranteed. The AfD therefore rejects any influence by the EU on the operation and financing of hospitals in Germany as well as further privatization. This also applies analogously to inpatient care facilities and medical care centers (MVZ).
¦ Securing the supply of medicines
A nationwide network of owner-managed pharmacies is still essential to ensure a nationwide supply of medicines, which is particularly important for structurally weak regions, as local pharmacies are one of the key prerequisites for regional structural policy. However, this regionally anchored supply model is threatened by the increasing sale of prescription medicines. For this reason, most EU countries have banned or severely restricted mail-order sales. In Germany, too, the mail-order sale of medicines should no longer be permitted. Non-prescription medicines can still be sold over the Internet without any restrictions.
In order to avoid supra-regional supply bottlenecks, it must be ensured that medicines used in Germany are produced exclusively in Europe. In addition, pharmaceutical wholesalers in Germany should be obliged to keep at least an average two-month requirement of supply-relevant pharmaceuticals in stock at all times. Short distances and the strengthening of domestic production should be promoted.
¦ No medical treatment in the sense of "gender mainstreaming"
Following the changes to the law in May 2021 ("Act on the Protection of Children with Gender Development Variants"), gender reassignment surgery is now much easier in Germany, even for minors without the consent of their legal guardians. This includes the use of so-called "puberty blockers" to pharmacologically delay the sexual development of minors and to prepare for surgical interventions in the sense of "gender reassignment". The consequences for adolescents are irreversible; the lifelong physical and psychological damage is immense.
What already exists in legal form in Germany is to be introduced at EU level as binding "law" for all citizens. We strictly reject this. Early sexualization in childcare facilities and schools, which is intended to encourage this, must also be resolutely opposed.
¦ No compulsory vaccination
The Standing Committee on Vaccination (Stiko) lists a comprehensive table of standard vaccinations that are only explicitly recommended and are therefore subject to the personal responsibility and self- determination of citizens. A state-generated vaccination printout (e.g. for Covid-19) and a digital vaccination certificate planned by the EU would be the first steps towards further state-prescribed vaccinations, including mRNA injections. In this way, the state is restricting citizens' right to self- determination over their own bodies, which is enshrined in the German Basic Law, in violation of fundamental rights and is shifting the decision to vaccinate from the personal to the state level, where a decision in favor of vaccination is to be forced through massive pressure, including the deprivation of citizens' economic livelihoods. A free and legally effective vaccination decision is impossible under these circumstances. The fundamental right to physical integrity and the right to self-determination must not be infringed under any circumstances.
¦ Stop all corona vaccinations
Due to the disproportionately high incidence of severe vaccine damage, alarming excess mortality, the toxic spike effect and proven vascular damage that can affect any organ, we call for the EU Commission to stop the approval of mRNA and vector-based corona injections and for a broad and public investigation by an independent body. We consider a legal review of the approval of corona injections by the EU Commission on the recommendation of the European Medicines Agency to be indispensable. In the meantime, more and more warning voices are being heard from the fields of medicine and science, especially from gynecologists and pediatricians. There are even warning voices from the funeral profession! These people must be heard clearly and their warning signals must be examined seriously and independently. In order to involve the public in the investigations, citizens should be directly involved and those affected by the coronavirus in particular should be able to report on their experiences. We also demand the full rehabilitation of all citizens who have suffered legal disadvantages and legal proceedings in the course of the corona crisis due to their critical stance on state vaccination and corona policy.
¦ 
Preserving the profession of alternative practitioner
The ECJ has confirmed the ban on alternative practitioners practising their profession in Austria, thereby making it clear that the activity of alternative practitioners is not worthy of protection. In Germany, too, there are efforts to severely restrict or completely ban the practice of this profession. For the AfD, the possibility of using the services of alternative practitioners is part of the patient's self-determination over their body and their personal health care. Every patient should decide on their own responsibility about the medical measures that affect them. State paternalism in this highly personal area must be firmly rejected. This should not involve an obligation to reimburse costs by the statutory health insurance providers.
¦ Only deploy personnel qualified to German standards
Trust cannot be built up with doctors, therapists, pharmacists or nurses who have language deficits, nor can misunderstandings in the treatment process be ruled out. Employing foreign staff, who often have language deficits, is therefore not a solution to the staff shortage in the healthcare sector. Medical staff must have good language skills and their professional qualifications must fully meet German standards. The shortage of doctors must be addressed primarily by increasing the number of university places, especially as there is no shortage of qualified applicants in Germany.
¦ Medical technology
The new Medical Device Regulation (MDR) adopted by the European Parliament, which is directly transposed into national law, poses enormous bureaucratic challenges for German manufacturers of medical devices, which are also associated with considerable costs for the companies (and ultimately for the end user of the medical devices). Every medical device already on the market will have to be retroactively certified under the aforementioned directive by
July 22, 2022, which was probably not even possible.
Although this deadline has now been extended for individual product groups, the many smaller manufacturers in Germany (mainly in south-west Germany) cannot cope with the bureaucratic burden, especially as the number of certification bodies is far too small. It is in the interests of the many innovative, small (and also larger) medical technology companies in Germany to work towards the introduction of grandfathering for products already on the market. These tried and tested products would then be recognized as certified following an unbureaucratic registration process.
¦ Preventing the misuse of medical data
The planned European Health Data Space (EHDS) is intended to enable the use of individual health data for the general public. It would be another bureaucratic monstrosity, harboring considerable potential for abuse and leading to a restriction of personal freedoms. Personal health data is not a public good. It is an expression of individuality worthy of protection and requires the utmost discretion. It must never be at the disposal of political and commercial desires and ideological interests. For this reason, the AfD strictly rejects the centralized storage of patient data at EU level.

Family policy
¦ Family and demographics
The family is the heart of every society and therefore enjoys special protection in Germany under the Basic Law. All people have the right to freely choose their marital status. Other forms of cohabitation than marriage between a man and a woman are to be respected, but are not to be treated equally. In its family policy, the AfD is committed to the classic model of the family, in which father and mother take permanent joint responsibility for their children. The unique and privileged position of father and mother with regard to the protection of the child's welfare and upbringing must be fully preserved. We strive for equal opportunities for women and men and support people living traditional gender roles.
¦ Children are meaningful, enriching and vital
Without families with children, our European societies, our cultures and our freedom cannot exist. That is why the needs of children are at the heart of our family policy.
Not only Germany, but almost all European countries are struggling with the resulting problems of low birth rates and an ageing society. Many governments are trying to compensate for the population decline through immigration, although this has been proven to be unsuccessful and leads to massive cultural and social problems when living together. The AfD, on the other hand, wants to encourage and support significantly more young couples to start a family and have several children. The support should go well beyond what is already being implemented in France, Poland and Hungary. Children are the future!
¦ Strengthening the personal responsibility of families
Families are best able to manage their own affairs independently and on their own responsibility. Only if this is not possible should help for self-help be provided. The AfD calls for this to take place exclusively at national level. The EU is not responsible for family policy. It must therefore not interfere in families, influence their life plans or even control them through quotas. By increasingly taking over areas of social and family policy, the European Union is violating the f u n d a m e n t a l principle of subsidiarity to which it has committed itself. The AfD will vigorously oppose this. We strictly reject any link between financial contributions and the implementation of ideological goals. Legislative competence on all ethical and family policy issues, in particular the right to life, self-determination, marriage and divorce, must remain with the nation states.
¦ Recognizing the social achievements of families
Everyone benefits from the services provided by the families. However, the costs, the work and the sacrifices required are largely borne by the families. Due to this equity gap, fewer and fewer couples are deciding to have children.
The rapid decline in the number of multi-child families in the middle classes and the high number of childless people among the top performers are the main reasons for the demographic catastrophe in Western societies
and for the resulting shortage of skilled workers. Added to this is the very low esteem in which parents and their educational work are held by politicians, the media, the economy and society. Families are at a disadvantage compared to those without children. The AfD therefore advocates national concepts to improve the quality of life of families.
¦ Abortions must become the exception
The right to life is a fundamental human right. It is diametrically opposed to the desire for abortion. Without the right to life, no other human right can be claimed. Every human being is a human being from the moment of fertilization (ECJ ruling C-34/10). Abortion must therefore become the absolute exception,
e.g. in the case of criminological or medical indications.
Influential groups in the EU are currently trying to make abortion the norm, or even the norm.
"human right". Some even describe the lack of abortion options as "torture". This would also overturn the balanced regulation of § 218 StGB in Germany. The AfD will resolutely oppose this grotesque trivialization and trivialization of infanticide in the European Parliament.
The AfD rejects any EU funding for organizations or measures that promote abortion. We are committed to ensuring that mothers receive comprehensive support during pregnancy and after birth, especially in difficult circumstances.
On the other hand, more and more unintentionally childless couples are willing to pay money for a child. However, paid surrogacy is a form of child trafficking. We therefore reject a "right to have a child" and commercial surrogacy. Adoption can be a solution to both problems, but should continue to be regulated at national level.
¦ Stopping gender ideology
It is a biological fact and not a social construct that there are exactly two genders: Woman and man. The pseudo-science of gender ideology denies this basic biological fact. The EU must stop all promotion of this scandalous ideology immediately.
Gender ideology causes the greatest damage to children and young people during puberty. It massively impairs their development and in many cases causes permanent damage. The AfD is calling for a ban on "sex changes" for minors and a rigid restriction of drug treatments, e.g. with puberty blockers.
¦ Child benefit as required
In 2021 alone, around 459 million euros of German tax revenue was paid abroad as child benefit - regardless of the living conditions of the children in the recipient countries. This is unfair and creates considerable incentives for social migration. The existing regulation must be amended by correcting EU Regulation 883/2004.
