We will continue to campaign for the social sciences and humanities to be given a permanent place in the EU funding framework and for critical sciences to be taken into account, as they are of great importance for a vibrant and resilient culture, society and democracy. By creating a better understanding of social contexts and necessities, they help to overcome multiple crises with holistic solutions. Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine, which violates international law, teaches us that peace research and research on the countries of Eastern Europe, the South Caucasus and Central Asia must be intensified. We want to promote cooperation between European and Ukrainian universities. We want to continue to strengthen Open Access, i.e. the principle that research results and research data should be findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable, as a principle of Horizon Europe and support it in international cooperation.
Horizon Europe is already connected to many partner countries worldwide, which promotes the exchange of knowledge. However, we want to make Horizon Europe more accessible and more international for our researchers. To this end, we want to simplify the application process, reduce bureaucracy and involve more partner countries. In scientific cooperation with non-European partners, it is important to protect European technological sovereignty and guarantee scientific freedom.
Good policy is based on verifiable facts and scientific findings. We advocate standards and transparency guidelines when commissioning scientific studies and expert opinions.
Turning ideas into wealth
Innovation is crucial for Europe's economic future. We want to support ideas on their way from the laboratory to practice. Innovations are a decisive building block for the economic success of tomorrow.
Building on basic research, we are shaping mission- oriented research that helps us to tackle the major challenges of our time and understand their causes: For example, we need a faster roll-out of renewable energy, effective treatments for cancer, smart digital solutions and approaches to tackle social inequality. The missions of Horizon Europe should continue to be guided in particular by the Green Deal. To implement them, we want to bring together universities, institutes, civil society and business.
Innovation policy is an important part of our active economic and industrial policy. We want to expand the transfer-oriented program components of Horizon Europe so that the best ideas are supported on the way to their implementation. In order to make participation in funding programmes more attractive for SMEs, municipal institutions and non- governmental organizations (NGOs), the application and documentation of projects should be simplified as much as possible.
To this end, the EU should also increasingly support regional innovation ecosystems in which science, society, business and the public sector work together on the necessary solutions for the future. Such clusters of research, teaching and practice are key to promoting innovation, accelerating its application and creating climate- neutral prosperity locally. In addition to universities, universities of applied sciences and universities of applied sciences should also be considered. To date, they have often not benefited from EU funding to the same extent as universities, but are particularly strong in applied research. In order to improve this, we want to look at the application and funding conditions of the relevant programs.
We want to make the existing instruments more manageable and faster. This applies, for example, to the Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs), which are particularly dedicated to training young talent, for example in master's or further education programs. By strengthening the
knowledge triangle of higher education, research and innovation, we can give as many people as possible the chance to get involved in key issues of the future.
Transparency and traceability of decisions are also of great importance in this relevant area: the Commission has created a large number of public- private partnerships that manage EU funds together with industry. We would like to launch a transparency initiative here, review existing partnerships and ensure that universities, research institutes and start-ups benefit more from these funding instruments. In addition to proven research formats, long-term studies are also an important contribution to balanced research.
Space is crucial for Europe's technological and strategic sovereignty. Europe must therefore play a leading role in space and needs independent and reliable access to space. We are strengthening the competitiveness of the space industry under the principle of "New Space", for example by promoting new technologies and a European launcher competition. We promote the EU space program, the European Space Agency (ESA) and the astronaut program.
With a European Space Act, we are leading the way internationally, ensuring sustainability and creating growth opportunities and legal certainty for European companies.
Taking off with European start-ups
An innovative corporate landscape needs a lively start-up scene. This is where the start-ups and business models of tomorrow are born. To achieve this, founding must become easier and faster. We want to ensure that there are one-stop stores in every member state. There, founders can find support and advice from a single source. A digital compass should provide an overview of all funding programs for start-ups. Our goal is to make it easy to apply with just one click.
We need a clear responsibility for young companies in the Commission so that the transfer of know-how in the EU is better coordinated. With a European start-up strategy, we are bundling important measures to improve access to venture capital, to attract talent and to public contracts for young companies. The potential of underrepresented groups, especially women and people with a history of migration, should also be better utilized and supported sothattheir ideas have a fair chance of being implemented.
The European Tech Champions Initiative, which the German government has launched together with other EU member states, is an important building block to better support start-ups in the growth phase. In addition, we want to create regular European matching hubs that bring private investors together with founders, a trade fair for business models of the future. Good innovation support also consists of implementing and sustainably securing good and reliable working conditions in science and business.
We want to expand and make greater use of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to strengthen innovative start-ups and climate- friendly industry, especially in cross-border regions.
Promoting SMEs and skilled trades
The innovative capacity and drive of SMEs and the skilled crafts sector are the driving force behind the European economy. Particularly in rural areas, the skilled trades and SMEs provide jobs and stability. They develop, produce, install and maintain future technologies such as solar systems and heat pumps. Europe thrives on cooperation and local problem solvers. However, SMEs, from industry to the skilled trades, are particularly burdened by the introduction of new regulations and bureaucratic hurdles in funding programs. We will therefore improve and consistently apply the SME tests, which assess the impact of new laws on SMEs in line with the "Think
small first" principle should always be reviewed in advance and adjustments made accordingly. We also advocate appropriate exemptions and transition periods for SMEs in new laws and provide support during the changeover. We particularly promote training in the skilled trades. By simplifying application procedures and reducing reporting requirements, we are making it easier for SMEs to access EU funding and investment programs. With the help of fixed SME quotas, we ensure that they actually benefit from these programs. We will standardize the funding landscape in the EU and dovetail it more closely with national funding instruments.
Some legal regulations are now outdated, while others are unsuitable in practice. We advocate a regular review of all regulations in order to simplify bureaucratic requirements and remove regulations that fail to achieve their objective. Where possible and equally effective, we prefer graduated and flexible regulation for companies instead of hard regulation. For example, we want to replace the reporting requirement for overnight stays in tourism and A1 certificates with a more practical approach with pragmatic solutions for small businesses.
A central means of reducing bureaucracy is the digitalization of administration. This can eliminate many administrative procedures, automate data exchange and make it easier to submit applications.
Administrative services should be digitally as far as possible. The status of
procedures should be accessible online. Through stronger networking between European and national authorities, the once-only principle is to be introduced so that in future data will only be requested once from companies so that it can then be exchanged within the framework of data protection regulations and within the authorities. We want to largely abolish the written form requirement in administrative procedures.
6. 
Digital sovereignty
Making Europe digitally fit
Digitalization provides a key to the central challenges of our time. It makes it possible to completely rethink fundamental areas of life such as transportation, education, health and energy. As a result, it offers enormous opportunities for economic development and for simplifying many tasks for everyone - from tedious administrative processes and the management of supply chains in industry to the research and treatment of serious diseases. We want to make it the foundation of a fair, decentralized, highly networked and resilient economic system.
We are also experiencing systemic competition in the digital sector - between emancipatory digitalization that empowers citizens and strengthens freedom, and digitalization that disempowers citizens and promotes surveillance for economic or political interests. Europe must consciously position itself in this competition and take a big step towards being an attractive location for talent and innovative companies and thus help shape the rapid digital development. We therefore want to secure, strengthen and expand Europe's digital sovereignty.
The basis of European digital sovereignty is, among other things, a resilient and climate- friendly infrastructure, which includes broadband networks, mobile networks, hubs, data centers and the reliability of sensitive supply chains. We want to drive forward the development and production of infrastructure components in Europe, be it the production and development semiconductors, satellite communications and mobile communications technology. We want to shape the connection to the global network infrastructure, whether for submarine cables or nodes, with strong European players.
Digital sovereignty means the development and application of key technologies such as AI, quantum computing and communication in Europe.
Here, too, we can rely on strong European companies in various sectors and strengthen this development with a bundling o f measures - for example, targeted investments as part of the investment program for innovation, sovereignty and resilience.
Wherever possible, we advocate the preference for free and open source software.
software and open data solutions. For critical infrastructures in particular, the European Commission must work together with the Member States to ensure that European standards for
IT security without backdoors and innovative digital offerings "made in the EU", such as software for controlling energy and water supplies, rail infrastructure or health information systems.
Advancing digitalization also means taking it into account in political projects. We want to consider the digital implementation of proposed legislation as early as the legislative process. This will enable government services to be provided faster and more efficiently. Above all, the digitalization of administrative processes can help to make political rules - from the CBAM border adjustment mechanism to data protection - manageable in economic practice.
Shaping artificial intelligence in Europe
Progress in the development and application of AI represents a huge opportunity for many areas of life. It can serve people, simplify our lives and make our lives easier.
It can change and simplify processes in everyday life, education and science, administration and business. Modern AI-supported processes can help to reduce the use of water and pesticides and increase crop yields at the same time. They protect the environment and increase economic efficiency.
At the same time, new risks are emerging due to the rapid progress of AI. These range from large- scale cyberattacks through AI-supported vulnerability scans to the structural
discrimination of social groups to risks such as incorrect situation assessments in autonomous driving. We want to use AI in accordance with our shared values to ensure effective protection of human rights and equality. We therefore support research and technology impact assessment to accompany the introduction of this technology and advocate regulation not only at European but also at global level. We support the approach of regulating AI applications with regard to their potential risk and, where necessary, making the underlying source data transparent.
With the Artificial Intelligence (AI) Act, the EU is taking a major step in this direction, which is being noticed and closely monitored worldwide. We want to shape and harness the potential of AI. In addition to the availability of computing capacity, we also need support for specialists, better availability of data and support for research and transfer.
In addition to the international establishment of eco- logical IT standards, we want to develop and implement sustainability standards for software designs andoperate energy-intensive data centers in a climate-neutral manner in the future. Sustai- nability by design must be the rule for software and networked devices; the EU must develop sustainability standards for AI, cloud platforms, browsers, search engines, digital marketplaces and social networks. We are calling for a Digital Sustainability Act at EU level in order to focus the innovative strength of companies in information technologies more strongly on sustainability. We also want to integrate a waste heat infrastructure for data centers into the European energy infrastructure.
Use data based on rights
Data and the processing of large data sets are the basis for numerous innovative technologies and AI in particular. The smart use of data makes an important contribution to enriching our lives together and tackling numerous social problems
as well as social and ecological innovations, to conserve resources and to advance scientific research.
We want Europe to take a decisive step forward in the availability of data, as this is critical for our competitiveness.
are. This applies to the development of AI, the success of European AI models and our ability to innovate as a whole. To this end, we want to make non-personal data more usable and more easily accessible based on rights. To facilitate access to personal data, we are examining procedures for anonymization, pseudonymization and the possibilities of synthetic data gen- eration. We have contributed to the implementation of this principle in legislation on t h e use and improved exchange of data between companies as part of the data strategy. We are therefore committed to ensuring that the public administration publishes its data in machine-readable formats. Projects such as Smart City Barcelona can serve as an example of how data can be made available and how research and innovation can be driven forward.
With the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the EU has strongly shaped data protection worldwide in recent years and set global standards in the regulation of personal data protection.
However, enforcement of the rules in the member states varies. While Germany needs less bureaucracy and more legal certainty, the rules for international digital companies based in other member states must be enforced just as consistently. Due to lax enforcement in recent years, big tech companies in particular have been able to gain competitive advantages that are crucial for all sectors of the economy, especially in the areas of advertising, social networks and AI. The European Commission must therefore ensure that the GDPR is enforced uniformly and consistently in order to effectively protect fundamental rights and citizens' rights and create a level playing field for all companies that use a
Exclude special treatment of large corporations compared to SMEs. We want to use the upcoming evaluation of the GDPR to simplify the regulations and make them more practicable while maintaining the same level of data protection, also to take into account the special needs of SMEs and start-ups.
We see further potential to support users in enforcing their claims, simplify implementation for SMEs and create all-round legal certainty through the digitalization of data protection agreements and an automated information option for collected personal data. In this way, we give users more transparency and control over the processing of their personal data. In addition, the approach makes it easier for citizens to donate their data for research purposes and thus create the data pools required for AI models.
Setting digital standards
Trust and reliability are the be-all and end-all of successful digitalization for consumers and companies. This trust is promoted and guaranteed by common standards. We therefore advocate fair, open and resilient digital regulatory frameworks.
We pay particular attention to the necessary investment security for European companies, especially SMEs. Because only clear and reliable rules ensure innovative, trustworthy and therefore successful economic spaces. With the Digital Services Act (DSA) and the Digital Markets Act (DMA), we have taken important steps towards this in the EU. The completion of the digital single market can help Europe to be globally competitive.
A key to successful digital policy lies in interoperability: Europe's digital systems must speak the same language.
Interoperability refers to the ability of
IT systems to handle business processes across the boundaries of companies, authorities and research institutions - fully automatically,
without manual input or media disruptions. This requires the standardization of common software interfaces, specific to each use case. In this way, individuals, companies, research institutions and NGOs can carry out transactions with each other equally.
Experience shows that standardization can help innovative technologies achieve a breakthrough. Examples of this are the World Wide Web and digital mobile communications (GSM).
Interoperability breaks through monopolies, opening up economic areas and markets worth billions, which offer huge opportunities, especially for SMEs from Europe.
With the European Interoperability Framework (EIF), the EU has created an initial crystallization point that we are using as a starting point: In various groups, representatives of different interest groups are developing the standardized IT interfaces (profiles) for the respective application.
The development of these standards must be democratically legitimized. Arbitrary consortia of large international companies lack this. We therefore want to open up standardization to developers, civil society and SMEs. Their commitment must be remunerated so that everyone can participate in this design under the same conditions. We see it as a central task of the EU to monitor this democratic governance and ensure planning and investment security. These standards should be freely available and usable without license fees. The EU can also make a decisive contribution to enforcing these standards on the market through the power of the public sector as a customer.
Digitize consumer protection
Disinformation and hate are taking up more and more space in digital media and endangering social coexistence. The increasing relevance of software and digital platforms in society and our democracy must be reflected in consumer protection. Over the past few years, the EU has made significant progress in this area.
Progress has been made. With the DSA and the DMA, we in Europe have laid the foundations for creating clear rules on the internet and restoring competition. Big tech companies must now regularly assess the risk that their algorithms pose to society - and propose countermeasures where necessary. Under our pressure, scientists and NGOs will be given access to the platforms' data in order to research their effects and make them public. The advertising and tracking-based business models, whose algorithms prefer to show emotionalizing content in order to bind users to the respective platform, must also be put to the test.
The task now is to consistently enforce the DSA and the DMA in Germany and Europe and to further develop them based on the knowledge gained through data access. Laws to protect consumers in the digital space must be enforced and applied; to this end, we want to strengthen consumer protection agencies at national and European level. The regulation of digital platforms must take a closer look at the dominance of large digital marketplaces. In this context, fundamental rights are increasingly being violated on these platforms when users are blocked for no reason.
In addition to the rules of digital consumer protection, digital education is also an important building block to guarantee the rights and participation of all citizens in the digital social debate and to strengthen their information literacy.
We want to ensure fair competitive conditions that offer SMEs good access and do not expose consumers to unlimited market power. It must be ensured that SMEs can trade their products online under fair conditions. To this end, we will tighten up competition law if necessary. Digital business models must be sparing in their use of personal data. We want to strengthen the rights of users on digital communication platforms. Interoperability helps here:
Platforms should be able to communicate with each other so that users of different services can interact with each other. This will enable and improve the transfer of data so that users can access it when they leave platforms.
7. Circular economy
Reducing resource consumption and dependence on raw materials
The consumption and waste of resources contribute to the ecological and social crises of our time. We will therefore also campaign at European and international level for binding resource protection targets in order to reduce the absolute consumption of resources so that our economy comes into line with planning limits.
We need raw materials for a climate-neutral economy, the necessary technologies and products, because they are in the e-car on the road or the solar panel on the roof. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), the demand for metallic raw materials for green energy technologies alone will quadruple by 2040 inordertomeet the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement. A large proportion of these raw materials are currently mined in countries of the Global South - and processed in smelters and refineries in the People's Republic of China.
German and European companies are dependent on imports for 75 to 100 percent of a number of metals. With China currently occupying the central position in the raw material supply chain, Europe must diversify its raw material sources in order to secure its own independence. A particular
The provision of high-quality secondary materials plays a particularly important role here. We therefore advocate the establishment of a European raw materials agency as well as regular and mandatory stress tests for affected companies in order to ensure the security of raw materials for the European economy.
With the EU Critical Raw Materials Act (CRMA), we have taken a major step towards greater raw material security. The aim of the CRMA is that no more than 65 percent of imports of critical raw materials may come from a single third country.
Our diversification approach is based on various pillars: the reduction of raw material consumption and the implementation of an effective circular economy, the substitution of particularly scarce raw materials, the use and further processing of domestic raw materials in the EU and the implementation of a sustainable foreign policy on raw materials, which focuses on the expansion of partnerships with countries worldwide and pursues ambitious sustainability goals. For greater raw material security and environmental protection, we want to implement outstanding legislative proposals from the Green Deal and the action plan for a circular economy in a timely manner - while adhering to the waste hierarchy. In doing so, we are focusing on ambitious avoidance, reuse and recycling targets as well as more eco- design instead of downcycling.
Circular economy
The smart use of resources is one of the key prerequisites for a competitive economy. The circular economy has arrived in the mainstream and we are making it a European model for success. The greatest contribution to raw material security is saving scarce raw materials and reusing them. The circular economy aims to ensure that materials and products are shared, leased, reused, repaired, refurbished and recycled for as long as possible.
and recycled and waste is reduced to a minimum. This starts with the design of new products. That is why we want to support resource-conserving, durable and environmentally friendly design in the sense of "Design for Reuse, Repair and Recycling". It is good that the Eco-design Directive is now being further developed in this sense. Consumer goods should meet stricter minimum criteria in orderto protect the climate and conserve resources.
Producers must consider the entire life cycle of their products so that not only production but also use and recycling are as sustainable as possible.
We
advocate a circular economy that prioritizes the preservation and renovation of existing buildings, promotes the reuse of building products and supports the expansion of digital building component exchanges. We focus on ecological and recycled building products, the digital building passport and a digital building material and component passport.
All too often, for example, a washing machine ends up in the bin because it is easier and cheaper to buy a new one than to have it repaired. This uses up resources unnecessarily and causes 35 million tons of waste from still usable goods in the EU every year. For a society without waste, we want to strengthen the right to repair, introduce an obligation to provide spare parts and minimize the destruction of new goods. Transparency and reliability for consumers through a durability and repair index for large household appliances, for example, and longer warranty periods can be key approaches here. This should also soon put an end to the destruction of returned goods from online retailers. In addition, we want to strengthen opportunities to rent and borrow products under socially just conditions.
We want to build on the EU textile strategy and achieve circular textile production with better durability, repairability, reusability and recyclability. To this end, we want to promote alternative business models such as repair, rental and sharing services for textiles.
We are still losing valuable raw materials for the production of goods due to incomplete
Rules. We want to put a stop to illegal waste exports by consistently implementing the new Waste Shipment Ordinance. We want to stop plastic pollution worldwide and are committed to ending plastic waste exports to third countries altogether. In the current negotiations on a global plastics agreement, the EU should advocate globally binding rules for sustainable product design and the promotion of plastic avoidance, reuse and recycling.
In order to increase security of supply in the EU, we need a European approach so that we can better coordinate the sources and processing of raw materials.
capacities on our continent effectively. This also includes the domestic mining of scarce raw materials and the strengthening of
processing capacities in the EU. We will work to ensure that the EU makes ambitious progress in this area in compliance with high sustainability and human rights standards.
We want to reduce the extraction of raw materials in opencast mining as much as possible.
However, sources of raw materials do not only exist underground: in our homes, infrastructures, but also in our landfills and dumps, there are sources of raw materials that we have not yet sufficiently tapped into. That is why we want to promote the consistent reuse and further utilization of raw materials through a circular economy that makes use of the opportunities offered by digital solutions and promotes urban mining. This will enable us to create new business models while reducing the need for scarce primary raw materials.
We want to introduce reusable and deposit systems throughout Europe and give them priority over single-use packaging. In order to achieve the national collection quotas for batteries, we want to create a Europe-wide deposit system for batteries. Reuse always has priority over recycling. The use of critical raw materials such as lithium should be replaced by less critical minerals, for example through the increased use of sodium-ion batteries. We want to provide further research funding for this.
Forming raw material partnerships
In order to diversify our sources of raw materials outside the EU, we are committed to a sustainable foreign raw materials policy. It aims to establish new and strategic partnerships in the raw materials sector and deepen existing partnerships. We support international cooperation formats such as the Mine- rals Security Partnership (MSP) and increased
G7 cooperation within the framework of the Critical Raw Materials Club.
In addition, we want to deepen partnerships with resource-rich countries around the world and thus support them in implementing and enforcing the UN Sustainable Development Goals and international human rights standards. We do not want to align cooperation offers unilaterally with European supply interests, but rather support partner countries in increasing their value creation in the raw materials sector. We want to work with them to build the green supply chains of the future and give the population a share in the profits from resource extraction. We want to support countries in this task via the Global Gateway and other financing initiatives and, in this context, also promote the expansion of transportation and energy infrastructure.
8. Modern mobility
Advancing Europe's transport transition
Everyone in Europe should have the opportunity to be mobile in a climate-friendly, barrier-free, safe and affordable way. We are committed to ensuring that climate-friendly mobility is also the most attractive in terms of price and affordable for everyone. This includes ensuring that people can move around comfortably even without their own car. To achieve this, we are modernizing the European rail network and making it the backbone of the infrastructure union. For a successful transport transition throughout Europe, we need modern, well- developed rail routes and attractive trains across borders, a dense network of cycle paths and cycle routes, barrier-free pedestrian traffic, the expansion of e-charging infrastructure, a safe road network, climate-friendly air and sea traffic and attractive offers to combine different modes of transport.
Integrated urban development and spatial
planning with the concept of short distances make a decisive contribution to this. With the instrument of Sustainable Urban Mobility Plans (SUMPs), we want to promote this in all major European cities. Innovative means of transportation and new
We want to support mobility solutions such as cable cars or autonomous local public transport.
Such a turnaround in transportation is a central building block for a good and self-determined life in harmony with climate protection - in the city and in the countryside. We are committed to the further development of the European rail network, also in order to promote climate-friendly tourism in Europe. To this end, the expansion of the Trans- European Transport Networks (TEN-T) rail network must be completed much faster and with a higher share of EU funding. The restoration of gaps between countries, European freight transport and good night trains are also a priority for us. We want to create further incentives for shifting freight to rail and inland waterways. For this we need
We are creating a standardized Europe-wide freight train network with fast loading terminals for combined transport, where loads can be transferred from trucks to trains. This will make the environmentally friendly transportation of goods more competitive, more reliable and cheaper. In the medium term, we want to expand the German cycle into a European cycle.
Night trains are a comfortable and climate-friendly way to travel long distances within Europe and are therefore a good alternative to flying. A massive expansion of barrier-free night train services is therefore necessary. We are therefore advocating reduced track access charges, better funding for cross-border trains, the rapid expansion of rail infrastructure and, in particular, an industrial policy offensive for modern sleeping cars.
Strengthening the rail and bicycle industry offers great employment potential
in development, production and maintenance. In particular, the industrial policy potential of the bicycle industry for local, resource-efficient production is far from exhausted. We are therefore advocating a European cycling strategy that also includes the construction of safe cycle paths and the promotion of the private and commercial use of cargo bikes.
Book tickets easily
What is a matter of course when booking flights should also be standard for all train journeys in Europe in future. With a cross-provider ticketing system, we can enable booking platforms to offer cross-border, end-to-end tickets including sharing offers as well as boarding and alighting assistance for everyone. The cheapest tickets will be made easily accessible. Travelers will receive clear and transparent information on costs, travel times, accessibility and the climate impact of each travel option and will be able to choose the best option for them. To bring Europe closer together by rail, bookings must be simplified.
This should also apply to the offline sale of tickets. It should be easier to reserve Interrail tickets. We want to invite people to travel with confidence and therefore strengthen passenger rights. For example, travelers should be able to use any next train or bus in the event of a train cancellation, even if it is operated by another company.
Consistent implementation of the open data principle with open interfaces in public transport should also ensure that mobility services can be used easily and cheaply by everyone throughout Europe. In particular, sharing models and the combination of different means of transport, for example e-bike and train or park and ride, should benefit from this. In order to promote climate- friendly and barrier-free mobility, we want to enable passengers to take bicycles on new trains and ensure the right to transport necessary mobility aids free of charge.
We also want to strengthen the flat-rate principle in public transport in Europe, which we have successfully established in our own country with the Deutschland-Ticket. The Deutschland-Ticket should also be valid in the first state in the neighboring country in order to strengthen cross- border exchange. Flat-rate tickets with a similar principle should be mutually recognized. In this way, we are gradually achieving that
with a Europaticket you can use local transport in the
throughout the EU.
Implementing the drive turnaround
We want to design comprehensive offers for climate-neutral mobility: Attractive public transport enables a traffic turnaround and, in combination with integrated urban planning for shorter journeys, even a mobility turnaround. In this way, we make it possible for everyone to get around comfortably, even without their own car, with reliable and cost-effective services. And for the climate, at the heart of the mobility and transport transition is the drive transition, which ensures that things move in a climate-neutral and quiet way. The principle of operating as many means of transport as possible electrically with renewable energies must apply. We support the use of green hydrogen and the e-fuels based on it in shipping and air traffic. In road transport, however, we reject the use of e-fuels due to their lack of energy efficiency as well as their lack of climate and environmental friendliness. We only promote green hydrogen in road transport for heavy commercial vehicles.
As a key industry, the automotive industry provides many jobs. We want to support the industry - andin particular its employees - on the path to climate- neutral and resource-efficient mobility services. In a historic decision, the EU has decided that from 2035, no more fossil combustion engines may be newly registered in passenger cars. By 2030, emissions from new passenger cars are also to be reduced by 55 percent compared to 2021.
The CO2 reduction of passenger car drives by 2035 is to be pursued consistently and even more ambitiously than before. This is good for the
Germany as a business location, climate protection and consumers. Now we want to ensure that it is just as easy to drive an e-car to the nearest train station as it is to go on a family vacation. We have laid the foundation for a nationwide, intelligently networked and efficient charging infrastructure for all means of transport with the reform of the Alternative Fuels Ordinance: Over the next few years
sufficient charging points for cars and trucks set up on long-distance roads and in rural areas. Charging points must display their prices transparently.
Customers must be able to pay simply, transparently and without excessive roaming charges.
We also want to create incentives for e-vehicles to make them lighter and even more energy-efficient.
The proportion of freight traffic that remains on the road will in future be largely battery-electric. This requires the rapid expansion of the charging infrastructure for trucks along Europe's long- distance roads, in depots and freight distribution centers. We have successfully campaigned for this and will continue to do so. At the same time, the networks need to be efficiently upgraded to make them fit for the future.
New cars and other means of transport should be more closely aligned with the circular economy through efficiency standards right from the manufacturing and development stages.
and general energy and resource efficiency. We want to create greater incentives for manufacturers to offer lighter and more efficient solutions and reduce emissions, for example through tire and brake wear. By providing consumer-friendly information on the weight and carbon footprint of vehicles, we are ensuring greater transparency and making purchasing decisions easier.
In order to make heavy air and shipping traffic climate-neutral, we are supporting the production of sustainable fuels from renewable energies, for example e-kerosene, promoting fuel-saving technologies and the rapid development of a climate-neutral energy supply in ports, in particular a climate-neutral shore-side electricity supply. This will make fossil and biogenic fuels in transport a thing of the past in a generation. We are developing a European port strategy that ensures fair competitive conditions between European ports and strengthens the resilience of the European maritime location, also in the face of foreign investors who are looking to acquire and otherwise control the European maritime infrastructure. The port strategy optimizes the
investment needs, strengthens our continent in global supply chains and protects against too much influence from authoritarian states. We need
They are also needed to prevent further ecological damage caused by competition between locations for ever deeper shipping channels. We promote rail and inland waterway transport to ensure good hinterland connections. By including shipping in EU emissions trading, we are achieving a binding reduction in emissions.
We support the research and development of climate-neutral technologies for air travel. Shifting air traffic to more climate-friendly alternatives - especially for short-haul flights - remains our goal. We are calling for the EU-wide introduction of an air traffic tax based on energy content, similar to the one already levied in Germany. The majority of the resulting revenue should go to the EU budget. This should not put European airlines at a disadvantage compared to their international competitors.
Making traffic safe
We are pursuing Vision Zero for road traffic. Our goal is to ensure that there are no more traffic accidents with fatalities and serious injuries. We are committed to a safe transport infrastructure for everyone, especially children and the elderly. Municipal decision-making sovereignty over
Our goal remains a 30 km/h speed limit in urban areas and an EU-wide speed limit on major roads. We want to continue to promote the voluntary retrofitting of turning assistance systems in trucks in ordertoachieve the fullest possible coverage as quickly as possible.
Noise is still underestimated as a health factor. We are committed to more ambitious reduction targets for traffic. We want to make airplanes, trains, cars and motorcycles more responsible for people's health. To this end, we want to further develop the EU Environmental Noise Directive and source- related noise directives (e.g. limit values for vehicle noise emissions) and adapt them to the state of the art. Multiple pollution
We want to take greater account of this. In this way, the impact of traffic on people's health can be reduced by up to 50 percent. Nitrogen oxide, (ultra) fine dust, tire and brake abrasion must also be minimized to protect health. The Clean Air Directive and the
Euro 7 emissions standard are important steps in this direction. We are also striving to harmonize the European rules for environmental zones.
In lower airspace, new forms of mobility must be measured against the benefits they bring to society. We therefore advocate for regulations that only permit these in harmony with the protection of people, nature and the environment and under high safety requirements. We want to strengthen the right of local authorities to actively participate in the planning and design of airspace for drone operations over their territory.
9. Intact nature
Preserving our nature
We are part of nature. Our prosperity, our quality of life, our future and our survival depend on it.
Protecting nature and ensuring that we can continue to use it responsibly and respectfully in the future is a crucial political task. The
This is not least because the wealth of European habitats - from the almost untouched forests of northern and south-eastern Europe to the countless lakes and diverse cultural landscapes of Central Europe and the Mediterranean - shapes our self-image as Europeans and stands for our continent worldwide.
Thanks to our efforts in Germany and Europe, we have achieved major breakthroughs here in recent months:
The EU Nature Restoration Law (NRL), the agreements reached at the World Conference on Nature in Montreal in 2022 and the UN agreement on the protection of biodiversity on the high seas are historic milestones.
ne. Thanks to these agreements, 30 percent of land and sea areas are to be under nature conservation, 10 percent of the areas even under special protection. The task now is to fully implement the agreed targets and restoration plans, as well as the EU Biodiversity Strategy, and to set binding interim targets and measures. We therefore advocate the creation of a network of well-monitored and effective protected areas on land and at sea, including zero-use zones.
Endangered species and habitats should finally be better protected and damaged ecosystems restored.
Binding rules for the protection of the high seas were also agreed for the first time. Overall, marine resources may now only be used sustainably. With the NRL, we in the European Parliament have set our continent o n course for the urgently needed restoration of European nature. We must now put these plans into practice: Significantly improved nature conservation funding and a reorientation of agricultural and fisheries subsidies towards ecological use are essential for achieving global and European goals. That is why we are calling for a dedicated nature conservation fund in the EU budget. We want to finance the restoration of nature by comprehensively reducing environmentally harmful subsidies. The NRL aims to put all ecosystems on the road to recovery by 2050. We are working towards rapid and complete implementation of the targets and interim targets. When intervening in nature, unjustifiable risks such as the endangerment or even extinction of entire populations or species through genetic engineering methods must be ruled out.
We also want to strengthen the legal framework in environmental law. In order to prosecute environmental crimes, we support the reform of the EU Environmental Criminal Law Directive and the outlawing of the most serious environmental crimes as part of the amendment to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. At the same time, we are working in Germany and the EU to prevent further sealing of agricultural, forest and natural areas.
and consistently - with the aim of achieving a circular economy.
Saving biodiversity
Alongside the climate crisis, the biodiversity crisis - the rapid extinction of species - is the second global crisis affecting our livelihoods and our
Health threatened. Both crises are interdependent. Essential ecosystem services such as pollination, soil fertility, erosion control, water and carbon storage as well as the recreational function are under threat. At the same time, intact nature is our most important ally in the fight against the climate crisis. Nature conservation and climate protection must therefore be considered together. This is why we combine the faster implementation of climate protection measures and the expansion of renewable energies with compliance with the highest ecological protection standards, in particular the European Flora-Fauna-Habitat and Birds Directives.
In order to tackle the climate and biodiversity crisis together, we particularly want to promote natural climate protection. The key elements here are the rewetting of moors and floodplains, the preservation and renaturation of species-rich grassland, near-natural forest conversion, which also protects animals and plants, and effective marine protection.
We are committed to ensuring that there will be no deep-sea mining until there is sufficient scientific knowledge about its effects and serious environmental damage can be ruled out. After all, alongside peatlands and forests, the oceans are among the most important allies in the fight against the climate and biodiversity crisis.
Intact ecosystems can only exist with a vibrant diversity of species. Of the 8 million animal and plant species on our planet, 1 million are threatened with extinction - and thus an infinite wealth. This mass extinction must be stopped as a matter of urgency. An important lever for this is the way in which we cultivate land. We want to stop the loss of species in and around agricultural land and forests by reducing the use of land.
and strengthen nature conservation in the management of land. The preservation of ecosystems and the protection of key species in particular, which are essential for the functioning of biotic communities, must therefore always be given high priority.
become. We want to promote organic farming and near-natural forest management. This protects our soils as well as animals and plants and increases biodiversity. Europe's forests are severely threatened by the consequences of the ongoing climate crisis. We are committed to moving away from monocultural management, significantly reducing the use of pesticides and promoting a near-natural transformation, primarily based on natural regeneration. The valuable old-growth forests
in Europe and make 10% of the EU's forests available for natural development. Illegal deforestation and clear-cutting must be stopped. Instead, reforestation should be specifically promoted. This requires uniform minimum ecological standards for forestry throughout Europe. Natural wood is
a versatile raw material for construction and housing that is too valuable to burn in large power plants. In view of the increasing drought and heat, we also need a European forest fire strategy that reduces the risk of fire through comprehensive preventive measures, near-natural forests, the avoidance of clear-cutting and ecological protection corridors.
We want to reconnect natural habitats to preserve biodiversity. The aim is to create a sustainable green infrastructure for Europe's nature. We want to restore the Natura 2000 network to a good conservation status and link it with corridors that strengthen exchange. This is because intact habitats and genetic diversity promote the resilience of our ecosystems and thus also create added value for society. The corridors should be created in close cooperation with local authorities, farmers, forest owners and foresters. Financial incentives for farmers and landowners should serve the goal of introducing sustainable practices that promote the protection of nature and the preservation of biodiversity. Measures for ecological land use such as
Multifunctional agroforestry systems or the creation of hedges at the edge of fields can be important tools for creating a network of biotopes and new habitats. In this context, we want to restore climate-resilient ecosystems and create alternative protection areas for cold-loving species as well as aid programs for particularly affected species.
We want to advance the Montreal Convention on Biological Diversity through a global implementation mechanism with concrete instruments. The aim is to effectively protect nature on 30 percent of the earth's surface and to restore 30 percent of the area already in use. To this end, the financial resources pledged by the EU must be used quickly, effectively and in a partner- oriented manner. Global biodiversity partnerships should enable comprehensive cooperation for the protection of ecosystems and the restoration of nature
- also together with civil society and municipal actors.
Protect the environment
Alongside the climate and biodiversity crisis, increasing pollution and littering is the third major challenge for the protection of our natural resources. It puts a strain on ecosystems and our health. Environmental pollution from chemicals and plastic waste plays a central role here. We want to ensure that the planetary boundaries are observed here too. It is particularly urgent to focus on substances that cause lasting damage to humans and ecosystems. These include so-called perpetual chemicals such as perfluorinated and polyfluorinated chemicals (PFAS). These have been widely used for decades, for example in the production of semiconductors, medical products, textiles and refrigerants. Wherever they can be easily replaced, and especially in consumer products, we want to phase out their use quickly.
At the same time, we need a differentiated
regulatory framework to strengthen the development of alternatives and accelerate the production ramp-up of important future technologies.
gies such as electrolyzers or electric drives
not to jeopardize the health of our employees. Among other things through proper
We want to continue to ensure the production of important future technologies with the right transitional periods, but at the same time accelerate the replacement of PFAS in these areas through a research offensive and strengthen the research and development of non-toxic production methods. In doing so, we will be guided by the latest scientific findings.
We are also committed to a chemicals strategy that truly implements sustainability requirements, especially for toys, food contact materials and cosmetics. We therefore want to make faster progress with the reform of the European instrument for the safety of chemicals (REACH regulation). We advocate the use of a more comprehensive approach to risk assessment that takes into account different dimensions of the impact of chemicals, faster procedures and better sanctioning options. Effective strategies are also needed,
halve the environmentally harmful effects of chemicals by 2030 in accordance with the Convention on Biological Diversity. In order to better protect important environmental assets, we want to improve the Environmental Liability Directive and implement the polluter pays principle.
In the EU, we advocate ambitious international agreements and cooperation to curb global pollution and environmentally harmful practices. Our aim is to establish an international chemicals law within the framework of the circular economy that takes risks into account in accordance with the precautionary principle and regulates the production of demonstrably harmful substances.
We reject the export of pesticides banned in the EU to other countries. Above all, however, we want to make our chemical industry sustainable and thus fit for the future. That is why we are advocating a new investment program for safe and sustainable chemicals "made in EU" (EU Sustainable Chemistry Act) to promote the market ramp-up of green chemistry. This is part of our program for a climate- friendly industrial policy.
Clean water for all
As the climate crisis progresses, extreme droughts and heavy rainfall events are also increasing significantly in Europe. Germany, for example, has lost 20 percent of its water reserves over the past 20 years. Regionally, this has had catastrophic consequences in some cases. We therefore need a European water strategy that buffers extremes, ensures clean drinking water for all and meets the needs of agriculture and natural habitats. We need landscapes, villages and cities that store water in the ground to get us through the hot and dry summers.
to bring. Clean water for all is a basic right. We are reducing water consumption by promoting climate-adapted land management, protecting wetlands, renaturalizing water bodies, rewetting moors and wanting to allow more and more rivers to flow freely again. We also maintain clean water by reducing the pollutant load in water, for example from mercury or PFAS, and by further strengthening the polluter pays principle for the
discharge of pollutants and wastewater treatment. In addition to the Nature Restoration Act, the objectives of the Water Framework Directive must also be implemented in the current decade in order toachieve good quality rivers and lakes throughout Europe and prevent the overexploitation of groundwater and the resulting threat of damage to wetlands and rivers.
In order to cope with the consequences of the climate crisis, we want to increase funding for the EU's climate adaptation strategy, including a European heat action plan for cross-sectoral measures, from warning levels to infra-structural adaptations. The expansion of European civil protection is necessary in order to cope with the increasing number of extreme events.
We are committed to the conversion to a climate- resilient water infrastructure and nature-friendly flood protection. We are reducing the risk of flooding caused by heavy rainfall events by giving streams and rivers more space again through an unsealing offensive and more rainwater storage. In the
In rural regions, we support the agricultural sector in creating its own water reserves by developing sponge farms in which water is stored as a reserve for times of drought, to replenish groundwater and for other uses such as paludiculture, fish farming and as recreational water. In the cities, green spaces, trees and green roofs help. The conversion to a sponge city also provides cooling, improves air quality and increases biodiversity. In this way, we can better prepare our cities for the consequences of the climate crisis.
We need Europe-wide cooperation, clear limits and rules to ensure that transnational water crises such as the one on the Oder are prevented in the future. We are committed to the goal of restoring 25,000 kilometers of free-flowing rivers in the EU - as envisaged in the EU Biodiversity Strategy. We want to prevent the planned expansion of the Oder for transport purposes in cooperation with the riparian states, as this endangers one of the last natural and free-flowing rivers in Europe. We advocate a binding priority for drinking water over commercial or agricultural use. Water belongs to everyone and is not an object of speculation. We therefore reject the privatization of the water supply.
We will focus on the economical use and storage of water in the landscape and strengthen this through rules and incentives, whether in arable farming through drought-tolerant crops or humus build-up, in vegetable growing through drip irrigation, in forests through near-natural, hardwood-oriented mixed forests or in trade and industry through more economical processes, closed water cycles, limited water withdrawal, cascade use and recycling. We are increasingly focusing on cooperation within Europe and with the countries bordering the Mediterranean.
After all, the experience gained in the arid regions of the south is urgently needed in other parts of Europe.
Protect animals
We also consistently take sides with animals. Society has a special responsibility for animals in human care. We want the EU to protect all animals through consistent and ambitious legislation and the enforcement of existing regulations. Because Europeans want animal welfare: six of the ten successful citizens' initiatives in the EU are committed to this.
We are following this wish and are campaigning for animal welfare as an EU common goal, explicit political responsibility for animal welfare in the EU Commission and EU funding for animal welfare.
We call for the implementation of the "Fur Free Europe" initiative to ban fur farming and the trade in farmed fur products on the European market.
Building on this, we are committed to the consistent implementation of the EU action plan to combat illegal species trade. International species protection agreements, in particular CITES and all its annexes, must be consistently implemented in the EU. We want to effectively prevent the commercial wildlife trade. Targeted research and species protection programs by scientific institutions and experts on non- commercial wildlife trade should be implemented.
The import and trade of illegally exported specimens should be made punishable. The import and trade of specimens illegally exported from their country of origin should be made a punishable offense. We are in favor of a ban on the import of hunting trophies from animal species protected by the Washington Convention and the EU Endangered Species Regulation, as already called for by the EU Parliament. We want to relieve the burden on animal shelters by, among other things, labeling and registering dogs and cats as well as a positive list for the trade and keeping of exotic animals. We advocate high animal welfare standards in trade agreements.
We want to put an end to the import of animal products for which conditions have not been verified in accordance with EU animal welfare standards. We want to make animal welfare a goal of sustainable development.
The EU and member states should draw up concrete plans for phasing out animal testing that consistently end experiments on animals for cosmetics and wherever possible for chemical testing and medical products. The number of animal experiments for drug development and basic research should be reduced. Animal-free education and training initiatives should be promoted. We want to strengthen and accelerate the development, recognition and broad application of animal-free methods in practice.
Once recognized, they should be immediately included in test guidelines and replace animal testing. Whereitis not yet possible to completely dispense with animal testing, they must be implemented as gently as possible for the animals. The standards applicable in the EU should also apply to imports from other parts of the world.
10. A strong agriculture
Reorganizing the common agricultural policy
Farmers provide us in Europe with a variety of valuable foods. At the same time, agriculture shapes our cultural landscapes, the fields, meadows and vineyards that characterize Europe. We want to strengthen an agriculture that works in harmony with nature, in the service of all people, producers and consumers alike.
We are therefore striving for a fundamental reform of EU agricultural policy that consistently rewards services for the common good - in particular measures for the climate, water, soil, biodiversity, health and animal welfare - rather than land ownership. This r e q u i r e s clear regulations and incentives for the reduction of pesticide use, fertilization and livestock numbers as well as for crop rotation, the cultivation of protein crops and extensive grassland farming. business.	The	funding	should	be	low	in bureaucracy, enable planning security, have a sustainable impact and directly benefit those working on the ground.
farmers - especially smaller farms. A good approach is to use level and points systems that clearly focus on
The aim is to promote the common good, ecological measures and regenerative systems such as agroforestry systems, promote multi- annual measures and view farms as a system. Animal welfare promotion should be made mandatory by the Member States in their strategic plans. We want to create additional incentives for extensive grazing. Further developing organic farming should become the guiding principle of European agricultural policy. We call for a clear alignment with the objectives of the Farm to Fork Strategy and the NRL.
When promoting rural areas, we want to focus not only on the necessary infrastructure for a good life and social cohesion, but also on the (re)development of decentralized artisanal food processing, regional value chains, the diversification of agricultural businesses and the strengthening of producer groups. There is also new potential for more value creation in the energy sector - for example through
Agri-photovoltaics or by using agricultural machinery as electricity storage in the energy transition.
In view of the major ecological challenges in agriculture, we are also dependent on further innovation. Digitalization can help tomake agriculture more sustainable. For example, through GPS-controlled hoeing devices or in fertilization. This can save on fertilizers and pesticides. We want to protect the rights of farmers when it comes to the data they collect and access to the software of their machines ("right to repair").
We can thus shape EU agricultural policy in such a way that it offers prospects to all women and men working in agriculture, especially career changers and start-ups, because every farm counts. By creatingregional value chains from farm to fork - also digitally through product passports
and supply chain monitoring - and strengthen the food trade, we improve their economic framework conditions. In doing so, we are also promoting local food distribution channels.
Farmers must be strengthened vis-à-vis processors and retailers in the value chain. Retailers in particular can and must make a greater contribution to stabilizing revenues for producers and prices for consumers.
We are therefore campaigning for Europe-wide regulations to put an end to price dumping in the food sector.
Good food for everyone
Food is a central part of our culture and individual identity. Nutrition is crucial to our health and our quality of life. We want to make good nutrition possible for everyone. This is also a contribution to strengthening regional economic areas, as the production and processing of food locally creates well-being and regional identity.
Everyone should be able to decide for themselves what goes on their plate. The EU can protect consumers' freedom of choice by providing reliable information about the origin and content of food.
We are therefore advocating Europe-wide mandatory labels to support sustainable, regional and plant-based nutrition. We want to introduce mandatory labeling for animal husbandry in the European single market. On the other hand, misleading practices with private labels that advertise supposedly climate-neutral products, for example, should be put a stop to under the EU Green Claims Regulation.
We are setting the course for sustainability with an EU-wide framework for sustainable food systems. For example, we want to create incentives for better nutrition in communal catering, from daycare centers to hospitals, through changes to public procurement law. We want to create an environment in which it is easy to eat healthily and sustainably - along the lines of the planetary health approach.
- to eat. We want food to be free from chemical residues such as pesticides and hormones. By continuously increasing the proportion of organic food from regional production in communal catering, we are expanding reliable sales markets for organic farming. In this way, we are creating sustainable and healthy nutrition for everyone, especially children.
We want to increase the range of plant-based products, make them more easily accessible and change the EU's food-related funding programs to make them climate-friendly. This is also important for achieving climate and species protection goals. We are therefore improving the framework conditions for plant-based foods by promoting research and market launches, among other things. In order to better counter future crises, the EU needs a protein strategy with efficient approval procedures that increase the self-sufficiency rate for vegetables, nuts and plant-based and alternative proteins. We support the research and development of modern fermentation processes and cell cultivation to a new extent for the development of sustainable food and for Europe as a location for business and innovation.
We are in favor of agriculture that conserves resources and is environmentally friendly and is based on the principles of organic farming with its principles of animal welfare, freedom from genetic engineering and freedom from synthetic pesticides.
As with any technology, the political compass for dealing with both old and new genetic engineering methods must guarantee the freedom of research on the one hand and exclude risks to humans and the environment during application on the other. New genetic engineering methods in agriculture should also be researched with regard to their opportunities, risks and consequences. For sustainable and transparent agriculture
It is essential that companies that want to operate GMO-free can do so safely. A strict approval procedure and the precautionary principle enshrined in European law must be upheld. To this end, risk assessments on a comprehensive
We need a scientific basis and regulation that excludes uncontrollable spread and protects GMO- free production and consumers' freedom of choice through mandatory labeling. We reject patents on plants and animals. This will secure the future of small and medium-sized farms and breeding operations in particular.
Food belongs on the plate and not in the tank or even in the bin. We therefore advocate legally binding measures to halve food waste by 2030, including the reassessment of sorting characteristics and supermarket standards as well as the introduction of consumption dates instead of best-before dates to provide more binding information on the safe consumption of food.
Shaping agriculture ecologically
Europe's agriculture must become more sustainable in order to secure the food supply of the future. In times of climate crisis, droughts, fires, storms and heavy rainfall, resilient cultivation systems are becoming the focus of all agricultural policy measures. This includes improving soil fertility and health, binding more CO2 than we emit, cultivating a greater diversity of crops and varieties in the fields and limiting the use of pesticides and synthetic chemical fertilizers as much as possible. We are guided by the criteria of regionality, circular economy and agroecology as well as the guiding principle of organic farming.
Our goal is to achieve a 25% share of organic
f a r m i n g by 2030 and to increase this share by 2035.
and beyond. In Germany, organic farms generate a higher income per person than conventional farms. This shows that it is already financially worthwhile to invest in regional and sustainable farming methods. We want to strengthen the framework conditions for this.
This also includes the EU's research and funding policy. It needs at least 30 percent of the funds earmarked for agricultural research.
and rural development, for the further development and promotion of the greening of agriculture and innovative concepts for the organic value chain, as well as for organic breeding research. We want to improve the EU organic label and its application - for example in animal husbandry. Organic farms should no longer have to provide double evidence, but should be recognized as organic due to their environmental performance.
"green by definition" apply.
For sustainable and transparent agriculture, it is essential that farms that want to operate GMO- free can do so safely. The EU should guarantee that everyone knows what they are eating and where it was produced. Transparency and freedom of choice must be ensured, especially in the case of genetically modified feed and food. We reject patents on plants, regardless of whether they originate from conventional breeding or genetic engineering.
The heavy use of pesticides pollutes our natural environment in many ways. However, the European plans adopted to date to reduce pollutants have not yet been sufficiently implemented.
We want to change this and ensure that the EU's targets and approval procedures are revised on a scientific basis. We want to oblige the member states to take further effective measures, such as a pesticide levy. Despite the setback in the European Commission's decision to extend the approval of glyphosate, we are continuing to fight for a ban on glyphosate in the EU as quickly as possible.
We are closing legal loopholes that currently allow the use of fertility-damaging chemicals in fertilizers or microplastics in pesticides, for example. In the approval process for pesticides, the relevant authorities must become more independent of the applicant manufacturers and their claims.
Manufacturers must no longer be able to choose in which Member State the authorities examine their applications. In addition, risk assessments must be developed and taken into account for other endangered animal groups. To save time and capacity
To ensure that we gain a competitive edge, we are accelerating the approval process for substances for which it is clear at an early stage that they cannot be approved due to exclusion criteria. We are also committed t o t h e consistent implementation of the polluter pays principle so that companies that use pesticides in are liable for any damage caused, for example to groundwater or organic farming.
Securing food with sustainability
Agriculture is suffering particularly from the climate crisis with long droughts and sudden heavy rainfall. If we put an end to over- fertilization, reduce the use of fossil fertilizers and turn soils back into CO2 sinks, agriculture is a key part of natural climate protection. That is why we are committed to rewetting peatlands, building up humus in arable soils and building up wood mass in agroforestry systems - with stable income prospects for farmers. In this way, agriculture can make the necessary contribution to climate protection and climate adaptation.
The rewetting of peatlands can only be achieved together with farmers. It is important to us that value creation is maintained in the peatland regions. That is why we support farmers in the cultivation of rewetted peatlands (paludiculture) and also promote the production of raw materials for climate-friendly building and insulation materials as well as for the soil industry and the establishment of new value chains in rural areas. We want to promote the use of rewetted peatlands as part of the CAP and reduce climate- damaging subsidies. Peatlands are real climate protectors, as significantly more carbon is stored here than in arable soil.
Pasture farming with suckler cow husbandry is one of the most animal-friendly forms of husbandry and contributes to species conservation. This is another reason why we want to give it more support.
Agroforestry systems, in which areas that have been farmed or grazed are planted with trees and shrubs.
The combination of shrubbery and organic farming is feasible with both organic and conventional agriculture. They are important for climate protection, soil fertility, the water balance and biodiversity, and thus for the development of resilient ecosystems. The diversification of business sectors creates greater income security for farmers. To ensure that the many positive effects can be realized, we want to remove barriers, promote research into them and develop their broader application in practice.
The European seas and their fish stocks are in a poor state. We will therefore better protect the marine environment in order to give fish stocks and our fishermen a sustainable perspective. That is why we support the Commission's action plan for the conservation of fisheries resources and the protection of marine ecosystems and are committed to faster and full implementation of the Marine Strategy Framework Directive. The planetary boundaries must also be respected in the use of the oceans. We promote alternatives to gillnet and trawl fishing and take action against environmentally harmful fishing methods and excessive inputs of fertilizers and pollutants.
Keeping animals well
We want to shape animal husbandry in such a way that it respects the needs of animals as living beings and can supply sustainably produced, valuable food. The aim is to achieve land-based animal husbandry as quickly as possible. We support farms in this process. We see natural grazing as an integral part of our diverse landscapes. Industrial livestock farming, on the other hand, causes great animal suffering and endangers essential livelihoods and human health: Zoonotic pathogens, multi-resistant germs, drinking water pollution, habitat destruction, loss of species, food waste in animal fattening and excessive greenhouse gas emissions - when we harm animals, we ultimately harm ourselves.
In future, the number of animals we keep in European agriculture must be based on the Paris Climate Protection Agreement. We therefore want to keep fewer animals, significantly improve their husbandry conditions and focus breeding more on animal health. We are therefore committed to the establishment, improvement and better control of uniform Europe-wide animal welfare standards for breeding, husbandry, transport, killing and trade. This includes the end of cage and crate farming as well as the lack of fire safety precautions.
Accordingly, the funding framework is to be geared towards land-based animal husbandry and special support is to be given to pasture and grassland- based husbandry. The aim is to give animals considerably more space and year-round access to the outside and to ensure that they no longer have to stand on fully slatted floors. We need a significant reduction in live animal transports, a limit on long-distance transports to a maximum of eight hours and an end to animal transports to third countries outside the Schengen area. This also strengthens local processing. When it comes to slaughter, we demand better controls and advocate better, mandatory stunning methods, including for fish, crabs, lobsters and squid. We also want to make it possible to slaughter at the farm of origin if a certificate of competence is available and a veterinarian is present. The killing of chicks should be banned throughout the EU.
Human and animal health is under massive threat from the excessive use of antibiotics in livestock farming. Currently, more antibiotics are administered to healthy animals than to sick people. We want to drastically reduce the use of antibiotics in order to prevent the development of multi-resistant germs, which pose one of the greatest threats to human health. This requires a switch to better forms of husbandry, an increase in animal health, the restriction of group treatment and priority treatment of sick individual animals.
Reserve antibiotics should be reserved for human medicine. In animal breeding, we want to put an end to artificial stimulation using hormones from horse blood.
 What protects justice 
Inflation with the rising cost of living, the pandemic, war and increasing weather extremes have presented many people across Europe with major challenges. Many have had to accept painful cuts due to the price increases. Many self- employed people and small businesses have lost their livelihoods. And skyrocketing living costs are causing acute, sometimes even existential hardship far into the middle of society.
At the same time, the crisis management of recent years has shown what is possible whenwe stand together - in Germany and Europe.
In these times of crisis, people are longing for stability and cohesion. Europe offers the answer. European unification has raised the standard of living of millions of people and brought more social security. We are convinced that, especially in times of crisis, people in Europe must be able to rely on a strong welfare state that provides effective protection against poverty and social exclusion.
The EU can offer a protective space that secures social rights across borders and for the entire breadth of society. At the same time, the EU can provide the economic framework conditions that enable fair prosperity. A prosperity that must reach those who create it - a prosperity for the many. By building the infrastructure for a climate-neutral economy across Europe, we generate added value and maintain and create good jobs for millions of people: Economic and social infrastructure go hand in hand and are interdependent.
The strong and fair Europe that we want to shape is essentially aimed at protecting each and every individual andrespecting the achievements of all. It protects the rights of workers against exploitation. It respects the dignity of
pensioners and the unemployed. It reduces inequality. It secures citizens' entitlement to effective medication and access to high-quality and inclusive healthcare.
