In these challenging times, the EU must actively seek all opportunities for international cooperation and use all channels of cooperation in order to preserve peace, realize human rights, strengthen democratic forces and promote the rule of law.
to prevent conflicts and promote prosperity. In addition to strengthening the relationship with In addition to its allies in the transatlantic and trans-Pacific region, the EU must actively seek partnerships with countries of the Global South.
We want to promote global justice in line with the Sustainable Development Goals. In doing so, we pay attention to the coherence of our political action across all policy areas such as economic and trade policy.
Often enough, however, women in particular are not at the table during negotiations. This makes it more difficult to develop fair and viable solutions. Societies are demonstrably more peaceful and prosperous when all people can participate in political, social and economic life. Peace and security are more sustainable when women are involved.
That is why we
We are actively committed to ensuring that women in particular are represented comprehensively and equally in foreign policy.
The most existential challenge facing humanity, the climate and environmental crisis, can only be tackled globally. Europe and the other industrialized countries have a special historical and dual responsibility due to their decades of emissions: in their own interest, they must quickly become climate-neutral themselves and at the same time support poorer countries in partnership on their path to climate-neutral and climate- adapted prosperity. This is why we are placing climate diplomacy at the center of our plan for a European foreign policy and thus paving the way for resilient partnerships - partnerships that create win-win situations and benefit both the people in our partner countries and help to secure our supply of renewable energy and raw materials. A strong European external climate policy also means that the EU must play a pioneering role in the implementation of the Paris Climate Agreement and, together with the private sector, make a decisive contribution to the necessary investments for climate-friendly development worldwide. In the same way, Europe must tackle the global biodiversity crisis: pursue ambitious goals itself, finance
and support the countries of the Global South in implementing their goals.
If the worst comes to the worst, we must be able to defend our peace in the alliance militarily. The use of military force remains the last resort for us. For the EU's ability to defend itself, overall national and societal resilience is also indispensable. To this end, it is essential to be able to withstand shocks and disruptions in the sense of a comprehensive concept of security. This includes increasing cyber security and the fight against disinformation, strengthening infrastructures as well as state and economic supply structures and strengthening civil protection. This can
We can do this better, more efficiently and more effectively if we coordinate our security policy at European level and exchange information faster and better. We want a comprehensive approach to European foreign policy that focuses on human security, focuses on the prevention and civilian management of crises and conflicts and actively seeks opportunities for de-escalation.
Those who contribute to maintaining peace prevent the need to create peace - this is how Europe protects itself. The commitment to a culture of non-violence, military restraint and a world without war is an important cross-cutting task that encompasses far more than the area of foreign policy. We think security in terms of each individual person, whose dignity and freedom are at the heart of our policy. This understanding of a precautionary and values-based security policy is part of the European promise.
Its weight, in turn, is most evident where there is invitation and hope. The aspirations of many Ukrainians to assert their freedom and become part of the European family may have been met with brutal armed force by Vladimir Putin. But it lives on and proves the power of the European project beyond its own borders. The idea of a common European home was linked to the wish that people from different nations could live together peacefully under one roof.
It is precisely this wish that Russia has clearly rejected with its war of aggression against Ukraine in violation of international law and against Ukraine's right to self-determination. Nevertheless, we are sticking to this wish. We are committedto the start of Ukraine's accession process - and at the same time see it as recognition of the immeasurable work that the country does every day for the security of us all and for European values.
The Europe we want to shape does exactly that. It protects and defends its own values. It asserts itself - and at the same time confidently reaches out to others. We want to work on this Europe.
This is the Europe we want to be.
1. A European foreign policy
Acting together on foreign policy
We need a strong and sovereign EU that can act as a global political player. So far, however, EU foreign policy still requires the approval of all 27 member states. We advocate an expansion of majority decisions in the Council that takes into account the interests of both the larger and smaller member states. In order to achieve this, we want to use the existing possibilities within the European treaties and at the same time advocate treaty amendments.
Our values and interests need a common EU voice
- we want to turn the existing role of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy into that of a European Foreign Minister. We also want to strengthen the European External Action Service in terms of personnel and institutions. In order to implement a common European foreign policy, we need a genuine European diplomatic service. That is why we want to firmly establish the European Diplomatic Academy in order to develop competencies in the area of EU foreign policy among
diplomats from the member states. We want to increasingly bundle consular services of the member states, such as visa issues, legal assistance or applications, in the European embassies.
At the same time, there is a need for better coordination of the foreign policies of the EU Member States and closer coordination between the European Commission and the European External Action Service. For better democratic control, we advocate a stronger role for the European Parliament in the Common Foreign and Security Policy.
We want to strengthen foreign cultural, education and science policy as well as science diplomacy, which can build cultural bridges in the face of major global challenges, have a positive impact on civil society, advance research and promote peace.
Protecting the climate globally and fairly
The climate crisis is the central global challenge of our time. It threatens livelihoods in many parts of the world and is driving millions of people to flee their homes. It is exacerbating conflicts over increasingly scarce resources such as food, water and raw materials. Its consequences are already having a noticeable negative impact on people's habitats and future opportunities.
No state can stop the climate crisis alone. Our goal is a strong European foreign climate policy that is in line with the Paris Climate Agreement and the sustainable development goals. We stand for an EU that establishes global climate partnerships to mitigate climate change.
emissions, supporting partner countries in the socially just and climate-neutral development and restructuring of their economic systems, infrastructure and energy supply as well as in adapting to the unavoidable consequences of the climate crisis. As one of the largest emitters of greenhouse gases in the world, the EU must, in accordance with the agreement in the Paris Climate Agreement, advocate that USD 100 billion per year from public and private sources for climate change mitigation and adaptation be mobilized quickly, in a targeted and targeted
manner.
in line with the UN's sustainability goals in countries of the Global South. Just Energy Transition Partnerships, which the German government has already concluded with several countries together with other international partners, are a model for this. They make offers for a comprehensive and socially just energy transition and modernization. We are also supporting the international process to design a loss-and-da- mage fund to provide appropriate financial support to communities affected by the effects of the climate crisis.
Our goal is to drive forward socio-ecological modernization in all areas. We are therefore committed to phasing out fossil fuels, a binding global target for the expansion of renewable energies and ambitious climate financing. This requires
additional funds to the Official Development Assistance (ODA) quota, taking into account the principle of "common but differentiated responsibilities" of the Paris Climate Agreement. International financial institutions such as the World Bank, the regional development banks, the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) must play an even greater role in modernizing the economies of our partner countries in a spirit of partnership.
We want to strengthen and expand the Team Europe approach - closer cooperation between the Commission, member states and EU financial institutions - in order to forge international alliances. The climate club proposed by the G7 can play a central role in supporting international structures within the framework of the Paris Agreement and promoting ambitious goals for climate protection, climate adaptation and sustainable growth. We would like to take the Federal Government's planned strategy for foreign climate policy as a basis for further development at European level.
Climate neutrality and the management of climate impacts must be incorporated into our international political action across all departments.
The climate crisis has long been a reality in many places. Despite all our efforts, this c r i s i s will force people to leave their homes.
Historically, the western industrialized countries are the main producers of climate-damaging greenhouse gases and therefore bear a special responsibility. The EU should therefore support the affected countries technically and, if necessary, financially with the necessary adaptation measures. In addition, Europe should lead the way together with other industrialized countries and support processes in which international regulation is discussed with affected states within the framework of international law to deal with climate-induced migration, flight and displacement as well as access to international protection.
Like the climate crisis, the global loss of species and biodiversity poses an enormous threat. That is why we want to accelerate the implementation of the Kunming-Montreal Convention on Biological Diversity
in Europe and worldwide. We are increasing European engagement with the countries most affected by biodiversity loss and supporting the protection of land while respecting the rights of indigenous peoples. Our goal is to put Europe's and the world's biodiversity on the road to recovery.
Making Global Gateway a success
In many parts of the world, there is a huge need for investment in order to achieve growth and prosperity with good mobility and digital participation. This must happen under the conditions of climate neutrality, climate adaptation and social justice. So far, the Chinese "New Silk Road" program, which creates financial dependencies and systematically uses them as political leverage, has been the main response to the need for investment. As an alternative to this, we want to turn the European Global Gateway Strategy into a successful geostrategic project that supports partner countries in sustainably improving their living and economic conditions. In this way, we are making a strong European contribution to the G7 infrastructure partnership and, by complying with high human rights, social and environmental standards, we are helping to strengthen the global economy.
international standards of the G20 for infrastructure planning.
Through targeted investments in socio-ecological modernization in our partner countries, we want to create climate-friendly prosperity, strengthen the protection of human rights, diversify supply chains and promote accessible digital infrastructures and the production of green energy in our neighbourhood. In doing so, we want to reduce dependencies by strengthening sustainable value creation in partner countries and combining this with investments in social infrastructure that are in line with local development agendas.
However, Global Gateway can only be a success if the EU provides the program with substantial funds that, in conjunction with the leveraged private capital, can provide the necessary resources. In order to improve the visibility and connectivity of the program globally and within the EU, we also want to appoint aspecial envoy for it.
The EU must set clear strategic priorities for Global Gateway and develop all projects on the basis of equal cooperation with the partner countries and with the involvement of local civil society. For us, the benchmarks here are human rights, the UN's 2030 Agenda and compliance with the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement and the Kunming- Montreal Biodiversity Agreement. For example, mobility infrastructure means prioritizing investment in climate-friendly modes of transport such as rail, and energy generated must always be made available to the producing countries on site first. In addition, the EU Commission must ensure policy coherence for sustainable development and greater transparency in the selection of structural policy projects and in their implementation and evaluation. In order to make Global Gateway a success, development policy expertise must be used during implementation and the principles of development policy effectiveness must be implemented.
Strengthening international organizations
The UN and its organizations remain the foundation of multilateralism. In the case of the Russian war of aggression against Ukraine, the international community in the
The UN General Assembly proved that it is very capable of acting when an overwhelming majority repeatedly and clearly condemned this brutal war of aggression. However, it is clear that the situation in the Security Council makes it difficult for the UN to take peacekeeping measures.
Regional organizations such as the EU therefore have a key role to play in crisis management, including with their own missions. The EU and its member states make more than half of all contributions to multilateral organizations such as the UN system. In the upcoming reform discussions, we want to make the UN and its organizations fit for the future through a coordinated EU approach. This includes reforming the Security Council, in which we want to ensure fairer representation of the world's regions. In addition, we aim to abolish the right of veto and support mechanisms such as the option adopted in UN General Assembly Resolution 377 "Uniting for Peace" to deal with the matter in the event of a persistent blockade and to adopt recommendations - i.e. diplomatic measures, sanctions or military measures in accordance with Chapter VII of the UN Charter - by a qualified majority.
The G7 and G20 are also proving to be additional forums for tackling global challenges, in addition to our involvement in the UN. We therefore support the G7's efforts to work more closely with partner countries around the world and, in particular, with the UN.
in the Global South, and expressly support the permanent membership of the African Union as part of the G20.
In order to be able to respond to the global and development challenges of our time, the EU must advocate comprehensive renewal, democratization
- including greater participation of actors from the Global South - and sufficient funding.
capacity of the international financial institutions. The World Bank has already begun this reform process with its "Evolution Roadmap" and must now continue it with determination. It is crucial that goals such as reducing inequality and protecting planetary boundaries are systematically taken into account and operationalized through indicators. UN specialized agencies such as the refugee agency UNHCR or the health organization WHO provide vital support to help people in need. The EU must therefore continue to support and strengthen these organizations. Corresponding funds should be provided as flexibly as possible.
We also advocate an active, fair personnel policy for the EU when filling positions in international organizations such as the International Standardiza- tion Organization (ISO) or the World Bank Group.
Defending human rights worldwide
Opposition activists are being persecuted in many places around the world, the scope of action of civil society and independent media is being restricted and protests are being crushed. Regardless of this, Wherever people live, they have the right to demand and receive help to protect and promote their basic human rights. We stand up for democracy and human rights and strengthen independent media, non-violent pro-democracy movements, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and human rights defenders in both the analogue and digital space.
We want to expand funding opportunities and financially stabilize the corresponding protection instruments and institutions, such as special rapporteurs and the European Democracy Fund, and make them more accessible and sustainable. This should also create spaces for exchange and networking between civil society organizations, pro-democratic
movements, independent media and individual activists should be created and strengthened.
The protection and promotion of democracy will be more effective if we pool our efforts and coordinate them at European level.
The protection of human rights is first and foremost the responsibility of the state.
Cooperation with democracies worldwide has a special role to play in promoting freedom and self- determination. We want to actively support and strengthen states that have embarked on the path to democracy in this process. In line with the EU's Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime, we support the imposition of targeted sanctions against state and non-state actors responsible for or involved in serious human rights violations and abuses. The EU and its member states must take decisive action against violations of sanctions and also hold international partners to account. In addition, we want to examine the extent to which abandoned assets can be used to make reparations to victims in a legally secure manner.
Human rights defenders risk a lot. They need our protection, our solidarity and our active support. We want to consistently implement the EU guidelines for the protection of human rights defenders. A gender-specific perspective is important here, as women and marginalized groups, such as defenders of indigenous rights, are exposed to a higher risk of violence. We want to offer vulnerable human rights defenders and their families protection in the EU with faster and simplified visa issuance. We are committed to ensuring that the EU's diplomatic missions abroad stand up for human rights defenders. This includes, for example, monitoring the court proceedings of political prisoners, creating international visibility, providing immediate assistance and holding regular exchanges/meetings. This also applies to those who defend the right to conscientious objection.
As part of our support for human rights defenders,
we are committed to providing EU missions abroad with more training in conflict-sensitive democracy promotion and human rights protection.
Following the example of the Canadian resettlement program, we advocate a European protection program for human rights defenders.
This enables them to receive protection quickly and unbureaucratically and to continue their work in a safe environment. Attacks on human rights defenders are increasingly taking place in the digital space. In order to protect them, we support secure, encrypted communication options and the right to use the internet anonymously and are campaigning against the further fragmentation of the internet and internet shutdowns.
Investigative journalists and whistleblowers like Julian Assange also need special protection. They bring crimes and societal abuses to light. Their protection is an essential part of press freedom, which must be urgently defended both internally and externally.
Implementing foreign and development policy in a feminist way
Equality makes societies more peaceful, just, sustainable, resilient and economically successful. It is an integral part of universal human rights.
Structural injustices mean that certain groups, especially women and marginalized groups, are particularly affected by violence, poverty and war, but also by the consequences of the climate crisis. At the same time, there are often only a few of them at the table when it comes to finding solutions to these crises. With UN Resolution 1325 and its follow-up resolutions, the protection of women and girls in war zones and their participation in conflict prevention and resolution is already anchored internationally. We want to go further. We are committed to a feminist foreign and development policy that strengthens the rights, resources and representation of women, girls and marginalized groups in all areas worldwide.
Based on human rights, it has the overcoming
of all forms of discrimination. In this context, particular attention is paid to multiple forms of discrimination. Building on the Federal Government's guidelines, we want to anchor feminist foreign and development policy as a guiding principle of the EU's external relations and international cooperation.
We are committed to equal representation of women in the EU's foreign policy institutions and to significantly increasing the proportion of women at all levels of Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP) missions - especially at management level. The perspectives of women and girls should be included in all EU international negotiations. We want to strengthen the capacities for gender and diversity in EU diplomacy and significantly increase the participation of women and marginalized groups in relevant delegations.
We call for the EU to become a global pioneer in the fight against sexualized and gender-based violence in its external relations. Because misogyny, queer and trans hostility is a security threat for many people. Following the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention, we are calling for its consistent implementation by the EU member states. We also call for the global implementation of the Yogyakarta Principles against discrimination and for the protection of the human rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans*, inter* and queer people (LGBTIQ*).
We want the EU to align its development policy with the principles of feminist development cooperation in a partner-oriented and sustainable way, and to make existing practices more sustainable.
critically evaluated. It must achieve its self- imposed goal of ensuring that 85% of EU development programs also contribute to gender equality by 2025. To this end, the EU should structurally provide more funds to promote women and marginalized groups, for example through cooperation with feminist civil society actors or support in the areas of basic education and vocational training, entrepreneurship and sexual and reproductive health. In accordance with the EU Action Plan for Gender Equality, we want to systematically anchor gender- transformative and intersectional approaches in our development policy activities.
2. 
A European security and defense policy
Defending Europe together
Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine, which violates international law, has clearly shown us that we must be able to effectively deter potential aggressors from attacking us and defend our way of life militarily in an extreme emergency. The future of alliance defense and collective response capability lies in the European and transatlantic integration and interoperability of our armed forces.
The closer we work together in the EU on security and defense policy, the better, more cost- efficiently and more effectively we can ensure Europe's defense capability, especially as part of the transatlantic alliance (NATO). The EU's strategic compass and its integration into NATO's strategic concept are key to this. We stand by our alliance commitments within the framework of the EU and NATO and the capabilities and capacities required for this. Based on our historical responsibility and the lessons learned from the Russian war of aggression, we are committed to protecting the Baltic states, including through military cooperation as part of a long-term deployment of Bundeswehr units in the Baltic states.
We therefore want to continue working on a common European security and defense union with strong parliamentary participation and control. We want to expand increased cooperation between the armed forces, for example within permanent EU units or transnational units such as the German-Dutch Corps. This requires common framework standards and working conditions for soldiers as well as the creation of the basis for a uniform EU duty of care towards deployed forces and civilian personnel. We want the common
EU command structure and European military cooperation initiatives, for example in the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO).
We are strengthening civilian and military missions within the framework of the CSDP and their planning staff in terms of funding and personnel.
These missions must always be embedded in an overall political concept, be subject to continuous risk analysis, take into account the actual needs on the ground and be oriented towards the guiding principle of human security. For civilian CSDP missions, we must combine long-term financial frameworks with a more flexible concept so that they can be deployed more quickly and adapt appropriately to changing circumstances. Joint EU missions abroad should be accompanied, monitored and evaluated more closely by the European Parliament. We are consolidating support for Ukraine within the framework of the European Peace Facility (EPF) and strengthening its unit for risk analysis and arms control. The structures of the EPF should be adapted to improve the availability of funds, the predictability of expenditure and parliamentary control in the European Parliament and the member states. We also see the establishment of a European air defense system as a necessary component of a common European security architecture.
In the defense sector, the uncoordinated procurement of EU member states leads to a complex system diversity, a lack of economies of scale and thus the ineffective use of taxpayers' money. Our goal is a joint and thus more cost- effective European development and procurement of armaments. This requires the effective implementation of the annual capability analysis in close coordination and agreement with the NATO planning process on the basis of the same standards and norms, financial incentives for and trust between the member states, but also the political will to set aside industrial policy interests in favor of greater common security. This will enable us to consolidate the European defense sector. The European Defense
Agency (EDA) has not yet achieved this to a sufficient extent. We share the objectives of existing financial instruments such as the European Defense Fund (EDF) or joint procurement (EDIRPA). However, these instruments are inadequate, legally fragile and parliamentary control is severely limited.
That is why we want to create a legally secure extra-budgetary financial instrument in the medium term to replace the existing individual programs and cover the entire military capability cycle - from industrial research and development to procurement, maintenance and training. The expenditure of this pot
must be subject to strict and coordinated control by the European Parliament and the national parliaments.
European regulation of arms exports
The joint development, procurement and use of European weapons systems creates greater security and efficiency. And thus also contributes to a common value-based security and defense policy. These joint EU projects require uniform and restrictive European export regulations. To this end, we want to adopt an arms export control regulation based on the EU's common position, which creates transparency and clarity and is based on European values and a common assessment of the security situation. There must be clear
decision-making mechanisms and sanctions that are enforceable before the European Court of Justice (ECJ). Prior risk analyses as well as binding and physical end-use controls must be prescribed and consistently implemented. European weapons must no longer be allowed to end up in the hands of regimes that systematically violate human rights or use them for crimes of aggression. We advocate a ban on the export of surveillance technologies to repressive regimes and a comprehensive ban on the export of small arms to third countries.
Disarmament, arms control and the non- proliferation of weapons are and will remain essential pillars of any peace policy. They mean greater global security for all. The goal of our efforts remains a peaceful world free of nuclear weapons. Even in uncertain times, we therefore want to strengthen arms control, promote confidence-building measures and advance bilateral and multilateral disarmament initiatives. The EU should therefore work to strengthen the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) as a central pillar of nuclear arms control. In addition, the EU should encourage its member states to constructively support the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons, to participate as observers in the Conference of the States Parties and to commit to the Global Zero vision. These are the first steps on the way to successive joint accession and a world free of nuclear weapons. We support efforts under international law to regulate lethal autonomous weapons systems. There must be no use of weapons systems that make the human factor technically dispensable in life and death decisions. We condemn any use of armed drones in violation of international law, even if it is carried out by our allies. We reject the use of cluster bombs, including in Ukraine. We also want to work with the EU worldwide to dissuade non-parties from using cluster munitions in accordance with the Oslo Convention.
Preventing crises
We are committed to a forward-looking foreign and security policy that recognizes conflicts at an early stage and counters them. Cooperation between policy areas and coherence are key to this.
of approaches is important. We want to make comprehensive use of EU funds for civilian peacebuilding actors.
increase funding. The EU must provide greater support for local civil society concepts and actors in peacebuilding, make funding guidelines more flexible in this context and make it easier to plan the allocation of funds over the long term. We want to strengthen EU funds and approaches for stabilization measures in order to be flexible in crises,
to act in a targeted and effective manner. We want to systematically strengthen the peacekeeping and conflict resolution capabilities of the UN and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) as well as regional organizations such as the African Union. We want to strengthen research into the causes of current conflicts, their progression and their peaceful resolution and promote international networking in peace and conflict research.
The EU must use and expand its strength worldwide as a mediator in conflicts and as an alliance for peace through cooperation. We want to strengthen civilian CSDP missions as an instrument of EU foreign policy with more financial resources and personnel and systematically develop them further, for example to support the police or the judiciary in fragile states. With institutions that are based on the rule of law and close to the people, they can build trust and prevent conflicts. We are opposed to focusing civilian CSDP missions on migration management. Effective civilian crisis prevention, stabilization, humanitarian aid and peacekeeping measures require in-depth context analyses, better coordination and effective evaluations. We want to expand the European Center of Excellence for Civilian Crisis Management in order to better network member states in their civilian crisis prevention and crisis management measures.
Through a policy of prevention, we are also making an important contribution to combating the causes of displacement. Established local structures and functioning state institutions that protect human rights and provide services of general interest
reduce the likelihood of conflicts that cause human suffering and force people to leave their homes.
With humanitarian aid, we support people worldwide who are in humanitarian emergencies. We want to strengthen European and international organizations in this area. This includes, in particular, better funding as well as more efficient and flexible structures and allocation guidelines for European organizations.
humanitarian aid organization ECHO. We also want to improve the coordination of national European aid. Finally, we want to oblige European emergency aid organizations to pay more attention to gender-specific needs and the needs of marginalized groups.
3. Global justice
Being a reliable partner
At the heart of our development policy commitment are the people we want to support in their quest for better living conditions on the ground. We therefore stand for human rights- based cooperation with countries in the Global South. China's development initiatives often aim to create one-sided dependencies. In its war of aggression against Ukraine, which violates international law, Russia has shown that it is prepared to use hunger as a weapon. Rising prices for food, energy and transport have exacerbated hunger and economic crises, destabilized countries and brought hardship to people around the world. We want the EU to actively compete for partnerships with the Global South and to intensify the coordinated approach it has begun with the member states to build fair partnerships. We are committed to partner-oriented, feminist, decolonial and sustainable approaches in development cooperation that effectively address systemic injustices.
to dismantle in a targeted manner. In doing so, we also want to
do justice to our colonial past and critically question colonial continuities.
We want to promote local knowledge and local initiatives in order to support the development of economic cycles and social security systems. To this end, we want to further develop the existing instruments of European development cooperation in dialog with our partners. To this end, the EU must strengthen local and civil society actors in universities and NGOs and make funding guidelines more flexible. Collaboration with the private sector, including
Start-ups are part of this. We are committed to ensuring that civil society and, in particular, women's rights organizations from countries in the Global South receive direct support from the EU, following the example of the Canadian Equality Fund. We also want to strengthen global city partnerships that bring issues of global justice into the living spaces of local people and make an important contribution to municipal development cooperation.
In view of the global challenges, substantial funds are needed for development cooperation. We are committed to ensuring that all EU member states keeptheir promise to spend at least 0.7 percent of gross national income on development financing (ODA quota). However, it is not only the quantity of support that is important, but also the implementation of projects in a partner-oriented, fast, unbureaucratic and impact-oriented manner. The development funds must primarily go to the countries most in need and contribute to the fulfillment of the sustainable development goals as well as the Paris Climate Agreement and the Montreal Biodiversity Agreement. In cooperation with our partner countries, we also want to strengthen people's social security. We support the development of social security systems as a sustainable instrument against poverty. The reconstruction requirements for Ukraine should be made available in addition to the ODA quota.
All too often, the EU Commission and member states still work side by side in the field of development policy. We therefore support the Team Europe approach, which aims to improve cross-sectoral coordination, coherence, visibility and effectiveness in cooperation with the private sector. In order to increase coherence and transparency, we advocate cross-sector evaluations and a transparency mechanism for public development cooperation in the EU. We want to better involve the European Parliament in development policy decision-making processes.
In the area of digital development collaboration, we want to create human-centered and responsible
We want to shape responsible digitalization globally and promote digital self-determination. We want to strengthen digital policy exchange, because
As the EU, we can learn a lot from digital pioneers in countries of the Global South. We want to expand adequacy decisions with our partner countries and thus promote participation in international digital value creation.
Securing food globally
The multiple crises of our time, above all the climate crisis, pose existential challenges for food security worldwide. The EU must work towards a sustainable and resilient global food system and thus contribute to the implementation of the right to food.
A resilient and productive organic agriculture with strong regional markets, but also access to supra- regional markets, is the best way to make agriculture more resilient to political crises and the consequences of climate change. European development cooperation projects should increasingly promote economically viable and ecologically and socially sustainable farming systems with nutrient cycles that are as closed as possible. We are committed to ensuring that European agricultural subsidies, patented seeds and land grabbing do not undermine farming structures and markets in countries of the Global South and create one-sided, expensive dependencies. Respect for the individual development opportunities of the countries and the self-determination of the people has the highest priority for us. We want the
Promote the establishment and expansion of local
seed banks and breeding infrastructure so that traditional knowledge and biodiversity are preserved and remain accessible and dependencies in seed development are reduced. We want to advocate stricter mechanisms within the EU to prevent excessive food speculation, especially in emergency situations. Speculation in water must also be strictly regulated. We want to prevent water scarcity from being exacerbated by speculation in addition to increasing droughts and rising water prices.
We want to end exports of synthetic chemical fertilizers and pesticides, which are banned in the EU.
The promotion of agriculture based on agroecological principles in countries of the Global South must be implemented as part of comprehensive strategies to strengthen food systems, including access to technologies, infrastructures, markets and financial resources as well as mutual knowledge transfer. The role of women and marginalized groups in nutrition and food production must also be taken into account.
Accepting global responsibility
The legacy of the colonial era still weighs heavily on relations between Europe and former colonies. It can be seen, for example, in the unequal global distribution of wealth, economic dependencies and a lack of representation. The member states of the EU must face up to their historical responsibility resulting from the crimes of colonial history and address power imbalances. This requires an anti- racist perspective and an examination of post- colonial continuities.
We will work to ensure thatthe debate on the recognition of human rights violations, war crimes and the appropriation and destruction of cultural heritage committed by EU member states during their colonial era in countries of the Global South is also conducted at EU level. We want to find a common way to apologize appropriately, to take responsibility with words and deeds and to make idealistic and material reparations within a framework of international law.
We want to correct disadvantageous clauses in trade agreements and drive forward reforms at development banks. We want to better respect the human and land rights of indigenous and local communities in international nature and environmental protection agreements. The euro
We want to continuously evaluate and further develop European development cooperation in cooperation with partner countries and civil society in the sense of a critical reflection of power relations.
Many countries in the Global South are in a debt crisis that massively restricts their options for socio-ecological modernization processes. The EU and its member states must advocate solid debt restructuring and debt relief for particularly burdened countries. To this end, debt restructuring must be further developed under the G20 Common Framework in order to make it more transparent and include all private and public creditors in a binding manner. In the long term, this procedure must be established at the UN. We want to prevent European jurisdictions from being misused for money laundering or tax avoidance, which the
further restrict the financial scope of action of countries in the Global South. We are also committed to reforming the global tax architecture and involving the Global South as partners in order to promote global justice and sustainability. This includes promoting inclusive, fair and effective international tax cooperation at UN level, for example through negotiations on a comprehensive UN tax convention.
4. Fair trade
Creating prosperity with trade
Trade promotes exchange between people and societies and can increase prosperity. This has been demonstrated by the EU itself, of which the single market remains a key pillar to this day.
In Germany in particular, our prosperity depends on well-functioning global trade due to the strong export orientation of our economy. It is therefore a political task for the EU to use its economic and political influence to set global standards for social justice, climate and nature protection as well as human rights through trade policy and to ensure that the EU's trade policy is in line with these standards.
to promote value creation. In this way, we also protect our own standards from undercutting competition and thus act in line with our values and interests.
The crises of recent years - the pandemic, extreme weather and war - have shown that we need to reduce risks in supply chains and access to raw materials. A forward-looking, open trade policy that establishes reliable partnerships makes an important contribution to this. To this end, we must support European companies in diversifying their investment activities and value chains.
Realigning trading instruments
Global trade needs global rules. The World Trade Organization (WTO) is the best possible framework for formulating and reviewing these rules and settling any disputes. We want to fundamentally reform the WTO so that it can once again fulfill this role. Good labor standards, access to health products and green technologies, fair development as well as climate, environmental and animal protection must also be placed at the center of global trade policy.
However, the WTO is currently barely able to act due to the tense geopolitical situation and there is little willingness to reform it globally. We are therefore increasingly focusing on regional trade agreements on an equal footing with partners such as Australia, India, the countries of Latin America and the Southeast Asian community of states ASEAN, which are also committed to rules-based global trade. We advocate high environmental and social standards worldwide, also in order to level the global playing field.
We are therefore committed to ensuring that sustainability goals and human rights are included in all future international trade agreements and are enforceable, as in the recently concluded agreement between the EU and New Zealand. In the event of blatant disregard for human rights or violations of the
Paris Climate Agreement, the EU should make consistent use of these clauses or suspend the agreement.
We want to realign the Agreement on Trade- Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS), not least in consultation with civil society actors. In this way, we will support the transfer of climate-friendly technologies and important health technologies from the Global North to the South in order to promote the development of the local economy and reduce global emissions. We also want to break down barriers to innovation and its market penetration, particularly in areas that are geared towards the common good and areas of public welfare. To this end, we want to examine the further development of European patent law, for example.
Digitalization can significantly simplify globally fair trade, for example by automating the monitoring of supply chains. Digital trade in goods and services, intellectual property rights, data protection and net neutrality must always be considered in the EU's trade agreements and trade instruments. This requires a revision of European trade instruments in the areas of data regulations and data localization,
Research and development, national tax systems and the digital single market.
We also want to improve the democratic control of trade agreements. Before negotiations begin, the European Parliament should determine the negotiating mandate together with the Council of the EU.
If EU industries are harmed by unfair trade practices, EU trade defense instruments must provide an effective response to protect fair competition.
Conversely, we want to offer less industrialized countries in particular an open dialogue and give them a fair chance in trade agreements to pursue an industrial policy with the aim of creating their own value. In this area, we have made significant progress by constantly expanding our trade
political toolbox has already achieved a great deal. For example, through the instrument against coercive measures (anti-coercion instrument), with which the EU can defend itself against unilateral coercive measures by trading partners.
We are committed to transparent and publicly legitimized forms of dispute resolution in free trade agreements, where these are necessary.
Acting in harmony with the climate
We want to transform our economy into a climate- neutral one and develop it into a strong circular economy. This includes developing standards together with our trading partners so that global markets for green products such as climate- neutral steel can emerge.
The introduction of the border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) is an important step towards introducing fair carbon pricing in global trade and supplementing and safeguarding the EU emissions trading system. This will make imports of certain products such as steel or cement from countries without emissions trading more expensive if they are produced using climate-damaging processes. The CBAM thus also supports the modernizatio
The European Green Deal is an important step in the development of our industry, for example by protecting producers of green steel from non- European competition from fossil-based steel and ensuring fair competition.
It is important that we end investments in fossil fuels and other climate-damaging activities and instead incentivize sustainable investments. This requires a fundamental change in the model for bilateral EU investment treaties. The withdrawal from the most climate-damaging investment protection treaty in the world - the Energy Charter Treaty - by Germany and other EU countries is a great success. We are now consistently fighting for the entire EU to withdraw from the Energy Charter Treaty.
The law on deforestation-free supply chains is an important building block in the goal of combating grave deforestation rates worldwide. To ensure that the law has the desired effect
the EU must now seek partnerships with producer countries and support them in building sustainable supply chains and complying with the requirements. We want to particularly promote the import of products from agroforestry systems in tropical forests.
Focus on fair partnerships
As a global economic player, the EU must place human rights and social justice at the center of a future-oriented trade policy. Ambitious European laws to regulate supply chains and their national implementation are an important lever for achieving these goals and covering not only the direct suppliers, but the entire supply chain.
We are also transposing the new European Supply Chain Directive into national law and adapting national requirements where necessary. We enable injured parties in the EU to assert their rights. In this way, the EU and its member states are taking responsibility for effectively curbing social and environmental dumping worldwide.
Ratification and implementation of the core labor standards of the International Labor Organization (ILO) should be considered a minimum requirement for any trade agreement. Trade agreements must also take into account the concerns of indigenous peoples and communities on the ground and protect their rights.
There are currently more than 25 million forced laborers in the world. Products from this modern form of slavery have no place on the EU domestic market. The EU ban on imports of products from forced labor must therefore be implemented consistently. We want to focus on all forms of forced labor, including in the digital space.
We must ensure fair economic relations with countries of the Global South. We want to review the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA) with the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the South Pacific in the interests of fair and development-oriented trade. This includes recognizing the special advantages of the Least Developed
countries that allow these countries to import goods into the EU duty-free, also as part of EPAs, and to enable the countries of the Global South to pursue an active industrial policy. In order to support countries in the Global South in reducing their export dependency on unprocessed raw materials, we want to design European and international free trade instruments in such a way thatthey do not prevent the development of local industries and integration into higher value-added chains.
5. More EU in Europe
Prospects for expansion
The enlargement of the EU is a success story and is in our own best interests. It strengthens our security, our stability and our prosperity. That is why it is our responsibility to actively support countries with a European perspective. We want to combine clear criteria for accession with binding offers of cooperation in a fair accession process. In order for an enlarged EU to remain capable of acting, it must reform its structures: Enlargement and reforms must go hand in hand.
All candidate states must fulfill the Copenhagen criteria, the EU's accession criteria, without any exceptions and fully adopt the EU's common law, the acquis.
By advancing EU enlargement step by step, we are dynamizing the lengthy and often cumbersome accession process and securing the credibility of the European project.
It must become more visible: The pace of reform in the accession countries alone determines the pace of accession. National vetoes by EU member states in the opening of chapters should not be allowed.
Accession process must not be blocked. We want to shape the accession process with visible intermediate steps and recognize these with positive incentives, for example access to roaming, Erasmus+ or parts of the internal market. A standstill in the negotiations for a longer period of time
Any delay or even regression should, conversely, lead to a loss of benefits. One focus in the accession process must be on strengthening the rule of law and democracy as well as the fight against corruption and organized crime. To this end, we want to extend the mandates of the
EU anti-corruption authority OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor's Office to the accession countries and the EU funds they use.
Strengthening civil society in the accession states and networking them with each other and with the EU member states is also key for us. On the road to the EU, close cooperation with all democratic forces in the accession countries is important to us, even beyond the governments. Government representatives from the accession countries should be able to participate in selected meetings of the Council of the EU. We expect all accession candidates to fully align with the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy, including the adoption of sanctions against Russia.
Western Balkans
The future of the six Western Balkan states of Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Serbia lies in the EU.
The promise of EU accession continues to be an important driver for the sensitive peace and reconciliation process in the countries of the Western Balkans. The EU must not jeopardize this promise of accession. The start of accession talks with Albania and North Macedonia, candidate status for Bosnia and Herzegovina and visa liberalization for Kosovo are important steps forward on the road to the EU.
At the same time, the challenges remain great in view of corruption, organized crime, weak rule of law structures and the inadequate processing of war crimes in some cases. We want to provide the countries in the accession process with intensive support in overcoming these challenges. The EU must counter attempts by authoritarian states to destabilize the region with determination and resolve.
We are united in our opposition. We support democratic development and coming to terms with the past in Bosnia and Herzegovina and welcome the presence of EUFOR to strengthen security in the country. We call on the Serbian government to take a public stand against violence and for peaceful understanding and call on Serbia and Kosovo to reach a lasting solution at the negotiating table. This is a prerequisite for peace and stability in the region and a key to Serbia's EU accession process. We are strengthening KFOR to support the peace process. We want to provide even better support for the region's civil societies, in particular strengthen cross-border youth work in the region and support an inclusive culture of remembrance. As part of the Green Agenda for the Western Balkans, we want to support the region quickly and effectively in developing good jobs, renewable energies, modern rail infrastructure and sustainable investments.
Ukraine
Ukraine is at the center of the European family. Its place is in the EU. Every day, millions of Ukrainians courageously oppose Russia's war of aggression, which violates international law: they are resisting Russia's brutal attempt to subjugate their country and eradicate their culture, to destroy international law and the European peace order.
We are committed to ensuring that the EU does not let up in its humanitarian, political, financial and military support for Ukraine. We will continue to resolutely support Ukraine so that it can regain and defend its sovereignty and full territorial integrity. We stand firmly by Ukraine, its people and their right to freedom, self-determination and self-defense and support the desire for a sustainable peace and robust, reliable security guarantees.
We will also provide Ukraine with comprehensive support on its path to the EU. Both sides will benefit from an orderly and swift
accession process. We are focusing on transparency, the rule of law, a consistent fight against corruption and an active role for civil society and the regional and municipal level. We are already seeing great progress in the reforms necessary for the EU accession negotiations. The people of Ukraine deserve our recognition for changing their country so fundamentally in the midst of a war.
We are committed to ensuring that the EU and its member states provide financial, technical and investment support for the reconstruction of Ukraine. This also requires major financial efforts, the involvement of Ukrainian civil society and significantly accelerated procedures in order to achieve rapid results and strengthen the country against Russian attacks. We are committed to long- term and sustainable financing for the reconstruction of Ukraine. In addition to various state and private financial instruments, this requires grants in particular. We want to examine whether and how abandoned Russian assets can be used for the reconstruction of Ukraine in a legally secure manner.
We rely on a variety of international investigative and judicial bodies to investigate and punish Russian crimes against humanity and war crimes, including the crime of aggressive war. An international mechanism should decide on the compensation of property damage and personal injury caused by Russia to Ukraine and thus create a legal basis for Russia to finance the reconstruction of Ukraine.
Ukraine's economy has been severely weakened by the war. We would like the EU to further stabilize Ukraine's economy through macro- financial assistance and to continue this as a sign of solidarity and as a contribution to European security. This also includes pushing ahead with the expansion of alternative export routes for Ukrainian agricultural products beyond the Black Sea (solidarity lanes). This will help Ukraine economically and contribute to global food security.
Georgia and Moldova
The future of Moldova and Georgia lies in the EU. Both countries have long been the target of military aggression and attempts at destabilization by Russia. These have intensified since the beginning of the Russian war of aggression against Ukraine. We stand resolutely by the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the two countries. We will actively support Moldova and Georgia on their path to the EU, but at the same time demand the necessary reforms. Ins-
As an EU accession candidate and since 2020, Moldova in particular has embarked on a courageous and ambitious reform course, which we consistently support. The Georgian people's desire for EU integration remains huge; the government must now implement the necessary reforms to fulfill the country's European dream.
European Neighborhood
The European family is bigger than the EU. We want an EU thatworks constructively with its European neighbors.
We would like to intensify the EU's cooperation with the Council of Europe in the promotion and defense of democracy and human rights on the European continent. To this end, we are also working towards the EU's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.
We welcome the European Political Community as a platform for closer cooperation with European countries, regardless of whether they are seeking EU membership or not. In the field of energy in particular, this cooperation is in the strong European interest.
We want the EU and the UK to continue to work constructively to intensify their relations again after Brexit. Close economic and military cooperation between the EU and the UK is in our mutual interest. We welcome the fact that the United Kingdom has rejoined the
EU research program Horizon Europe. At the same time, we expect the British government to remove practical hurdles to exchange and cooperation with the EU, such as student visas, as quickly as possible.
In view of the challenges posed by the Russian war of aggression against Ukraine, we want to preserve the OSCE as an important forum for dialog and crisis prevention. It can play a central role in shaping the post-war order in Eastern Europe.
Turkey
Turkey and the EU - and Germany in particular - have a long-standing friendship and partnership that is reflected in close social, cultural and economic relations. We believe that a democratic Turkey, in which the rights of all its citizens are respected, has a firm place in the EU.
Unfortunately, the current political reality is different: In recent years, the Turkish government has moved further and further away from the rule of law and human rights. With an aggressive foreign and regional policy, Ankara is in some cases aggressively targeting European interests.
The initial blockade of Sweden's accession to NATO and the military offensive in northern Syria, which violates international law, also show what a difficult partner Turkey is for Europe and NATO in the current security situation. At the same time, it has acted as a mediator in the war against Ukraine and beyond.
Despite this ambivalent role, Turkey remains a strategic partner within NATO, for Europe and for Germany. An active Green foreign policy faces up to this dilemma. For us, there can only be a resumption of talks on EU accession once Turkey has credibly embarked on the path to democracy and the rule of law.
We support cooperation inthose areas where it is necessary and possible,
for example on security in the Black Sea or in the fight against climate change. However, we firmly oppose authoritarian policies and nationalist rhetoric that are openly directed against the EU, against the safety of Turkish opposition members in the EU, against refugees, against Kurds and other minorities or against human rights defenders in our own country.
The Turkish government must release the countless political prisoners, including Osman Kavala and Selahattin Demirtas, and comply with the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR). With
Turkey's disregard for the judgments of the ECtHR makes the ongoing infringement proceedings within the Council of Europe unavoidable.
Disregarding court rulings creates legal uncertainty, which also puts a strain on civil society and economic relations with Turkey.
We continue to stand firmly by the side of the many Turks whoarecommitted to democracy and the rule of law. We would like the EU to give special support to Turkish civil society, which is committed to democratic change.
6. A strong Europe in the world
Eastern neighbors of the EU
Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine is a turning point for the EU and our continent. The EU is called upon to find new answers to its neighborly relationship with a hostile Russia. For our Eastern European partners in the EU, we need targeted measures for a new EU policy for Eastern Europe and Central Asia that take particular account of the changed security interests of our partners. At the same time, we must provide special support to the democratic reform forces and civil societies in Russia's European neighbors that are threatened by Russian interference.
We stand firmly by the courageous people in Belarus who have been working tirelessly for democracy and human rights in their country since the protests surrounding the fraudulent presidential elections in 2020. We will continue to stand in solidarity with and strongly advocate for the support of Belarusian civil society and opposition, the release of all political prisoners, the sanctioning of the Belarusian regime and free and fair elections in the country.
Dictator Lukashenka and his regime are guilty of serious human rights violations and war crimes in Belarus and by supporting the Russian war of aggression in Ukraine. They must be held accountable for this. We are committed to
in particular for the EU to support the collection and preservation of evidence.
The EU can and should become more involved in all countries of the South Caucasus and actively support existing democracy movements and civil society. Armenia's path to greater political participation and freedoms was paved by Russian pressure and the war over mountain ranges. karabakh massively more difficult. Azerbaijan has decided to use military force to establish facts
to create. We condemn Baku's military attack on Nagorno-Karabakh in September 2023. The EU must show the autocratic Azerbaijani government clear limits in the event of further offensives. Long- term peace can only be achieved through negotiations. We therefore welcome the EU's efforts to find a sustainable peace solution with Armenia and Azerbaijan. The EU Monitoring Mission in Armenia (EUMA) is making an important stabilizing contribution in this regard. Over 100,000 Armenians have been forced to leave Nagorno- Karabakh.
half of them children and elderly people. The EU should support the integration of refugees from Nagorno-Karabakh in Armenia or enable their return to Nagorno-Karabakh through international protection mechanisms. The protection of Armenian culture and Christian religion in Nagorno-Karabakh must be ensured in order to protect the region's common heritage. The EU should act between
Armenia and Azerbaijan should act as a stabilizing mediator and at the same time strengthen Armenia's democratic reform forces. This should also include the EU supporting Armenia in driving forward the democratic reform process despite all the challenges and strengthening the country's independence from Russia. This requires an even closer partnership and rapprochement between Armenia and the EU, as well as with Germany.
Putin and his regime of power have turned Russia into a totalitarian dictatorship. Security in Europe can currently only exist before Russia
- and not with Russia. Violence, lies, corruption and arbitrariness characterize the political reality.
Civil society has been silenced and the opposition is either in exile or in political prison. We will continue to campaign for the release of all political prisoners. We see ourselves as friends and partners of those whowant a free, peaceful and democratic Russia. We see ourselves as hard adversary of all those who support Putin's criminal regime. We therefore support the European sanctions policy against the regime and its representatives. There can be no economic and trade policy normality with this Russia.
We welcome the International Criminal Court's arrest warrant against the Russian President. He is guilty of the worst human rights crimes and must be brought to justice with the full force of the law.
Transatlantic relations
There is no other country outside Europe with which we Europeans share such a deep common history and such a strong partnership as with the USA. After the Second World War and the end of the Cold War, the USA made a significant contribution to economic development and political unification on the European continent and to the reunification of Germany.
However, transatlantic relations are also
of central importance for our European present and future. We value Canada and the USA as close and reliable value partners and would like to further deepen the EU's relations with both. Since the Russian war of aggression against Ukraine, our transatlantic partners, and above all the USA, have helped to defend the peace order in Europe and secure the political unity of the Euro-Atlantic alliance. The USA is a key strategic partner: for our security, for the climate-friendly renewal of our prosperity and for the self-assertion of liberal democracy.
Together, we are stronger in the systemic confrontation with China, Russia and other authoritarian and totalitarian regimes. Together, we can secure and expand global value partnerships and multilateral forums and agreements. Together, we can shape the global trade order and advance the climate-neutral transformation of our industries. And together we can develop future technologies and at the same time actively shape them for the benefit of people and their freedom.
A strong transatlantic relationship requires partners on both sides of the Atlantic who are able and willing to act. That is why more European efforts a r e needed to develop our own security, defense and economic policy capacities. We want to strengthen the European pillar of NATO, including through closer EU-NATO cooperation.
Anti-liberal tendencies on both sides of the Atlantic endanger the foundation of values on which the transatlantic partnership is based. They must be resolutely opposed.
This also means that we must simultaneously intensify and diversify our strategic partnership with the USA. On the one hand, diversification means putting transatlantic relations on a broader footing - by expanding partnerships with federal states, cities, civil society, business and science.
And diversification also means reducing one-sided dependencies and strengthening the EU's ability to act independently.
The joint EU-US Trade and Technology Council (TTC) is a suitable forum for developing joint responses to global challenges. We are in favor of deepening economic relations with the USA in order to createa transatlantic market that follows the highest social and ecological standards worldwide in accordance with the "race to the top" principle and acts as a driving force for green transformation worldwide. An important element of this is the joint work on a club for critical raw materials.
China
For us, China is a partner, economic competitor and systemic rival. However, due to China's increasingly aggressive behavior on the global stage, the partnership is increasingly fading into the background. Internally, the Chinese leadership is acting in a more repressive and authoritarian manner; externally, it is now openly pursuing hegemonic and imperial ambitions and is aggressively trying to expand its own global influence. To this end, China is also increasingly using its influence within the BRICS states (initially Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa, and now also Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran and the United Arab Emirates) and its close partnership with Russia.
This contributes to a further widening of the differences between Europe and China. We therefore advocate closer coordination between the member states and the EU as an institution, as well as a structured exchange of information and closer coordination of relations with China, particularly with our transatlantic and Indo-Pacific partners.
The EU must reduce its one-sided economic dependencies on China, for example in raw materials and medicines, much more quickly and support the European economy in remaining competitive in the long term. This cannot be achieved without an ambitious, independent industrial and investment policy. It is crucial that the EU formulates an independent course towards China. On the other hand, we reject those who advocatea complete decoupling from China.
China is the EU's largest trading partner, but only our third largest export market. The trade deficit is growing: imports from China are increasing, while exports to China are decreasing. China is still dependent on technologies from Europe, and the European market is also attractive for Chinese companies. The EU can make better and more confident use of the existing scope for action here, especially in the area of transparency obligations of Chinese companies with regard to labor, social, environmental and safety standards. Critical infrastructure, such as ports, railroads and digital infrastructure, as well as key industries must be protected from Chinese investment in the long term and throughout the EU.
We support the introduction and use of the EU's anti-coercion instrument as well as a coordinated approach to controls on investments in China and export restrictions in the area of sensitive technologies. With joint instruments, the EU can better defend itself against economic blackmail attempts and achieve a deterrent effect.
The massive and systematic human rights violations against Uyghurs in the province of Xinjiang, but also against Tibetans, religious minorities and representatives of civil society, especially democracy activists in Hong Kong, by the Chinese government must be ended. The protection of human rights is the basis of European policy. This also applies to the international supply chains of European companies. Products from forced labor
in China must not be given access to the European market. We therefore also expect China toratify the key core standards of the ILO.
As part of the EU's one-China policy, we support the relevant participation of democratic Taiwan in international organizations. At the same time, we recognize that the risk of escalation in the Taiwan Strait has increased significantly due to t h e increase in military pressure from the People's Republic of China. A change in the status quo in the Taiwan Strait must not take place against Taiwan's will. We regard Taiwan
as a democratic value partner and arecommittedto intensifying economic, cultural, civil, social and political exchange.
We will work together with China wherever possible on key global challenges such as the debt crisis in countries of the Global South, the financing of economic modernization and climate protection and adaptation measures. This also applies to global health protection, the protection of biodiversity and the protection of the world's oceans. In these and other areas, we remain open to cooperation on the basis of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the core principles of the multilateral order.
Middle East and North Africa
The Middle East and North Africa is a region in upheaval and an important neighbor for the EU. The hopes of the revolutionary movements in the region have remained largely unfulfilled, and in recent years authoritarian actors have once again become entrenched in the region. Despite the difficult situation, however, we want to work closely together to promote economic development in the region.
to support development for the benefit of the people. Their desire for a life in dignity and security and more political participation should be at the heart of European Middle East policy.
There is great potential in the expansion of renewable energies. We see cooperation between small and medium-sized companies as a particular opportunity to strengthen structures beyond the often state-dominated large companies in the region.
In its cooperation with civil society, the EU must be a reliable partner for all those who want to create women's and human rights perspectives and promote freedom and self-determination. Due to its history of colonialism and decades of support for authoritarian governments, Europe has a special responsibility here.
We want to shape a migration policy that does not make us vulnerable to blackmail by authoritarian regimes in the region. A political focus on refugee defense in relation to the southern Mediterranean countries supports authoritarian and dysfunctional regimes that themselves create reasons for flight.
The existence and security of Israel as the national home of the Jewish people with equal rights for all its citizens are non-negotiable. The Hamas terror attacks on Israel on October 7, 2023 were a turning point. After these terrible acts, we stand firmly by the side of Israel and its citizens. Like every other state, Israel has the right under international law to defend itself against attacks such as these within the framework of international humanitarian law. Israel's security is part of Germany's reason of state and the guiding principle of our actions. Peace and security require a two-state settlement with the creation of a sovereign, viable and democratic state of Palestine on the basis of the 1967 borders. To this end, the EU should join the forces of the member states for negotiations between the two sides and offer its active and generous support for the realization of peace.
In addition to our u n w a v e r i n g solidarity with Israel, this also requires consistent support for pro-democratic Palestinian voices. This is also a basis for the creation of Palestinian political institutions based on the rule of law. The peace
perspective also includes the Palestinian Authority clearly condemning terror against Israel and taking action against it. We reject the ongoing Israeli settlement construction, plans for annexations contrary to international law and settler violence against Palestinians in the West Bank as obstacles to peace. We want to continue to work in solidarity with those forces in Israel and Palestine that are fighting for peace on both sides. sides for democracy and freedom, human and civil rights and peace. As the largest donor, the EU should also promote the development of democratic institutions and democratic education in its development aid for the Palestinian territories in order to counter hate.
and to promote understanding between Israelis, Palestinians and people from the surrounding neighboring states.
In Iran, we stand alongside the feminist protest movement against the Iranian regime.
This is committed to a democratic Iran, fighting for respect for human rights and the self-determination of the population, including the abolition of dress codes such as the forced veil. We want the EU to critically examine the extension of sanctions against those responsible for the regime and the tightening of sanctions on trade and financial relations on an ongoing basis.
The Islamic Revolutionary Guard must be listed as a terrorist organization with legal certainty. In addition, the EU must support the democratic opposition in Iran and in the diaspora and quickly take in politically persecuted Iranians. The Islamic Center Hamburg as a coordination point for monitoring the diaspora in Germany must finally be closed, as must representations in other German cities. The regime is trying to use an aggressive foreign policy and
terror financing to destabilize the region. The terrorist financing of the Iranian regime, which is used, among other things, for the declared goal of destroying Israel, must be combated. With Israel's security in mind, the EU must work together with the USA to prevent Iran from going nuclear. Iran must adhere to international nuclear non- proliferation agreements. Iran has continued to massively violate its obligations under the JCPOA (Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, nuclear agreement with Iran) since 2019 and has repeatedly turned down the opportunity to return to the JCOA. This is why the proliferation-related measures in the nuclear sector and sanctions must remain in place. We want to learn from the lessons of the JCPoA negotiations.
We want to counteract the arms spiral in the region with a united EU. We support diplomatic efforts to de-escalate in the region. The normalization of relations must not lead to punitive measures.
This can also lead to a lack of humanity, for example in view of the human rights crimes committed by the Assad regime in Syria.
We bear a special responsibility towards Afghanistan as a result of our many years of involvement and the subsequent hasty withdrawal of Western troops.
Above all, we condemn the ousting of women from almost all areas of public life and do not recognize the Taliban as the government of Afghanistan. We are committed to ensuring that the EU continues to p r o v i d e humanitarian aid in view of the dramatic situation in the country and explicitly involves women.
