Due to their work - for example for the German Armed Forces and international organizations - or their deployment, local forces and human rights defenders are
for human rights in danger. We therefore stand for the consistent protection and reception of local forces and human rights defenders and their threatened families.
Africa
African countries and Europe are closely linked both geographically and historically. We want to support the diverse countries and societies on the African continent in their efforts to create sustainable development and good jobs locally.
We see growing cooperation between the EU and the African continent in politics, business, technology, science and civil society as an opportunity for both sides.
We want to work togetherwith our African partners for mutual benefit and make attractive European offers for sustainable development.
We see the strengthening of democracy as an important task and condemn unconstitutional changes of power, coups and unfree elections that jeopardize democratic development in some African countries.
The European Climate, Energy and Hydrogen Partnerships and the Climate and Development Partnerships are a good example of how they can help to make industry climate-neutral on both continents. We therefore want to expand them. In doing so, it is clear to us that the energy generated and the associated value
The benefits of the value chain must always be available to the producing countries first, especially the poorest and most marginalized people.
The planned cooperation within the framework of the Global Gateway Initiative is a step towards the further sustainable development of both continents and, as an attractive European offer for the major investment needs, contributes to reducing dependence on China and Russia. We want to support regional integration in the African Economic Communities and the African Union, including the emerging pan-African free trade area.
Good governance and the rule of law are indispensable foundations for social and economic development. We want to support civil society and democratic political actors, especially where state structures are weakened or autocratic structures prevail. In the EU, we want to actively support the non-violent commitment of young people in particular to a pluralistic civil society in their countries and to civil conflict resolution. Women and marginalized groups have a special role to play here.
We are committed to ensuring that third-country nationals who are studying in Europe, traveling on business or attendingconferences, for example, have easier and faster access to visas. One contribution to this is the digitalization of visa procedures.
Europe's integration with Africa is still characterized by an imbalance of power.
In addition, the African continent is already suffering particularly badly from the consequences of the climate crisis, which was caused to a significant extent by European emissions. Conscious of our colonial heritage and the associated economic exploitation, we want to shape relationships thatare based on respect and equality.
Indo-Pacific
The economic center of gravity has shifted to the Indo-Pacific region. This is where a large part of global growth, innovation and development takes place.
We want to expand our close cooperation with Europe's key partners such as Japan, South Korea, Australia and New Zealand and intensify our exchange with ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) and its member states as well as the oceanic island states. We also want to focus on more cooperation on climate protection and economic modernization and at the same time strengthen cultural exchange, civil society actors and the protection of human rights. In particular, we want to further intensify cooperation with Japan as our closest partner in the Indo-Pacific region and the only member of the G7 in the region. One example of this is the digital partnership that the EU concluded with Japan in May 2022 as its first ever partner country.
In the Indo-Pacific in particular, China is becoming increasingly aggressive and at the same time propagating its authoritarian state and social model as a role model. That is why we also want to expand cooperation between the EU and Indo- Pacific states in the area of security and defense policy.
There are many countries in the Pacific region whose existence is threatened by the climate crisis, even though they themselves have contributed little to global emissions. We want to provide them with concrete and financial support in dealing with the consequences of global warming and rising sea levels. We want to anchor climate protection more firmly in trade relations with the countries of the entire region and jointly promote the production of green energy in the region, for example through the EU's Global Gateway Initiative.
We aim to deepen and broaden the EU's relations with India. We welcome the launch of the EU-India Trade and Technology Council in 2023 as well as the
Connectivity partnership. We recognize India's new importance for the provision of global digital goods and want to explore increased cooperation on digital payment systems. Economic cooperation must be based on clear social, minority and climate protection standards. We are increasingly concerned about current domestic political developments in this regard. We support Indian civil society and are committed t o the peaceful resolution of territorial conflicts in border regions.
The EU member states should work within the UN to condemn behavior by the military regime in Myanmar that violates international law and to demand free and fair elections in the country.
Latin America
The countries of Latin America are not only important economic partners, but many are also our value partners. The many democracies there are natural partners for Europe in strengthening multilateralism. Forums such as the revived summit between the EU and the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) enable intensive cooperation and partnership with the countries of the continent.
In some Latin American countries, authoritarian governments have established themselves that severely restrict civil society's scope for action. Democratic states are also still under pressure, as demonstrated by the storming of government buildings in Brazil in early 2023. Events like these make it clear that democracy must be defended against autocratic tendencies and groups.
Cooperation with democratically elected governments and a strong civil society are essential for this. We want to protect activists for human rights, environmental protection and the rights of LGBTIQ*, women and indigenous people and actively support their work. Effectively combating corruption and drug-related crime is also important. In addition to police and criminal law measures, this also includes the creation of
economic alternatives, reducing dependencies on cartels and strengthening cross-border investigations.
Over 55 percent of the world's rainforest is located in Latin America. The region is central to protecting our global climate. That is why we want to intensify climate, commodity and development partnerships and expand cooperation for sustainable agriculture and effective nature and tropical forest conservation. The protection of the rights of indigenous peoples must be considered and prioritized in all projects.
Europe needs close trade relations with Latin America, not least in order to diversify its supply chains with a view to China. These can only be successful if they are negotiated in a spirit of partnership, both sides benefit and a substantial share of trade is created.
part of the added value remains in Latin America. The EU's Global Gateway Initiative can play an important role in this. We want to learn from the mistakes of the past and shape our future trade policy in such a way that no environmental destruction is fueled and no neo-colonial exploitation occurs. We want partnerships at eye level. We reject the
EU-Mercosur agreement in its current form and call for renegotiations to bring about fundamental changes - for a fair, ecological and post-colonial agreement that respects human rights, promotes technology transfer, and promotes the development of new technologies.
and puts an end to the intensive extraction of raw materials in the Global South for consumption in the Global North. We will only ratify the Mercosur agreement if both sides agree to implementable, verifiable and legally binding, enforceable obligations in the areas of environmental, social and climate protection. Especially in times of right- wing populist governments, all of these standards can only be implemented if violations of them can be sanctioned just as effectively as the trade provisions of the agreement. The possibility of suspending trade preferences
The protection of the environment in the event of violations of sustainability standards is therefore an essential prerequisite for approval of the agreement. At the same time, for us, the Mercosur agreement can only exist together with an equivalent additional agreement on the protection and preservation of the rainforest, the protection of indigenous peoples and human rights. This will ensure that our partnership with the Mercosur countries is intensified and that human rights, biodiversity and the global climate are protected at the same time.
 What protects freedom 
The European Union (EU) is an area of freedom, security and democracy. Europeans have built it on the ruins of war and oppression. Today, it guarantees that we can travel without border controls where barbed wire, walls and barriers once separated us. It ensures freedom of expression where dictators ruled just a few decades ago. It protects the rule of law. It guarantees that all EU citizens can freely elect their governments - from the municipal level to Brussels.
The Europe that we want to continue to shape offers security and protection, brings people together and integrates them. We must not only endure differences, but see them as opportunities; we must build bridges across borders and divides; we must seek the unifying element instead of inactively accepting what divides us: Nothing else is the founding idea of the EU.
But security and protection need institutions that create and maintain them. We want to strengthen them. Extremism, disinformation and crime do not stop at national borders, on the contrary: in recent years in particular, we have
experienced how authoritarian states attack our free society. The EU has a responsibility to offer the protection that citizens rightly expect through coordination and strong institutions of its own - especially as this experience of security and state reliability directly increases trust in the democratic association of states that makes up the EU.
The development of the EU is a development towards an ever closer alliance. This is good, because we need the EU's weight and capabilities to solve many of the pressing problems of our time. How we do this must be determined in a democratic process. At the heart of this is the European Parliament, whose rights we want to extend. In this way, we will create the basis for a federal European republic with its own constitution. Even if decision-making processes in Europe are sometimes tedious and lengthy, they are still of great value: with the power of the word and discussion, a compromise is often reached at the end that may not completely satisfy everyone, but helps everyone move forward. This is what we stand for.
After all, the increase in freedom, security and democracy that European unification has brought since the Second World War is one of the greatest political successes in world history. It is not without reason that the EU is the target of extremists of all kinds: those who believe that women should not have the same rights as men, those who want to silence free media, those who want to enforce their interests through disinformation and hate speech - the EU is a thorn in their side.
We want to strengthen the EU's ability to protect the rights and freedoms of those who live here. Our credo: We protect our freedom best when we expand it. We want to strengthen European democracy so that the best ideas can compete fairly for the future of our continent. We want to expand the rule of law, which offers all citizens security and equal rights. We want an EU that works for its citizens. We want them to be able to have an even clearer say in its course through the European Parliament.
And we also want the EU to demonstrate the necessary assertiveness internally, for example against governments such as Viktor Orbán's Hungarian government: Anyone who violates the EU's fundamental values should not be able to benefit from its privileges without restriction.
The possibility of equal participation for all is one of these fundamental values - and a basic prerequisite for our cohesion. This applies not least to women's rights. As long as half of the population is disadvantaged in many areas of life, our democracy will not be complete. And as long as trans, inter and non-binary people are discriminated against, not everyone can participate equally. Authoritarian forces within and outside Europe are calling our cohesion into question by declaring individual groups to be the enemy. This weakens us all and threatens to divide our continent. We are firmly opposed to this. A diverse Europe is a strong Europe: it ensures that everyone can contribute and participate. We stand firmly by the side of all those who are marginalized and discriminated against. And because we see the EU as a pioneer of value- driven digitalization, we also want to safeguard democracy and the rule of law online.
The EU is strong when it is essentially an alliance of values. These values must be credibly
be lived. This applies not least when dealing with people who want - or need - to come to Europe. The deaths in the Mediterranean and the situation at Europe's external borders are untenable. We stand for humanity and order in dealing with refugees. We want to offer protection for people fleeing war and political persecution. have to flee. We want to shape immigration in such a way that those who want to contribute to the success of our community as computer scientists or nurses, as students or harvest workers can also make this contribution. Migration is not only a driving force for progress, it is also an effort.
People come to Europe with different perspectives, experiences and images of society. We want to face up to this major challenge politically. So that
this succeeds, it requires the willingness to work together
Shaping immigration societies on the basis of European values. This applies to the people who live here as well as to those who come to Europe, some of whom have completely different values.
United in diversity, that is the motto of the EU. It should be a community, it should remain a community - across all differences and challenges. We are committed to an EU that sees itself as the driving force behind the ever closer integration of our continent. For a continent in which people live securely in freedom and under democratic values. For an EU that offers a home and does not isolate itself. We want to be this Europe.
1. Democratic institutions
Defending the rule of law
Respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law, including the rights of minorities, is the foundation of the EU. When governments in member states systematically erode this value base by undermining the independence of the judiciary - the first guardian of the rule of law -, c u r t a i l i n g	t h e freedom of the opposition and civil society, fighting free media, restricting women's, minority and LGBTIQ* rights, denying the right to asylum or opening the door to corruption, they pave the way for discrimination.
In doing so, they weaken the EU. It is therefore essential that the existing rule of law instruments are used and developed more consistently and quickly.
The Charter of Fundamental Rights, the basic law of the EU, is intended to offer protection to all people living here. As its application is limited to the implementation of EU law, its protective effect has so far been limited. We want to change this: it should also apply to purely national actions of the member states and be enforceable there. If
a government violates the fundamental rights of its citizens
violated, it should also be able to be prosecuted at European level. We also want to strengthen the enforceability of the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights, which monitors compliance with the European Convention on Human Rights, within the EU.
We want to give more weight to the existing Rule of Law Check and the Rule of Law Dialogue, which examine the rule of law situation in all member states. We will ensure that the freedom of civil society in particular is measured and protected in a more targeted manner. In order to increase the pressure for reform, we rely on binding reform agreements between the EU and the member states, which must be subject to sanctions in the future. Public debates on this in the European Parliament must become the rule and be incorporated into the assessments. The rule of law procedure under Article 7, which can lead, for example, to the withdrawal of voting rights in a multi-stage procedure, should be made usable again. This is to be achieved by the Member States in the Council of the EU (Council of Ministers) and in the European Council no longer voting by consensus but by qualified majority at all stages of the procedure.
The disbursement of EU funds should be linked to compliance with the rule of law, democratic principles and fundamental rights. In order to effectively stop the misuse of European taxpayers' money, for example through systematic corruption, favoritism and nepotism in favor of certain parties, the review must not stand alone. An effective separation of powers and the comprehensive granting of fundamental rights are also crucial. That is why we are extending the budget mechanism to include compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. This means that in the event of violations, EU funds must be frozen proportionately and, if necessary, in stages.
When it comes to infringement proceedings, we rely on clear rules and more transparency. The Commission fulfills its role as guardian of the treaties when the law is respected. Delayed enforcement of EU law harms everyone.
In order to strengthen our common values, we rely on a better coordinated, mutually reinforcing application of all legal instruments between the Council, Commission and European Parliament. We combine the respective findings into a common basis for evaluation. In order to guarantee a regular charter check that is accepted by all member states, we are creating an independent commission of experts to support the EU Commission. If member states want to receive EU funding in the future, they must commit to cooperating with the European Public Prosecutor's Office. However, when funds are cut, it must not be the people in the municipalities who ultimately suffer because corrupt governments shirk their financial responsibility and prefer to point the finger at Brussels. Therefore check
we are investigating how municipalities can be
supported directly.
Daring more democracy
The strengthening of the EU must go hand in hand with its further democratization and greater proximity to citizens. To this end, we want to further strengthen the directly elected European Parliament. The Parliament should be on an equal footing with the Council in all policy areas and, like any parliament, be able to pass laws on an equal footing, for example in tax or security policy. It should be given a full right of initiative so that it can initiate laws independently. We want to extend its right to convene committees of inquiry and summon witnesses. It should also be able to elect the Commission on the proposal of the Commission President and dismiss it again in an emergency.
More democratic legitimacy of decisions at EU level requires more transparency in the European Council and in the Councils of Ministers. The debates and the positions of the individual member states should be made more comprehensible.
Our vision is the European Federal Republic with a European constitution. The parliament should be united in a bicameral system.
become an equal part of the legislative power with the Council.
In order to make the European elections more European and democratic, we want all parties to nominate lead candidates. In turn, the European Parliament elects the next President of the Commission from their ranks. In addition, only candidates from their own country are eligible to stand in the European elections. We want to change this in the interests of a cross-border election campaign. In future, some MEPs should no longer be elected via national lists alone, but via European transnational lists. The European affiliation of national parties should also be clearly recognizable in the remaining national or regional constituencies. We also advocate that the European Parliament should better represent women and underrepresented groups.
We advocate lowering the barriers to voting. Anyone who lives permanently in the EU must also be able to participate in politics there. EU citizens should be able to vote at their permanent place of residence in the Union - not only for local parliaments and the European Parliament, but also in regional and national elections. Anyone who has their permanent place of residence in Germany must have the opportunity to take part in all elections, votes and democratic processes here on an equal footing.
Young people are getting involved and want to help shape Europe. That is why the introduction of the right to vote from the age of 16 in Germany for the European elections was a great success.
We want young people to be better involved in political processes. That is why we will lower the voting age further if necessary on the basis of an evaluation immediately following the European elections.
In addition to the democratic representation of citizens in the European Parliament, we also want to enable more direct participation at EU level. In the Parliament, we will also
work towardsgiving MPs more time to work in their home regions so that they can be approached locally.
With the European Citizens' Forum, whichtook place for the first time in this legislature as a conference on the future, European citizens, who are drawn at random and representatively from the entire population of the EU, can formulate concrete proposals for action in a citizens' report. We want to firmly establish this instrument, enable digital participation and workto ensure that citizens' proposals are implemented.
We want to expand the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI), which allows citizens to place an issue directly on the European political agenda, and make it more binding and better known.
A successful ECI must be followed by a legislative proposal from the European Commission within one year and submitted to the European Parliament and the Council for a vote. The initiators of an ECI should also be able to convene a European Citizens' Forum as an intermediate step.
Becoming more capable of action
In view of the many challenges we face, we are dependent on an EU that is capable of acting. That is why we want to make decisions faster by extending majority voting, for example by applying the passerelle clause. Where unanimity was previously required between states and decisions could therefore easily be blocked, in future, voting should be by qualified majority. It is important that the interests of smaller member states continue to be heard and respected.
Secondly, we want to make better use of the enhanced cooperation clause provided for in the treaties. It allows a group of at least nine EU Member States to cooperate more closely in selected policy areas and initiate joint projects. This will enable them to get important projects off the ground more quickly.
the future. What is important for us is that the European Parliament should be involved - and all other member states should also be able to join in at a later date.
Some of the reforms are possible without amending the treaty. They should be implemented swiftly and promptly. A number of the reform proposals that we advocate require a treaty amendment. To this end, we want to convene a convention with the involvement of EU citizens.
This should incorporate the recommendations of the groundbreaking Conference on the Future of the EU. Here, citizens played a key role in formulating new perspectives for the EU.
Fighting corruption
Democracy depends on the trust of citizens, any appearance of politics for sale causes damage. We are therefore ensuring greater transparency in the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council in order to strengthen the credibility of democratic processes and trust in the EU. We make lobbying interests and conflicts of interest visible to everyone. With the corruption scandal involving individual MEPs in 2022, this is more urgent than ever. We support the extension of criminal liability for bribery and corruption of MEPs at EU level.
We are finally putting the European Parliament's Code of Conduct into sharp focus. Financial penalties must be swiftly enforced in the event of legally established violations. With a lobby register that is binding for all EU institutions, including the Council, we will disclose who comes in and out of the institutions at all political levels. We will make those who influence legislation visible by means of a "legislative footprint", which will make it comprehensively comprehensible which positions have been introduced in the legislative process.
We will put an end to ineffective self-regulation and set up an independent ethics authority to enforce the rules on lobbing control for all EU institutions. When switching between politics and business, we will ensure that there are clear
time rules that are adapted to transitional payments and for their control. The fact that MEPs now have to disclose their financial circumstances to Parliament and investigating authorities makes corruption more difficult. We want to make this transparent, as is already the case in many Member States.
We guarantee more fairness with an EU-wide database that transparently records political online advertising and its clients and donors and sets clear limits on the use of personal data in digital election campaign advertising
in democratic competition and more protection against disinformation and online hate.
The legal framework for the confiscation of assets acquired through corruption or from the proceeds of such illegal assets is to be further strengthened.
2. Feminism
Making Europe a driving force for women's rights and equality
We want a Europe in which all people, regardless of gender, can live self-determined lives and participate equally. Structural disadvantage and gender-specific discrimination prevent women, trans, inter and non-binary people in particular from doing so.
Our response to this is a feminism that takes all people and multiple discrimination into account.
Women and girls should be able to live an equal and self-determined life throughout the EU. In politics, business, culture, science and society - there is still a lot to be done everywhere. Europe has often been a pioneer for women's rights and gender equality. But right-wing and right-wing conservative forces in many countries are targeting our achievements. They are trying to push women out of the labor market through backward-looking family policies. Reproductive rights, especially the right to abortion, are human rights
and must apply equally to all and in all member states. However, the reproductive rights of women, especially those from marginalized groups such as queer women, are being openly questioned.
Achievements
in the fight against violence against women are being pushed back and the rights of trans, inter and non-binary people are being called into question. We are opposing this with all our might.
Our goal is for the EU to become a guarantor of gender equality on our continent. Gender equality should permeate all policy areas of the Union. That is why we want to strengthen and expand the EIGE (European Institute for Gender Equality). This requires greater knowledge, more data and scientific expertise. This is another reason why we will continue to promote gender studies and defend them against attacks.
The EU Commission's Gender Equality Strategy, which expires in 2025, must be evaluated swiftly and comprehensively. Based on these results, we will draw up an ambitious plan in the coming legislative period in order to make great strides towards equality.
All people must be able to make their own decisions about their bodies and their lives. We therefore also want the EU to strengthen the self- determination rights of women and girls. This includes ensuring reproductive health and the right to physical self-determination and self- determined family planning for all. We want to strengthen unrestricted access to contraceptives. Professional advice on family planning is the basis for self-determined decisions.
It must be widely available in the EU. We support the initiative to enshrine the right to abortion in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Access to menstrual hygiene products is part of good healthcare. That is why we want to improve it.
Realizing equal opportunities on the labor market
Everyone benefitswhen women have better opportunities on the labor market. As engineers, educators, doctors and in countless other professions, they create prosperity - for Europe and for themselves: because fair participation in the labor market helps women to improve their economic situation and avoid poverty in old age, for example. We also want to pave the way politically to achieve this goal.
The gender pay gap, i.e. the gap between men's and women's wages, is wide in all EU countries. On average
It is 12.1 percent in Germany and even around 18 percent. The adoption of the Pay Transparency Directive was therefore a great success. It creates more transparency through the right to information and reports, compensation claims in the event of gender-based pay discrimination and thus strengthens the rights of female employees. We are doing everything we can to ensure that this directive is also implemented consistently in the member states. And, of course, so-called care professions, which are mainly carried out by women, must be upgraded through better working conditions and pay, and the fairer distribution of paid work and unpaid care work between women and men must be improved.
In order to create equal access and advancement opportunities for women in the labor market and to increase gender equality, the European Council issued a reconciliation directive. This is intended to enable parents to reconcile their professional and private lives as partners. With the family start time, which allows partners to take 14 days off work after the birth, the German government will take a further step towards fulfillment and support couples in the division of work between partners. We are continuing to push for the implementation and expansion of this directive. In particular, we want to encourage fathers to take parental leave. A good work-life balance for couples
is an effective measure to counteract the existing shortage of skilled workers by increasing the employment rate of women. Many women would like to work more, and more and more men would like to share family tasks equally - but the conditions do not allow it.
Particularly striking is the low proportion of women in all areas of the so-called STEM professions and the corresponding degree courses throughout Europe. Even though the number of female first-year students is increasing, this is not reflected in academic careers. This must change, because in view of the shortage of jobs and skilled workers, it would be downright negligent to forego this potential. Accordingly, we want to actively promote women and girls and, at the same time, improve the labor supply for the STEM sector. At EU level, we are also calling for better financing options for loans and equity financing for young female entrepreneurs and innovators through EU funds and programs, as well as easier access for women to existing funds, but also to well-paid jobs.
Enforce protection against violence
We want a Europe that offers protection and support for all victims of gender-based violence. We are committed to ensuring that violence against women is prevented, prosecuted and condemned through preventive measures. An important building block for this is the financial independence of women, especially mothers and their children, as it facilitates separation from violent partners and is therefore an important prerequisite for a self-determined life. The Istanbul Convention is the first instrument in Europe to lay down legally binding standards specifically to combat violence against women and domestic violence. Thanks to the German government's initiative, all reservations have finally been lifted in Germany.
To date, however, six member states - Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania and Slovakia - have not yet ratified this convention. It is therefore a
It is a great success that the EU itself has acceded to the Istanbul Convention comprehensively and without exceptions. We want all services provided by the Member States to protect women to at least meet the obligations of the Istanbul Convention and its explanatory report - including the standards for shelters, support centers for victims and emergency hotlines. In addition, intersectional protection concepts and shelters, especially for trans, inter and non-binary people, must be developed and provided. The supplementary new EU directive on combating violence against women and domestic violence must now also be adopted and implemented swiftly. We are committed to ensuring that the Istanbul Convention is also implemented with regard to the protection needs of trans, inter, lesbian and non-binary people.
is implemented.
Women affected by violence whose residence status depends on the residence status of their husband or partner should be able to obtain an independent residence permit. To make it easier for these women to claim and enforce their rights, they need low-threshold access to trained multilingual advice and support structures.
Sex workers also need rights and protection from violence, stigmatization and criminalization.
Strengthening women's rights and combating human trafficking
Human trafficking is a serious criminal offense and human rights violation that we must consistently combat through joint European action. The most widespread form of human trafficking in the EU is for the purpose of sexual exploitation. Trafficked persons are forced to work in prostitution under inhumane conditions. More than half of the victims of human trafficking for the purposeofsexual exploitation in the EU are EU citizens, predominantly women and girls.
We want to strengthen international cooperation in prevention, prosecution and protection.
of those affected along the lines of existing agreements. In order to better protect women from human trafficking and violence, we want to strengthen their rights. We are doing this by supportingthe upcoming revision of the
EU Victims' Rights Directive to ensure that all victims of crime are better protected. We want to strengthen access to information on victims' rights and ensure good coordination between the Member States, public bodies and judicial authorities. The protection of victims must be at the center of our actions. Deporting victims of human trafficking is wrong. Instead, we want to protect them through permanent residence rights and protection programs. This would also increase their willingness to report and testify and make it easier to prosecute the perpetrators.
Turning half the power into reality
As long as women are not adequately represented in key areas of the economy, politics and society, democracy is not complete. Even in Europe, we still have to look with a magnifying glass to find women on supervisory boards and management boards. We welcome the fact that the directive on management positions has finally come into force. The Commission must now ensure that the relevant quotas are achieved through regular reviews. After all, binding quotas are an effective means of ensuring that management bodies in business and politics are gender parity, including in the institutions of the EU itself. The Commission itself should also have gender parity.
To make financial power in Europe more gender- equitable, we want effective gender budgeting and gender equality checks
for the EU budget. We have succeeded in making future EU budgets fairer for all genders: The new Financial Regulation now stipulates that the allocation of EU funds by gender must be made transparent. We are committed to ensuring that this transparency is also emphasized in the negotiations with the Council and included in the Financial Regulation for the EU.
all funding is determined. This makes existing inequities in the distribution of funds visible and can be corrected. The Commission has also developed a method for measuring
of the impact of budget funds on equality. However, this still needs to be improved in some areas. Due to the new data situation, the next multiannual financial framework must be designed to be gender-equitable.
3. Europe's diversity
Strengthening civil society
Europe is characterized by its diversity and the coexistence of different people. Queer and non- queer people, people with and without disabilities, atheists and religious people, young and old each contribute their perspectives on life and shape our coexistence and our democracy. Our pluralistic democracy is strong because people in citizens' initiatives and parties, associations, non- governmental organizations (NGOs) and religious communities shape a vibrant civil society. It is the task of the EU to safeguard these freedoms.
We therefore support the European civil society in thinking and organizing itself across borders. In the European Parliament, we have successfully launched an initiative for a European law on associations. In this way, we are ensuring that civil society initiatives can operate with legal certainty throughout Europe.
Civil society initiatives are often the first point of contact for people who experience discrimination such as anti-Semitism, racism, misogyny or queerophobia and violence. We want to further promote and expand the existing advisory structures so that they can provide appropriate advice to those affected.
We are committed to ensuring that funding programs such as "Citizens, Equality, Rights and Values" (CERV) are adequately funded.
become. For example, we support initiatives and self-advocacy organizations that campaign against discrimination and for equal rights for all people and are particularly active in countries wherethe rule of law, democracy and minority rights are under particular pressure. We must also strengthen and safeguard the values of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, such as freedom of assembly, in the EU.
We firmly oppose the restriction of civil society's scope for action and are committed to the protection of human rights defenders within the EU.
Religion and faith are part of our cultures and have an integrative power for broad sections of society. They are the basis of many communities and institutions that contribute to cohesion. Religious freedom is constitutive for a diverse and free society. People who are persecuted because of their faith, non-faith or world view deserve our protection. We want to deepen interfaith dialogue and support communities in this,
to bring people of different faiths into contact with each other. We are convinced that mutual respect and dialog at eye level will strengthen our diverse Europe.
Overcoming discrimination
Safety, the right to physical integrity and civil rights apply to all people. They are the prerequisite for a life
in freedom. They must apply regardless of where a person comes from, how he or she loves, lives or believes. A Europe that holds together in its diversity and protects the rights of each and every individual creates democratic progress, participation and freedom for all. However, people in Europe are still exposed to violence and exclusion due to anti-Semitism, racism and other forms of group-based misanthropy. We want to eliminate discrimination at all levels.
In order to fulfill the promise of a diverse Europe of participation, the EU must take consistent legal action against discrimination.
approach. We want to draw particular attention to multiple discrimination.
Anti-Semitism is still deeply entrenched in the heart of European society. Jewish institutions are threatened and attacked.
We are resolutely opposed to this. This applies in particular to us as Germany and to the promise "Never again!", to which Europe also committed itself after the Second World War and the Shoah. It is the responsibility of all member states to guarantee the safety of Jewish communities and to ensure that Jews in Europe have a secure future.
We are therefore in favor of increasing European funding for security projects to support them in this. As Europeans, it is not
It is not only our task to counter anti-Semitism in all its forms, but also to make Jewish life visible in all its diversity and to strengthen it. Culture plays an important role in this. The perspectives of Jewish artists are an important part of European culture. Discrimination and boycotts against Jews must therefore be resolutely opposed. In order to impart knowledge about Jewish life in general as well as contacts and experiences with Jewish people throughout Europe, we want to promote political and cultural education programs.
Muslims are the second largest religious community in Europe. Muslim life is part of Europe and at the same time has become the target of right-wing and conspiracy ideology movements.
We welcome the fact that, after a long time, the EU has finally filled the position of EU coordinator against Islamophobia. We want to strengthen her role.
We want the fight against antigypsyism to become a new priority and move away from paternalistic approaches. People with a Romani background are often disadvantaged when it comes to access to education, health, housing and work. We are setting up a European advisory body to promote political participation and the fight against racism against Sinti*zze and Rom*nja. This includes
We work with experts, self-advocacy organizations and local and regional authorities, among others. We advocate the introduction of binding laws to promote equal participation.
People who experience discrimination, whether by public institutions, in housing or on the labor market, must not be left alone, but must know that the law is on their side. The EU has the potential to improve protection against discrimination, be it on the basis of social origin, racial discrimination, sexual orientation, disability or age. We want to make consistent use of this. In order to standardize and strengthen the level of protection and close gaps in protection, we want, among other things, the 5th Anti-Discrimination Directive to finally be adopted. Germany should also give up its reservation. We stand firmly by the side of people who experience violence as a result of discrimination and want to support them, for example by providing access to legal, medical and psychological advice. We want to strengthen the systematic recording of cases of discrimination throughout Europe in order to further develop European anti-discrimination work in a targeted and scientifically sound manner.
We want to promote research into racism and its various forms, such as anti-black racism, at European level. The
We are driving forward the UN Decade for People of African Descent. Measures to reduce racism, anti-Semitism and discrimination should be developed with the continuous involvement of experts and self-advocacy organizations. We also want the EU to support member states, for example through training, in counteracting discriminatory attitudes in law enforcement agencies. The office of the European Commission's Anti-Racism Commissioner should be strengthened and staffed beyond 2025. We support the Minority Safe Pack initiative and want to strengthen minority rights such as the preservation of language, culture and identity in the EU. We also need an independent institutional European
Promotion of national minorities. In order to guarantee minority rights in the EU, the responsibility for the protection of national minorities and autochthonous ethnic groups should be bindingly regulated within the EU Commission.
The diversity of European society is currently not adequately reflected in the staff of the European Commission. We are therefore working to ensure that the Commission, as an employer, actively develops and implements concepts for discrimination-sensitive opening, for example in application procedures.
Protecting queer rights
The opportunity to develop freely and live in one's own individuality is a core of European values.
Although queer people have been able to successfully fight for many of their rights in recent decades, we are seeing authoritarian forces trying to roll them back. Queer people still do not have access to non-discriminatory healthcare, a self- determined change in their gender registration or marriage everywhere. It is not uncommon for lesbian, gay, bi, trans*, inter* and queer people (LGBTIQ*) to be unable to lead a self-determined life in safety because their rights are restricted or they are hostile, pathologized or attacked in everyday life and queer hostility is widespread in large parts of society. We do not accept this and clearly oppose these attempts, regardless of their motivation or who they come from. We want a Europe that recognizes sexual and gender diversity as a matter of course.
On our initiative, the European Parliament has declared the EU an "LGBTIQ* Freedom Zone". On this basis, we are committed to ensuring that the EU Commission and the Council use all the instruments at their disposal - including
infringement proceedings and sanctions - to stop the systematic actions of governments against LGBTIQ* people and the dismantling of democracy and the rule of law.
pen. In this way, we are strengthening the community in its fight for its rights in these countries.
In order to combat queer hostility, we are committed to continuing the European Commission's LGBTIQ* equality strategy beyond 2025 and are working towards its further development with the participation of civil society. We want to set up an EU-wide multilingual advice hotline to which victims of queer hostility can turn for low-threshold advice.
Family is where people take responsibility for each other - for example with two mothers, two fathers, several parents, single parents or with a mother and father. We are committed to equality for two- mother families and for a non-discriminatory life for rainbow families. National borders must not determine whether children grow up with their parents, because the right to freedom of movement must also apply to rainbow families without ifs and buts. We are fighting for parenthood, registered partnerships, extended custody declarations and same-sex marriages established in one EU country to be recognized throughout the EU.
Realizing an inclusive society
We want an inclusive society that overcomes disadvantages of all kinds and offers equal opportunities and possibilities to all people. Consistently removing barriers ensures cohesion, prosperity and freedom. The European disability movement has successfully campaigned for their right to equality and participation. With the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the EU member states have committed themselves to removing all barriers that stand in the way of participation in political and social life. We want to ensure that this finally becomes a reality throughout Europe.
In order to enable self-determined living, we want to provide greater support for independent living, inclusive living and working. In particular, we want to promote participation in work
and training in the regular system and consistently expand them. The Commission should regularly review the progress made in the Member States. We want to further develop the sheltered workshop system in the direction of inclusive companies - because social protection and minimum wages must also apply to people with disabilities. EU funds should not flow into forms of work that are contrary to Article 27 of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and inclusion companies should be promoted more strongly.
The needs-based expansion of affordable, barrier- free and disabled-friendly housing and self- determined forms of living is and remains a central task in shaping an inclusive society.
People with disabilities are more affected by violence than non-disabled people. We want protection from violence to apply to all people in Europe. We are committed to ensuring that forced sterilizations, which particularly affect women and girls with disabilities, are ended in Europe and made a punishable offence.
Poor usability of websites, steps without ramps, doors that are too narrow - people with disabilities, but also older people or people with limited mobility, experience various barriers in their everyday lives that restrict their participation in public life. We are committed to ensuring that the EU Accessibility Directive, known as the European Accessibility Act (EAA), is implemented and enforceable in all member states - including Germany - in a timely manner. In order to support the member states in implementing accessibility measures in a coherent manner, we want to set up an EU Accessibility Center.
We want to strengthen and consolidate the office of the Equal Opportunities Commissioner. We want to remove bureaucratic hurdles and technical standards that prevent people with disabilities from participating and check that they are barrier-free.
In order to guarantee European freedom of movement for people with disabilities, we want to
We will introduce a European disability card that can be applied for at a low threshold, implement mutual recognition of national definitions of disability and barrier-free travel throughout Europe. This also applies to the use of social benefits.
4. A vibrant cultural landscape
Culture as a pillar of democracy
Few things unite Europe as much as its diverse, vibrant culture. It arises from the interplay of traditions from the entire continent
with external influences and the constant development of new forms of expression. Culture is a value in itself and at the same time an indispensable part of European democracy, because it is here that exchange and coexistence across borders take place in the most diverse ways. An open and diverse culture is the best protection against nationalistic thinking, isolationism and lack of freedom. Because of their indispensability for a consolidated democratic society, cultural institutions and cultural workers are put under massive pressure and even attacked by right-wing extremist forces. We therefore defend free art and culture against anti-democrats and state interference and support them through public funding that enables artistic creativity beyond the logic of the market.
We therefore want to expand the "Creative Europe" program financially and simplify it significantly in order to facilitate cooperation and exchange between artists and cultural organizers throughout Europe. It should see itself as a service provider for cultural professionals that is approachable and provides fast and targeted support. The independent scene in particular should be given new access to strengthen European exchange, for example for ensembles and groups that work together across borders. To this end, we are also developing offers for groups that have been separated due to flight and migration.
The EU must guarantee and support the freedom of culture and its diversity. We therefore want to shape cultural funding in such a way that it is also open to those who have few own resources or no national funding.
The goal of climate neutrality is particularly relevant to the European dimension of culture, which thrives on the movement of cultural assets and people. We therefore want to create a program within the framework of Creative Europe in which advice and funding for the transformation of European cultural cooperation towards climate neutrality are bundled. We also want to further develop the idea of the New European Bauhaus, which promotes an interdisciplinary approach to climate-neutral building and design, in a participatory manner and anchor it as a separate mission in Horizon Europe.
Cross-border cultural exchange also requires unbureaucratic and fair regulations for the taxation of income from artistic activities that avoid double taxation.
The European Capitals of Culture program allows us to experience and promote the diversity of our continent. We want to continue this successful concept, but at the same time review the application procedures and make them more transparent.
European culture also includes its growing structure of independent and diverse cultural and creative industries with small and medium-sized enterprises. They create games, films, series and books, work in the design industry, the art market, the music industry, the press market, architecture, the broadcasting industry, the performing arts and the advertising market. They are key drivers of innovation and growth - far beyond their own sector. We want to promote these structures and protect them against the market power of the large international platforms, for example by advocating the preservation of the cultural exception in trade agreements. We want to strengthen the local structure of bookshops by working to ensure that price-
bound books are exempt from the rules of European public procurement law.
With the KulturPass, the federal government has introduced a new, innovative cultural policy instrument: Young people are given a budget to discover art and culture in all its diversity and breadth. In this way, we are also strengthening cultural institutions. Building on similar projects in France, Spain and Italy, we now want to introduce a joint European cultural passport so that young people can explore and discover the wealth and diversity of culture in Europe across borders.
Strengthening creativity
The creative power of artists and creatives is the basis for our vibrant cultural landscape. In the face of technological and societal changes, they must constantly reassert their place in the exploitation chain of cultural production. This applies above all to the new developments in artificial intelligence (AI). This uses images, sounds and texts created by humans togenerate new content. AI products compete with human creators. We are therefore committed to ensuring that authors can exercise their reservation of use and, where applicable, other rights vis-à-vis commercial AI simply and centrally and, where appropriate, in a machine- readable manner. Copyright law should continue to protect the creative work of natural persons and must not be extended to automatically generated content from AI systems. We want authors
to support the fair remuneration of their works
and at the same time strengthen access to knowledge and culture for all in order to create good conditions for the creatives of tomorrow. Work users as well as authors and other cultural professionals such as actors and musicians must havea seat at the table when the course of the digitalized cultural world is being negotiated. In the interest of equal opportunities, we also want to enable digital lending (e-lending) of content in the context of libraries, educational and research institutions, as has been the case to date.
By extending the Erasmus program to artists and creatives, we want to further strengthen the mobility and European perspective of cultural professionals. We want to offer a safe haven and support opportunities for cultural workers who are at risk of persecution outside the EU.
We also want to close the gender pay gap in culture. We will strengthen the role of women in the cultural sector, for example by advocating equal representation on awarding bodies and juries in the EU.
Guaranteeing media freedom
Free and democratically oriented media are an indispensable basis for the formation of public opinion. This foundation is also under attack in EU member states today. We therefore support more transparency about ownership structures and binding instruments to combat the restriction of press freedom - be it in the form of open censorship, through the control and centralization of publisher ownership or by other means. Here, too, we believe that all control mechanisms must follow the principle of independence from the state. Media freedom also means that journalists and editors can work freely within the framework of professional standards or editorial statutes. A new European body for media services must not undermine existing media rights and freedoms in Germany. In order to protect journalists and their sources from surveillance and persecution, we call for effective regulation and judicial control of the use o f	spyware. We will take action against misuse. We want to effectively protect whistleblowers from persecution.
Excessive concentration of media ownership, including in individual EU states, must be effectively prevented - if necessary by splitting up companies or ownership structures. Transparency of ownership structures is essential for this. This is the basis for a diverse press landscape that enables journalists to report freely and critically.
The economic model of private media in print and online is also severely impaired by false incentive structures in the competition for advertising revenue and the market power of social media platforms. This is threatening the existence of more and more quality media and is a pressing problem for diversity of opinion. We are therefore striving to use suitable instruments to improve the competitive situation for journalistic offerings - especially online - and to develop practicable financing instruments at member state level to strengthen journalistic content, develop sustainable business models and ensure a nationwide supply of journalistic offerings.
Where new technologies such as generative AI are used, we advocate clear labeling of AI-generated images, texts and videos.
The EU's cross-border and linguistic area poses a particular challenge for the development of a common public sphere. We therefore advocate the expansion of transnational and multilingual public service broadcasting. Specifically, we first want to expand the successful approach of the arte channel and gradually develop it into a joint European offering.
In addition, we are committed to networking the offerings of public service broadcasting in Europe and to improving findability.
European cultural and media offerings online. In this way, we want to create a fully-fledged European, public media offering in the long term, with a comprehensive and transnational offering of news, sport, culture and entertainment, for example in the form of a European media portal.
The
is also a contribution against disinformation and conspiracy myths. We want to create support and protection for media in exile so that the EU can also be a space of free expression for people from countries where freedom of the press and freedom of opinion are suppressed.
European remembrance
The memory of past injustice is one of the foundations of all societies. Europe as a continent was not only characterized by war and violence for centuries; war and violence also emanated from here for centuries. As a peace project, the EU has the task of relating these perspectives to one another. Remembrance should contribute to reconciliation and understanding, not divide. It is important to promote a multi-perspective culture of remembrance that also takes into account the history of groups that have been unjustly ignored. We want to strengthen cross-border cooperation and are committed to preserving existing places of collective remembrance, commemoration and reflection as well as creating new ones. We want to use European funds to support initiatives that are dedicated to the task of understanding and, for example, make the historically overlapping experiences of violence caused by Germany's war of aggression and the oppression by the Soviet Union understandable and comprehensible in their complex legacy in Eastern Europe. Here
This also includes cooperation with schools,
universities and cultural institutions as well as supporting civil society actors. We firmly oppose efforts to reinterpret history in the service of nationalist tendencies.
We clearly oppose all attempts to draw a "line" under the memory of the crimes of National Socialism and especially the Shoah or to make them harmless. They are incompatible with democratic values. We will not leave this unanswered - not in Germany, not in Europe, not anywhere.
The cruel history of genocide, colonialism, enslavement and exploitation in Africa, Latin America and Asia is also part of the European legacy. Even during the emergence of the European peace project, colonial violence and economic exploitation persisted. Many European states and companies were involved in these crimes, and Europe still benefits today from the dependencies created at that time.
capabilities. That is why we want to work closely with descendants, researchers and civil society initiatives from formerly colonized areas to come to terms with colonial history, including at a European level, and strive for reparations. This includes the restitution of looted art or human remains, for example, but also the promotion of educational work and the strengthening of multi- perspective historical research. The effects of colonialism o n today's societies should become more visible. To this end, we want to strengthen the remembrance policy dimension in thematically appropriate EU funding programs.
Fair play in sport
Whether it's amateur soccer or the Champions League, a bike ride or the Tour de France - sport is at the heart of Europe. Exercise and sport unites people, creates and conveys regional identities, provides a topic of conversation and contributes to the development of Europe.
to health. The focus is on the many people who volunteer in clubs and associations. We want to strengthen organizations and initiatives that are particularly committed to social cohesion, democracy and equality as well as combating exclusion and hatred. We want t o make European funding more easily accessible for them - sports organizations should also be strengthened as important civil society partners outside of Europe.
Sport can only act as a role model and unite people if it functions fairly and transparently and if clubs and associations act in accordance with the law.
Fraud, doping and corruption are diametrically opposed to its essence. We therefore want to establish an independent European agency that works with NGOs, anti-corruption experts and international investigators to ensure transparency, integrity and genuine accountability in cases of corruption and fraud in global sport.
In this way, we want to restore trust. This is also a basis for international
Major sporting events in Europe will continue to have their place. If they work with clear and reliable standards for social and ecological fairness and sustainability, they can gain a competitive advantage worldwide and set an example. We are particularly committed to the cross-border organization of sporting events that protect the climate and the environment. In this way, we make top-class European sport a shared experience.
We want to make sport resilient to the effects of the climate crisis. Many sports depend on an intact natural environment, but at the same time sport causes damage. Through a new European program, we want to show ways in which Europe's diverse sports scene can contribute to meeting climate targets and develop. Our aim is to ensure that sporting events can be held in a climate-neutral way.
5. Refugee and migration policy of humanity and order
Fighting the causes of flight
The number of people displaced by wars, the climate crisis or a lack of economic prospects has doubled worldwide in the last ten years. The vast majority of people are fleeing within their own country or to neighboring regions. However, we are also noticing the effects of the increasing numbers of refugees in Europe. We are facing up to this responsibility, because flight and migration are a historical and global reality and will remain so. The suffering that people experience on escape routes to Europe and at Europe's external borders is intolerable. The fact that people still take these routes shows how great the suffering, danger and lack of prospects are in many regions of the world.
Tightening asylum laws does not tackle the causes of migration. The policies of the EU and its members must recognize their global responsibility.
and also contribute to enabling people in their home regions to live a safe and peaceful life. By expanding reliable humanitarian aid and structure-building transitional aid in crisis regions, we can support people in acute emergencies. In this way, we help to alleviate suffering directly on the ground. With development cooperation on an equal footing and fair trade relations, we can contribute to improving people's prospects in the long term. At the same time, Europe must not close itself off, especially in the face of many crises and disasters, but must take on a fair share of the responsibility for taking in people seeking protection. We advocate the rule of law and humane treatment of people seeking protection in Europe.
Welcoming skilled workers and employees
Europe is facing demographic change with a rapidly ageing population and is desperately looking for skilled workers. In order to secure our future, we must become more attractive in the global competition for skilled workers and labor and shape immigration in a modern way. It is important to us that the interests of the countries of origin are also taken into account, as skilled workers are also needed there. Instead of bureaucratic and lengthy procedures, we want to promote the immigration of specialists and workers with different levels of qualifications with EU-wide common framework regulations. This includes making the recognition of educational qualifications from third countries uniform and unbureaucratic.
In order to recruit qualified specialists, we want to further expand the EU talent pool. This requires more staff in the European embassies and a digitalization offensive so that applications can be submitted quickly and digitally.
An active welcoming culture also makes us attractive as a business location. To achieve this, we must counter racism and exclusion. We want to create targeted integration opportunities for the various forms of migration throughout Europe. In order to offer good
and rapid integration on the ground, we want to strengthen the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF). This will enable local authorities to prepare for the admission of skilled workers and their families. In addition, the rights of third- country nationals living here permanently must be protected and preserved. That is why we support an improvement of the Permanent Residence Directive in this direction. We want to promote voluntary circular migration and also train future skilled workers in Europe.
We want to protect all workers against exploitation
- including undocumented workers. Fair working conditions must not depend on origin. To this end, we want to expand multilingual and low-threshold complaint and advice structures and strengthen trade union structures so that all workers can turn to them.
Tackling common asylum policy
We are fighting for an EU that guarantees access to the human right to asylum and complies with humanitarian and international legal obligations such as the UN Refugee Convention. We are currently a long way from achieving this goal. The human rights of refugees are being violated in many places, including at Europe's borders and in EU countries, and disregard for EU law has become part of everyday asylum policy. This has not created order and structure, but more chaos and suffering. The Dublin system is unjust and does not meet the current challenges.
A long-term, orderly and fair common EU asylum policy is needed to put an end to the inhumane and chaotic conditions.
Reforms alone are not enough; existing EU law must also be enforced. We are campaigning against the Common European Asylum System (CEAS) becoming a program to dismantle refugee rights.
We want to use the scope for improvement. With a fair and binding distribution of people seeking protection, we are strengthening solidarity between the member states. Isolation and border fences create chaos and suffering, the rule of law
fair procedures, good integration offers and humane conditions ensure humanity and order.
Countries with Europe's external borders are particularly dependent on orderly distribution and support from the EU as well as solidarity in legal border management. Our goal is a binding distribution mechanism for people seeking protection. On the way there, a permanent, reliable and binding solidarity mechanism should significantly improve distribution.
In order to overcome the common challenges, all member states must get involved - whether by taking in people seeking protection or by providing financial support for the reception of refugees.
Contributions in cash or in kind to third countries are not compensation. Member States that take in refugees to a particularly large extent must be strengthened and financially relieved.
Many municipalities in the EU are prepared to take a bold approach and assume responsibility. We welcome these efforts and are committed to supporting precisely those municipalities that do not receive this support from their national governments. We would like to expand the possibility for municipalities and aid organizations to access the AMIF more directly. European networking and exchange between municipalities can help with integration. This can be seen, for example, in
the successful establishment of cross-border networks of municipalities. When it comes to the distribution of refugees at European level, we want to bring the resources of the federal states and municipalities in line with the needs of the refugees via a matching mechanism. This should take into account family backgrounds, language skills and professional qualifications, for example.
EU states that receive a disproportionately high number of refugees as a result of the application of the mass influx directive must receive fair financial support from other states, as provided for in the directive. We oppose
the so-called screening within the sovereign territory. The registration of minors must not lead to a violation of children's rights.
The mass influx directive was a good tool in dealing with the millions of refugees from Ukraine. We want to analyze the experiences of this unbureaucratic and pragmatic approach in detail and develop proposals for asylum policy.
It is unacceptable that individual member states treat refugees so badly that courts consider it unreasonable for them to remain there. Everyone has a fundamental right to be guaranteed a humane minimum standard of living. The Reception Directive ensures that people seeking protection in every Member State are guaranteed living and humane conditions, and standards based on the rule of law must be guaranteed throughout the EU. We are therefore committed to ensuring that the EU Commission and the Council use the instruments available to them to stop the abuse of EU law and the criminalization of humanitarian aid. This also includes freezing EU funds if national governments systematically break EU law. The EU Asylum Agency should support the member states, particularly in asylum procedures, and ensure that asylum applications are processed swiftly in accordance with the rule of law. It can help to prevent congestion.
Ensuring humanity and order at the external borders
The EU is an area of freedom, security and justice. The right to freedom of movement and the dismantling of borders within Europe was and is one of the greatest achievements in bringing the European community together. We therefore reject permanent and stationary internal border controls.
It goes without saying that the EU must control its external borders - and this is not just about migration. For freedom and security at home, we also need to know who is coming to Europe.
The fact that constitutional controls or reliable registration at the external borders have nothing to do with unlawful isolation against asylum seekers can be seen in the movement of refugees from Ukraine. Millions of people are reliably checked but have been able to find protection in the EU. Unfortunately, however, many other asylum seekers do not encounter constitutional controls at EU borders, but rather injustice and violence.
The credibility of European values, and therefore the influence of European policy on the outside world, requires respect for the law and values in our own actions. It is difficult to reconcile this realization with the fact that the European promise of humanity and the rule of law is shattered for thousands of people every year by barbed wire and patrol boats. We oppose violations of the rule of law, freedom of the press and human rights as well as the unlawful push-back of refugees.
People seeking protection in Europe must be reliably registered, provided with initial care and housed in a humane manner. The right to a case- by-case assessment and the principle of non- refoulement apply everywhere and at all times. The asylum applications of people who arrive in the EU or are already here must be examined in Europe. Border procedures must not lead tothe creation of further large detention camps such as Moria at the external borders, which violate the dignity and rights of people seeking protection. We oppose the disenfranchisement of people who are instrumentalized by authoritarian states.
Despite the principles enshrined in international and European law, we repeatedly experience systematic violations of the law at Europe's external borders.
People are subjected to mistreatment, denied access to the asylum procedure or denied the right to asylum.
they are abandoned to their fate in distress at sea. We are committed to ensuring that illegal pushbacks are consistently punished and sanctioned legally and politically. We also want to strengthen the EU Fundamental Rights Agency and further expand the state and civil society human rights monitoring system. An independent
Monitoring with investigative powers at the external borders should be made possible. Aid and human rights organizations as well as lawyers need access to refugees and border regions at all times. Free reporting by journalists must be guaranteed.
Cooperation between the EU and third countries must always be based on fundamental and human rights. We want to finally end cooperation with the Libyan coast guard.
Border controls at the external borders are an EU Community task that should increasingly be carried out by European officials. That is why we want to further develop Frontex in line with the rule of law. This means that Frontex must not participate in operations that violate human rights and must end such operations consistently and promptly, as provided for in the Frontex Regulation. At the same time, Frontex operations must be subject to close parliamentary scrutiny.
We are committedtoensuring that Frontex is better monitored not only by the European Parliament, but also by national parliaments. This also includes access to mission reports. It must become easier to hold Frontex accountable for violations of the law, for example through a separate liability basis.
We stand resolutely by the side of the many committed people who care for and advise refugees. The fact that refugee aid is made more difficult or even punishable in many countries is unacceptable. We want to work to ensure that support for refugees is not hindered, but made possible. We want to ensure that NGOs and lawyers have unhindered access to them in order to carry out their humanitarian work. We must pay particular attention to the needs of particularly vulnerable groups such as women, queer people, children and people with disabilities. This includes safe accommodation as well as trained counseling structures and interpreters. Voluntary counseling structures do important work, especially for vulnerable groups. We want to strengthen them through state and professional support, among other things.
Millions of children are fleeing wars, violence, hunger or political persecution alone or with their parents. We must protect them better from criminal structures. Children must be accommodated and cared for in a child-friendly manner; this applies to all children in Germany as well as at Europe's external borders. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child also applies without restriction to refugee children, regardless of where they are. People must not be detained simply because they apply for asylum. Families with children should never be subject to border procedures
and Member States are not obliged to carry out border procedures.
Migration agreements, lane changes and safe returns
All people seeking protection in Europe have a right to fair asylum procedures based on the rule of law. We demand that they have access to independent asylum advice in order to know and assert their rights. Legal recourse against negative decisions must always be open.
At the same time, we know that not all asylum procedures lead to a residence permit. Anyone who has not been granted a residence permit after careful examination of the requirements under asylum and residence law and after exhausting all legal remedies must leave the country quickly - provided there are no obstacles to deportation.
Returns are always associated with particular human hardship. We want voluntary return to take precedence over forced return measures. That is why we are committed to Europe-wide, open-ended and independent return counseling.
It is also clear that people may not be deported to countries where there are reasons of human rights or international law to the contrary. People may only be returned to countries to which the person concerned has a clear connection. It must be ensured that these countries respect the rule of law when dealing with refugees. We continue to support the concept of safe third countries
wrong. The conclusion of migration agreements with countries of origin and transit must be based on human rights, and cooperation with the respective countries must be based on partnership and on an equal footing. It must not be made dependent on financial support as part of development cooperation and should also serve to combat the causes of flight. The agreements should give the population prospects and not strengthen autocratic regimes.
