The ÖDP's understanding of education expressly does not exclude the practical orientation of educational measures. Rather, the aim must be to dovetail practice and critical reflection. Particularly in the area of vocational qualification, training measures should be geared towards the specific occupational requirements. At the same time, working conditions and the economic and political framework conditions affecting them must always be scrutinized. Even in the so-called "general education" system, life references should - where possible - be established in order to develop concrete skills. The ÖDP advocates progressive approaches in this area that break down the traditional divide between education and practice.
The ÖDP is therefore calling for this at EU level:
 Implementation of the human right to education, as set out in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (Art. 26),
i.e. orientation of education policy towards the full development of people.
 It must be possible for everyone to continue their education and personal development even at an advanced age.
 Introduction of a different understanding of "lifelong learning" at EU level and corresponding adaptation of EU treaties. It should no longer just be about adapting to technology and market requirements, but about the opportunity for personal development.
 Financial aspects must not be an obstacle to participation in educational measures.
 The European Commission's "skilled workers on demand"16 approach for universities must be ended immediately.
16 The European Commission is calling for universities to be restructured in such a way that they produce the graduates that the economy needs. Students' personal educational a s p i r a t i o n s do not play a role in this.
 Promotion of practice-oriented approaches both in the so-called "general education" system and in the area of vocational education and training.
 The European Qualifications Framework and the classifications of the national qualifications frameworks must be further developed so that the basis for classification is no longer educational certificates but actual knowledge, skills and competences.
 The European Qualifications Framework for the comparability of European qualifications needs to be more differentiated overall in order to adequately reflect qualifications.
 Project funding for the introduction of educational measures that promote and increase people's awareness of the interrelationships and mechanisms of action in nature.
 Organize competitions for educational institutions that focus on the sensitivity of nature.
 Expansion of educational measures aimed at respecting and upholding human rights and democratic values.
 Promotion of didactic approaches to political education and democracy education and networking of the educational institutions supported.
 Promotion of innovative educational institutions that focus more strongly on musical, artistic, sports and humanities education in their didactic approaches.
 Strengthening extracurricular education (e.g. clubs, youth associations).
 Generally launching programs to support the financially disadvantaged to participate in educational measures.
Work
The extremely different living conditions within the EU and worldwide have led to labor migration. This has a whole range of negative consequences such as wage dumping and undeclared work, growing competition in the low-wage sector and for affordable housing, ghettoization and social imbalances - even within the EU member states. Cross-border labor migration often deprives the countries of origin of important skilled workers trained there. To avoid these negative consequences, both the world of work and labor migration need clear framework conditions. European legislation on migration should focus in particular on comparatively motivated and adaptable workers.
To date, the EU has been involved in the negotiations on TiSA within the framework of the WTO. Everything known so far from the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) violates the values of the EU. For example, workers coming from non-EU countries are to be paid and treated according to the country of posting, not according to the social and labor regulations of the EU country in which the service is provided.
The ÖDP is therefore calling for this at EU level:
 The immediate withdrawal of the EU from the TiSA negotiations.
 For the world of work:
 Principle of "equal pay for work of equal value" instead of "equal pay for equal work".
 Enforcement of the right to form trade unions and protection and expansion of employees' co-determination rights.
 Legal guarantee of living wages for all workers.
 Right to (paid) further training for employees.
 Expansion of exchange programs for young people such as Erasmus+.
 EU-wide maternity protection regulations: Extension of the minimum period of maternity protection to 18 weeks, including at least two weeks before delivery.
 Continued payment of 100% of the salary subject to social insurance contributions during maternity protection.
 Adapting occupational health and safety to the challenges of a changing world of work.
 Protection of whistleblowers in companies.
 For labor migration from EU countries:
 Narrow interpretation of the work contract regulation so that it can no longer be used to circumvent employment subject to social security contributions.
 Compliance with the environmental, social and employment standards (including minimum wage) of the member state in which the service is provided.
 For labor migration from non-EU countries:
 The creation of a uniform European immigration law that offers fair opportunities for legal immigration into the EU, but does not lead to an excessive exodus of well-qualified skilled workers from the countries of origin.
 Minimum protection of employee rights in accordance with the core labor standards of the International Labor Organization (ILO).
 Creation of a social security system that is comparable in all EU member states, taking into account national circumstances.
 Practice-oriented training in which attention is paid to professional and linguistic qualifications and cultural integration. Conveying the guiding principle of the European idea and commitment to the common good.
 A probationary period with regard to the residence permit, which serves the purpose of probation and prevents the pursuit of social benefits. Application of the "demand and encourage" principle.
Combating the causes of flight - humane asylum and refugee policy
Flight and migration - especially to neighboring countries - have many causes: Wars and civil wars, often involving the use of German weapons, persecution on religious grounds, mismanagement and corruption and the consequences of free trade agreements and the way of life and economy of industrialized nations. Increasingly, climate change is one of the causes or the main cause of flight and migration. As refugees are usually denied normal travel options, they often fall into the clutches of organized traffickers and attempt to reach Europe at the risk of life and limb.
We are partly responsible for many of the causes of flight. The current policy of the EU and its member states does too little overall to address them: promoting just structures, respect for human rights and good governance in the world, fair trade relations, peaceful resolution of conflicts and the fight against climate change and its consequences. This leads to hunger, unbearable hardship, oppression and conflict and, as a result, to flight and displacement.
Granting asylum and implementing the Geneva Convention on Refugees is our duty and an indispensable act of humanity. Europe cannot take in all refugees, but we reject the idea of sealing ourselves off in a "Fortress Europe". The Dublin procedure places an excessive burden on member states at the EU's external borders and the preferred destination countries in the center and north of Europe, pushing them to the limits of what is possible or desirable.
The ÖDP is therefore calling for this at EU level:
 A common European asylum law.
 Eliminating the causes of flight:
 Conversion of all trade contracts into fair trade contracts.
 Helping people to help themselves and supporting reparation and reconciliation processes in crisis regions.
 Economical and efficient use of raw materials.
 No arms exports outside the EU and NATO, unless a country is defending itself against an attack in violation of international law.
 Humane treatment of refugees at the EU's external borders and in the host countries and more consistent monitoring of compliance with human rights by the European border and coast guard agency Frontex.
 Fair distribution of refugees or financial compensation according to the population and economic capacity of the EU member states. Abolition of the unfair distribution of refugees, as is currently carried out by means of the "third country regulation" of the Dublin Agreement.
 Creating opportunities to apply for asylum in the EU outside the borders of EU states.
 Combating human trafficking by opening up safe and legal escape routes.
 Residence permit on humanitarian grounds for quota refugees until return to their home country is possible.
 Expansion of the organized admission of particularly vulnerable refugees recognized by the UN Refugee Agency UNHCR who can neither return to their home country nor remain in their first country of refuge (resettlement programmes).
 More financial aid for refugee camps outside the EU.
 Recognition of climate refugees.
 Creation or expansion of permanent prospects for rejected asylum seekers in their home countries.
 Securing funding for the UNHCR and the World Food Program (WFP).
Life protection and bioethics
Human dignity is inviolable, regardless of the stage of life, physical and mental health and state of consciousness. An elementary expression of this dignity is the right to life of every human being, from conception to death, as well as the principle that human beings must never be regarded as objects and under aspects of use or commercialization.
The inviolability of human dignity and the right to life are increasingly being questioned and threatened, especially at the beginning and end of life. The ÖDP is committed to upholding these fundamental rights. Prenatal and pre-implantation diagnostics must not be used to select and kill people.
The ÖDP consistently opposes any commercialization that violates human dignity. This includes surrogate motherhood, which disregards the relationship between mother and child during pregnancy and its importance for the child's further development, as well as commercial organ donations, which open the door to the abuse of people as spare parts stores for organs.
The ÖDP is opposed to the right to direct active euthanasia, as this entails the risk of pressure being exerted on the elderly and seriously ill or their relatives to consent to euthanasia, especially if palliative care cannot be guaranteed due to a lack of care facilities or financial resources.
Genetic engineering, cloning and research on and with e m b r y o s raise further ethical questions. New findings in research and medical practice as well as social change must be considered in the light of fundamental values, above all human dignity.
and must be discussed comprehensively in society. This is often done inadequately and too late.
Modern biochemical techniques such as CRISPR/Cas make it possible to easily modify the genetic make-up of living organisms. Although they offer enormous potential for research, biotechnology and medicine, they also open up opportunities for misuse, such as the optimization of human embryos. The ÖDP opposes this.
Genetic modifications of germline cells are hereditary and cannot be reversed if genetically modified organisms are released into the environment. That is why the ÖDP rejects the release of any kind of genetically modified organisms.
The ÖDP is therefore calling for this at EU level:
 Creation of child- and family-friendly structures in social services, the economy and the world of work as well as the provision of comprehensive support for pregnant women in conflict situations, so that a yes to the child is made possible and supported and the number of abortions is reduced.
 Consistent implementation and further development of the EU strategy in favor of people with disabilities, especially with regard to comprehensive support for parents who are expecting a child with a probable disability or who have a child with a disability.
 Programs for the EU-wide adoption of children from emergency situations, e.g. those conceived by women raped in war zones, as well as medical, psychological and material support for women in emergency situations during pregnancy and after birth.
 Prohibition of surrogacy and the associated physical and psychological exploitation of women.
 No selection of embryos, for example through prenatal and pre- implantation diagnostics.
 Comprehensive embryo protection. A ban on the production and import of human embryonic cell lines.
 Ban on human cloning and genetic enhancement17 as well as genetic engineering interventions in the human germline.
 No obligation to donate organs in member states and ban on organ trafficking.
 Directive on the needs-based expansion of palliative care and corresponding financing of hospice units and
-services.
 No patenting of genetic material. Genetic diversity is a common good.
 Restricting the use of genetic engineering methods, taking into account strict ethical criteria and possible risks to humans and the environment.
17 Targeted manipulation of the human genome to induce desired characteristics or suppress undesired ones. Schleicher, N.: Art. "Enhancement" (Version 1.0 from 08.02.2017) in: Ethik-Lexikon, available at: https://www.ethik-lexikon.de/lexikon/enhancement.
Civil rights, data protection and internal security
in digital progress
As a society and, above all, as human beings, we are facing a multitude of challenges as digitalization progresses with its diverse communication and data processing possibilities, especially when it comes to safeguarding our civil rights, protecting our personal data and maintaining internal security. In this development, the ÖDP is committed to future-oriented digitalization: It wants to use and promote the potential of digital solutions, but at the same time protect the rights and interests of all citizens from the numerous encroachments of profit- and power-hungry Internet players and support digital projects that have a lasting positive effect on our living space and the common good. The ÖDP also represents the guidelines set out by the German Ethics Council on digitalization.18
Strengthening citizens' rights in the EU
People in the EU often benefit from the civil rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights: personal, civil, political, economic and social rights, protection against discrimination and protection of personal data. We sometimes lose sight of the latter when, in our enthusiasm for technology and the many possibilities it offers, we agree to all cookies and terms and conditions with a quick click in order to "be part of it". For the benefit of the big data professionals.
18 Publications: "Man and Machine - Challenges posed by Artificial Intelligence" 2022 (https://www.ethikrat.org/fileadmin/Publikationen/Stellungnahmen/deutsch/stellungnahme-mensch-
-und-maschine.pdf); "Big Data und Gesundheit - Datensouveränität als informationelle Freiheitsge- staltung" 2017 (https://www.ethikrat.org/fileadmin/Publikationen/Studien/befragung-big-data-und- gesundheit.pdf); "Pflege - Roboter - Ethik: Eine spannungsvolle Beziehung" 2019 (https://www.ethikrat.org/fileadmin/user_upload/infobrief-02-19-web.pdf).
With its basic program, the ÖDP advocates the protection of the individual and their basic rights, whether analog or digital. That is why it demands:
 Further strengthening and enforcement of EU fundamental rights in all EU member states, particularly in the digital sector through compliance with data protection (GDPR19 ) and its consistent enforcement.
 A Europe-wide action plan that opposes all forms of discrimination and violence, such as racism and queer hostility, and promotes cooperative coexistence.
 Avoiding the compulsion to use automated systems (e.g. online systems of public authorities, cashless payment) by retaining traditional, analog means of exercising their civic rights and duties (digital sovereignty ).20
 Safeguarding media and press freedom, in particular investigative journalism.
 A comprehensive EU whistleblower protection program.
 Disclosure and thus verifiability of the algorithms that make a selection or decision instead of a human being.
 The promotion of technical facilities to support individual freedoms in mobility, communication, education, generally accessible open source databases and program systems, etc.
 Determining the compatibility of new communication technologies with data protection prior to their approval or introduction
19 General Data Protection Regulation, https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal- content/DE/ TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32016R0679
20 Digital sovereignty describes the abilities and possibilities of people and institutions to perform their role(s) in the digital world in an independent, self-determined and secure manner. See also: https://www.bundesdruckerei.de/de/innovation-hub/digitale-souveraenitaet-was-ist-das
and the other EU regulations by democratically legitimized bodies.
 New regulations on the handling of personal medical data, which must not lead to a deterioration in healthcare provision.
 Protection and promotion of access to education, fair working conditions and social participation.
More consistent data protection as an urgent task for the EU
Digital communication systems (internet) offer us many advantages in everyday life, but are also highly associated with the risk of data misuse, which is why the EU has created a strict set of rules to prevent this with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), with the rights to information, erasure, objection, rectification, restricted processing and data portability, as well as a prohibition on linking (i.e. no linking of data from different areas). Unfortunately, educational institutions are still very poorly informed about the basics of data protection and possible risks when using digital services.
Nevertheless, data protection is being violated in many places: firstly through illegal activities such as the further unauthorized evaluation of registered data from smart meters for electricity and heating consumption, GPS data from mobile devices, information from cashless payments, etc. to obtain information about users' everyday behaviour. Another example is the illegal tapping and analysis of the medical data of all patients currently stored centrally by health insurance companies. Finally, the illegal further use of telephone recordings and the recording of telephone connections should be mentioned.
However, we also "voluntarily" disclose a lot of personal data about ourselves: on the Internet, you usually have to enter your personal data when you access a page.
"necessary" cookies, before using social media and many other programs, as well as some video conferences, you must agree to the terms and conditions that allow personal data to be tapped. A gray area is formed by new car models that use many sensors to store, send and make available for analysis data on the number of passengers, often also on their body weight, driving style and much more without explicit consent. All of these activities contribute to the multi-million dollar business of big data, where marketing strategists and political groups try to identify certain groups of people with such collections of personal data and use this knowledge to further their interests.
The many public surveillance cameras with facial recognition pose a further problem, as do the digital passports with significantly more biometric data that the German government, like many other European countries, wants to introduce. If you have the appropriate access, you should not only be able to retrieve the data from a standard passport, but also your vaccination status and other personal details.
For this reason, the ÖDP still sees considerable deficits in the enforcement of data protection and is calling for this:
 Compliance with the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and its consistent enforcement by supervisory authorities in all EU member states as well as higher penalties for violations.
 National laws must not conflict with the intention of the European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) or override the provisions contained therein (e.g. blanket release of personal data to the USA).
 The unrestricted right of all citizens to information about the processing and forwarding of their personal data.
 No softening of data protection through free trade agreements and other EU treaties with third countries.
 No lowering of the high data protection standards for medical data for health policy reasons, in particular no disclosure of medical data without the patient's consent, even for research purposes.
 A reservation of consent for data subjects if their data, which directly or indirectly contains information about their everyday behavior (e.g. smart meters for electricity consumption, GPS data from mobile devices, information from cashless payment), is used or passed on beyond the permissible purpose of registration.
 The special observation of non-European digital companies with big data interests (e.g. Facebook, Amazon, Google) operating on the European Internet with regard to compliance with the GDPR and other EU regulations.
 A ban on the unprovoked evaluation of video recordings in public spaces with facial recognition.
 A systematic evaluation of monitoring powers and programs.
Protecting internal security
The security authorities of the member states are working ever more closely together to maintain internal security in order to better counter cross-border crime. The exchange of database information from the various EU states via digital channels plays an important role in this. Also
Software systems for predicting serious crimes could contribute to stabilizing internal security.
The conflict-laden debate about climate protection and thus about the future expectations of future generations is currently increasingly leading to a division in society and thus to a threat to internal security by destabilizing the social consensus.
The availability of digital communication systems and thus the accessibility of a large number of people can make a positive contribution to such consensus-building. However, this reach can also be misused, namely for disinformation: Cambridge Analytica, for example, has influenced over two hundred elections worldwide, including the 2016 US presidential election and Brexit. However, it is not just about elections, but also about influencing and controlling groups with the aim of destabilizing the state.
That is why the ÖDP is calling for this in the EU:
 Better protection of critical infrastructure and public security against cyberattacks, espionage and terrorist attacks in all EU countries.
 Protection against targeted social and political manipulation by internet services such as social media, made possible by individually selected and filtered information distribution (content allocation ).21
 An expansion of the online network of the search databases22 of all EU states to support the national authorities and Europol in the EU-wide prosecution of criminal offenses, while safeguarding citizens' rights.
21 Personalized linking of data from different areas to profile an individual in order to assign them to a target group
22 For example, the Schengen Information System (SIS)
 A further expansion of Europol's staff to provide more effective support to national law enforcement authorities against international terrorist networks and organized crime such as human trafficking, organ theft and extortion.
 No reduction of police posts in favor of further use of surveillance technology.
 The development of an international crime prevention strategy.
 An extension of the powers of the Fundamental Rights Officer at Europol, in particular with regard to the right to issue instructions. The parliamentary monitoring group at Europol must be given a higher status and more powers.
 Democratically legitimized supervision of the activities of the European secret services.
 More protection for human rights activists and members of the opposition.
 The rejection of chat controls, unless they are ordered by a court in individual cases.
 No use of state Trojans and spying software (e.g. the "Pegasus" program) without a court order.
 Ensuring general life satisfaction through the problem-free supply of everyday goods with EU regulations on supply chains and ownership regulations for relevant infrastructure elements (e.g. ports, public transport, medical care).
 Increased EU-wide consensus building on climate protection and its consistent implementation as a security-promoting contribution to preserving the livelihoods of future generations (grandchildren's policy).
 Practicing peaceful conflict resolution in schools, the media and politics.
Foreign and defense policy
Although the European Union (EU) sees itself as an area of freedom, security and justice, it does not fully observe these principles in its foreign policy actions when it comes to asserting its own interests. For example, the Treaty on European Union (Treaty of Lisbon) allows military operations for peacekeeping, conflict prevention and strengthening international security in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter, even outside the EU (Art. 42 (1) of the Treaty on European Union)23 . However, such deployments are also possible in the service of its [the EU's] interests (Art. 42 (5)), which goes beyond the scope of military defense and enables wars of aggression, e.g. to secure access to oil wells, which is dressed up as a responsible security policy: Energy supplies will come from a limited number of countries whose stability [...] is by no means assured. They therefore present us with a variety of security challenges that require a responsible and united approach by all member states. 24 Decisions on such missions must be taken unanimously by the Heads of State and Government of the European Union and the Council of Ministers (Art. 42 (4)), but are taken without the European Parliament and the parliaments of the Member States having a say. A review of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) by the European Court of Justice is not possible.25
23 https://dejure.org/gesetze/EU/42.html
24 Council of the European Union, General Secretariat of the Council, European Security Strategy :
a secure Europe in a better world, Publications Office, 2009, https://data.europa.eu/doi/10.2860/1402
25 "Legal acts adopted by the Council within the framework of the CFSP are in principle not subject to review by the European Court of Justice (ECJ) ...", https://www.auswaertiges- amt.de/de/aussenpolitik/europa/ aussenpolitik/gasp/-/201776
The ÖDP is therefore calling for this at EU level:
 Global respect for human rights as the primary goal of the CFSP.
 Focusing the CFSP on peace, conflict prevention, the search for peaceful solutions in conflict situations and humanitarian aid.
 No military deployment without a decision by the UN Security Council, with the exception of deployments under Article 51 of the UN Charter (right to collective self-defense).
 Commitment to consistent compliance with international law and the application of international criminal law instead of support for "humanitarian interventions" that are questionable under international law.
 Greater European independence from the USA through a common defense policy and coordination of armaments projects within the EU.
 Involvement of the EU Parliament in decisions on the EU's common foreign and defense policy, in particular the right to stop military operations.
 EU commitment to a global ban on nuclear weapons, as now demanded by more than 122 states in the UN.
 Amendment of the EU Treaty to prohibit military operations by the EU for oil and raw materials and to secure trade routes.
 A joint EU seat on the UN Security Council as an expression of the common foreign and security policy.
 Commitment to the abolition of the right of veto in the UN Security Council and the introduction of majority voting.
 Initiative to record looted cultural assets in European museums and offer to return them to their countries of origin.

Our vision:
a Europe that protects our livelihoods!
The ÖDP stands for a Europe of peace, freedom, democracy and human rights and for a socially just Europe that operates within planetary boundaries, preserves the natural foundations of life, puts the common good before individual profit and involves citizens in decision-making processes. This requires a departure from the dogma of unlimited economic growth, an efficient use of resources and the transition to a sustainable European circular economy.
Less is more! The ÖDP would like to work towards ensuring that all planned limits are observed. This requires comprehensive protection of the climate, species, biodiversity, air, water and soil. These protection goals must not be played off against each other and one must not be undermined at the expense of the other. Compliance with planetary boundaries is only possible if the common good, social justice and the participation of people in the necessary transformation processes are taken into account at the same time. Social equality, reducing income and wealth inequalities and the participation of citizens in direct democratic processes are the means we would like to use to achieve this.
We are aware that the rich countries of the EU must lead the way in this transformation in order to create a sustainable, just and peaceful future for all. We see a great responsibility towards future generations, but also a global responsibility towards the economically poorer countries of the global South.
Our political agenda aims to create a sustainable, just and peaceful future for all. We will fight to make our vision a reality. The protection of our natural resources, the common good and co- determination are the primary goals of our political action.
To this end, we are asking voters to cast their votes in the 2024 European elections.

Election program of the Humanist Party (PdH) for the 2024 European elections
Adopted at the European Party Conference of the PdH in Lübeck on November 4, 2023
Foreword
Europe needs a new style of politics.
A political style of listening, proximity to citizens and facts. We meet Europe's challenges in an open-minded and unbiased way - this is the only way we have a chance of meeting them. We listen to experts and work with them to develop solutions that improve the lives of all people and give them the freedom to shape their own lives.
We are the PdH. The voice of the social-liberal awakening, the Rethinking politics.
Together, we are shaping the future of Europe and A sign against the standstill.

3	TABLE OF CONTENTS
First the facts, then the position!
Our political style
Progressive policy develops solutions based on scientific findings.
First we gather all the important facts, then we develop our position. In doing so, we are not only guided by scientific consensus, but also work according to scientific principles ourselves. Time and again, we critically question whether our viewpoints still correspond to the latest scientific findings. Changing your mind is not "buckling", it's sensible!
We fulfill this promise on the basis of our socially liberal values and the philosophy of evolutionary humanism. We are convinced that people themselves know best what is good for them and that neither the state nor society should stand in their way of realizing their life plans. To this end, it is essential that Europe meets its central challenges. We currently see these in five key areas:
1. Climate change & environmental protection
2. Migration & Integration
3. Economic recovery
4. European sovereignty & cooperation
5. Digitization & data protection
We are a full program party. The challenges mentioned represent our priorities for the 2024 European elections, not our entire party program. We are convinced that policies that listen to experts and combine their knowledge with social-liberal values are needed in every field. This includes a reform of the healthcare system, a fundamentally new approach to the education system, more state support for science and research, consistent secularization and a restructuring of social measures that are currently far too bureaucratic.
You can find our positions on these and other challenges at pdh.eu/program.
4	OUR POLITICAL
Climate change & Environmental protection
Climate change and environmental protection are key challenges of our time. Since the 19th century, the emission of greenhouse gases, primarily through the burning of fossil fuels, has led to a significant increase in the average global temperature. As a result of man-made climate change, the probability of extreme weather events such as droughts, hurricanes and floods is increasing.
These changes threaten our livelihoods: landscapes are becoming uninhabitable due to rising sea levels and the biosphere cannot adapt quickly enough to climate change. The effects of climate change in Germany to date have been comparatively mild and public awareness of this problem has only increased in recent years. We are now at a point where rapid action is essential. The scientific consensus calls for a drastic reduction in human emissions in order to avert the most serious consequences of climate change and ensure a sustainable future.
The global community must become more active than before. Investing in climate protection and research will be more cost-effective in the long term than ignoring the impending dangers and clinging to an economic system based on fossil fuels.
In order to achieve the European climate targets, we adhere to a fixed upper limit for CO2 emissions. European countries issue limited CO2 emission allowances that can be purchased and traded by companies. This system makes it possible to reduce emissions in a market-conform and cost-efficient manner. Part of the revenue from emissions trading and CO2 taxation is used to promote the decarbonization of our economy and society. The remaining share is divided equally among all citizens and repaid. This redistribution mechanism benefits the lower income groups in particular. They receive back more than they have paid in, while the population with greater purchasing power is encouraged to prefer low-carbon products.2 With this approach, we create a balance between environmental protection and social fairness.
In order to create incentives for a recycling-oriented circular economy and minimize waste management, we are introducing a mandatory recycling quota for all EU member states, which wi l result in sanctions if it is not met. In order to prevent the circumvention of recycling quotas through waste exports, we are working with other member states to develop solutions to reduce their waste and are working towards an increasing recycling rate. We also promote
	ocean cleanup technologies and implement them in the
The scientific consensus calls for a drastic reduction in human emissions in order to avert the most serious consequences of climate change and ensure a sustainable future.
As one of the leading economic areas with one of the highest levels of greenhouse gas emissions since the 19th century, Europe has a special responsibility. It must not only achieve its own targets, but also establish a global strategy for reducing emissions in cooperation with other major emitters such as the USA and China. This can only succeed if Europe itself plays its part in climate protection. Environmental protection is also an urgent task. For example, the biodiversity crisis and plastic waste in the oceans ultimately threaten our food chain. We are tackling these challenges with a clear and targeted policy without ideological blinkers and are giving the fight against climate change top political priority. In order to reduce emissions and protect Europe from the effects of climate change, we are anchoring the consideration of ecological and social aspects in the European market economy.
within the framework of European projects.
In order to effectively bind emissions and protect Europe from the effects of climate change, we are adapting our natural landscapes to climate change. We are achieving this through targeted renaturation measures in forests and wetlands. Peatlands in particular play a crucial role in climate protection, as they can store enormous amounts of CO2 and water. However, their drainage significantly reduces their CO2 storage function, which is why the protection and sustainable management of moors and alluvial forests are key measures for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. We are also focusing on increased coastal protection. We recognize the potential of geoengineering methods and are promoting their use and further development. Geoengineering encompasses various technologies that can have a direct impact on the climate.
Some of these methods are already showing great promise in slowing global warming, while others require even more intensive research. We are convinced that they will be a valuable addition to our conventional climate protection strategies in the future.
In order to reduce emissions and protect Europe from the effects of climate change, we are actively promoting the development of new methods for low-CO2 electricity generation and storage. In doing so, we consistently and undogmatically consider all existing technologies and ensure a balanced mix of centralized and decentralized generation and storage capacities. Renewable energies are at the forefront of our strategy, and by promoting them we are creating jobs and boosting the economy. In order to make it possible to phase out coal as early as possible throughout the EU, we will continue to rely on low-carbon nuclear energy.2 We are modernizing safe nuclear power plants and ensuring their continued operation, while resuming research and development of new types of power plants. We are equipping nuclear reactors for fast load sequencing so that they can be used in conjunction with renewable energies.
The further development of nuclear fission technologies to fully utilize the energy content of uranium and to convert long-lived radioactive waste into short-lived radioactive waste as well as nuclear fusion are also central components of our research funding. We are having a panel of experts work out the exact timetable for the transition to modern nuclear reactor types. We will also revise the EU taxonomy: It is the result of political negotiations rather than scientific analysis. For example, we are critical of the inclusion of natural gas in the taxonomy and call for nuclear energy to be recognized as a long-term climate-friendly and environmentally friendly technology instead of just a bridging technology.
In order to reduce emissions and protect	Europe from the effects of climate change, we are creating a climate-friendly	and	climate-resilient transport infrastructure. Rail	transport	is	one	of	the	most climate-friendly means of transportation for both freight and passengers and is therefore the focus of our efforts.	In	the	 long	term,	we	are	working	 on	the harmonization of cross-border rail transport in Europe in	order	to	overcome	technical	challenges	such	as different track gauges or current voltages. To make train travel in Europe more attractive, we are introducing a European ticket for all European local and regional transport, supporting the establishment of night trains and reforming the Interrail ticket. Standardized booking platforms	and	tariff	 systems	will	complement	this process and reform rail transport in Europe.
In order to reduce emissions and protect Europe from the effects of climate change, we are modernizing European agriculture.
We promote the bioeconomy, which uses biological instead of fossil raw materials, through targeted measures in research, education and industrial development. We minimize the environmental impact by promoting the combination of conventional and organic farming methods. We strive for sustainable intensification using all available technologies in order to free up land for renaturation. Biodiversity benefits more from this than from land-intensive organic farming. Agricultural certificates such as
"Organic" labels are only awarded if the production
is sustainable, resource-saving and low in CO .2
We are also committed to scientifically sound decisions on	genetic	 engineering	applications	and	products	and increasingly	support	biotechnological	research	in agriculture	and	medicine.	We	reject	dogmatically motivated	restrictions	on	the	use	 of genetic engineering. Glyphosate has been scientifically proven to be one of the most efficient plant protection products. When used correctly, there is no increased risk of	cancer	for	users	or	consumers.	We	therefore extend the approval of glyphosate and reject approval requirements that come close to a ban in practice. We promote	and	simplify	the	replacement	of animal products with plant-based, biotechnological or synthetically produced alternatives. To this end, we are reforming the EU Novel Food Regulation to improve the integration of new food technologies and products.
Standards in livestock farming must be based on scientific findings about the high sensitivity of animals. In this way, we are creating comprehensive improvements in the living conditions of millions of animals. We reduce animal testing to the minimum necessary to combat life-threatening human diseases and are committed to the development and use of alternative methods to animal testing.
We are fundamentally changing EU subsidies for agriculture. Instead of flat-rate subsidies or support based on acreage or production, farmers would be supported on the basis of concrete, verifiable results in areas such as animal welfare, climate protection and environmental protection. They would also be remunerated for ecosystem services such as the creation of flower strips, the improvement of soil and water quality or the storage of CO2 in arable soils. You can find all of our positions on climate, environment, agriculture and animal welfare at pdh.eu/gsp/climate-environment- agriculture-animal-protection and the detailed section on climate protection at pdh.eu/climate-change.

Migration &
Integration
Migration, a shortage of skilled workers, demographic change and the associated young talent, education and pension problems pose major challenges for Europe. Immigration into the labor market helps to counteract the shortage of skilled workers and demographic change. Recognized refugees and asylum seekers with the prospect of staying are, if successfully integrated, an asset to our society and our economy. At the same time, immigration is associated with risks if the authorities and local authorities are overburdened by the influx of asylum seekers. The consequences are unregulated immigration, rejected but not deported asylum seekers and a lack of integration, which contributes to the emergence of parallel societies. In addition, there are mass deaths in the Mediterranean and on the refugee routes as a whole, which must be stopped as a matter of urgency.
Strict controls at the EU's external borders are necessary to curb illegal immigration and ensure Europe's security.
Those who make it to Europe are often not the most vulnerable or needy, but tend to be those who have the means, resources and physical strength to make the dangerous journey. This raises questions about the current direction of our asylum policy. Furthermore, Europe must not violate its values, for example through illegal pushbacks. These politically unresolved grievances also contribute to the rise of right-wing populism and right-wing radicalism, which further deepens the social divide. It is therefore imperative that we recognize both the opportunities and challenges of migration and identify rational solutions. If Europe succeeds in combating the causes of flight, managing migration, promoting legal migration into the labour market, ensuring the integration of asylum seekers with prospects of remaining and recognized refugees and consistently deporting asylum seekers without prospects of remaining, Europe will benefit.
For a regulated and responsible migration policy, we are	clearly	committed	to	the right to asylum, the Geneva	Convention	on	Refugees	and	 the	right	to subsidiary protection. We reject populist and restrictive solutions such as upper limits, as they	could lead to us not granting adequate protection to refugees in need of protection in emergency situations, such as the	attack	on	Ukraine,	which	is	contrary	to international law. For the security of our
society, migrants who have repeatedly or seriously committed criminal offenses must be deported. If they are threatened with persecution or punishment practices that violate human rights, such as torture, in their home country, they cannot be deported. They must then be treated	in	accordance	with	 German	criminal	law.	If asylum applications are rejected or the need for protection no longer applies, we pursue a consistent repatriation	policy	that	deals	humanely	with situations	such	as	illness,	pregnancy	and	affected children.
Strict controls at the EU's external borders are necessary to curb illegal immigration and ensure Europe's security. Internal European border controls, on the other hand, contradict freedom of movement, one of the central achievements of modern Europe, and are also highly ineffective. The infrastructure required is disproportionate to the potential benefit of identifying immigrants, who ultimately still have a right to a regulated procedure.
For a regulated and responsible migration policy, we are pooling Europe's strengths in a joint office for refugees	and	migration.	This	is	where	 we coordinate European refugee policy centrally. We are in	favor	of	automated,	computer-aided	preliminary checks	of	asylum	applications	whose	 algorithms	are transparent and comprehensible. This not only speeds up the	admission	process,	but	also	improves	 the consistency and objectivity of decisions. A fully digital solution simplifies	and	speeds	up	the	process	 of registering,	distributing	and	 forwarding refugees. This significantly reduces bureaucratic effort, relieves the burden on authorities and enables asylum procedures to be processed more quickly.
For a regulated and responsible migration policy, we are establishing a fair system for the distribution of refugees and asylum seekers throughout the EU. The current regulation, according to which every person seeking protection must apply for asylum where they enter the EU, is unfair and overburdens countries at the EU's external borders. Together with other EU member states, we are working towards fair distribution in order to relieve the burden on the primary countries of arrival, such as Greece and Italy.
For a regulated and responsible migration policy, we define	clear	European	criteria	for	third	countries	to determine	which	of	them	can	be	classified	as safe countries of origin. These criteria should be adopted by parliament. Instead of each European country deciding individually which third countries it classifies as safe, we are striving for a
coordinated and uniform approach. This is essential for an EU external border without controlled internal borders, avoids inefficient and lengthy political debates about individual countries and instead creates clarity. A third country that meets the defined criteria is classified as a safe country of origin. If it no longer meets the criteria, it loses this status. Together with our European partners, we are developing these criteria, whereby the rule of law and respect for human rights are absolute minimum standards. These minimum standards apply not only to safe countries of origin, but also to all other third countries with which we are aiming to conclude repatriation agreements and negotiations on migration cooperation. The joint approach serves a migration strategy based on solidarity and strengthens the united external impact of the European Union.
For a regulated and responsible migration policy, we actively	tackle	the causes of flight. This	can	be achieved by tackling factors such as a lack of economic prospects	or	threats	from	climate	change	locally. Climate	change	is	one	of	the	biggest	causes	of displacement. Countries with low levels of prosperity are particularly at risk. Effective climate policy can therefore also help to regulate migration. By helping to tackle these problems locally and at the same time curbing our own emissions, we can limit displacement before it occurs.
We see great benefit in the expansion of partnerships between the EU and other nations. These are indispensable in view of China's growing influence in Asia and Africa. Europe must present itself there as an attractive partner and initiate long-term economic relationships that improve local living standards and also create new sales markets for the European economy. We use our refugee aid effectively where people are in need, especially internally displaced persons. We are increasing the budget of the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) and making international efforts to improve the living conditions of those seeking protection in the host countries.
In order to benefit from migration, we define our economic needs. Immigration can help to counteract the shortage of skilled workers. Therefore, anyone who is in a position to meet such a need, for example by working as a skilled worker in Europe, should have the opportunity to apply their qualifications in the European labor market. That is why we recognize more international qualifications and specifically simplify immigration into our labour market.
This also includes approving, actively enabling and demanding gainful employment during the ongoing admission process. This facilitates integration and provides valuable insights into the qualifications of immigrants. Those who are socially integrated and working are not rejected, but accepted. We also carry out development work in emerging and developing countries by supporting skilled workers in their training with the option of working in Europe.
We	 see	immigration	and	cultural	diversity	as	an opportunity.	Immigration	can	strengthen	science, innovation, research and education in Europe and have a positive impact on the economic prospects of our	community	of	values.	We	therefore	promote international	cooperation	and	networking	of specialists and are a platform for professional and scientific	exchange.	By	expanding	uniform	European educational	guidelines,	we	 are	modernizing	the education system and facilitating access to top-quality education,	 including for children with a migrant background. Educational opportunities must be made available as early as kindergarten age within the framework of ideologically neutral kindergartens. This is how we counteract the emergence of parallel societies. Together, we will master the challenges of globalization, digitalization and technological progress with a high-quality education system.
For regulated and responsible integration, we rely on the principle of "support and demand". This means that all migrants are granted fundamental rights and equal opportunities.	In	return,	 we	strictly	demand	a willingness to integrate and the recognition of European, humanistic values. Lip service is not enough and must be underpinned by clear actions. These fundamental values include equal rights for all genders, democratic principles, freedom of opinion, freedom of religion, self-determination	and	responsibility,	respect	for minorities	and	sexual	self-determination.	We	make	it unmistakably clear that religious fundamentalism, such as Islamism, is incompatible with our secular values and has	no	place	 in	our	society.	Free educational opportunities, in particular integration and language courses, are central to integration and must therefore be provided	to	a	greater	extent.	We	not	 only	attach importance to vocational qualifications, but also to teaching	 the	cultures and lifestyles of the host country. All-day schools and early childhood education with special integration programs are particularly important here. Another focus is the rapid integration
of migrants into the labor market. Finally, we emphasize the importance of active participation in social life. In order to promote integration into local community life, we provide financial support so that all immigrants have the opportunity to play an active role. You can find all of our positions in the area of Democracy & Home Affairs at pdh.eu/democracy-home-affairs.
Summary
 Commitment to the right to asylum
Rejection of upper limits and clear position on the right to asylum and the Geneva Refugee Convention and the right to subsidiary protection
 Strict EU external border controls
Ensuring Europe's security and curbing illegal immigration, while intra-European Border controls can be avoided
 Joint Office for Refugees and Migration
Central coordination of European refugee policy and introduction of automated, transparent preliminary examinations of asylum applications
 Fair distribution in the EU
Establishment of a system for the fair distribution of refugees and asylum seekers throughout the EU, to relieve the burden on primary countries of arrival
 Clear criteria for third countries
Introduction of uniform criteria for determining safe countries of origin and development of repatriation agreements
 Combating the causes of flight
actively combating factors such as climate change and a lack of economic prospects; expanding partnerships between the EU and other nations
 Integration through education
Modernization of the education system, access to education for all and prevention of parallel societies through early childhood education and all-day schools
 Principle of "support and challenge"
Granting rights and equal opportunities for migrants while at the same time demanding integration willingness and recognition of fundamental European values
 Active social participation
Promoting the active participation of migrants in social life
Economic
Recreation
The European economy is the engine of our prosperity and our welfare state. This prosperity can be increased and the recovery of the European economy secured with smart political decisions. In the midst of global changes, we are facing urgent challenges. Tax avoidance must be consistently combated in order to ensure fair competitive conditions and fair revenues for all member states. The transformation towards a CO2 neutral economy and adapting to the already noticeable consequences of climate change are key tasks that we face.
Rapid digitalization and technological innovations offer immense opportunities, but also entail risks. Uniform, reformed standards in dealing with public debt are necessary to ensure financial stability and at the same time enable investment for future challenges. Our aim is to seize these opportunities and ensure that no one is left behind. Globalization, despite its benefits, also brings with it geopolitical challenges and dependencies in supply chains. It is therefore important to strengthen our resilience while reaping the benefits of global trade.
In view of these challenges, we are committed to a socio-ecological market economy based on human values such as individual freedom and fair compensation. The overarching goal is a market economy that is geared towards the well-being of all and protects the livelihoods of future generations. By joining forces and sharing common values, Europe will shape a future in which prosperity, sustainability and social justice go hand in hand.
For the recovery of the European economy, we are giving all economic players active in Europe a fair share of the public finances. Tax avoidance not only contradicts democratic principles, but also threatens social justice. In fact, the EU member states, and therefore its citizens, lose almost one trillion euros a year through tax evasion. In response,	we	are	creating	a	European	authority aimed at combating tax evasion and eliminating tax loopholes	and	establishing	a	consistent	European	tax system.	Furthermore,	we	are	implementing	a global minimum tax of 15 % on corporate profits in order to minimize	tax	avoidance	and	prevent	tax	dumping between countries. Countries that do not comply with this minimum rate will be subject to sanctions. When it comes to taxation, we attach great importance to ensuring that it is shared fairly between the country in which the profit is generated and the country in which it is earned.
and the country in which the company is based. This ensures that companies contribute appropriately to tax revenues, which in turn creates room for tax cuts for the general public or investments in social welfare, education, health and defense.
Becoming a leader in developing solutions to the challenges of our time is crucial for the recovery of the European economy. Europe must reduce its CO2 emissions and at the same time prepare for the already unavoidable consequences of climate change. These challenges also present economic opportunities. The technologies that are currently being developed are of great importance to us. We are therefore committed to ensuring that they are developed and produced in Europe in order to minimize our dependence on totalitarian regimes such as China and endangered democracies such as the USA. With targeted investment in the research, development and application of climate-friendly technologies, Europe can dominate a new economic sector, combat climate change and protect itself from its effects.
Globalization, despite its benefits, also brings with it geopolitical challenges and dependencies in supply chains. It is therefore important to strengthen our resilience and at the same time benefit from the advantages of global trade.
A secure and affordable energy supply is essential for the recovery of the European economy. However, the integrated European electricity grid, an impressive technical achievement, is facing challenges due to rising	energy	prices,	increasing	electricity	demand and the need for decarbonization.
To meet these challenges, we are focusing on the expansion of low-CO2 energy sources and promoting innovative energy storage technologies. These measures balance out fluctuations in the electricity grid and increase security of supply. At the same time, we are investing in research and development in order to make our energy system future-proof and sustainable. In this way, we are ensuring a fair and sustainable energy supply for future generations. Rising energy prices can lead to social imbalances and put a strain on the European economy. A reform of the European electricity market is therefore crucial.
Our goal is a transparent, cost-efficient market that offers consumers planning security and meets climate protection targets. By strengthening European emissions trading, we can achieve these goals in line with the market. A revision of the market design, including the merit order principle, is essential. Some of the revenue from emissions trading should flow back to the population as a climate bonus in order to boost the economy and increase acceptance of climate policy.
It is crucial for the recovery of the European economy to catch up with digitalization and transform Europe into a pioneering continent for digital infrastructure. Investments in digitalization strengthen Europe as a business location and offer people new opportunities to overcome everyday challenges. A particular focus of our investments lies in the research and development of artificial intelligence (AI). AI has the potential to bring about revolutionary changes in areas such as health diagnostics (through early detection of diseases) or energy efficiency (through optimized control of smart grids).
It is crucial for the recovery of the European economy to catch up with digitalization and transform Europe into a pioneering continent for digital infrastructure.
Modern working conditions are another key item on our agenda. We create incentives for flexible working models such as working from home and remote working in order to meet the demands of today's working world. We also attach importance to shaping the structural change associated with digitalization in a socially responsible way, particularly when dealing with technologies such as AI. In addition to software development, we are promoting the development and production of hardware such as computer chips in Europe. This step not only makes economic sense, but also serves to ensure independence from increasingly uncertain international supply chains.
We are driving forward the modernization and digitalization of payment traffic to boost the European economy. Secure digital payment methods facilitate trade and offer consumers flexibility. We are committed to ensuring that card payments and digital payments, for example with smart phones, are widely possible and accepted throughout Europe. The issue of small coin denominations is also relevant in this context,
especially the one and two-cent coins. Their production costs exceed their face value and their purchasing power is minimal. Inflation further exacerbates this problem. While some EU countries already apply rounding rules to the nearest 5 cents, others do not. To create clarity and consistency across the euro area, we are campaigning for the abolition of these coins.
How we deal with public debt is crucial for the recovery of the European economy. The current Maastricht criteria, which limit this debt, are based more on political decisions than on sound economic knowledge. That is why we are reforming these criteria by scientifically reviewing and adapting them. Taxpayers' money and new debt must be used efficiently and invested specifically in future-oriented projects such as infrastructure, digitalization and sustainable energy development. This benefits European citizens twice over, as it limits debt on the one hand and invests in important areas that promote prosperity on the other.
We rely on robust and resilient supply chains for the recovery of the European economy. European companies are heavily integrated into international production and trade networks, which opens up opportunities but also	entails	risks.	One	example	of	this	is	the dependence on rare earths from certain countries, which are essential for many technologies. Another example is the dependence on pharmaceuticals and medical products, which are often produced outside Europe.	In	times	of	geopolitical	tensions	or	global pandemics, this can lead to bottlenecks. To counter such risks, we diversify our sources of supply and promote the extraction and processing of critical raw materials and the production of essential medicines directly in the EU. In order to meet the challenges of globalization, we are strengthening our resilience and at the same time focusing on fair competitive conditions.
To boost the European economy, we are strengthening its backbone: entrepreneurship.	Performance	and initiative must be rewarded in order to help Europe achieve new growth and offer everyone the chance to advance. High taxes and excessive bureaucracy must not be allowed	to	slow	down	entrepreneurs.	Market regulations must not be barriers to market entry for start-ups and thus protective walls for corporations.
Small and medium-sized enterprises and innovative start- ups in particular are bringing a breath of fresh air to the market, challenging established players and creating new jobs.
With their creativity and ambition, they make a significant contribution to social prosperity. Our support for these players includes financial support, facilitating investment and reducing bureaucracy. We simplify and promote the participation of employees in companies and encourage companies to offer their employees this opportunity. We therefore also support the jointly democratic legal form of the cooperative. This turns employees into co-entrepreneurs, giving them a say and a fair share in the joint success. In addition, social security is guaranteed by a basic income to be gradually introduced. This contributes to social stability, supports education and training, enables artists, for example, to pursue their passion, reduces poverty and creates incentives for innovation and entrepreneurship.
For the recovery of the European economy, we support citizens who want to live self-determined lives and take advantage of the opportunities offered by our economic system. This includes small investors who want to provide for their future or strive for financial freedom. In view of the uncertain outlook for pensions, it is important to provide not only state
Summary
to also promote funded pension provision. Direct banks and neobrokers give consumers better opportunities to invest in the capital market at low cost and to become informed investors through free financial education. We reject the currently planned ban on "payment for order flow". This enables securities trading at favorable conditions even for small investors without large trading volumes. A ban would mean the end of neobrokers and damage the share culture. Young people in particular, who use this form of retirement provision, would be harmed. Instead, we are calling for more transparency regarding the remuneration of neobrokers.
These developments democratize the capital market and enable citizens to build up assets over the long term. As long-term investing over more than 15 years is a proven strategy, we are increasing the saver's lump sum across Europe to EUR 3,000, adjusted for inflation. This allows small investors to benefit optimally from their investments. You can find all our positions in the Economy & Taxes section at pdh.eu/economic-taxes.
 Fair public finances
Closing tax evasion and loopholes for all economic players
 European Tax Authority
Combating tax avoidance and introducing a global minimum tax
 Climate investments
Promotion of climate-friendly technologies and measures
 Energy supply
Safeguarding through low-CO2 energy sources, innovative technologies and revision of the merit order principle
 Digitization offensive

 Maastricht reform

European sovereignty &
cooperation
27 member states, around 450 million inhabitants and a gross domestic product that rivals that of China - all united by a common set of values: that is the European Union. Its motto i s : "United in diversity". We live by this principle. At the moment, however, Europe often plays small.
The EU is failing to pursue a coherent foreign policy and assert its interests internationally due to disputes and blockades by some member states. Only a Europe that stands together can present a united front to the outside world and take its place on the world stage. This also includes expanding protection against divisive external influences, such as those recently exerted by Donald Trump or Vladimir Putin. The people themselves are crucial to this. They shape the continent of Europe, the direction of its politics and international coexistence. In this chapter, we outline our goals for the next steps in the development of the European Union, which we will pursue in the European Parliament: how we can strengthen Europe's unity, secure its sovereignty on the
interest of the general public. EU citizens must always be able to see which players have a financial influence on political decisions. We are optimizing the EU's information portal and making it more user-friendly so that citizens have easier and more intuitive access to relevant information.
For true transparency, we are reforming the provisions on the "legislative footprint". In the annex to reports on legislative texts, this lists all lobbyists with whom a member of parliament was in contact during the drafting of a law. We are abolishing the current practice for lobbyists to choose their own "registration category". Finally, we emphasize the protection of whistleblowers from reprisals where there is a justified public interest. In these cases, the public interest outweighs the welfare of the state or private institution.
In order to strengthen European cohesion, we are giving the Parliament elected by the citizens of Europe more rights.
world stage and implement a common foreign policy.	
In order to strengthen European cohesion, we are giving the Parliament elected by the citizens of Europe more rights. Until now, the European Parliament has only had a very limited right of initiative. We are extending this to a fundamental right to introduce legislative initiatives. This will allow citizens to participate much more directly in European legislative projects.
We	are	ending	the absurd coexistence of two parliamentary seats in Brussels and Strasbourg, which not only costs at least 100 million euros a year, but also involves enormous logistical challenges, the monthly transportation	of	vast	amounts	of	 material	and	the movement of thousands of people, as well as causing enormous amounts of CO2 every year, in favour of the Brussels	location.	In	addition,	we	are	reducing	the unanimity principle in the Council of the European Union to a minimum. A qualified majority will then apply to most political decisions. This will increase the EU's efficiency and ability to act.
In order to strengthen European cohesion, we are increasing transparency and thus creating new trust in the institutions of the European Union. This includes mandatory registration of all political actors in the lobby register. We are abolishing existing exemptions for religious and political actors in order to ensure complete transparency. We are reforming the regulations on party donations. In doing so, we are balancing the protection of the privacy of the individual and the
In order to secure Europe's sovereignty globally, we are implementing a common foreign policy. Europe is currently economically dependent on states that act in an authoritarian manner and disregard human rights. It is unacceptable that products that are consumed and used in Europe were produced using forced labor, by children or under other inhumane circumstances. In order to live up to our responsibility, we enforce compliance with human rights with our trading partners. All our external and economic policy activities are intended to help improve the situation of people in these countries.
We are introducing an EU-wide supply chain law that obliges companies to comply with social, human rights, environmental and climate-friendly standards throughout their entire value chain. We will sanction companies that do not meet these standards. In this way, citizens can be sure when buying and consuming products that they meet basic ethical standards. In the long term, we are striving to reduce our global dependency by becoming a leader in the development of future technologies. To this end, we invest heavily in research and development. We are convinced that the most advanced countries will prevail in global competition and thus be able to initiate relationships that do justice to their own interests. We must be one of these countries. Economic strength is essential for this. We describe how we are giving the European economy new impetus in the "Economic recovery" chapter.
In order to secure Europe's sovereignty globally, we are shaping further-reaching and comprehensive development cooperation with countries in the Global South. China has also recently been able to expand its influence in this area. We present ourselves to the Global South as an attractive and reliable partner that keeps its promises and supports sustainable development based on the principle of helping people to help themselves locally. This creates new sales markets and potential research locations for us and improves relations with young and unestablished democracies. In order to make development cooperation more efficient, we are gradually transferring bilateral state development cooperation from the individual member states to the EU as a whole. The member states should consistently adhere to the 0.7% of GDP set for development cooperation. A basic democratic orientation is a fundamental condition for any cooperation that serves the further development of a country and its society. Humanitarian aid is not affected by this.
In order to secure Europe's sovereignty globally, we are striving for greater integration of the existing national armies in the EU and are focusing on the creation of a common European army in the long term. There are 27 national armies within the EU, each with its own structures, weapons systems and training. A more integrated military structure would not only be more cost- efficient, but also more effective in terms of defense and international peacekeeping. It would also reduce military dependence on the USA and enable Europe to do more justice to its contribution to transatlantic burden- sharing. In order to live up to our global responsibility, we must be in a position to independently counter security-relevant trouble spots in the long term. Particularly in the immediate geographical vicinity of Russia, it is important to represent our own geopolitical interests as a sovereign defense actor.
In order to strengthen European cohesion, we are developing Europe into a continent of first-class, free education for all. The independence and
We promote student autonomy to a greater extent than is currently the case in European education systems, for example through earlier and more extensive opportunities for students to design their own timetables and subject combinations. We are harmonizing educational standards, thereby achieving Europe-wide recognition for them. We promote regular exchange programs for students and teachers, also for the purpose of exchanging teaching methods, and lifelong learning.
In order to secure Europe's sovereignty globally, we are striving for greater integration of the existing national armies in the EU and are focusing on the creation of a common European army in the long term.
To strengthen European cohesion, we connect the people of Europe. This includes the student exchange programs described above and an expansion of the Erasmus+ program. We are establishing a Europe-wide, discounted European rail ticket and expanding the Interrail offer. We are also establishing media partnerships between other countries along the lines of the Franco-German broadcaster arte. We are also reforming and bundling public media institutions into a European institution with various sub-houses.
This public broadcaster should exclusively pursue an educational and informational mission within the framework of critical and neutral reporting and - in contrast to the German ÖRR - not dedicate its main output to entertainment. Together we are shaping an informed, educated and globally neutral Europe. You can find all our positions on Europe in general at pdh.eu/Europe, and all our positions on foreign policy and defense at pdh.eu/gsp/foreign-policy-defense. We present our long-term vision for the continent at pdh.eu/bundesrepublikeuropa.
