To this end, we will advocate for the full implementation of the European One Health Action Plan against antimicrobial resistance and increased cooperation with our international partners with the aim of achieving a global agreement on the use of and access to antimicrobials. We will also work to ensure that the chronic consequences of infections are made a priority
- people suffering from Long Covid, Post Vac and ME/CFS, for example, urgently need approved medicines and deserve our solidarity. As part of the European research program, we will continue to advocate for the advancement of gender-specific medical research and the expansion of therapy development in the field
o f autoimmune diseases.
4. Ensuring a non-discriminatory society
A Europe of respect is a discrimination-free Europe, because discrimination-free societies are happier, healthier, more resilient, more prosperous, safer and, above all, fairer. Nevertheless, we are increasingly seeing attempts to undermine the rights of women, people with disabilities and LGBTIQ+ people in some member states. Group-focused misanthropy, homophobia, racism and anti-Semitism are poison for good and peaceful coexistence.
These anti-human and anti-democratic tendencies are visible within the EU and worldwide. We will not accept and allow conservative and right-wing governments to question and attack the rights we have fought for. Women's rights, the rights of people of color as well as the rights of people with disabilities and LGBTIQ+ people are human rights. We have achieved a lot in Germany and Europe in recent years and decades - but by no means everything.
Developing the EU Charter on Women's Rights
We call for an EU Charter of Women's Rights. We need a catalog of fundamental rights to be protected, absolute minimum standards, such as universal access to contraception, sexual and reproductive health and rights, including reproductive self-determination and safe and legal abortions as well as sex and relationship education. We also strive to ensure that there is free, low-threshold access to abortifacients such as the "morning-after pill" in the long term. Safe abortions should also be available free of charge to as many people as possible in the EU in order to ensure reproductive self-determination and health. The aim must be to protect, expand and enshrine rights. The right to safe and legal abortion should also be enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.
Renewing European equality strategies
The European Gender Equality Strategy must continue to be implemented effectively, particularly in the form of qualitative and quantitative measures that strengthen women's participation in the labor market. The LGBTIQ equality strategy, which now exists for the first time from 2020 to 2025, must also be consistently implemented and continuously developed. Both strategies should be renewed for the period from 2025 to 2030, taking into account previous experience and with their own budget.
Economic independence for women creates social justice
We want to close the gender gap in employment, pay and social security in order to strengthen women's economic independence. Above all, we need high-quality jobs as well as fair wages and pensions. We are proud that we were able to push through the European directive on pay transparency, which means that more women receive their fair pay. However, there is still a need for implementation, especially with the German Pay Transparency Act. In order to close the gender pay gap, we are campaigning for an EU directive on anti-discrimination in wages in addition to the implementation of the directive on pay transparency. Because it is clear to us that pay transparency alone does not do justice to our social democratic aspirations. We want equal pay for equal work in the same place in the European Union. The adopted minimum wage directive will also ensure that women in particular, who often work in the low- wage sector, are better protected from poverty. We also want to close the gender gap in care and support. Care work is still a woman's job and must not remain so. We are therefore striving for the "equal carer - equal earner" model, i.e. a gender equality-oriented employment and care model.
Getting more women into management positions
We empower women in the economy, especially as founders of companies and start-ups. We ensure that women are more fairly represented in decision-making processes in politics and in companies. Quotas and zipper lists, but also a better gender-sensitive political culture and corporate culture are suitable measures here. The EU Leadership Directive (2022) is a milestone for gender equality in Europe. It strengthens the position of women on supervisory boards and paves the way for them to join the management boards of listed companies. As a next step, we plan to look at the management boards of all companies based in the European Union.
Tax equality
Women consume differently and have lower incomes - but bear a higher VAT burden. We are committed to ensuring that the tax burden is finally distributed more fairly. This ranges from reduced tax rates in the EU on feminine hygiene products to the abolition of the additional price on products and services for women (pink tax). In other words, we ensure that equivalent products and services cost the same for men and women.
Fighting and preventing violence against women together
In order to end male violence against women, we must address, analyze and break down harmful norms, structures and stereotypes, promote sex education in schools and offer Europe-wide violence prevention through gender-sensitive educational programs for boys and girls. Only a rethinking of society as a whole and the anchoring of modern role models will promote the equal perception of women in all areas of society and thus also put an end to violence.
The adoption of the Istanbul Convention is a strong signal from the EU that common values are non- negotiable - including women's rights. It must be a matter of course in all member states of the European Union to take consistent action against gender-based violence. The Istanbul Convention must therefore be ratified in all EU member states and the provisions must be transposed into national law.
right can be transferred.
The directive on combating gender-based violence is also an important step towards establishing Europe- wide minimum standards for the protection of women. We want to go further and are campaigning for gender-based violence to be recognized as a European-wide criminal offence in order to be able to combat all forms of violence against women even more comprehensively in the future.
Protect against human trafficking and exploitation
We want to continue Europe's joint fight against human trafficking and adapt the existing legislation to the latest challenges in this area. A key objective must be to protect women who are trafficked into and within the EU for the purpose of sexual exploitation.
Equality and parity in the European institutions too
We are striving for gender parity in the new EU Commission and will ensure that a female Commissioner is once again explicitly responsible for the topic of equality - equality between women and men, anti- discrimination and LGBTQI+ rights. We are also committed to further strengthening the European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE). The EU budget should be set up in a gender-equitable way using the instrument of gender budgeting.
Protecting the rights of queer people
The European Union guarantees the freedom of queer people. This has been expressly decided by the European Parliament with the support of the Social Democrats. The declaration and support of the "LGBTIQ+ Freedom Zone" follows a concern that steps taken towards the freedom of queer people are acutely endangered. We stand in the way of any discrimination and hostility. We call on the EU Commission, as guardian of the treaties, to react harshly to the anti-LGBTIQ+ actions of individual member states. They are incompatible with the values of the European Union. They must be stopped and reversed. We also demand that European rainbow families are not hindered in their freedom of movement and that registered civil partnerships and same-sex marriages are recognized throughout the EU.
Protecting national minorities
In accordance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, we are committed to protecting national minorities in Germany and Europe and support measures to preserve their cultural heritage.
An age-appropriate Europe
Active and healthy ageing has a positive impact on society, the labor market, social systems and productivity. We therefore campaign against age discrimination and want to help people to lead their lives independently for as long as possible and to b e able to participate in society.
5. Protecting security and freedom
Respect also means living without fear of crime and being allowed to be different without fear. All Europeans should feel safe in the EU and have the freedom to inform themselves independently and form their own opinions. To this end, we want to protect the independence of the media and take more effective action against disinformation. Crime often takes place across borders, which is why our national police and security authorities must cooperate even better. We want to set rules at European level to strengthen European consumer protection in the single market. In view of an increase in climate change- related disasters, in addition to other emergencies, we also want to improve civil protection by working even more closely with our European partners and, where appropriate, managing them centrally.
Ensuring freedom of the media
Media freedom is an essential part of the fundamental rights of European citizens. In recent years, we have seen how pressure has been exerted on the media in Europe and how European values have been violated. It is therefore high time to strengthen the independence of the media in all member states and to push back state influence where it is abused.
Governments must not be allowed to influence the reporting of public and private media or exert pressure on journalists. To this end, we are further developing joint instruments to protect the independence of the media and ensuring that non-governmental and civil society organizations are directly supported wherever democracy and the rule of law are under particular pressure. To this end, we are working towards a special fund for democracy and the rule of law.
Strengthening cross-border cooperation between security authorities
We want increased cross-border cooperation between police forces and security authorities in the European Union. This includes, in particular, strengthening Europol in supporting the member states. Cooperation should focus primarily on combating economic and cybercrime. It should also focus on trafficking in weapons, drugs and human beings, with a particular emphasis on sexualized violence against children and violence against women. It also remains the case that we can only counter extremist or terrorist acts of violence together as a European Union. To ensure that cross-border work works even better, we are committed to continuous training and further training with the same standards, e.g. with the help of the EU Agency for Law Enforcement Training. We also want to strengthen judicial cooperation at EU level. This applies to the European Union Agency for Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters (Eurojust), as well as to the expansion of common channels for the secure exchange of data. Further attention will be paid to combating money laundering with the planned anti-money laundering agency AMLA. With regard to the planned European anti-money laundering
AMLA agency, we are committed to the Frankfurt location. Strengthening the European Public Prosecutor's Office
The European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO) is an important authority in the fight against
(tax) fraud, corruption and money laundering. We are striving for all EU member states to quickly join the authority, in addition to the current 22 member states. We want to further strengthen the work of the EPPO by providing sufficient financial and human resources for its work. We want to e n s u r e better coordination between the national prosecution authorities, as well as in cooperation with European agencies such as Europol, Eurojust and the EPPO.
Facilitating the seizure of assets
The war in Ukraine has made it clear that increased European cooperation is also essential when it comes to investigating war crimes, punishing non-compliance with EU sanctions or confiscating and freezing the assets of oligarchs or members of organized crime.
Expanding European civil protection and strengthening crisis competencies
In the face of multiple crises and major disasters, we are committed to a European resilience strategy. It should encompass different types of challenges, including natural disasters, terrorist attacks, pandemics and other emergencies. We want to further strengthen the Emergency Response Coordination Center (ERCC) and better link it to the civil protection structures of the member states. There must be no bottlenecks in the European Union in the
supply of critical goods. When exercising crisis competences, the Commission must be subject to genuine parliamentary control. It may not exercise emergency powers without the active consent of the European Parliament.
Strengthening European consumer protection
The abolition of roaming charges, uniform charging cables and high standards for consumer and environmental protection are just a few examples that reflect the power of 450 million consumers in Europe. As citizens, we must be able to make informed decisions in order to actively contribute to tackling climate change and ensure fair coexistence. That is why we want to limit the opportunities for manipulation on the internet, which are far too often used to trick consumers into making decisions that they subsequently regret (dark patterns. Investment decisions are also often misguided by false incentives from intermediaries. We therefore advocate a ban on commission for the brokerage of financial services.
Empowered consumers need effective market supervisory authorities and a competition watchdog at their side that puts consumer protection first. Consumers must not be made solely responsible for the enforcement of market rules. This is why online marketplaces in particular must be held more accountable, have their own inspection obligations and be held liable for negligence. We want to consistently prohibit dynamic pricing by monopoly companies as an unfair business practice.
Decriminalization of cannabis
We are convinced that a licensed and controlled supply of cannabis will help to reduce the illegal drug trade and minimize health risks. We are committed to the responsible, swift legalization of cannabis in accordance with European law and want to create the legal conditions for this. The protection of health and young people is our top priority.
V. Conclusion
In times when Europe is once again threatened by nationalists and right-wing populists, in times of war on the European continent, in the face of social and economic imbalances and increasingly noticeable climate change, new impetus is needed to strengthen the cohesion of the European Union. As social democrats, we are united in the certainty that we as Europeans can only shape a better future together. In recent years, we have clearly shown that we as Europeans are capable of doing this. But there is still a lot of room for improvement.
For us, there is no either-or. The necessary restructuring of our economy, good jobs for the future, climate protection and support for the many - the SPD brings them all together. We shape progress so that things are fair.
Our Europe is socially and ecologically sustainable. Our Europe is fair, also in its external impact. Our Europe is strong and capable of action. For a better future and for our common security in all areas of life. Our Europe is a strong Europe because it holds together and because it makes people's lives better.
 
European election program 2024-2029
EUROPEAN ELECTORAL PROGRAM 2024-2029 INTRODUCTION
European election program 2024-2029
Our vision for the European Union (EU) is a climate-neutral, innovative, fair and federal Europe. We are convinced that a strong Europe is the solution to overcoming crises.
First of all, the EU needs radical democratic change. This does not just mean a top-down change, but the collective participation of all citizens and the European Parliament. For our defensive democracy, we stand for a European constitution. This will anchor our rights in a new system that is not only more responsive, but also more appealing to everyone.
We are committed to a permanent general citizens' assembly. Here, all European citizens can actively participate in shaping the future and democracy of the EU. This will promote trust, transparency and our European community.
We want to renew the European Parliament. It should b e characterized by transnational parties and have the power to initiate, amend and approve legislation. In this way, governance should be based more on the interests of the citizens than on the concerns of the member states.
Publicly accessible meetings and qualified majority voting must replace outdated veto powers to ensure that decisions are in line with the European Constitution. In this new federal Europe, member states can no longer disregard EU principles. Similarly, the European Court of Justice must have enhanced powers to prevent democratic decay and protect the integrity of the Union.
We want to revive Europol in order to strengthen Europe's internal security and to be able to resolutely counter any threat to Europe's security.
In addition, we believe that the EU must welcome new members who share our commitment to democratic values and human rights. We are laying the foundations for an EU that actively promotes justice and equality, secures European peace and prosperity and prevents social division and the destruction of democracy.
The EU economy must achieve net-zero CO2 emissions by 2040 by minimizing greenhouse gas emissions and offsetting them with carbon sequestration technologies. Companies and European citizens should actively work together on political goals and thus create a wave of collective action.

EUROPEAN ELECTORAL PROGRAM 2024-2029 INTRODUCTION
This future cannot succeed without the solid foundation of an independent energy supply in the EU. We want to achieve energy self-sufficiency by 2040 by p r o d u c i n g all energy from renewable energy sources, nuclear energy and hydrogen in Europe. In doing so, we represent the idea of a green future for Europe. All citizens should be able to participate in the development of a diverse and flexible energy mix and energy storage infrastructure. In this way, we want to enable a stable and reliable energy supply.
The creation of a green European economy requires a redesign of the EU's infrastructure. This includes sustainability, resilience and convenience. High-speed trains, efficient public transport, clean energy and advanced internet c o n n e c t i v i t y	are the foundation for Europe's future. Our waste management systems must be sustainable and investment in infrastructure must act as a bulwark against the effects of the climate crisis. On the other hand, they should create jobs and boost economic growth.
We therefore strive for economic prosperity and growth that is seamlessly linked to environmental protection and sustainability.
protection. We are redefining growth by introducing a "Green Net GDP". Carbon and resource pricing mechanisms will steer industries towards sustainability. At the same time, the revenues generated should promote innovation and the transition to a greener economy.
A pan-European social contract should ensure that prosperity is a common heritage in which citizens actively shape economic decisions. The first condition for such a treaty is to create equal opportunities. Our goal is a Europe in which every citizen is empowered to develop his or her full potential and does not experience inequality based on social background, disability, ethnicity or religion.
Such efforts must also include a fairer and more transparent system against tax evasion and avoidance. Through global cooperation, high transparency and effective enforcement, we must create a progressive and lean tax system. Every citizen should be able to make a fair contribution and at the same time rely on a fair share being paid. Our vision: breaking down barriers to success and shaping a society in which fairer wealth distribution and equal opportunities thrive.
Inclusion includes a firm commitment to accessible healthcare for all. Above all, we want to offer children a solid foundation for their careers. Young people should be supported through inclusive, gender- and culturally-sensitive education. Daycare centers and preschool programs should improve the opportunities of every child and provide unrestricted support. This applies to every child. The education system should lead us into a future in which primary, secondary and higher education are not luxury goods, but an opportunity for all. Financial resources must do justice to this aspiration and pave the way for a society based on inclusive values.

Our educational concept places the pupils at the center by incorporating interdisciplinary learning and project-based approaches. In our vision, education goes beyond the mere acquisition of knowledge: children should develop into responsible citizens by learning democratic participation, media literacy and critical thinking. Education systems that are harmonized across borders promote a socially united Europe that celebrates cultural differences and enables mobility.
Valuing diversity in Europe requires respectful, dignified and compassionate treatment of migrants and refugees, including climate refugees. We want a continent without deaths in the Mediterranean. A continent where economic migrants are not criminalized and people seeking refuge have not only the right to exist, but equal rights and opportunities. This includes access to essential living conditions, basic healthcare, employment opportunities and education. The latter includes education in the respective national language.
Respect and dignity are the cornerstones of our social policy. This includes robust workers' rights, decent wages, health and safety protection, trade union rights and flexible working arrangements. A comprehensive social safety net should develop and benefit employees, entrepreneurs and freelancers alike. There should be the opportunity to take risks without the threat of financial ruin.
Tackling our challenges at national level alone would not be enough. Our vision for Europe therefore goes beyond mere unity. We call for the EU to become a symbol of strength and diplomacy on the global stage. This includes European armed forces that defend democracy across Europe and beyond its borders and work for solidarity and security. Supported by a common defense budget and targeted, strategic resource management, this development not only secures the interests of Europeans; it also creates independence. At the same time, the principles of democratic accountability are upheld.
A future common EU foreign policy that radiates cohesion and proactivity on a global level is indispensable for this. We call for a European Foreign Minister and a European Foreign Ministry to make decision-making more effective. This is an essential complement to a European army to ensure a feminist foreign policy and open diplomatic channels. In this way, we can bring our interests to the international stage. This will make the EU an important force in multilateral organizations and lead a reformed UN. The EU must take global democracy seriously and speak up for the rights of minorities and the fight for climate justice. We want to use diplomacy and economic resources as instruments to promote peace, security and stability worldwide.

The EU must stand up for those in need of protection and shape a future in which the community stands for positive change. It is our community and our environmental and economic goals that will enable the EU to meet the global challenges of the climate crisis and climate justice. By working consistently with the countries of the world, the EU must not only secure its future, but also pave the way for a stable, low-emission world in which global warming is limited to below 2 degrees by 2040.
The EU must become the global center for climate-positive projects, offering long-term, low-interest loans and incentivizing private capital to secure climate justice. The EU has a responsibility to help global communities transition to sustainable, low-emission pathways and strengthen its commitment to the Paris Agreement. We strive f o r sustainability, resilience and equity that benefits all.
Our Europe should actively promote the economies of non-European countries, eliminate the causes of displacement through sustainable development cooperation, create financial aid and education programs, dismantle networks of illegal migration and put the needs of victims first. Our Europe should ensure legal pathways for both refugees and migrants. We want to create pathways that are standardized in all member states. Inclusion, equal burden-sharing and the free movement of people must be guaranteed.
Our cooperation must be based on democratic values and aim to reduce poverty, conflicts, climate crisis and political instability.
One thing is clear: we must act quickly. The climate crisis, conflicts, overcrowded refugee camps and social resistance will not tolerate any further delay. Together, we can shape a future that offers solutions that are stronger.
We want positive change that not only prevents the worst, but enables the best: a strong, climate- neutral, innovative and fair Europe. Volt is already working across Europe on bold, concrete and constructive solutions. For a Europe in which we not only prevent the climate catastrophe, but also enable a better future: clean i n d u s t r i e s , an innovative economy, social peace and safe coexistence.
But we can only achieve this together.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029
A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
1. Europe's path to sustainable prosperity
Today, the EU is the world's largest economic area. This success story is the result of decades of economic integration. The EU's economic weight and global network have enabled significant social progress. This ranges from rising incomes and increased well-being to peace and stability.
We want to grow together economically and implement an urgent renewal of our economic structure. This is necessary to overcome the challenges we face today within Europe and around the world. The climate crisis, geopolitical dependencies, the digital transformation and the social divide that fuels extremist politics are major challenges that we need to solve quickly. We therefore want to promote innovation, ensure effective taxation and conserve resources.
cations for the promotion of sustainability and a fair society within and between States fairly.
As a progressive movement, we do not want to play economic growth, justice and sustainability off against each other. Instead, we promote a vision in which government action simultaneously protects, provides opportunity and drives economic progress. As we strive for long-term prosperity, our way of measuring growth must respect both natural limits and the goal of a just and resilient society.
Research and innovation are key components in the promotion of European, new and established industries. At the same time, they make it possible to counteract global societal challenges such as the climate crisis, digitalization and global health risks. We must create framework conditions for innovative technologies such as carbon capture and storage (CCS) and artificial intelligence to enable consumers and companies of all sizes to use them. At the same time, our natural and social limits must be respected (e.g. in terms of data protection or energy consumption, see also the chapter "Good jobs and prosperity for all").
Our vision differs fundamentally from the current economic and political climate.
spirit and lays the foundations for the development of Europe's sustainable prosperity. By putting itself at the forefront of this development, Europe will continue to help accelerate these developments worldwide and thus strengthen democratic institutions worldwide.

1.1 Rethinking the economy
 Introduction of new and progressive economic indicators and targets to be used for the evaluation of public investments. These indicators and targets take into account the value of natural resources and set incentives against their exploitation.

 
Intensify the efforts of European institutions to coordinate the collection and use of economic data. This should help to create sustainable economic indicators.
 Inclusion of sustainability and quality of life measurements in political decisions. This applies to the application of European budgetary rules, EU budget negotiations and the European Semester process.

1.4 Shaping digital transformation responsibly
 Continuous research into technologies and the impact of current legislation. This should result in new laws that facilitate the development of digital technologies. The focus should be on preserving European values and creating future industries.
 Ensure the security and protection of users of digital technologies. For example, the security situation of the critical infrastructure should be communicated to the public on an annual basis.
 Promotion of barrier-free and accessible open source technologies. We want to increase access to open source software for EU institutions and industries and ensure that everyone in Europe has access to new technologies. Supportive legislation must be created here.
 Promoting sustainable and durable technologies. For example, we want to Strengthen the "right to repair" so that everyone who can repair their product themselves has access to affordable spare parts and repair information. Similarly, manufacturers should be required to publish the environmental footprint of products in their specifications (including the manufacturer's supply chain).
 
Ensure that current and new technologies do not violate fundamental rights and freedoms. For example, we want to introduce mandatory reviews of AI systems to ensure that they do not violate privacy or create discriminatory effects.
 Supporting entrepreneurs in adapting to the EU regulatory framework. In doing so, we want to regulato
sandboxes" and provide funds for technological support in existing and future EU funding programs.
 Fair taxation of digital technologies. Taxation should take place where the turnover of the digital product is generated.
 Strengthening the EU framework conditions for the design of technologies. Suppliers operating in Europe should be put in a position to future-proof their emerging technologies.
shape the future. Securing the future is particularly important in the current global Industrial Revolution 4.0 and enables the EU to contribute its values to the international dialog.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029
A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
1.5 Permanent European investment programs
 Permanent inclusion of the recovery and resilience program in EU budget negotiations. This is the largest EU program to promote economic development as well as social and environmental goals. We are committed to ensuring that this program strengthens the EU's strategic autonomy. In this way, we want to strengthen our economic supply chains and create incentives for critical goods to be produced and stored in the EU (re-shoring).
 Strengthening programs such as "Invest EU". These offer support for small and medium-sized enterprises. This applies in particular to companies with innovative business models or companies that provide critical goods. The investment rules of such programmes should strengthen regions that are affected by brain drain in order to counteract the geographical centralization of the European economy.
 Reforming the rules for the import of goods and services. We want to prevent European taxpayers from paying for the import of goods from outside the European Economic Area. This applies when these are of strategic importance for the
economic autonomy of the EU and would therefore have to be offered in the EU itself. Imports of strategic goods lead to dependencies that counteract our desired goal of increased strategic autonomy.
 Introduction of a "Small Business Act for Europe". This reserves 25% of public contracts at EU and national level for small and medium-sized enterprises. At the same time, legislation and requirements at both levels should not harm such companies. We want to simplify the public procurement process and reporting requirements for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029
A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
1.6 Stronger integration of the European single market
 Promoting the integration of the European market. This applies in particular to the financial markets. A truly integrated financial market should enable entrepreneurs in Eastern Europe, for example, to have the same financial opportunities as those in Western Europe.
 Completion of the banking and capital market union. To this end, we want to introduce a Europe-wide deposit guarantee for bank deposits and European government bonds in order to offer banks effective investments and adequate protection. This will support the completion of European banking regulation.
 Development of safe assets. These are covered by government bonds issued by the EU, the repayment of which is secured by European debt and taxes.
 Increasing the accessibility of capital markets for consumers and companies. This affects both debt and equity capital and our small and medium-sized enterprises. At the same time, it will be easier to raise capital via alternative financial instruments such as crowdfunding and peer-to-peer loans.
 
Strengthening corporate governance standards through tax incentives. In this way, we want to reduce the risk of mismanagement, fraud and excessive speculation. To this end, we want to increase the required equity capital for European banks in order to avoid taxpayers having to pay for expensive bank bailouts.

1.7 Trade, sustainability and human rights
 Introduction of mandatory human rights and environmental sustainability criteria. All EU trade agreements must be reviewed in this regard and ongoing negotiations must be interrupted in the event of repeated violations.
 Introduction of mandatory measures for monitoring and identifying products. This is intended to prevent products from forced labor from entering the market.
 
Consideration of economic realities in third countries so that both parties benefit from EU trade agreements.

1.8 Critical infrastructure protection
 Expansion of the definition of critical infrastructure. This should also include European transport systems, infrastructure for waste disposal and water supply, the healthcare system and public health services, energy supply networks, ports, airports, nuclear power plants, digital communication networks, data centers, network cables, farmland and chemical plants.
 Bringing forward investment in critical pan- European infrastructure projects. This includes a renewed commitment to Trans- European Transport Networks (TEN-T). To this end, we want to double the EU funding instrument "Connecting Europe".
 
Introduction of the right for the EU to prevent foreign direct investment (FDI) in critical infrastructure. This should happen if it comes to the conclusion that an investment poses a security risk to the European economy. This ensures that the EU retains its necessary autonomy. The same
a p p l i e s t o the use of foreign parts.
 Introduction of the right for the EU to acquire critical infrastructure directly. This should apply to objects that are to be sold to foreign buyers if such a sale is deemed a security risk.

A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
1.9 Payment transactions and financial services - more secure and competitive
 Introduction of measures that offer EU citizens and companies secure and affordable options for payments and digital financial services. The aim is to prevent a few companies that charge high transaction fees from dominating the market.
 Combining competition and good offers for customers. Competition in the market for financial services and the introduction of useful features such as inexpensive card payments or instant bank transfers must be reconciled.
 Initiation of competition proceedings in cases where the market for payment services is dominated by a small number of companies.
 Review of the establishment of a European public company for payment processing. This applies in the event that it should be determined that large American payment processors exploit their dominant market position to charge excessive fees.
 
Introduction of a digital euro as a useful means of payment without having to rely on a bank account. This should also create competitive pressure on the market for deposits and payments. There should be no upper limits on the amount of digital euros held by private individuals and salary payments should be able to be made in these.
 Preservation of cash. Cash should be preserved and protected as the central legal tender in our economy. However, real estate transactions with cash should be limited throughout Europe in order to prevent money laundering.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029
A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
1.10 Combating tax evasion and avoidance
 Measures to combat tax evasion and avoidance. This is widespread in the EU due to tax competition between member states and often allows large international companies to avoid taxes, while small and medium-sized enterprises have to pay their fair share.
> Harmonization of corporate taxation.
This is to be achieved by using a common corporate tax base (CCCTB) in the EU. The profits of multinational corporations should be distributed among the member states using a precise formula.
> Introduction of an effective minimum corporation tax. This should amount to at least 22%. At the same time, mandatory national surcharge taxes should be levied on corporate profits from low-tax countries in order to effectively achieve at least 22%. In addition, optional national surcharge taxes up to the national tax rate should be made possible.
> Facilitating the automatic and mandatory exchange of information between all EU member states. This is to be achieved with the help of our proposed EU Ministry of Finance as the coordinating institution (see the "Strengthening the EU" section).
 Effective action against tax evasion and illegal money flows. We currently have no overview of where a large proportion of private and corporate assets are located in Europe or abroad.
is located at all. By i m p r o v i n g the exchange of information between national authorities, we can better understand wealth inequality, fight against tax evasion and stop the flow of illegal money from abroad into Europe.
> Introduction of a central asset register. The aim is to merge data from various sources,
e.g. from national tax and land registers. The EU Ministry of Finance should take responsibility for this project in order to close the current knowledge gaps on the distribution of wealth.
> Worldwide exchange of data with other such registers. Suitable mechanisms must be created for this. In particular, this should be carried out with regard to information on offshore tax havens.
European data protection standards must be guaranteed for such exchanges.
> Authorization of the EU Ministry of Finance to negotiate reciprocal exchanges. The Ministry needs the right to negotiate agreements for the reciprocal exchange of such data with the competent authorities in international financial centers.
> Enforcement of EU rules on the registration of beneficial owners. Member states must be obliged to keep national registers so that real estate investors can no longer hide behind anonymous front companies.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029
A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
How do we bring these proposals to the European Parliament?
The measures described in the chapter "Europe's path to sustainable prosperity" require both minor and major changes to the existing legal framework of the European Union.
Some would require additional changes to the treaties. These include, for example, the use of new indicators for the application of the European Union's budgetary rules, which would require an amendment to Articles 121 and 126 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and Protocol 12 of the Treaty. Similarly, some measures to protect critical infrastructure require an amendment to the EU Treaties, as national security is the responsibility of the Member States. In addition, a deposit guarantee financed by the European Union and covered by European debt and taxes is likely to require a treaty amendment.
Other proposed measures require less far- reaching changes to existing legal or administrative instruments. For example the measures to promote green
economy, new legal instruments and amendments to existing or proposed secondary legislation by the Commission are required, including Regulation (EU) 2023/1781 (Chips Act), the Critical Raw Materials Act (not yet adopted) or the Net Zero Industry Act (not yet adopted). Similarly, the measures to complete the banking and capital markets union require the adoption of new secondary legislation in this area without amending the treaties. Furthermore, to facilitate the exchange of information between Member States, the introduction of new secondary legislation is required, possibly amending existing instruments such as Council Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. In addition, new investments require the agreement of the Member States to increase the EU budget within the framework of
of the multiannual financial framework. Finally, the proposal "Sustainable European Investment Programs" requires an amendment to Directive 2014/24/EU on public procurement.

What expenditure and income do these proposals generate?
The total cost of the measures in this chapter, including implementation costs and annual costs over five years, is 316,364,000,000. The implementation costs amount to  308,646,500,000 and the annual costs amount to  1,543,500,000.
Examples of implementation costs include the development of political and legal frameworks, capacity building and the training of (new) staff, the development of IT or physical infrastructure or public awareness campaigns.
Examples of annual costs include salaries and social benefits, administrative costs, infrastructure maintenance and the costs associated with implementing the proposed measures.
The total costs of the complete election program are listed separately from the total revenue.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029
A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
2.1 The EU must speak with one voice in the world
 Development of the European External Action Service (EEAS) into a Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the European Union (MAAEU). This reform is intended to make the EU's foreign policy apparatus more efficient, effective and globally influential. Due to its democratic mandate, the newly created Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the European Union is the sole representative for the jointly formulated foreign policy of the EU. The Ministry is to perform key tasks in the area of political (international cooperation, human rights, neighborhood and enlargement, humanitarian aid) and scientific diplomacy (climate and global health, development of an EU space strategy and civil exploration of Mars, the moon, etc.).
 Division of the role of the High Representation of the EU for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy into two separate positions. One is responsible for European foreign policy and the other for European defense. This division of tasks is intended to enable specialization and focused leadership in their respective areas of responsibility.
 Promotion of a common diplomatic culture. This is to take place at both national and ministerial level. The number of EU staff is to be increased in proportion to the number of seconded national staff.
At the same time, participation in the European Diplomatic Academy and its training programs will be mandatory for all EU diplomatic staff (both national and ministerial).
 Improvement of consular services. The ministry is to manage the bilateral representation and consular services for all EU member states in third countries without a national diplomatic presence in these member states.
 Establishment of an appropriate joint intelligence analysis unit. The EU Intelligence and Situation Center will be empowered to collect and process information gathered by Member States and ministerial delegations. The intelligence service will also establish its own intelligence gathering capabilities under effective parliamentary and judicial scrutiny to ensure respect for human rights. EU intelligence analysis will inform the decision-making processes of common EU foreign and security policy, including the identification of common security threats and priorities.

2.2 A progressive foreign policy
 Promote a strong awareness of the colonial and imperialist legacies of member states in third countries in the European diplomatic corps. This should be reflected in EU diplomacy towards these third countries by creating a diverse and united diplomatic representation with a European voice.
 Highlighting different historical contexts in Europe. This should help to establish a structured dialog with third countries and be based o n equality and respect. The aim is to move away from past paternalistic and exploitative legacies and counteract resentment.
 
Integration of a feminist foreign policy within the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the European Union. Internally, this requires ensuring equal participation of women* and other disadvantaged groups in the EU diplomatic service, including in leadership positions. Externally, the EU will promote equal participation in negotiations and peace agreements with other international actors. EU delegations to international negotiations will be composed according to the principles of feminist foreign policy.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029
A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
2.3 The vision of a bigger, stronger and more inclusive Union
 Introduction of a new enlargement methodology based on gradual and phased integration into the EU. This replaces the current "all or nothing" approach with an efficient, transparent and fair process. As accession countries make progress in implementing reforms to align with EU law, they will gradually gain more access to EU resources such as the EU budget and participation in EU institutions. These stages can be reversed if the reforms take a step backwards. The then European government (formerly the Commission) will monitor this process. Candidate countries must be able to fully understand the process and the assessment of their progress and have the means to review decisions. The new system will accelerate candidate entry times through new incentives for reform, counteracting "enlargement fatigue" while improving the flexibility of the EU's "absorption capacity".
 Adaptation of EU enlargement to other non- European organizations. The new staged enlargement should be complemented by membership of other framework organizations such as the European Political Community (EPC) and the Council of Europe. Membership of such organizations should not be an alter- native to EU membership for future candidates, but should be differentiated in terms of different priorities and the
complement the scope of the commitment. The
EU enlargement should be based on a performance-based
open-door policy.
 Providing special support for nations confronted with foreign aggression. To this end, a
clearly prepared range of options will be developed. Countries aspiring to EU membership and under threat will be provided with appropriate instruments to protect their sovereignty, territorial integrity and societal resilience on their path to EU accession. In addition, the EU is to fulfill special long-term political, financial and military commitments to protect Ukraine and secure its path towards EU accession.
Financial resources that are confiscated as part of sanctions against Russia are to be used for such aid, accession reforms and reconstruction.
 Reform of the EU in preparation for enlargement. In particular, decision-making procedures that currently require unanimity in the Council must be replaced by qualified majority voting (QMV) in order to avoid blockades caused by the individual veto of member states. In addition, the EU budget must be reformed in order to meet the financial needs of an enlarged EU (see chapter "Reforming the EU").

A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
2.4 A smaller global North-South divide in the economy
 Establishment of a "European Development Aid Agency" to pool national development aid efforts. According to the OECD figures for 2022, the 27 member states and institutions of the European Union together contribute 115 billion US dollars to development aid, twice as much as the sum of American aid. In order to increase effectiveness and visibility, Volt proposes that funding and mechanisms for official development assistance be pooled at European level within the framework of a "European Development Agency". Specific financial, personnel and institutional regulations should be created for this purpose. This transfer would provide the EU with unique opportunities to contribute to the implementation of sustainable development goals and to strengthen its capabilities in the area of foreign policy. strengthen "soft power".
 Development and promotion of a "Strasbourg Consensus" on development aid. This is linked to the further development of similar models from the USA and China. In the "Washington Consensus", the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) linked loans to the opening of national economies, with sometimes catastrophic effects. For their part, China and its allies have developed a "Beijing Consensus". This promises to finance infrastructure. However, little consideration is given to the countries' indebtedness, principles of governance and human rights.
The EU can develop and promote an independent consensus that reshapes international cooperation in the field of development aid. It should be based on the following principles:
> Reorganization of the debt of the least developed countries within the framework of the Paris Club (60 countries are affected by over- indebtedness).
> Introduction of a new clause in loan agreements for developing countries that automatically suspends repayments in the event of a severe natural disaster.
> Revision of the regulations of international institutions. The recruitment of World Bank and IMF executives should be based on their skills. Representatives of civil society and NGOs should be involved in the committees of these institutions.
> Credit conditions that are linked to the fight against corruption, respect for the rights of minorities and guidelines for the promotion and protection of women*.

2.5 Autonomous competence for military and civil defense
 Development of the EDA (European Defence Agency) and the defense-industrial elements of the European Commission (e.g. DG DEFIS) into a European Ministry of Defense (EUMD). This is intended to create a centralized institution for European defence matters. This includes strategies, operations, research, procurement of the technical and industrial base.
 Establishment of a European Military Headquarters (EMHQ), which is responsible for developing strategies and making decisions on operations.
of the EU military units. This EMHQ reports to the EUMD and should be supported by a European Military Academy (EMA), which trains and educates a new generation of military personnel with a common military culture and creates a common military culture.
 Strengthening regional specialization in certain areas (e.g. air, land, sea) and capabilities (e.g. cyber, amphibious, airborne operations). In the short term, this will promote the joint development o f defense capabilities and increase the cost efficiency and interaction of national EU forces. At the same time, best practices in the regional integration of national units will be promoted and standardized at the operational level. Examples include Franco- German and German-Dutch units. This is intended to
contribute to the development of a common military culture and operational effectiveness.
 Development of joint EU defense capabilities. In the medium term, the aim is to ensure that the Rapid Deployment Capacity (RDC) is operational by 2025. This should be further expanded, provided with EU personnel and standardized equipment and given extended mission objectives. In addition, the EU should establish a standing European Intervention Force (ERF) with a personnel strength of 60,000 soldiers. It will be equipped with a wide range of land, air, sea and space resources. Its main purpose is to be the first response force to threats to the territorial integrity of the EU and to complement national armed forces. This capability is the EU's first priority. It can also be made available to NATO. The EMA will train the personnel of the RDC and ERF.
 Establishment of transnational military units under EU leadership. To this end, an agreement accessible to all EU members will be created, which will form a steering body with the necessary powers. This body can set up integrated
Establish EU military units where decisions are taken by qualified majority and in coordination with NATO. Such units will be placed under the authority of the reformed European government (see Chapter 7).

2.6 More strategic autonomy for the EU defense industry
 Authorization of the EU Ministry of Defence t o identify military requirements and to ensure research, development and provision of these capabilities through tenders.
This will equip the European armed forces with state-of-the-art military capabilities. As long as this main objective is achieved, procurement should promote development in economically underdeveloped regions of the EU.
 Strengthening the EU's position as a global innovator in the defense sector. The EU should become a driving force for the development of emerging and ground- breaking strategic defense technologies. Existing efforts such as the EU Defense Innovation Scheme (EUDIS) and the Hub for EU Defense Innovation (HEDI) should be safeguarded and their mandates and funding increased. This initiative should focus on capability areas where the EU can achieve global competitiveness, such as the development of cyber-,
AI, carbon neutrality (e.g. green hydrogen), quantum computing and space defense technologies.
 Consolidation of the European Defense Fund (EDF). The aim is to bring together existing separate EU funding instruments in connection with joint defense initiatives, including research, development and procurement. The EDF will become a permanent part of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) in the next budget cycle
and will comprise at least 6% of the EU budget. In addition, a new target will be established that requires at least 60% of all defense spending by member states to be made available for joint projects.
 Integration of the EU defense industry into the internal market. National industrial protectionism is to be dismantled in order to create significant economies of scale. This will be replaced by the creation of EU regional defense industry hubs (industry, education, etc.) around leading countries. SMEs and companies in neighboring Member States should be involved in this.
 Develop precise common rules on arms exports and ensure strict and consistent enforcement for EU defense companies operating outside the EU.

2.7 Europe as a strong pillar for NATO and the democratic states
 Establishment of an EU-NATO Strategy Coordination Group. By this we mean a political steering body that
structured, long-term cooperation between the two associations. The committee will develop a joint strategic document defining common priorities, threat perceptions, capacity requirements, availability of forces and areas of specialization (such as territorial defense vs. hybrid resilience). It should also delineate regional and thematic roles, particularly with regard to the distribution of roles in Europe and the Indo-Pacific. At the same time, emerging and groundbreaking technologies that could be decisive for defense should be included.
 Continuation of the task force on the resilience of critical infrastructures. Here, concrete measures are to be taken to ensure the effectiveness and resilience of critical infrastructures in the Euro-Atlantic military supply chain network. This includes undersea communication cables and infrastructures that are crucial for energy supply and military mobility. EU and NATO candidate countries should also be included.
 Increase interdependence to minimize the risk of transatlantic political tensions. This should
be promoted through joint integration in non-military initiatives. This would relate in particular to market integration, setting regulatory standards and minimizing strategic dependencies in relation to emerging technologies (AI, quantum computing), critical value chains for rare earth minerals and semiconductors. We want to illustrate such efforts using the example of the
EU-US Trade and Technology Council (TTC) and the sustainable Club for Steel and Aluminium (GSA). These efforts should help to create a transatlantic "Brussels effect".
 Develop a broader strategy for deeper cooperation with other countries that share political norms, values and interests with the EU and NATO. This includes candidate countries of both organizations, key non- NATO allies and regional organizations. This voluntary cooperation should include efforts to increase mutual deterrence, societal resilience and political cooperation in order to strengthen the unity of democracies.
 The Summit for Democracy should be institutionalized as a forum for coordination. This forum should pursue clear membership criteria and an open- door policy.

2.8 Ensuring comprehensive strategic deterrence
 Promote the global ban on nuclear weapons and support the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW) as a long-term strategy for the global disarmament of nuclear weapons. This is subject to the condition that it is compatible with the fundamental need for a credible strategic deterrent in the event of persistent threats.
 Reduce the global stockpile of nuclear weapons, both in terms of operational warheads and those decommissioned or in storage. This would alleviate the problem of verifiability, reduce the risk of human error in the event of a (large-scale) nuclear attack and improve the effectiveness of monitoring, while at the same time reducing the risk of circumvention.
 Transfer of control of the French nuclear deterrent potential to the European government. This is to take place following the adoption of a European constitution and the establishment of fully democratic and accountable federal institutions. Over time, the personnel, systems and procedures will be fully integrated into European structures.
 Development of a strategic defense system capable of effectively countering airborne threats to the
EU territory. This includes the ability to respond to limited (ballistic) nuclear attacks.
 Establishment of a conventional strike force. This should offer a broader range of options along the escalation ladder and minimize dependence on nuclear deterrence wherever possible.
 Pursuing a holistic approach to governance. The aim is to ensure the EU's resilience in times of peace, conflict and war as well as in the "gray zone" in between. Current EU policy is mainly focused on promoting resilience as a framework to combat different threats. Although this framework is effective, the EU needs to develop specific policies and measures to implement this framework effectively.
 Integration of existing instruments (Cyber Diplomacy Toolbox, EU Hybrid Threats Framework) to create a doctrine for different types of threats. This doctrine will build on the Council of Europe's "Helsinki Approach" to establish a uniform classification for different types of threats. The first implementation of this framework will be cyber resilience under the Cyber Solidarity Act.

2.9 Advocating for a reformed multilateral system
 Adoption of a comprehensive pan- demic agreement to implement a robust framework for pandemic prevention, preparedness and response. This also includes a mandate for comprehensive information gathering. Particular attention will be paid to bridging the capacity gap in the healthcare system in developing countries.
 Restructuring of the global financial system to promote inclusivity and fairness in the global financial system. This applies in particular to the effective
Tackling climate finance for developing countries. Initiatives such as the Paris Summit for a new global financial pact will be an integral part of this. The ratification of a global minimum tax rate for companies will be accelerated.
 Introduction of new own resources for the UN, creation of financial mechanisms such as a Global Resources Dividend (GRD) or a Tobin tax. In this way, we want to finance transitions in line with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and distribute the financial burden of the United Nations more fairly.
 Convocation of a United Nations Parliamentary Assembly (UNPA). This is intended to strengthen the democratic legitimacy of the UN and set a precedent for the
representative democracy at UN level, which could be further expanded in terms of its mandate and scope in the future. This includes abolishing vetoes by permanent members of the United Nations Security Council (UNSC). The UNPA should introduce a representative electoral system that takes into account the population size of the member states.
 Reform of the UN Security Council (UNSC). In the short term, we want to add more permanent members to the UNSC and convert the French permanent UNSC seat into an EU seat. In the long term, we want to abolish the permanent seats and introduce regular elections for UNSC seats by the General Assembly (later the UNPA). These elections would draw from a pool of candidates from regional groups. The UNSC should increase the total number of seats to better reflect regional, economic and population diversity. This includes the allocation of seats to regional organizations. In addition, the majority voting principle should replace unanimity on matters related to genocide, crimes against humanity or war crimes. This includes decisions that legitimize military interventions.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029
A STRONGER EU: THE GEOPOLITICAL IMPORTANCE OF EUROPE
How do we bring these proposals to the European Parliament?
The Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) is based, among other things, on Articles 21-46 of the EU Treaty and Articles 205-222 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). In the area of CFSP, the EU currently has special legislative competences, which include specific institutional features such as the limited participation of the European Parliament in the decision-making process. The CFSP is currently defined and implemented by the European Council and the Council of the European Union.
In order to implement the measures of the Act, it is legally necessary to amend treaties. These changes include the establishment of common legislative competences to enable the Union to introduce common standards through legislation. Policy measures, such as "One voice for the EU in the world", require a comprehensive review of the existing legal framework. This includes restructuring the European External Action Service (EEAS) into a European Union Ministry for Foreign Affairs (EUMFA) and splitting the role of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy (HR) into two positions, namely an EU Minister for Foreign Affairs and an EU Minister for Defense. To implement this policy, we propose amendments to the Treaties
before. We want to amend Title III of the EU Treaty "Provisions relating to the institutions",
Title V of the EU Treaty "General provisions on the Union's external action and specific provisions on the common foreign and security policy", Title V of the
TFEU on "International Agreements" and the Declaration on the Common Foreign and Security Policy.
In addition, subsequent legislation is required to create and further define ministerial
o f f i c e s .	Volt s e e k s to strengthen the EU's strategic autonomy in the defense industry by enhancing the EU's position as a global defense innovator. To consolidate and improve entities such as the EU Defense Innovation Scheme (EUDIS) and the Hub for EU Defense Innovation (HEDI), there is a need for amendments and updates to existing secondary legislation, such as EU Regulation 2021/697 on the European Defense Fund.
They also require
political efforts to strengthen and renew the role of the Union in the global context, the advocacy of principles
such as feminist foreign policy within the existing framework of NATO and the United Nations as well as in new bilateral and multilateral agreements.

Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU) enshrines the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy and equality. All European laws should be based on these principles and promote their implementation in the lives of all EU citizens and people living in the European Union.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 QUALITY OF LIFE
4. Good jobs and prosperity for all
Average incomes in Europe have grown in recent decades. However, this has not happened fast enough and has not benefited everyone. The increase in productivity has also slowed and has not benefited everyone equally. As a result, there are significant inequalities within the EU, both locally and between member states. Such a two-tier market means that some workers have secure and stable jobs, while others with fewer rights have to remain in insecure and precarious employment.
Some regions with great potential for sustainable growth experienced a significant shortage of skilled workers and the associated disadvantages for young people on the labor market.
At the same time, women* continue to be underrepresented in well-paid jobs and bear the greater burden of unpaid domestic and care work.
There are many vacancies that remain unfilled due to poor working conditions, with labor rights and protections unevenly enforced across member states. These inequalities affect the well-being of workers and hinder the creation of social cohesion across borders.
The clear lack of sufficient mechanisms for social cohesion at European level further exacerbates the situation and slows down the cooperation needed to overcome common challenges. As a result, poverty remains at an alarmingly high level.
By creating a productive, fair and meaningful working environment for all citizens, we can achieve the emergence of a European social union that supports all Europeans and guarantees their rights. The use of technologies such as automation, AI and green technologies will increase labor productivity, leading to new types of jobs, higher wages and reduced working hours. If we ensure that EU citizens have the skills and education required for these technologies, their use will reduce the burden on workers. Remote work can unleash the full potential of the European labor market. At the same time, robust labour rights ensure fair wages and working conditions for all workers by harmonizing standards across the European Union.
Finally, we propose ending tax competition between Member States and facilitating the harmonization of taxation by defining a common minimum tax base for direct taxation in the EU.
Volt Europe	49Volt Germany | Choriner Str. 34 | 10435 Berlin
EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 QUALITY OF LIFE
4.1 A genuine European social union
 Development towards a genuine European social union. This is to be achieved in the course of establishing a new EU Ministry of Finance (see the chapters "Europe's path to sustainable prosperity" and "Strengthening the
EU") as the coordinating institution, which will manage an EU budget that is three times larger. This enlarged budget aims to make strategic investments, address social inequalities and protect against economic downturns. Our proposals are:
> A European Basic Income (EBI). This is based on a negative income tax, where people below a certain income threshold receive payments instead of paying taxes.
This creates a safety net and promotes employment, which helps people to escape poverty traps. The EU Ministry of Finance is to finance this from the EU budget so that all EU citizens, adjusted to the purchasing power of the respective region, have access to an income of at least
500 per month. This income would help many EU citizens to cover their basic living costs. With the European Basic Income, we can take a big step towards a truly united European Union. The legal basis for the European Basic Income has already been established for all member states by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
Article 107 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union on state aid is binding.
> Creation of incentives for member states to reduce the number of tax exemptions and to apply lower income tax rates and reduce the number of taxes.
This should simplify the tax system and at the same time ensure that citizens can lead a dignified life with the European Basic Income.
> Enforcement of regional minimum wage standards. This should be done in coordination with the member states or a high degree of trade union coverage to ensure that the European Basic Income cannot be exploited.
> Harmonization of taxation procedures between member states so that people have fewer obstacles to working and living in different European countries.
> Creation of a common EU tax base for direct taxes. In doing so, we want to introduce EU-wide minimum effective rates for gift, inheritance and wealth taxation using the European Central Wealth Register (see chapter
"Europe's path to sustainable prosperity").

The European economy should not exist as an end in itself, but should guarantee prosperity and economic security for all citizens of the European Union. The legal framework of the European Union must better reflect this goal of shared prosperity and economic security. To achieve this, we need legislative changes and new laws.
This chapter describes ambitions for a European basic income, an EU tax reform, a European minimum wage and collective bargaining as well as a European social union. The introduction of a European basic income requires far-reaching changes, as the EU currently has no direct competence for social security. Article 153 TFEU (Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) allows the European Parliament to adopt supporting measures to ensure basic social rights. A new protocol could give the EU the competence to develop and finance such a basic income. A harmonized EU tax base for gift and inheritance taxes as well as wealth taxes can
be achieved through the adoption of directives similar to the VAT Directives.
The introduction of EU taxes requires, among other things, an amendment to Article 311 TFEU, which deals with the system of own resources of the EU.
European Union. A treaty amendment is necessary to enable direct tax collection by the European Union. We therefore support Parliament's call to open up the EU treaties to a convention consisting of representatives of the national parliaments, the heads of state or government of the member states, the European Parliament and the Commission to examine the proposal for a treaty amendment. In doing so, we will ensure that the European Union is given responsibility for tax collection and borrowing. Potential indirect taxes, such as digital or emissions taxes, could be included in a new protocol with
be determined with the unanimous consent of the member states. Directive (EU) 2022/2041 on adequate minimum wages in the European Union already exists, but needs to be strengthened. To introduce European minimum wages and to promote
Article 153 TFEU is used for cross-border collective bargaining. This provision enables coordinated action with regard to working conditions and social protection. An amendment to the TFEU would make it possible to deepen the integration of social policy. This would create a legal framework for cooperation while preserving the autonomy of the Member States.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 HUMANE MIGRATION
5. Asylum seekers and refugees
Due to delayed decisions, inhumane reception conditions, mass detentions and the and exclusion at the EU borders, asylum seekers and refugees must
live in Europe under difficult conditions. The distribution of asylum seekers among the member states is still controversial and leaves people in need of protection in a legal limbo.
The current system is dysfunctional and forces asylum seekers to t a k e unsafe, illegal routes. Violations of EU law by European border control authorities and limited search and rescue operations exacerbate the disorganization. As a result, the questionable agreements between EU member states and autocratic
regimes at their borders are not a viable solution and contribute to unnecessary deaths.
The need for change is becoming even more urgent as unprecedented numbers of people worldwide are displaced by various factors such as wars, persecution and environmental disasters. However, most refugees seek refuge in neighboring countries, not in Europe. Volt recognizes that although refugees in the EU make up only a small fraction of the total population, they contribute to the multicultural and diverse fabric of European societies. To overcome these challenges, Europe needs an efficient, fair and humane system. The Asylum and Refugee Act offers concrete solutions to the challenges of integrating asylum s e e k e r s and refugees. It establishes uniform, swift and fair asylum procedures and reception conditions that ensure humane treatment on an equal footing.
In order to reduce the disproportionate burden on border states and ensure that people are placed in an environment where they can rebuild their lives, this chapter proposes a fair redistribution system. This starts on arrival: Asylum seekers are distributed evenly according to objective criteria, taking into account personal preferences. Priority is given to immediate access to social, legal, medical and psychological assistance. As a result, the law promotes the immediate integration and empowerment of refugees and asylum seekers and recognizes their potential to contribute to society.
We also emphasize the protection of the human rights of vulnerable people. Safe, regular routes should be created for refugees and violations of their rights should be monitored. Human rights are safeguarded through the legal recognition of climate refugees. This represents a forward-looking approach t o overcoming the challenges of climate-induced displacement. The establishment of additional regular channels for labor migration, as set out in the Labor Migration Act, will reduce the influx of asylum seekers to Europe. This law improves the conditions for asylum seekers within the EU. It also addresses problems beyond the borders of the EU. The focus here is on the causes of flight and improving reception conditions in the region.

5.3 Humane, fast and fair asylum procedures
 Asylum seekers should be registered upon arrival in open registration centers at the EU borders and informed quickly about the procedure. Efficient initial documentation, security checks and medical checks should take place there.

Women* and people with disabilities, who should be identified and receive appropriate support throughout the asylum procedure, especially upon arrival.
Unaccompanied minor asylum seekers must have a guardian or specially trained assistant available from the moment of identification.
 
Creation of a standardized database for use by national and EU authorities.
 Establish a system that ensures that all asylum seekers are transferred to their final member states as quickly as possible.

 Commitment of all Member States to a common European asylum system in which responsibility is shared between the Member States in a spirit of solidarity. "Special social group" of the Geneva Convention.

How do we bring these proposals to the European Parliament?
The right to asylum, enshrined in Article 18 of the EU Charter, is a fundamental right that Volt wants to secure and strengthen in further legislation. Volt aims to provide the Union with powers to legislate on harmonized integration policy on the occasion of an upcoming treaty change. We want to propose further updates to EU legislation. In addition, the so-called solidarity mechanism as set out in the AMMR, which currently facilitates relocation, needs to be amended,
to ensure fair and efficient resettlement. This amendment must take into account the personal connections of the refugees as well as the key indicators of the Member States such as
e.g. take GDP into account. Volt also calls for the proposed Asylum Procedures Regulation 2016/0224 (COD) to be amended to further
harmonization of asylum procedures and consideration for humane and lean procedures at the borders. The proposed Qualification Regulation 2016/0223 (COD) and the Reception Conditions Directive 2016/0222 (COD) must meet the standards
in the Member States. This includes a uniform approach to granting asylum and adequate reception conditions. Volt also wants to support the revision of Directive 2011/36/EU on combating trafficking in human beings and call on all member states to promote the early detection of trafficking in human beings. improve the identification and referral of victims to support organizations. This applies in particular in connection with the asylum procedure. Refugees and persons enjoying subsidiary protection have the same right to family reunification in accordance with Directive 2003/86/EC. The status of climate refugees should be recognized.
