EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 HUMANE MIGRATION
6. Labor migration
Europe's demographic challenge, made tangible by an ageing population and an acute shortage of skilled workers, can also offer an opportunity for innovation and growth. Facing up to the problem opens up opportunities that can improve Europe's long-term competitiveness and economic resilience. It is therefore necessary to attract international skilled workers without weakening the rights of non-EU workers. This balance is crucial to prevent labor exploitation and create an attractive environment for third-country nationals at all wage levels.
Workers in the low and middle-income sector are often exposed to precarious conditions. Especially without EU status, they run the risk of being exploited, as their employment is tied to very specific employers. In contrast, highly skilled migrant workers face bureaucratic hurdles that limit their flexibility within the European labor market and ensure that many skilled workers emigrate to more attractive countries such as Canada, the USA and Australia instead.
The fragmentation of labor markets within the EU member states poses a challenge to the competitiveness of the entire European Union. A common European approach to labor migration would stimulate the labor market and promote growth. To achieve this, migration must be managed effectively, skills shortages must be compensated for and critical sectors must be supported. This also promotes innovation in the long term. Increased mobility of nationals from non-European third countries would enable them to counteract critical developments in the respective labor market not only in a single country, but throughout the EU. This would benefit both the European economy and local communities.
Volt is committed to establishing an efficient migration system. This should respect the rights of migrants, improve their integration into the EU labor market, promote our global competitiveness and strengthen prosperity and social cohesion within the European Union.
To this end, we are campaigning for a uniform European legal framework. This should decouple residence permits from specific employers and ensure the right to family reunification and access to social benefits.
These changes empower migrants and create a fair and equal European labor market.
We are also committed to creating safe and regular migration routes. In this way, we want to eliminate labor shortages and skills gaps in a targeted manner and thus make the EU labor market more dynamic, more responsive and therefore more future-proof.
At the same time, the advantages of freedom of movement within Europe must be recognized. This leads to a simplification of processes, efficient labor markets and thus better integration of migrants. This approach makes the European Union as a whole more attractive, more competitive and promotes the development and prosperity of all member states.
Volt Europe	75Volt Germany | Choriner Str. 34 | 10435 Berlin

EUROPEAN ELECTORAL PROGRAM 2024-2029 MAKING EVERY VOTE COUNT
7. Strengthening the EU
For over 70 years now, after two devastating world wars, Europe has shown how we can stand together, across borders and with humanity, against division and destruction and achieve peace and prosperity. But the EU must continue to develop, because it could do so much more! At a time when populism is on the rise, we absolutely must shape our EU in such a way that it works for us all.
An "ever more united union of the peoples of Europe" cannot be achieved if we do not take ambitious steps towards a federal Europe.
The European Union is just as important today as it was when it was founded after the Second World War and is increasingly becoming a geopolitical necessity. Issues such as the climate crisis, migration, global economic competition and the disregard for the rules-based international order cannot be resolved by small, individual actors.
can only be tackled by the Member States themselves, but require joint action. Even within the EU, the current structure allows each individual member state t o t a k e important decisions.
block legislation, sanctions packages or trade agreements that can be of fundamental importance to millions of European citizens. To achieve tangible benefits and better help its citizens, the EU must be reformed.
The "Strengthening the EU" chapter aims to demonstrate the EU's ability to act collectively. Volt wants to ensure that member states work together effectively to overcome common challenges. Strengthening the democratic legitimacy of the EU is of central importance here. The current institutional framework prioritizes the interests of member states over those of citizens, leading to decision-making processes that are inefficient and heavily influenced by national interests. This limits the EU's ability to act quickly, purposefully and in the interests of its citizens.
In view of the forthcoming EU enlargement, the old decision-making processes also need to be reformed. This will make the countless interlinked challenges we face visible. Additional votes in the Council after enlargement will intensify the debate. This comes with the risk of regular deadlock. Furthermore, the European Parliament, the only EU institution directly elected by citizens, is still not entitled to propose legislation and must wait for other institutions to take action.
The introduction of a European constitution and an elected EU government will increase transparency and put citizens and democratic legitimacy at the heart of European democracy. Bridging the gap between the
This will strengthen trust in the Union, create a truly representative European democracy and counteract harmful disillusionment in the political system. It will also enable the EU to respond effectively to challenges at home and abroad. The formation of a genuine fiscal and monetary union will create a coherent, unified and transparent system that will improve the EU's ability to respond effectively to economic upheavals.
Volt Europe	83Volt Germany | Choriner Str. 34 | 10435 Berlin

7.2 A European government
 Reform of the European Commission into a European government.
> Election of an EU Prime Minister from among the Members of the European Parliament to replace the President of the European Commission.
> The prime minister will be in charge of a cabinet whose size is not based on the number of member states, but on the needs of the EU government and its citizens. There should be no more than one minister from each member state.
> The Prime Minister will be able to nominate ministers, who will then be elected by the European Parliament.
must be confirmed. Each of them will head a ministry, which will replace the current system of directorates-general in the European Commission.
> Any minister or the entire European government can be removed from office at any time by a vote of no confidence by the European Parliament. In this way, the European Parliament will be accountable to the European citizens.
> This executive will be accountable to the voters, depending on the confidence of the European Parliament and the European Senate.

7.4 A European Senate
 Introduction of a European Senate:
> Transformation of the Council of the European Union into a European Senate, which serves as the second chamber of the EU. The European Council is abolished.
> The member states are represented in the European Senate by the same number of senators, who are delegated by the respective national parliaments. The equal number of senators means that all member states have equal representation in this chamber.
 
Ensure that, in the meantime, decisions in the European Council are taken by qualified majority instead of unanimity. This is particularly relevant for issues that currently fall under the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), such as sanctions, but also for enlargement or taxes. For certain decisions, such as treaty amendments, military missions or EU enlargement, a form of enhanced qualified majority will apply.

7.6 Fiscal and monetary union
 Tripling the EU budget. We call for a fundamental reform of the European Union's finances by tripling the EU budget in order to enable public investment, eliminate social imbalances and
stabilize the economy during economic downturns.
 Levying European taxes. A democratic Europe should be able to levy taxes to finance the EU budget, in particular taxes on climate-damaging consumption and large fortunes. This should be flanked by clear and binding budget rules
for the member states, but which allow more flexibility than the current interpretation of the Maastricht criteria.
 The EU should be allowed to borrow for investments in economic development projects that benefit the whole of Europe. The creation of such European government bonds will strengthen the stability of the integrated financial market as a safe asset. At the same time, this new fiscal and monetary union should provide more effective institutionalized instruments to ensure that member states maintain a structurally balanced budget.
 
Creation of budgetary policy instruments that automatically increase European government spending during economic downturns and provide more financial flexibility in the event of an impending recession.
 Encouraging Member States that have not yet adopted the euro to do so in order to promote economic cohesion and stability in Europe.
 Expansion of the mandate of the European Central Bank (ECB) to a "dual mandate" aimed at both price stability and full employment, so that European economic performance is based on both financial stability and inclusive growth.
 Establishment of an EU Ministry of Finance to act as a central regulatory authority that sets standards for national tax and regulatory authorities.

How do we bring these proposals to the European Parliament?
To strengthen the collective action of the EU, Volt wants to set up a European Convention on a Federal Europe. This convention would transform the two EU treaties into a European constitution and modernize the legal framework by planning a reform of the role of the institutions of the European Union. The Council of the European Union should be transformed into a European Senate, which would act as a
second chamber of the EU. This requires an amendment to the Treaty with regard to the procedure for creating the Council in Article 15 TEU. In addition, the legislative powers of the European Parliament should be extended by giving it legislative competence. This requires an amendment to Article 17 TEU, which currently only allows the Commission to take such an initiative. This should apply unless otherwise stipulated in the treaties.
Volt aims to make the EU's decision-making process more effective by replacing unanimity for Council decisions with qualified majority voting in accordance with
Article 7 TEU replaced. Volt would also like to through the abolition of the veto right of the
Member States should strengthen the fundamental values and principles of the Union in Article 2 TEU, such as human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, in Council decisions. With regard to the Union's legal system, Volt advocates the binding nature of the enforcement of Article 6 TEU for the judgments of the European Convention on Human Rights for the EU and thus also for the Member States. This is essential for the equal protection of human rights standards in the Community. In addition, a truly uniform tax system requires that European taxes can be levied. The ability to levy direct taxes requires new EU laws that extend and supplement existing standards and allow taxation at European level. In order to
To exploit the potential of indirect taxes, such as digital or carbon taxes, a new protocol can be drawn up based on the consent of the Member States. The implementation of binding budgetary rules that keep public debt in check requires, among other things, a reform of Article 121 TFEU.

EUROPEAN ELECTORAL PROGRAM 2024-2029 MAKING EVERY VOTE COUNT
8. European democracy
The EU must become more democratic in order to become fairer and be able to overcome the current challenges. The current European Union prioritizes national interests over the interests of 500 million citizens. Such a system creates fundamental problems and widens the gap between citizens and the institutions that govern them. The result is a misalignment and a democratic deficit that undermines public confidence in the European project.
Political dissatisfaction is exacerbated by a lack of transparency. This obscures decision- making in the EU. The European Council has become one of the most powerful political bodies. However, it is also the least transparent body, as backroom deals are made without scrutiny that affect the fate of millions of European citizens. This has contributed to growing disappointment among Europeans. Because they are excluded from the processes that determine their lives.
The European Democracy Act aims to create a clear link between European citizens and EU decision-making processes, address systemic shortcomings and bridge the gap between citizens and their institutions. Citizens will be able to understand and influence the decisions that shape their lives. We will improve the transparency of EU processes by creating accountability within the EU apparatus and promoting citizen participation in the decision- making process.
Crucially, this law envisions a Europe in which the interests and voices of individuals are at the center and the limitations of national politics are overcome. By redesigning electoral and parliamentary systems, the aim is to create a European democracy that is honest, representative, accountable and responsive to the needs of all individuals.
This requires a robust European media landscape that promotes transparency and informed citizens. This legislative package therefore promotes the independence, diversity and integrity of the media and takes measures to combat rampant disinformation in the digital age.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 A PLANET WORTH LIVING ON
9. Prioritize climate neutrality
We are creating a strong Europe that is fair to people and the environment and safeguards our fragile livelihoods. Climate neutrality is our priority and not a "niceto-have". We are joining forces and skills to build a climate-neutral Europe: by reducing all member states' net emissions of greenhouse gases to zero by 2040. To achieve climate neutrality, we are not only relying on individual responsibility, but are also activating the major levers. This is because the responsibility lies with the perpetrators of the climate crisis, who have profited from climate and environmentally harmful production for years.
The dangers and threats posed by the climate crisis are undeniable. There is clear evidence that man-made climate change is leading to destabilization of weather patterns and the collapse of ecosystems. The human and economic costs of adapting to these negative consequences increase exponentially with each additional degree of global warming. It is widely recognized that the only way to mitigate the climate crisis is to rapidly and completely eliminate greenhouse gas emissions. But despite this clear political imperative, there is a lack of robust and ambitious climate policy, as other interests stand in the way of the transition to climate neutrality. Nevertheless, we must recognize the steps taken in the 2015 Paris Agreement as a diplomatic breakthrough in the fight against the climate crisis. Almost all countries committed to limiting global warming to 2°C and aiming for 1.5°C. This target should be achieved through rigorous and continuously reported Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs). On this basis, we can drive forward an ambitious climate agenda and introduce additional aspects into international climate policy. One example of this is the establishment of a fund for loss and damage.
The EU has taken and proposed various measures to achieve net-to-zero emissions by 2050. Most recently, this concerned the "European Green Deal", which
"Fit for 55" legislation. This was a major step forward, but it is still not enough to achieve the climate targets. Volt is strongly c o m m i t t e d to bringing European policy in line with the Paris Agreement. This includes the EU doing its part to meet the 1.5 degree target.
The CO2 reductions that we can achieve by 2030 are crucial and have the highest priority. We will therefore advocate for an additional climate emergency law that aims to achieve the greatest possible CO2 reduction by 2030. Furthermore, the climate crisis is developing in parallel with significant inequalities. The richest 10% of Europeans emit more than three times as much greenhouse gases per capita as the rest. However, those who have contributed the least to the climate crisis are likely to suffer the most.

9.2 Just transition without harmful subsidies
 Extend the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) to negative emissions and cover at least 90% (2021 approx. 40%) of all EU carbon emissions under a single cap by the end of 2025 at the latest. This means that the introduction of the planned ETS 2, which covers buildings, road transport and additional small industries and also includes emissions from industrial livestock farming, must be accelerated. A reduction in the number of certificates (adapted to the scope) in line with Volt's reduction targets is necessary.
 Extension of the Industrial Establishments Directive (IED) to all types of industrial animal husbandry. This refers to farms that keep a number of animals considered relevant by science.
 Introduction of a carbon tax for all sectors in which an extended ETS would cause a disproportionately high administrative burden (e.g.
highly fragmented industries that can hardly be identified in advance).
 Support the final implementation of a robust carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM).
 Ensure appropriate taxation of kerosene and other fossil fuels. This is one part of a broader just transition strategy that sets out clear and
provides for comprehensible targets for ending fossil fuel subsidies.
 Maintaining the high proportion of total revenue from the EU ETS that is used for climate and energy-related purposes (estimated at 75% between 2013 and 2021). At the same time, the aim is to ensure that this revenue is also used to support low-income communities and those most affected by the climate crisis. "Carbon dividends", i.e. direct cash payments to citizens, have become established in Switzerland and
in Canada have proven to be successful best practices.
 Ensure that transitions include adaptation strategies that enable communities to increase their adaptive capacity. We strongly advocate consistent and binding measures to adapt to the effects of the climate crisis:
> Strengthening flood protection and coordination of adaptation plans in endangered European coastal areas.
> Expansion of European disaster protection and humanitarian aid in order to be prepared for the increasing number of natural disasters.

9.5 Negative emissions strategy
 Commitment to a climate-neutral economy by 2040 (energy sector by 2035) with the aim of achieving a negative emissions capacity. The protection, restoration and growth of natural carbon sinks, which are essential for achieving this goal, are to be ensured:
> Increased efforts for sustainable forest management, restoration and reforestation.
> Commitment to the conservation and restoration of wetlands.
> Replace current subsidies for unsustainable agricultural practices with subsidies to encourage the rapid adoption of known or developing environmentally friendly practices (e.g. perennial agricultural production systems and polyculture).
> Promote the diversification of plant species that have a very high carbon sequestration per unit area and time and are a source of sustainable raw materials for a variety of value-added products, such as hemp and bamboo.
> 
Increase the number of protected wildlife areas in accordance with the UN Biodiversity Plan.
> Improve the protection and health of European waterways and develop a coherent strategy for the use of scientific knowledge, transnational cooperation and the creation of appropriate economic incentives.

9.6 Low-CO2 transport sector
 Strengthening and expanding the rail system in Europe, as more than 20% of CO2 emissions in the EU come from transportation, whether from road transport (72% of the total) or air transport (14%), while rail only accounts for 0.4% of carbon emissions. Here we propose
> Harmonization of infrastructure throughout Europe, in particular with regard to the European Train Control System (ETCS), platform height, track gauge and the approval of rail vehicles.
> Proposal for substantial EU-wide investments and subsidies at all levels of rail transport. This includes integrated long and medium distance networks for freight and passenger transport, a European high-speed rail network (HSR) and regional and local public transport. National and international night train services must be expanded and improved as a convenient alternative to air travel.
 Providing the proposed European Transport Agency (ETA, see "Act for a prosperous coexistence") with advisory legislative powers and financial resources. In this way, we want to monitor investments in the infrastructure of international high-speed trains throughout Europe and promote innovation and sustainability in the aviation and shipping industry.
 Promotion and subsidization of an EU- wide MaaS platform (Mobility as a Service)
service) with the aim of offering seamless, affordable and environmentally friendly transportation options that make it easier to move away from private car ownership.
 Ban on the use of fossil fuels in road vehicles by 2035. This does not include a ban on the sale or use of combustion engines as long as they are powered by biofuels or synthetic fuels.
 Abolition of tax exemptions for aviation fuel and increased e f f o r t s to achieve net-zero emissions in European, international and national aviation by 2040 by the Advisory Council on Aviation (ACARE).

9.7 Renewable energy systems
 Promoting changes in the energy supply mix and implementing alternative and carbon- free energy sources. The transition to a sustainable European system and the complete decarbonization of the energy system should be achieved by 2035.
> Promote the complete phase-out of coal combustion by 2030 (lignite by 2025) and ban new permits for drilling for fossil fuels and immediately stop flaring. It should also be ensured that 80 % of all known fossil fuel reserves remain in the ground. Advertising for fossil fuel products should be banned, similar to the example of cigarette advertising.
> Promotion of a diversified portfolio of renewable energy sources (RE). In order to enable a mix of intermittent and complementary sustainable energy sources, research into the conversion of ocean thermal energy, tidal and wave energy, residual heat from industry, biomass and new concepts for solar and wind energy should be promoted alongside research into geothermal energy. We particularly want to promote research in the field of alternative technologies. This includes low-carbon and pioneering technologies.
such as sustainable chemistry concepts, bio-based solutions and concepts for the conversion of organic and organic waste.
plastic waste i n t o fuels. A particular focus here is on large-scale applications.promoting functional and efficient systems for the use of renewable energies by counteracting the increased volatility on the generation side caused by the fundamental changes in the energy supply mix. To this end, the following flexibility measures should be introduced:
> Exploiting flexibility on the demand side by promoting the necessary technical solutions (digital monitoring and control systems) and business models (e.g. aggregation-based models such as virtual power plants).
> Use of storage solutions to utilize short-term (intraday) to long-term (seasonal) flexibility.
> Promoting the intelligent planning and operation of infrastructures to improve the connection between
The aim is to create a single point of generation and consumption in order to utilize the flexibility of a large interconnected system, eliminating existing sectoral silos and strengthening cross-sectoral connections (electricity, gas, heating and cooling, mobility, waste, water). This is to be achieved through technologies, business, regulatory and governance models in line with
with the EU strategy for the integration of the energy system in order to achieve the decarbonization of the entire energy system.

> Existing reactors should continue to be operated in their current form until the agreed end of their life cycle. The aim is to ensure that lifetime extensions are only permitted if, firstly, all safety regulations applicable at the time of the decision are met.
secondly, long-term operation is at the full cost of the operators, thirdly, the state of the art at the time of the assessment is achieved and fourthly, the reactor is needed to ensure climate neutrality.

industry and transportation systems, without affecting them financially.
> Replacing the use of natural gas in households with as much biogas as possible in the short and medium term. Biogas should be produced in the EU using innovative methods and transported to households via the same gas transmission infrastructure. We want to introduce price caps for EU biogas.

9.8 Improved electricity market
 The electricity market is to be reformed to ensure more effective support for a successful transition to renewable energies. energies can become possible. This means that
> Ensure that the original objectives of the market can also be achieved through a different or improved market design.
> Ensuring a high degree of market competition on the supply side through effective unbundling regulations and making it easier for consumers to switch providers.
> Guarantee that there are sufficient incentives for investment in new generation and infrastructure facilities required for the introduction of renewable energy systems.
> Maintaining effective economic use of generation and flexibility resources to meet energy demand at all times. To make this possible, cross-border trading capacity should be increased and more dynamic trading should be enabled (e.g. by reducing
minimum product quantities and trading hours).
> Improve the approach to incorporate the new market objectives and incentivize the introduction and effective operation of flexibility mechanisms (storage and
demand-side management). We want to introduce established central markets and decentralized market- oriented solutions that enable the introduction and operation of instruments for the locally required flexibility (e.g. local flexibility markets, aggregator business models).
> Consideration of the new framework conditions, which are primarily determined by three factors: Decentralization (redistribution and fragmentation of generation and flexibility resources), digitalization (improved monitoring and control) and democratization (more energy resources at the citizen and local level, empowering these local actors to participate more actively in energy systems).
 Propose a transitional period to take account of the complexity of identifying and implementing such far-reaching reform measures. We want to introduce short-term, possibly temporary measures to address issues where there is an urgent need for action. The general approach adopted by the Commission and endorsed by the Council should be followed:
> Improve investment conditions for renewable energy sources by expanding the use of contracts for difference and promoting the introduction of power purchase agreements.

> Strengthening consumer protection by protecting consumers from price spikes and promoting competition in the retail sector.

9.9 Resilience of the energy system and security of supply
 Reassess the scope and standards of the resilience of Europe's energy systems and security of supply. By doing so, we want to achieve the following:
> Ensure that the improved European resource adequacy assessments adequately incorporate new options to ensure resource adequacy. These include storage and demand-side management. The unequal adequacy between bidding zones due to structural constraints in the transmission networks must be adequately taken into account.
> 
Prioritize measures to ensure the adequacy of resources that reduce dependence on regions outside the EU.
> Promote resilience standards over absolute security standards for the digital infrastructure of the energy system, building on the EU Action Plan for the Digitalization of the Energy System.

9.10 Energy sources with low CO2 emissions
 Removal of complicated regulatory hurdles when issuing permits for new low-carbon energy plants. This can currently take several years. A quick conclusion,
which is provided for in the EU Directive, must be driven forward.
> Streamlining and harmonizing administrative procedures and reducing bureaucratic complexity.
> Improve the administrative framework for issuing permits and support capacity building to increase efficiency and effectiveness.
> Identify and share best practice information to promote mutual learning and optimize approval processes.
> Facilitating spatial planning through the creation of zone maps for low-carbon energy and the implementation of participatory processes to ensure sustainable land use.
> 
Strengthening public engagement by empowering communities to participate in low-carbon energy development, as well as the participation of low-income and vulnerable households.
> Improvement of the certification and validation procedures for nuclear energy plants and their generalization for all EU countries that have nuclear energy in their program. This will avoid unnecessary duplication of identical procedures in different countries.
> Facilitate and coordinate European initiatives for the full recycling of used nuclear fuel and accelerate the introduction of technologies for the recycling of nuclear waste. This will significantly reduce the volume of nuclear waste and the time it needs to be stored.

9.12 Sustainable buildings
 Promoting the replacement of individual heating and cooling systems powered by fossil fuels with alternatives such as renewable electric heating systems, heat pumps and solar water heating.
 Promoting better energy efficiency (e.g. insulation, energy-saving appliances, changes in behavior) and the use of sustainable materials in the construction or renovation of buildings.
 Definition of standards for nearly zero energy buildings (nZEB) for all new buildings in the EU by 2030 and net zero emissions for all buildings (including the existing building stock) by 2035.
 Development of standards for resource- efficient designs and integrated construction processes. The efficiency of building design is to be measured on the basis of annual energy consumption and the carbon footprint of the entire construction process (distinction between "operating carbon" and "embodied carbon").
We want to promote the mapping of buildings through continuous energy performance data in order to build consensus on the importance of sustainable design and construction. access to an accurate measurement of the "Whole Life Carbon" of the entire life cycle of buildings.
 Enable owners of residential and office buildings to make the necessary investments. To this end, we want to harmonize and increase public financing and offer direct low-interest financing through the European Investment Bank (EIB). Citizens should be made aware of and involved in the possibilities of green buildings and promote the development of an appropriately sized and well-qualified retrofitting industry through training, labor mobility and the exchange of best practices.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 A PLANET WORTH LIVING ON
How do we bring these proposals to the European Parliament?
The Volt Climate Transformation Act affects the directives and regulations that fall under the "European Great Deal" initiatives,
"Net Zero Emissions by 2050" and the "Just Transition Mechanism". In the chapter, we have advocated climate neutrality in various areas of climate policy, decarbonization, energy transition and sustainable development. This involves changes to the following three key legal instruments: Regulation (EU) 2021/1119 on EU climate law, Directive (EU) 2018/2001 on the Renewable Energy Directive II and Directive (EU) 2022/2464 on corporate sustainability reporting.
At the same time, the measures relate to others that fall under the aforementioned initiatives.
The proposed measures have an impact on existing legislation. This is because they propose new, innovative measures that can resolve key problems. For example, Regulation (EU) 2021/1119
on EU climate law should be amended to take greater account of the wide disparities in greenhouse gas emissions within Europe, as these are clear inequalities (i.e. the richest 10% emit more than three times as much per capita as the poorest 10%).
much than any other). At the same time, Volt recognizes Directive (EU) 2018/2001 on the Renewable Energy Directive II and adds to the already existing legislation the idea that decarbonization should not only take place at the production level, but also at the consumption level and across global supply chains. Only a few measures have an impact on Directive (EU) 2022/2464 on corporate sustainability reporting, as the articles drafted should focus more on the possibilities of green technologies. In particular, this relates to economic growth, job creation, the transition to a green economy and climate policy.

10. Healthy ecosystems
The environmental crisis we are facing goes beyond the climate crisis. It i n c l u d e s widespread pollution, the depletion of biodiversity and the destruction of our natural habitats. These problems are not isolated. They are caused by our unsustainable production and consumption patterns and the overstepping of our planet's natural limits.
To tackle these complex environmental challenges effectively, we need a comprehensive "One Health" approach and the involvement of all stakeholders. Tackling the climate crisis is inextricably linked to the preservation of vital natural ecosystems that serve as carbon reservoirs and the basis of our food supply. Furthermore, the destruction of these ecosystems makes us more vulnerable to increasing natural disasters such as floods and forest fires, which are already increasing at an alarming rate. Recognizing this would be the first step in a responsible policy.
Our actions have an impact on the health of the planet. At the same time, it is closely linked to human health. Increasing environmental pollution - from air pollution to soil and ocean contamination - is taking an ever greater toll on our wellbeing and placing an additional burden on our already overstretched healthcare systems.
We must no longer exploit the world and our ecosystems at all costs. But politicians are encouraging this with subsidies for harmful and polluting activities such as factory farming, deforestation, the excessive use of antimicrobials, overfishing and unsustainable consumption patterns. This makes it clear to us: we must act immediately. We must recognize that a harmonious coexistence of nature and humans is the only way for life to continue on this planet. We therefore believe that EU funds should focus on financing desirable practices and abolishing harmful subsidies and measures. We need to empower consumers to make more sustainable choices and promote circular consumption patterns to protect our natural world and its ecosystems. At the same time, other actors within the food chain must also be involved.
The first step towards more sustainable agriculture is crucial for the transition to a green economy. Of course, this is done in close cooperation with farmers. Small and medium-sized farmers' businesses are put under pressure by exploitative trade relations. This is reflected in the decline
of agricultural businesses in Europe. Reforms are urgently needed here. We want to offer farmers a better basis for their livelihoods, improve cooperation
Volt Europe	128Volt Germany | Choriner Str. 34 | 10435 Berlin
EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 A PLANET WORTH LIVING ON
between generations and boost the local economy. Rewarding farmers who work in harmony with nature is essential to creating a green future and securing an independent Europe. The need for change also extends to our forest and marine policies.
Together, these measures promote the development of resilient and sustainable communities. This is because they ensure that communities are equipped with accessible green spaces that enhance human well-being, improve animal welfare and combat antimicrobial resistance. This leads to the intertwining o f	human, animal and environmental health, benefiting public health, the well-being of present and future generations and all living organisms on this planet.

10.1 Nature Restoration Act
 Adapt the Nature Restoration Law (NRL) to environmental science, also taking into account the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines on air pollution, green spaces in residential areas, chemicals and noise, and set ambitious targets for all natural areas in need of restoration:
> Rewetting of at least 30 %
of peatlands in the EU by 2030.
> Conversion of at least 10 % of urban areas into green and blue areas (open streams, rivers, ponds and lakes) by 2040 and at least 15 % by 2050 and their legal protection.
> Extension of the NRL to the habitats of fish species that are in a critical state.
> At least 10 % of every farm is to be used for nature restoration by 2030.
> 
Pursuing a One Health approach by following the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines involves maintaining strict air quality standards that ensure the right and freedom of all people to breathe clean air and limiting long-term exposure to pollutants such as PM2.5 and NO2 across Europe by ensuring that levels do not exceed 5 µg/m³ PM2.5 and 10 µg/ m³ NO2.
> Enforcing a comprehensive ban on chemicals that are proven to harm human health and the environment is of crucial importance.
Volt Europe	130Volt Germany | Choriner Str. 34 | 10435 Berlin
EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 A PLANET WORTH LIVING ON
10.2 Ecosystems of the oceans
 Discontinuation of the use of fishing gear that has undesirable negative impacts on ecosystems, such as the destruction of corals and the capture of unintended species (bycatch), as well as a ban on destructive practices such as bottom trawling, starting in marine protected areas (MPAs). Also the abolition of harmful subsidies, in particular the exemption from fuel tax.
 Adaptation of fishing quotas to the recommendations of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES), which will officially accompany the decision-making process. We therefore call for transparency and accountability to apply to non-public Council meetings at which Member States' final quotas are set (which often exceed the recommended limits).
 Support small-scale fisheries through fair incentives under the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The aim is to enable it to participate effectively in the political decision-making process, as it plays an important role in the livelihoods of coastal communities and the local economy and is known to have a lower environmental impact than large-scale fishing.
 Support strong mechanisms and deterrent penalties to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing. In this context, effective cooperation with third countries to restore marine stocks and protect MPAs is also crucial.
 
Only support sustainable aquaculture. EU funds may only be used for truly sustainable aquaculture practices. In parallel, policy measures will aim to bring general food consumption to a sustainable level.
 Strengthen legislation on aquaculture and its effluents and wastes to avoid disruptive nutrient gradients and promote a sustainable, circular and biodiversity-friendly form o f aquaculture.
 Creation of an action plan to promote the sustainable production of algae and to promote the innovative use of products made with this protein. Europe consumes large quantities of algae, but 97% of the world's production comes from Asia. There is a clear opportunity for strategic auto nomy that can be fulfilled by creating realistic conditions for the algae sector to take off, including funding, investment in R&D and increasing consumer awareness and acceptance of algae products in the EU.
 Support for green hydrogen-powered fishing vessels to reduce dependence on fossil fuels.
Volt Europe	131Volt Germany | Choriner Str. 34 | 10435 Berlin
EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 A PLANET WORTH LIVING ON
10.3 Restoration of forests
 Promotion of natural carbon storage through increased efforts for sustainable forest management,
-restoration and reforestation. Agricultural and forestry practices should focus on reducing emissions and preserving the landscape. The aim is to restore carbon stocks in Europe to pre-industrial levels and combat desertification.
 Commitment to the conservation and restoration of wetlands. We want to focus on peatlands (which can store twice as much carbon as forests) by imposing an immediate moratorium on peat extraction. This should continue until the legal regulations have been tightened. In this way, we want to ensure the protection of the areas and their sustainable management. At the same time, we want to promote the active restoration of the natural state of already exploited peatlands.
 
Improving the protection and health of European waterways.
We want to achieve this by updating the Water Framework Directive (WFD) and the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (MSFD) and accelerating their implementation, as only 40% of the surface water bodies examined by the European Environment Agency (EEA) in 2018 were in good ecological status.
 Creation of an EU-wide action plan for the forestry sector. This is intended to support an ecosystem-based approach to forest management, as it is possible and necessary to reconcile nature conservation with the commercial use of forest resources. This approach aims to respect the natural cycle of forests as much as possible, contribute to the protection and restoration of forests in the EU and provide forest owners with a more sustainable source of income.

10.4 Social reform of the common agricultural policy
 Support for more in-depth monitoring of the EU food market, as food is an essential commodity. This should protect consumers and ensure stable and fair prices for farmers. The aim is to create a framework for fair individual trade agreements, a mechanism for local and direct sales regulations and improved anti-dumping measures and monitoring. This should include an examination of competition and pricing practices. Small and medium-sized farms face particular challenges due to exploitative relationships with retailers, corporate control and WTO pricing issues. They are confronted with high production costs and long-standing CAP policies that prevent fairness and sustainability.
 Support the establishment of local agricultural cooperatives in order to stabilize food prices, guarantee farmers a stable and fair income and promote local supply chains. We want to define guidelines for the Member States to promote the establishment of agricultural cooperatives at national level. At the same time, an EU-wide public platform for knowledge and information for consumers and producers should be established.
 Adopt EU-wide measures to reduce production costs for farmers and the additional price that consumers pay for healthier and more sustainable food.
pay for more sustainable food. We want to achieve this by rebalancing production subsidies in the common agricultural policy.
 Simplify bureaucratic procedures and increase transparency for recipients of CAP funds, especially for small and medium-sized farms. We want to achieve this by providing access to a central and intuitive EU platform for the exchange of knowledge and advice on procedures, rights and obligations, agricultural practices and the submission of documents. We want to work together with the relevant national ministries to achieve this.
 Training of the staff of the relevant national ministries so that they can help farmers with their questions appropriately.
 Adequate support for small and medium- sized farms and stronger incentives for young farmers to stay in business. This should also benefit new entrants, especially women*, in order to ensure the generational succession of farmers. The annual direct payment framework of the member states for generational renewal measures is to be increased from 3% to 6%.
 Development of a sub-program for trainees, newcomers or agriculture in general, for exchange within the framework of Erasmus, which focuses on sustainable agricultural practices.

10.5 Environmental reform of the common agricultural policy
 Abolition of subsidies for environmentally harmful agricultural practices and payments per hectare of land. These funds should be allocated to desirable agricultural practices. In doing so, we want to support the transition to a regenerative farming model that strongly promotes sustainable and organic food, the restoration of soil health, the reduction of pesticides, sustainable water and land use, the reversal of biodiversity loss and animal welfare. Guidance and financial support for farmers during this transition period must be guaranteed to ensure their stability and income.
 Promote rural development models that stimulate local supply chains by harmonizing overarching policy areas. For example, an effective transport system provides incentives for people to move to rural areas and supports farmers and local supply chains. The green agricultural transition also offers opportunities for the repopulation of rural areas as it creates new green jobs and attracts skilled young people.
 Creating incentives to reduce the number of animals kept, while at the same time limiting meat imports and adjusting the demand for meat through accompanying measures. Agriculture is responsible for
10.3 % of greenhouse gas emissions in the EU, 70 % of these
emissions come from the livestock sector. We need "less but better quality" meat if we want to return to a sustainable level of consumption and at the same time maintain the profitability of
f a r m s .
 Support research and development for innovative green energy-powered farming systems such as vertical farming and hydroponics in urban areas to ensure more sustainable and shorter food supply chains.
 Promote precision farming and farm automation where appropriate to reduce dependence on inputs (such as water and pesticides) and make agricultural practices environmentally sustainable. Promote cross-generational renewal of farmers by recruiting highly qualified people.
 Establishment of a fund for the green transition in agriculture that enables farmers to receive low-interest loans and state liability for adapting to the green transition.
transition to make it easier for farmers to meet sustainability requirements. Promote habitat restoration, conservation and biodiversity-friendly agriculture and exclude greenwashing measures.

Reducing the burden that frequent and incomplete rule updates place on the stability and income of farmers, with the aim of a science-based CAP.

Support further research and the eventual inclusion of genetically modified crops in the production portfolio of European farmers. These techniques should be used to promote resilience to the climate crisis and ensure the sustainability of food production and agricultural practices.

10.6 Ecological and Sustainable agriculture
 Support the European Commission's goal of reducing the use of chemical pesticides by 50% by 2030 while promoting the spread of integrated pest management (IPM) practices to reduce the need for pesticides and support other agro-ecological practices.
 Increased financial incentives under the common agricultural policy for the conversion of farms in order to achieve the Green Deal target of 25% organic farmland by 2030.
 
Use of the "eco-schemes" of the common agricultural policy, many of the proposed agro-ecological measures of which meet the requirements of organic farming. Organic farmland accounted for only 9.1% of the EU's total agricultural area in 2020 (5.8% in 2012), meaning that the EU will only reach 15% organic farmland by 2031 if growth continues at the same rate as 2012-2020.

10.7 Healthy and sustainable nutrition
 Harmonization of European policy to switch to a healthy diet. This should be rich in plant-based foods and contain less animal- based foods. This has a positive effect on health and the environment. An EU action plan should shape our food system and
habits to meet nutritional and environmental science recommendations, as Denmark has recently done. Subsidies and consumption targets should be adjusted to increase the proportion of plant-based foods and reduce the proportion of animal proteins.
 Adaptation of market mechanisms for better access and more favorable prices for plant proteins along the food chain. This should create a level playing field for these foodstuffs. We want to realign the common agricultural policy to favor products that are less emission-intensive than foods of animal origin.
 EU-wide measures under the Common Agricultural Policy to reduce the cost of healthy and sustainable food, including plant-based food.
 Binding EU guidelines on green procurement for public catering services (including
of the EU institutions). The guidelines set targets for the weekly availability (and often exclusivity) of plant-based dishes, food waste and organic content. Resources for the corresponding training of chefs are to be created.
 Increase funding for research and the development of healthy plant-based alternatives, as this sector is still largely underfunded compared to animal alternatives.
 Restriction of EU marketing aid to foods that we should consume more of according to nutritional and environmental science.
 Expand the "EU School Programs for Fruit, Vegetables and Milk" to include healthy plant-based alternatives to milk. In this way, we want to cater for children with allergies, other preferences or ethical concerns and promote a more sustainable diet. Increase EU R&D investment in cultured meat, seafood and other animal products and other relevant food technologies to accelerate their research and development. This can be crucial to making our food system more environmentally sustainable.

10.8 Strengthening consumer rights
 Uniform and mandatory labeling of foodstuffs with regard to origin and production methods. The same applies to processed food and meals sold in public establishments and restaurants. For animal products, including processed products, rearing, transport and slaughter conditions must be classified and labeled as mandatory. The same applies to the nutritional value of foodstuffs.
 Introduction of an EU-wide quality label (with a points system) for the eco- logical sustainability of products, including food. Environmental parameters such as carbon emissions, pesticide use and air pollution are taken into account.
 
Sustainability, recyclability and circular economy information for textiles to reduce waste, promote a circular economy and incentivize eco-friendly designs.
 Promotion of organic and regenerative agriculture through communication campaigns to attract more consumers and new farmers. These are financed, for example, via the
EU funding programs.

10.9 Animal welfare on farms
 Revision of the current EU animal welfare legislation, which is scientifically outdated, excludes many farm animal species and is inadequately enforced:
> Inclusion of species-specific and scientific laws covering all animals bred or kept by humans, including aquatic animals.
> Abolition of long-distance transportation of animals to non-EU countries and introduction of strict limits within the EU based on species-specific and scientifically justified minimum standards. Instead, we are in favor of the transport of meat/carcasses and genetic material and the promotion of local and mobile slaughterhouses. We want to introduce a strict and transparent monitoring and reporting system in order to effectively identify, prevent and sanction violations.
> End fur production in the EU and ban imports of fur products from third countries.
> 
Abolition of the keeping of animals in individual cages in agriculture.
> Prohibition of shredding and gassing of male chicks and transition to technologies that determine sex before hatching. Sex determination in the womb is already being introduced in some Member States.
> Immediate ban on the routine docking of pigs' tails, which is still routinely carried out in most Member States 15 years after an EU-wide ban came into force. Severe sanctions are imposed for non- compliance.
> Ban on the breeding of fast-growing breeds for reasons of profitability. This leads to suffering and health problems for the animals.
> Introduction of mandatory video surveillance in slaughterhouses to improve enforcement of animal welfare regulations.

EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024-2029 A PLANET WORTH LIVING ON
10.10 General animal welfare
 Ban on the breeding and use of wild animals for entertainment purposes. This includes use in circuses, bullfights and similar events, aquariums/dolphinariums and zoos. A transitional period is to be granted during which the facilities can adapt their business and bring the wild animals used for entertainment purposes together with rescue centers.
 Combating the illegal pet trade in the EU. We want to implement legal provisions for the licensing and registration of pet breeders. At the same time, we are committed to the development of a
EU database for the mandatory registration (e.g. by microchip) of pets (e.g. dogs, cats and ferrets).
 EU-wide ban on the breeding of physically impaired domestic animal breeds with chronic health and animal welfare problems.
 
Increase funding for research into alternatives to animal testing. To this end, a roadmap with clear targets for the reduction, improvement and replacement of animal testing should be drawn up. The EU must do more to meet its commitments on the use of animals in scientific experiments. Over 10 million animals are still tested every year.
 Regulation of the trade in exotic pets through an EU-wide positive list. This serves to protect biodiversity, human health and the health of other animals. The list specifies exactly which animal species may be traded as pets.
 Inclusion of animal welfare in the job title of the responsible EU Commissioner in order to increase institutional accountability and emphasize the importance of the issue.

10.11 Antibiotic resistance
 Development of an EU-wide binding and scientifically based system for the use of antibiotics in human medicine. First-line therapy must be defined uniformly for certain diseases. This will restrict the use of antibiotics in cases where they are not necessary.
 Regulations that only permit the use of antibiotics in the veterinary sector in emergencies.
 Expansion of ongoing R&D initiatives for new treatment approaches and medical technology.
 
Reducing the use of antibiotics in animal husbandry:
> Reduction in the number of animals of different origins in a herd (e.g.
B. calf rearing). Resistance occurs are particularly common.
> Support initiatives to reduce intensive livestock farming.
> A greater diversity of animal breeds must be maintained in order to prevent the occurrence and spread of diseases and to build up more resistant herds.
> EU-wide education and training programs for farmers on the use of antimicrobial agents.

10.12 Pricing
 Ensuring that the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) includes land use, land use change and forestry (LULUCF). Each Member State is treated as an individual emitter. The control is carried out at EU level, whereby the individual Member States can take their respective circumstances into account and pursue their own strategy.
 Taxing agricultural emissions from livestock farming and land use at source, as they are local and fragmented. Other non-sector- specific emissions in the agricultural sector (such as electricity and tractor fuels) are to be covered by the ETS. This takes place in processing or at the consumer level.
 
Extension of the ETS system to livestock farming, as pollution in this sector must also be taken into account.
 Extension of the Industrial Establishments Directive (IED) to all types of industrial livestock farming. This refers to farms that keep a number of animals considered relevant by the scientific community.

10.13 Transparency, monitoring and reporting
 Expansion of the Climate-ADAPT platform into an EU-wide harmonized real
The EU's climate emergency response and decision support system, as it currently only serves as a knowledge base for data and best practices to mitigate and adapt to the climate crisis. Establish an early warning system for extreme weather events and create an interface with the European Emergency Response Coordination Center and national governments to coordinate public aid.
 
Establish a comprehensive assessment system for monitoring ecosystem health and resilience that identifies areas in need of restoration. Application to all EU territories and visualization via an interactive map that contains regularly updated data and is publicly available online. Link this assessment system to the Climate-ADAPT platform.

How do we bring these proposals to the European Parliament?
The Healthy Ecosystems Act affects the directives and regulations that fall under the European Green Deal, Air Quality and Pollution Control, Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), Circular Economy and One Health Approach initiatives. The package of measures relates to the improvement of air quality, the reduction of pollution, sustainable agriculture and waste management and the interlinking of human, animal and environmental health. It requires amendments to the following legal instruments: Directive 2008/50/EC on ambient air quality and cleaner air for Europe, Industrial Emissions Directive (2010/75/EU), Waste Framework Directive (2008/98/EC), Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive (94/62/EC).
We call for a special focus on the interconnected environmental challenges. We recognize that tackling the climate crisis is inextricably linked to the preservation of vital ecosystems (e.g. carbon sinks, food supply). As such, we are pushing for changes to the articles that address these issues under Directive 2008/50/EC on air quality and climate change.
clean air for Europe. In addition, the Industrial Emissions Directive (2010/75/EU) must make a stronger call to move away from exploitative activities and unsustainable consumption.
Finally, it should protect natural resources, reverse biodiversity loss, mitigate the climate crisis and promote resilient and sustainable communities that improve human, animal and environmental health. In doing so, we promote things that benefit current and future generations and the entire ecosystem. The Waste Framework Directive (2008/98/EC) and the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive (94/62/EC) call for more attention to be paid to reversing biodiversity loss and promoting sustainable communities. This is to be achieved by reducing pollution from waste production and disposal. We support a revision of existing animal welfare legislation, including Council Directive 98/58/EC on the protection of animals. We are also committed to harmonizing the law on the restoration of nature and environmental science.
