3
EUROPEAN ELECTION PROGRAM 2024
of the Alliance for Innovation & Justice (BIG Party)
Preamble
Dear voters,
For almost 60 years now, European unity has been the guarantor of peace and prosperity in Europe. However, the geopolitical developments of recent years present the Union with unprecedented challenges and dangers. Great Britain will be the first member state to leave the European Union. Right-wing conservative and nationalist movements are gaining strength in many European countries and are increasingly calling the continued existence of European unification into question with their populist and reactionary demands. In some member states, these forces have even been elected to government. National interests are once again being placed above the European common good, while at the same time the democratic rule of law is being eroded by authoritarian means in certain member states. Transatlantic relations are in a serious crisis and international trade is increasingly determined by protectionism. Wars and humanitarian disasters continue to drive many people seeking protection to Europe.
In this critical overall situation, we as the BIG Party are unreservedly committed to European unity. The further political weakening of the EU as an economic area will inevitably lead to social upheaval in the member states. Social peace can only be secured in the long term through social peace. Separatism, division and small statehood inevitably lead to territorial conflicts and wars. European history has amply demonstrated this.
Being committed to Europe does not mean that grievances within the EU and its institutions should not be addressed. Constructive criticism and proposals for renewal even become an obligation in order to ensure the continued existence of the European Union. This is the only way to effectively counter the widespread disenchantment with the EU and nationalist and extremist tendencies.
Europe needs new approaches and ideas. We stand for a European Union in which the institutions work transparently for the common good of all EU citizens. All people must have an appropriate share in prosperity and social security. Individual fundamental and human rights must be guaranteed, regardless of status, origin, descent or gender. Global challenges such as migration, climate protection and digitalization require sustainable, responsible and ethical concepts.
Give us your vote - for an open, modern and fair Europe, a Europe of diversity, equal opportunities and justice!
4
Migration and refugee policy
Europe needs a humane and fair refugee policy. Asylum procedures must be simplified and accelerated, and illegal migration must be effectively curbed.
Reform of the Dublin system: faster decisions, fairer distribution
The Dublin system, according to which refugees must submit their asylum application in the country of first arrival, no longer works in its current form. The reception and distribution procedures must therefore be fundamentally reformed. We call for refugees to be distributed among the member states on the basis of their status. Connecting factors such as a previous stay in a Member State or family ties must be given priority. If such circumstances do not exist, the distribution must take place according to a fair distribution key within the EU countries. In a community, all members must meet their obligations; those who violate this principle of solidarity must be sanctioned economically, e.g. by the dispersal of funding.
Asylum procedures must also be simplified and accelerated, but with individual legal remedies preserved. People who do not have the right to stay are also entitled to legal certainty quickly. Family reunions must be carried out more quickly, and procedures must focus in particular on applications from minors seeking protection. They need special protection and increased care, for example through the provision of accompanying persons.
Internal security: strengthen borders, reduce fears
Internal security is one of the most important concerns of the people in the member states. Citizens' fears and irrational ideas must be allayed. Migration is not a threat, but a necessity from which society benefits. In view of population growth and the rampant shortage of skilled workers, there is no alternative to managed migration. Immigrants bring cultural diversity, labor and consumer power to the member states and create new social impulses. We must finally put an end to populist politics being carried out on the backs of migrants and people seeking protection. Scaremongering, agitation and deliberate misinformation divide society and exacerbate EU scepticism.
On the other hand, citizens must also have the feeling that governments are taking targeted and consistent action against illegal migration. The external borders must therefore be protected even more effectively. Migrants who are required to leave the country must be returned to their country of origin, but each case must be examined very carefully. Compliance with the European Convention on Human Rights must be ensured at all costs. Voluntary departures are
5
Deportations are always preferable, as they are typically associated with hardship. Voluntary return can be effectively supported through improved exit counseling. Deportations to war zones such as Syria or Afghanistan must be avoided as they violate fundamental human rights.
Immigration: promoting participation, ensuring equal opportunities
The influx of immigrants must not lead to the existing population suffering social disadvantages. Where there is competition for societal and social resources, immigration will always remain an issue of conflict. Sufficient childcare facilities must therefore be created, and the housing market and job creation must be particularly promoted. In addition, social entitlements and longer residence rights for immigrants should be linked to employment and a minimum length of stay.
But participation must also be further promoted. We need a framework that ensures that immigrants learn German quickly. Language courses must be compulsory and made available in sufficient numbers. This is the only way to enable access to the social environment and the labor market. In addition, the support and accompanying programs to promote participation must be further expanded and improved. Participation is a task for society as a whole that can only succeed with the efforts of all those involved.
Causes of flight: Prevent isolation, create safe living conditions
fen
Europe must not close itself off. In view of Europe's colonial history, there is an ethical co-responsibility for the precarious living conditions in many developing countries. A protectionist refugee policy is immoral and unworthy of an alliance of democratic industrialized countries. Every year, thousands of people seeking protection die on their way to Europe, most of them in the Mediterranean. Basic human rights oblige us to help these people, without ifs and buts. An EU-wide, coordinated system for sea rescue must therefore be installed immediately. Private aid organizations must not be harassed and criminalized.
The focus in combating the causes of flight must be on cooperation with third countries. Refugee routes must not be closed at all costs; compliance with basic human rights and procedural standards must also be guaranteed in third countries. Safe living conditions must be created in countries where people make their way to Europe due to a lack of social and economic prospects. Development aid and economic support must be focused on creating sustainable and humane living conditions. This requires in particular
6
fair trade relations in order to keep the markets in third countries competitive.
With your vote you decide in favor of:
 A humane and fair refugee policy
 Reform of the Dublin system, improved asylum procedures, fair distribution rules
 Internal security through stronger borders, effective containment of illegal immigration
 Socially responsible migration and increased participation efforts
 Responsibility for people in need, creating safe living conditions
Anti-discrimination policy
We want an equal Europe in which all citizens are guaranteed equal opportunities and all forms of discrimination are effectively combated.
Equal opportunities: quotas for women and early childhood support
Equal access for citizens to all areas of public life is one of the main pillars of a democratic society. All people must have the same opportunities to access education, the labor market, social services and benefits as well as the housing market. Experience shows that although equal opportunities largely exist on paper, they are often not implemented accordingly in practice. Much greater legislative efforts are required here. For example, women still suffer considerable disadvantages in education and employment, especially when it comes to promotion and pay. We therefore call for binding quotas for women in public administration and the private sector in all member states. Single mothers must also be particularly encouraged and supported, as they and their children are most at risk of poverty. The inclusion of people with disabilities in all public areas must be further improved. Citizens with a migration background must be effectively protected from discrimination when looking for work and housing. Early childhood support for children with a migrant background is a key factor in ensuring equal starting conditions for school education.
Anti-discrimination: better protection for victims, consistent punishment for perpetrators
The unequal treatment of certain groups of people without cause undermines the foundation of social coexistence. We therefore strictly oppose all forms of discrimination and racism. The protection of women and girls from sexual violence must be further strengthened. State prevention programs must be expanded and private counselling services must be better supported. Trafficking in human beings for the purpose of sexual exploitation m u s t b e prosecuted throughout Europe and
7
be sanctioned under criminal law. The right to sexual self-determination must be guaranteed and protected.
Misanthropy and hatred must be countered at all levels of society. Increasing racism, anti-Semitism and Islamophobia are poisoning the social climate in many European countries. Morals are increasingly deteriorating and verbal and physical attacks against people of other origins or religions are becoming more frequent. We call for a social culture of fairness, mutual respect and appreciation as well as responsible and dignified interaction with one another. We also call for a transparent and strict approach by the criminal investigation and prosecution authorities. Hate crimes must not be trivialized and the public must be adequately informed and sensitized. We demand an improvement in victim protection, for example through the establishment of municipal advice centers.
With your vote you decide in favor of:
 Equal opportunities and equal treatment
 Strengthening women's rights and early childhood development
 Fight against discrimination, racism, hatred and misanthropy
 Consistent criminal prosecution and improved victim protection
Social and Labor market policy
Only social justice can secure social peace in the long term. We need binding guidelines in the area of basic social security and the minimum wage. Employment must be secured and promoted, and youth unemployment must be combated effectively.
Social standards: basic security and minimum wage
Lasting peace and fairly distributed prosperity are the greatest promises of European unity. Social justice is the cornerstone of social peace. A lack of social security and unemployment always lead to social upheaval, which paves the way for extremism and anti-democratic sentiment. It must therefore be the top priority of common policy to create and enforce minimum social standards in the member states.
These minimum standards include adequate basic security benefits for pensioners. People who have worked all their lives must not spend their old age in poverty. A universal minimum wage must also be introduced in every Member State. Countries such as Italy, Sweden and Austria still have no such provisions. Where regulations do exist, there are considerable differences in the level stipulated. We therefore call for the swift
8
Creation of binding guidelines for fair and appropriate remuneration in all member states.
It will only be possible to harmonize living conditions in the member states in the long term if appropriate social standards are laid down. If the differences remain, phenomena such as social migration and wage dumping cannot be contained.
Labor market: strengthening employment, combating youth unemployment Employment is the foundation of the welfare state. However, employment rates currently vary considerably within the member states. While unemployment figures in Germany and other central European countries have been falling for years, southern and western European countries such as Spain and Italy continue to have major problems. This is particularly true in the area of youth unemployment. In Greece and Spain, one in three young people is without training or a job. The EU must therefore make every effort to improve employment conditions in the problem countries. Qualification and support programmes must be expanded and working conditions made more flexible. Deregulation must be driven forward and new markets opened up.
With your vote you decide in favor of:
 Minimum social standards for uniform living conditions
 Binding requirements for basic income support and minimum wage
 Strengthening employment and combating youth unemployment
Financial and Economic policy
An end to privileges and tax loopholes for large companies. The financial market, which has hardly been taxed to date, must finally contribute to the common good in an appropriate form. An EU-wide financial transaction tax is overdue.
Corporations: close tax loopholes
Europe needs fair taxation. While every hard-working citizen and every small or medium-sized company pays their taxes on income and profits at their place of work as a matter of course, large companies can shift their earnings to low-tax countries and pay taxes there. This form of tax dumping must finally be stopped. Corporations that generate billions in profits must also pay their taxes where they work and use the existing infrastructures. The first steps towards curbing tax avoidance have already been taken with an EU directive. However, the regulations are still far from sufficient. Taxation regulations must be standardized in the member states and competition law must b e tightened.
9
to be able to take effective action against the tax avoidance strategies of large corporations.
Financial transaction tax: making the financial market more accountable
As the financial markets have hardly been taxed to date, the introduction of a transaction tax for financial transactions is urgently overdue. As early as 2012, 11 member states agreed in principle to introduce a corresponding financial transaction tax across all countries. However, the tax has not yet been implemented as the states have been unable to agree on a specific form. This political stalemate must finally come to an end. Every year without a tax costs citizens billions of euros. According to calculations, the planned moderate financial transaction tax would bring in a good 50 billion euros a year for the member states. In view of the fact that the EU states supported the financial sector with around 4.6 trillion euros during the economic and banking crisis from 2008 to 2010, this tax would only be a drop in the ocean. The financial transaction tax must therefore be introduced promptly and set at a significantly higher rate. With a tax rate of just 0.5% on trading in shares, annual revenues of a good 250 billion euros could be realized. The financial markets must finally be held more accountable; those who claim trillions of taxpayers' money in times of crisis must also make an appropriate contribution to the common good in times of growth.
White-collar crime: draining tax havens, reducing	tax evasion
insulate
Every year, the member states of the European Union suffer billions in losses due to tax evasion, particularly in the area of VAT. These illegal activities can only be countered efficiently by creating a single VAT area within the EU. The Commission's efforts to this end must be supported at national level. In addition, efforts to drain tax havens must be further expanded. The exchange of information between countries on financial accounts needs to be further improved and tax evaders must be sanctioned more effectively. Only by curbing illegal money flows can crimes such as drug trafficking, terrorist financing and money laundering be effectively combated.
With your vote you decide in favor of:
 Tax justice and reduction of privileges for large corporations
 A financial transaction tax and more financial responsibility on the part of the financial sector
 Effective fight against white-collar crime
10
Alliance policy
The disenchantment with the EU and its institutions is largely homemade. Processes need to be simplified and made more transparent, and citizens need more opportunities to have a say. The influence of lobby associations must be reduced. Fair standards must be applied to EU enlargement.
European institutions: Strengthening opportunities to have a say
More and more people have the impression that the EU has largely withdrawn itself from the influence of its citizens. While the influence of business and industry is steadily increasing, the participation of citizens seems to be limited to their opportunity to vote every four years. It is understandable that people are therefore increasingly turning away from the EU and consider its institutions to be corrupt. The existing right of the European Citizens' Initiative has hardly been used to date, and simplifications are urgently needed here. The procedures must be simplified and the bureaucratic hurdles reduced. We call for a reduction in the minimum number of supporting signatures, an extension of the collection period and a lowering of the participation age to 16. In addition, the Member States must inform citizens better about the existing opportunities for participation.
Lobbying: limiting the influence of organizations
Political and economic power must be clearly separated in Europe. The transparency register that has already been introduced is an important step, but it has hardly had any effect in its current form. The biggest problem continues to be that participation in the register is not mandatory. The data stored there is also largely incorrect and incomplete. We are therefore calling for the register to finally be implemented effectively. This requires an extension of the scope of application to all EU institutions, including the Council of the European Union, the Council of Ministers and the permanent representations of the Member States. The verification and sanctioning system must be improved so that incorrect data can be tracked down and those responsible can be punished. In addition, client protection must be restricted so that lobby groups cannot hide behind confidentiality rules. Only by creating a comprehensive and robust transparency register will it be possible in the long term to effectively prevent undue influence and conflicts of interest in the institutions.
Enlargement policy: a sense of proportion and equal treatment
The enlargement of the European Union is a necessary process, as it secures peace and promotes progress and prosperity in Europe. EU accession countries are rightly required to meet certain minimum requirements in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of the press and the fight against crime and terrorism.
11
the fight against corruption. These accession requirements are precisely defined in the Copenhagen criteria. However, negotiations with the countries that have been offered the prospect of accession must also be conducted fairly and on an equal footing. This applies to the countries of the Western Balkans - Serbia, Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Kosovo, Montenegro and Macedonia - as well as to Turkey.
With your vote you decide in favor of:
 Strengthening citizen participation
 Improving transparency and weakening the influence of lobby groups
 Solid and fair enlargement policy
Foreign and trade policy
European foreign and defense policy must be geared towards securing peace. Clear responses are also needed to the global rise in protectionism. Arms deliveries to crisis areas must be consistently prevented. Trade agreements with developing and emerging countries must serve economic and social development.
Foreign policy: securing peace, strengthening defense
The focus of European foreign and defense policy must be on maintaining friendly relations with neighbors and securing partnerships. In times when the familiar world order is eroding, the EU must take responsibility and defend its values. It would be naïve to think that this could be achieved without modern and effective armed forces. Diplomacy is the silver bullet, but it cannot be successfully pursued without a solid deterrent. With the United States increasingly loosening its ties with Europe, the Union must improve its own defense capabilities. The defense resources of the member states do not necessarily have to be increased, but they should be deployed in a more targeted manner as part of a European defense strategy.
Trade policy: fair trade relations, not exporting war
International trade must be based on fairness and be conducted on an equal footing. The rise of protectionism and unfair trade practices pose new challenges that must be met with a policy of strength. Where diplo- macy and old alliances no longer help, new alliances must also be considered.
Trade with emerging and developing countries requires particular sensitivity; the EU must not exploit its superior economic position to the detriment of these countries. Trade agreements must therefore always be aimed at creating sustainable
12
production and supply conditions in third countries. The demanded complete opening of the markets in Africa must be rejected, as the producers there would not be able to compete with European suppliers and would inevitably be driven to ruin. The flooding of local markets with cheap goods must stop, as must the empty fishing of local coastal regions.
Peace is one of the most important achievements of European unification. However, securing peace must not only be a central goal within the Community, but also outside it. The EU must therefore make every possible effort to contribute to international conflict and crisis management. Peace diplomacy is essential for this, but the first essential step is to consistently prevent the supply of war equipment to crisis regions. All attempts to secure peace are implausible if armaments continue to be exported from member states to war zones on a large scale. We therefore call for the establishment of a strict EU-wide arms supply control system so that such exports can be effectively prevented and violations can be severely sanctioned. The Community must also continue to stand up for global nuclear disarmament and limit the expansion of autonomous weapons systems.
With your vote you decide in favor of:
 Securing peace and strengthening defense capabilities
 Fair and sustainable trade relations
 Stop arms deliveries to crisis regions
Environmental protection and energy policy
As one of the greatest challenges of our time, climate protection can only be solved globally. The cornerstone for this lies in energy policy. Environmentally harmful energy sources such as coal must be reduced and alternative energies must be consistently promoted.
Environmental protection: Advancing environmental protection globally, protecting resources and the climate
Healthy habitats are the basis of human existence. Wherever the earth is exploited and natural resources are destroyed, this results in global change. A responsible environmental protection policy can therefore not end at the EU's external borders. It must be the declared aim of Community policy to ensure that the strict environmental protection requirements of the Member States are also enforced globally. Important measures in the areas of production, agriculture and mobility are technologically and financially costly. Emerging and developing countries must therefore be supported economically in the creation of responsible ecological development. Ethical ecology also means that economically important resources must be used in a sustainable manner.
13
third countries should not be ruthlessly exploited. Similarly, waste disposal and recycling problems must not be exported to the third world.
Climate change is the best example of the global impact of human activity. Only with the combined efforts and goodwill of all nations can the advancing climate change be countered in a promising way. The EU must exhaust all diplomatic and economic means to persuade unwilling states to participate in climate protection agreements. The Paris climate targets must be strictly pursued and adhered to.
Energy policy: strengthen alternative energies, reduce coal power
The future belongs to alternative and renewable energies; environmentally harmful energies must be consistently reduced. Coal energy is harmful to the climate and to health. While many European countries are already pursuing a clear exit policy in this area, Germany is clinging to this anachronistic form of energy generation. The situation is different with nuclear energy. While Germany is implementing the agreed phase-out, countries such as France are pushing ahead with the construction of new nuclear reactors. We are therefore calling for a uniform European energy directive that makes the rapid phase-out of both forms of energy generation mandatory. Europe must also continue to emancipate itself in the energy sector and reduce its dependence on energy exports.
Research into and the expansion of renewable energies, on the other hand, must continue to be driven forward and promoted. On a European basis, this also means ensuring consistent availability at a stable price level. Further networking of energy supply systems and energy storage structures is required here.
With your vote you decide in favor of:
 Global environmental and resource protection
 Strengthening renewable energies
Research and Technology policy
Europe must remain competitive. This requires increased efforts in the area of research and further development. Digitalization must be shaped responsibly and in the interests of the common good.
Research: strengthening innovation, promoting sustainable technologies
In terms of innovation and development, Europe still has a lot of catching up to do in a global comparison. The USA and China continue to set the tone, especially when it comes to the development of new technologies. Efforts within the Community must be stepped up here in order to avoid f a l l i n g behind in the long term. Funds for research and technology development
14
must therefore be significantly increased. There is also a need for better cooperation and coordination in important research projects. The support of resource-saving and sustainable technologies should be at the forefront of this.
Digitalization: protect individual rights, prevent data monopolies
The rapidly advancing digital innovation offers people many opportunities, but it also harbors risks. We must use the advantages of digitalization in the interests of society, for example in the areas of environmental protection, transport planning and labour markets. Thanks to improved technologies, the added value of work performance has increased many times over in recent years. Where this leads to the loss of necessary human resources, social and societal compensation concepts are required. We reject digitalization at any price. It must be compatible with society as a whole and must not undermine individual rights. Above all, this means preventing the emergence of data monopolies. An important step in this direction would be to create universally accessible data infrastructures.
With your vote you decide in favor of:
 Strengthening innovation and promoting sustainable technologies
 Responsible digitalization, prevention of data monopolies
